site_title: White House condemns attack on Indians as 'racially motivated hatred'
summary: The White House condemned a shooting attack in Kansas that killed an Indian man and injured another, labeling it an "act of racially motivated hatred." The attack occurred at a bar where the victims were celebrating the end of a Cricket World Cup match. The White House initially faced criticism for not immediately condemning the violence, but later stated that President Trump would address the issue in his maiden address to Congress. The shooting has sparked concerns about the impact of Trump's immigration policies on the Indian community in the US.

site_title: Food Empire swings back into the black for Q4
summary: Food Empire Holdings reported a net profit of US$2.9 million for the fourth quarter ended December 31, 2016, compared to a net loss of US$3.2 million in the same period last year. Revenue grew 11.4% to US$70.0 million, driven by favourable exchange rates and higher selling prices in key markets. The company's full-year net profit was US$14.5 million, up from US$210,000 in FY2015, with revenue reaching US$242.2 million, a 4.2% increase.

site_title: Trump promises 'renewal of the American spirit'
summary: President Donald Trump delivered a speech to Congress, tempering his most inflammatory rhetoric while outlining his nationalist agenda. He criticized threats against Jewish community centers and condemned a racially-motivated killing, while also proposing a merit-based immigration system and bipartisan compromise on immigration reform. Trump also emphasized America's sovereignty and promised to work with allies, while softening his criticism of NATO partners. He outlined plans for tax relief, infrastructure rebuilding, and healthcare reform, but faces a difficult balancing act with fellow Republicans in Congress.

images.alt_text: President Donald Trump pledged a "renewal of the American spirit" Tuesday, as he tempered his most inflammatory rhetoric while fleshing out his nationalist agenda during a landmark speech to Congress.

site_title: Australia: Shares slide further, Telstra slumps; NZ dips
summary: Australian shares fell for a fifth-straight day, with the S&P/ASX 200 index dropping 17.4 points or 0.3% to 5,694.8, as investors awaited US President Donald Trump's address to Congress. Telstra slumped 4.2% after going ex-dividend, while global miners BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto fell 0.6%. New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index also fell 0.2%, with Fletcher Building and Spark New Zealand among the biggest decliners.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Stocks up by break
summary: Hong Kong shares rose 0.20% to 23,788.45, while Shanghai shares gained 0.38% to 3,254.17, following a better-than-expected increase in Chinese factory activity. The rally came after a four-day sell-off and was driven by optimism over China's economic growth. The Hang Seng Index also rose 0.59% in Shenzhen.

site_title: YouTube challenges cable TV with streaming service
summary: YouTube has unveiled a streaming television service, YouTube TV, offering bundles of live channels, in a challenge to traditional cable and pay TV. The service, set to launch in major US markets, will cost $35 monthly and allow six user accounts per subscriber. It will combine live channels with user-created content, offering limitless recording and viewing options. YouTube TV aims to cater to younger generations seeking flexible viewing options without cable or satellite subscriptions.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher ahead of Trump address
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on March 1, 2017, ahead of US President Donald Trump's speech to Congress. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.41% and the Topix index rose 0.38%. The gains were attributed to a weaker yen. Investors were awaiting Trump's address, which did not have a significant impact on markets at the time.

site_title: US Dollar firms on Fed rate hike talk, Trump promises spending boost
summary: The US dollar strengthened against major currencies following comments from two Federal Reserve officials suggesting interest rate hikes this month. US President Donald Trump's speech to Congress was met with mixed reactions, with investors focusing on the Fed's potential move. Trump pledged $1 trillion in infrastructure spending and tax cuts, but lacked detail on funding. World markets surged on Trump's election victory, but recent uncertainty and controversy have led to concerns about the presidency's impact.

site_title: Coffee shop meeting in Singapore inspires novel way to kill cancer
summary: A meeting between an immunologist and an oncologist in a Singapore cafe seven years ago sparked a novel way to kill cancer. The partnership led to Tessa Therapeutics, a biotechnology firm developing treatments that harness the immune system to hunt down and kill malignant cells. The company's treatment, TT10, has shown promising results in a clinical study, with 63% of patients still alive after two years. Tessa is seeking US$100 million in funding and aims to complete a phase-three trial, with possible approval from the US FDA for the first T-cell therapy for a solid tumour.

site_title: Macau signals rebound as gambling revenues hit 2-year high in Feb
summary: Macau's gambling revenue reached a two-year high in February, with a 23 billion patacas (S$4 billion) earnings, up 18% from the same period last year. The growth is attributed to new casino resorts, including Sands China Ltd and Wynn Macau Ltd, which have attracted mass gamblers and VIP spenders. Analysts believe the industry has reached a bottom, and Galaxy Entertainment reported a 51% rise in 2016 net profit, forecasting double-digit gaming growth for this year.

site_title: Australia economy rebounds in Q4, extends recession-free run
summary: Australia's economy rebounded 1.1% in Q4, extending its 25-year streak of uninterrupted expansion. This surpasses forecasts and marks 102 quarters without recession. The growth is attributed to a surge in commodity exports and consumer spending. The Reserve Bank of Australia is expecting growth to reach 3% this year and next, driven by liquefied natural gas exports. Despite record-low interest rates, there's no pressure for a rate hike due to near-historic lows in inflation and growing wages. This positive economic news has helped the conservative government of Malcolm Turnbull, which is riding low in the polls.

site_title: Female directors on SGX listcos paid substantially less than male counterparts: NUS study
summary: A study by the NUS Business School's Centre for Governance, Institutions and Organisations found that female directors of listed companies on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) earned 56.8% of what their male counterparts earned on average, with a 43.2% gender pay gap. The widest gaps were among large firms and executive directors, with female independent directors earning 83% of male independent directors' pay. The study suggests that women's lower representation on board committees and leadership roles contribute to the pay gap.

site_title: Asia: Stocks struggle as Trump offers few policy details, US dollar firm
summary: US stocks struggled on Wednesday as President Donald Trump's speech offered few details on infrastructure spending and tax reforms, leading to a choppy market reaction. Despite a firm US dollar due to rate hike expectations, stocks were down, with investors seeking clarity on Trump's plans. The US dollar firmed ahead of a potential rate hike this month, while Asian stocks struggled to make gains.

site_title: EU's Juncker to unveil plans for life after Brexit
summary: European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker is set to unveil a plan for the EU's future after Britain's Brexit vote, with a "White Paper" outlining four to five options for unity and cooperation. The plan includes allowing countries to integrate at different speeds, keeping the status quo, or pushing for a federalized Europe. Resistance has begun from Eastern European nations, who fear being frozen out by Western states. The plan aims to rebuild unity after years of economic and political crisis, ahead of a key summit in Rome marking the EU's 60th anniversary.

site_title: Women suspects arrive at court for Kim murder charge
summary: Two women, Siti Aisyah from Indonesia and Doan Thi Huong from Vietnam, were brought to court in Kuala Lumpur to face charges of assassinating North Korean leader Kim Jong Nam with a lethal nerve agent. They were escorted by police and entered the courthouse wearing t-shirts, surrounded by reporters and police. The women claim they thought they were taking part in a prank video and were paid RM400 for their role. If convicted, they face death by hanging, and the trial is expected to take months to start.

site_title: Fed officials signal more willingness to consider March hike
summary: Federal Reserve officials signaled a greater willingness to consider a March interest-rate hike, citing "compelling" risks to the outlook and an upside tilt. New York Fed President William Dudley and San Francisco Fed chief John Williams expressed openness to tightening monetary policy. The comments come after recent economic data suggesting a strong US economy, potentially paving the way for a rate increase at the March 14-15 Federal Open Market Committee meeting.

site_title: Europe: Shares end February near 14-month peak ahead of key Trump speech
summary: European shares rose 0.2% to near a 14-month peak in February, driven by optimism over US President Donald Trump's tax cuts and infrastructure spending plans. The STOXX 600 index ended the month up 2.8% and rallied over 10% since Trump's election. However, investors cautioned that Trump's speech could be a letdown, triggering a sell-off. Defence and engineering stocks surged, with Meggitt and GKN rising 13% and 4.9%, respectively, after Trump's remarks and solid earnings updates.

site_title: Trump says America is 'ready to lead' in remarks to Congress
summary: President Donald Trump delivered his first address to Congress, urging Americans to abandon conflict and help him remake the country. He stated that America is "ready to lead" and "strong, proud, and free." Trump aims to turn the page on his administration's chaotic beginning and bring clarity to his policy agenda. His remarks were seen as an attempt to reassert American influence globally and promote unity among Americans.

site_title: China's yuan slips as growing views of US March rate hike boost US dollar
summary: China's yuan fell against the US dollar on March 1, 2017, as the greenback reached one-week highs due to growing expectations of a US Federal Reserve interest rate hike this month. The People's Bank of China set the midpoint rate at 6.8798, weaker than the previous fix of 6.875. This move follows a pause in the US dollar's rally earlier in the year, which gave emerging market currencies a brief respite from depreciation pressure.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 0.300 points to 1694.640. The trading volume was 111.1 million lots worth RM34.8 million, with 116 gainers outnumbering 113 losers.

site_title: Trump pledges US$1t to rebuild US infrastructure
summary: US President Donald Trump pledged to bring $1 trillion in public and private investment to rebuild America's crumbling infrastructure. He made the promise in a speech to Congress, aiming to create millions of new jobs. Trump did not provide details on how the funds would be spent, but emphasized the need for a "historic" tax reform to cut corporate taxes and provide massive relief for the middle class. He also promised to impose tariffs on foreign imports to protect US industry.

images.alt_text: US President Donald Trump pledged on Tuesday to bring one trillion dollars in public and private investment to rebuild what he called America's crumbling infrastructure.

site_title: Lawsuit in US says automakers knew of Takata flaws
summary: Leading US automakers, including BMW and Nissan, equipped their cars with potentially deadly Takata airbags despite knowing of their flaws, according to a civil case. The lawsuit claims the companies had independent knowledge of the airbags' safety issues before installing them in millions of vehicles. The case expands responsibility from Takata alone, which recently pleaded guilty and agreed to pay $1 billion to settle the scandal. The automakers are accused of being "victims" who call themselves so despite evidence of their early knowledge of the airbag flaws.

site_title: South Korea's Feb exports post best growth in 5 years as global demand improves
summary: South Korea's exports grew at their fastest pace in five years in February, driven by a strong demand for electronics and semiconductor exports. The country's exports to China rose for a fourth straight month, while semiconductor exports posted their best monthly performance on record. This growth is seen as a positive sign for global demand, despite concerns over potential US protectionism affecting trade-reliant economies. The data also suggests a strengthening global economy, with the trade ministry praising the growth as a "strong signal" of the country's economic resilience.

images.alt_text: South Korean exports grew at their fastest pace in five years in February in a further sign that global demand is strengthening, even as trade-reliant economies brace for a possible rise in US protectionism.

site_title: Flu medication does not harm unborn babies: study
summary: A study of 700,000 pregnant women in Denmark, Norway, Sweden, and France found that taking flu medication during pregnancy, such as Tamiflu and Relenza, does not harm unborn babies. The study, published in The BMJ, compared women who took the medication to those who did not and found no increased risks of adverse outcomes, including low birth weight and birth defects. In fact, children whose mothers took the medication were less likely to be underweight. The findings contradict previous recommendations to avoid flu medication during pregnancy.

site_title: SGX slaps 'trade with caution' warning on ISR Capital as it lifts trading suspension
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has lifted the trading suspension on ISR Capital shares and issued a 'trade with caution' warning. The suspension began in November 2016 due to unverified trading circumstances. The warning comes after John Soh Chee Wen, one of three charged in a penny stock market manipulation case, was investigated for manipulating ISR's shares. Soh faces 188 charges and was under police bail at the time of the alleged manipulation. Shares of ISR plummeted on the day Soh was arrested, and the investigation led to evidence seizure. Trading resumes on March 6, 2017.

images.alt_text: THE Singapore Exchange (SGX) has slapped a "trade with caution' warning on ISR Capital as it lifts the trading suspension imposed on the shares.

site_title: Quotation of taxable book-entry Singapore Government Bonds
summary: Singapore Government Bonds quotation rose, but no specific details are provided in the given articles. Oil prices surged over 2% amid market uncertainty. Global stock markets declined, with Europe and the US experiencing bank and healthcare sector downturns. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer received significant interest, with an oversubscription rate of 9.8 times. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss. Meanwhile, Heathrow Airport plans to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade, and an Indonesian court detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case.

site_title: Opening of Trump tower in Vancouver met with protests
summary: US President Donald Trump's sons, Donald Jr and Eric Trump, inaugurated the Trump International Hotel and Tower in Vancouver, Canada, amidst protests. About 100 protesters gathered outside, chanting "Not in my city" and "Dump Trump." The building, Vancouver's tallest, features a spa designed by Ivanka Trump and luxury amenities. The construction has been marred by controversy, with the city council member Kerry Lang calling it "a beacon of intolerance." Mayor Gregor Robertson expressed his disapproval, stating Trump's name and brand have no place on Vancouver's skyline.

site_title: Oil prices slip as rising US supplies offset Opec cuts
summary: Oil prices slipped on Tuesday, with US West Texas Intermediate crude futures settling at $54.01 a barrel and Brent crude at $55.59 a barrel. The decline was attributed to rising US crude inventories, which have increased for seven straight weeks. Forecasts of another weekly build of 3.1 million barrels fueled concerns that demand growth may not be sufficient to absorb the global crude oil glut, offsetting OPEC production cuts.

images.alt_text: Oil prices slipped on Tuesday but kept trading in a tight range, as concerns about rising US crude inventories ahead of data overshadowed OPEC production cuts.

site_title: US: Dow streak ends; retailer shares tumble
summary: The Dow Jones ended its record-breaking streak as shares of retailers, including Target and Wal-Mart, tumbled 12.6% and 1.1% respectively, following a disappointing earnings report. Target's fourth-quarter earnings plummeted 42.7% to $817 million, with the company signaling lower-than-expected profits in 2017 due to increased investments in stores and low-priced offerings.

site_title: Brexit looms large as Northern Ireland holds snap elections
summary: Northern Ireland holds snap elections amid Brexit tensions, following the resignation of Deputy First Minister Martin McGuinness from the Sinn Fein party. The move aims to resolve a crisis sparked by Brexit, with long-simmering tensions boiling over between the rival Democratic Unionist Party (DUP) and Sinn Fein. The snap elections come as fresh allegations of corruption threaten the province's delicate peace. The outcome of the elections remains uncertain, but the bid to resolve the crisis highlights the ongoing impact of Brexit on Northern Ireland.

site_title: Yangzijiang Q4 net profit leaps to 607.8m yuan on advance payments
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding Holdings reported a 1,465% surge in Q4 net profit to 607.8 million yuan, driven by a 76% increase in revenue to 5.5 billion yuan. The company delivered nine vessels on schedule, exceeding FY2015's fourth-quarter delivery. However, full-year net profit fell 29% to 1.8 billion yuan, and earnings per share declined 29% to 45.73 yuan cents. The company proposed a final dividend of 4 Singapore cents per share, down from 4.5 cents previously.

images.alt_text: YANGZIJIANG Shipbuilding Holdings (YZJ) saw its quarterly net profit jump to 607.8 million yuan (S$124.5 million) from 41.5 million yuan a year ago on the back of a huge increase in other income due to recognition of advance payment from terminated shipbuilding contracts and lower expenses.

site_title: How to save a dying mall: Start by buying it on the cheap
summary: The Hudson Valley Mall in Kingston, New York, is struggling to stay afloat, having been the site of a 2005 Columbine-inspired shooting. To save it, experts suggest buying it at a low price. The mall's 765,000 square foot structure remains largely empty, despite its picturesque location. By acquiring the mall at a discounted price, potential buyers may be able to revitalize the property and turn it into a thriving shopping destination. This approach could help revitalize the local economy and breathe new life into the struggling mall.

site_title: SMRT Trains fined S$400,000 for safety lapses in 2016 fatal accident
summary: SMRT Trains Ltd was fined S$400,000 for failing to ensure employee safety while accessing train tracks during traffic hours in 2016. The company pleaded guilty to a charge under the Workplace Safety and Health Act. This is a record fine for the company.

site_title: VietJet jumps 20% in trading debut as air-travel demand soars
summary: VietJet Aviation Joint Stock Co., Vietnam's first mainboard-listed carrier, surged 20% in its trading debut on the Ho Chi Minh City Stock Exchange, valuing the low-cost carrier at 32.4 trillion dong. The listing reflects investor interest in the nation's growing air-travel demand, driven by rising living standards and affordable tickets from budget carriers. Vietnam is expected to see a double-digit increase in passenger numbers over the next decade, with VietJet's passenger numbers forecast to climb 30% this year.

site_title: Catering to SMEs
summary: Singapore SMEs face uncertain economic conditions, but this bleakness can lead to opportunities for growth. Banks are adapting to cater to SMEs, offering competitive packages and innovative products, such as digital accounts and virtual marketplaces. New entrants, like peer-to-business lending platform Funding Societies, are also disrupting the lending business. Technology and telecommunications providers are working with SMEs to enhance capabilities, such as increasing productivity and cybersecurity. Meanwhile, education institutions are partnering with SMEs to upgrade skills and provide training programs, enabling businesses to stay resilient and relevant in a slowing economy.

site_title: Gold down on hawkish comments by Fed officials, US dollar pressure
summary: Gold prices fell 0.5% to $1,244.93 per ounce as the US dollar strengthened following hawkish comments from US Federal Reserve officials and a speech by President Donald Trump that contained few specifics or surprises. The comments from Fed policymakers boosted expectations for a March US interest rate increase, sparking a surge in interest rate futures. Gold is expected to stabilize around support at $1,244 per ounce and rise into a range of $1,252-$1,258 per ounce.

images.alt_text: Gold fell on Wednesday as the US dollar strengthened on hawkish comments overnight from US Federal Reserve officials, while an eagerly awaited speech by US President Donald Trump contained few specifics or surprises.

site_title: The importance of being vigilant
summary: Singaporean small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) must prioritize vigilance to safeguard their interests in a challenging business environment. Proactive measures can help protect hard-won gains, despite initial costs. Meanwhile, Royal Healthcare plans to open a specialist centre in Tokyo or Osaka after being acquired by Sojitz. Researchers at NUS are working on sustainable marine fuel, aiming to halve its price. Other news includes OCBC targeting S$5 billion in loans for serial entrepreneurs by 2028 and Shatec shutting its Orchard campus and training restaurant.

site_title: UOB taps fintech firm to make supply chain payments easier
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) has launched a virtual payment service to ease cash flow pressures in businesses' supply chains. The service allows suppliers to receive payment immediately while extending the company making payments' cash flow for up to 90 days. The virtual corporate credit card account is a first in South-east Asia, with a fintech company, Invapay, processing transactions. A processing fee of 1.5-2% is applied, and the service automates account reconciliation. The move aims to help businesses manage cash flow and increase productivity in the current economic climate.

site_title: Uber software head leaves as past harassment claim surfaces
summary: Uber executive Amit Singhal resigned as senior vice-president of engineering after a past harassment claim surfaced. The claim, made against Singhal during his time at Google, was not disclosed during the hiring process and surfaced after he joined Uber. Singhal denied the allegation, stating he never committed such behavior and was leaving Google on his own terms. Uber's CEO Travis Kalanick requested Singhal's resignation amid the company's own sexual harassment crisis, which was sparked by a blog post from a former Uber engineer.

site_title: Amendments to Trustees Act submitted for first reading in Parliament
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Law submitted the Trustees (Amendment) Bill 2017 for first reading in Parliament, aiming to counter money-laundering, terrorism financing, and tax evasion. The proposed amendments require trustees to maintain beneficial ownership information and proper accounting records of express trusts, increasing transparency and prescribing minimum standards for financial record keeping. The bill is part of Singapore's ongoing review to prevent the misuse of corporate vehicles and trusts. The proposed amendments include penalties of up to S$1,000 for breaches of the obligations.

site_title: Uber CEO says he must 'grow up' after argument with driver
summary: Uber CEO Travis Kalanick said he needs to "grow up" and get help after a video showed him arguing with a driver over pay rates. The argument, captured in a dash cam video, saw Kalanick respond angrily to the driver's concerns, saying some people don't take responsibility for their actions. Kalanick later apologized, acknowledging the video reflects his behavior and criticizing himself as a leader. This comes amid ongoing challenges for Uber, including a lawsuit over self-driving vehicle designs and allegations of sexual harassment within the company.

site_title: Centurion's next stop: senior housing?
summary: Centurion Corp, a Singapore-listed accommodation provider, is exploring expansion into senior housing after success in student accommodation. The company, which has transformed from selling optical disks to managing dormitories and student hostels, has a track record of adapting to market trends. With a rapidly ageing UK population and severe undersupply of retirement housing, Centurion may consider acquiring retirement housing assets, potentially yielding 4.5% returns. The company's ability to diversify and maintain control over its operations could enable it to succeed in this new asset class.

site_title: Italy probes visas-for-sale security breach
summary: Italy's foreign ministry has launched an investigation into the suspected sale of European visas by officials at its consulate in Iraq, with reports suggesting up to 152 visas were issued for illicit payments. The official in charge of the section has been replaced, and the ministry has asked a prosecutor to look into the matter. The sale of visas, which cover the Schengen border-free zone, was allegedly made to buyers deemed a security risk by other European consulates in Arbil, Iraq.

site_title: Australia to bring back ambassadors to shape foreign policy
summary: Australia is temporarily recalling 113 ambassadors to help shape its new foreign policy, the nation's first of its kind. The ambassadors will meet with Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull and Foreign Minister Julie Bishop to contribute to a long-awaited foreign policy white paper. The meeting will aim to strengthen Australia's influence and standing in the world, particularly in the face of global uncertainty and rising tensions with China and the US. The white paper is expected to be delivered later this year, providing a comprehensive strategic framework for Australia's foreign, trade, and development policies.

site_title: Aussie up on GDP, NZD falters on Trump speech
summary: The Australian dollar rose 0.24% to US$0.7673 after data showed the country's economy rebounded 1.1% in the fourth quarter, outpacing expectations. The Australian economy has now expanded for 25 years, with the Aussie up 6.5% this year. In contrast, the New Zealand dollar fell 0.3% due to a strengthening US dollar following US President Donald Trump's speech, which lacked details on long-awaited stimulus plans.

site_title: UK house price rises accelerate in February
summary: British house prices rose 0.6% in February, the strongest monthly increase since November 2015, according to Nationwide. This follows a 0.2% rise in January, the weakest month in over a year. Annual growth was 4.5%, surpassing January's 4.3%. Economists had expected a 0.2% rise, but Nationwide's Robert Gardner believes the UK economy will slow this year due to Brexit and inflation, yet house prices may still rise by 2% in 2017.

site_title: Malaysian court charges two women with Kim murder
summary: Malaysian court charges two women, Siti Aisyah and Doan Thi Huong, with the murder of Kim Jong Nam, North Korea's half-brother, who was assassinated at a Malaysian airport in February. The women, from Indonesia and Vietnam, claim they were involved in a prank video and will face the death penalty if found guilty. They were charged without entering a plea and their trial is expected to begin in several months. Police accuse them of using VX nerve agent, a banned weapon of mass destruction, in the killing.

site_title: Warren Buffett on why Big Money is losing big sums to managers who charge big fees
summary: Warren Buffett estimates that US$100 billion has been lost by pension funds, endowments, and wealthy individuals over the last decade to hedge funds and other money managers charging high fees. In his annual letter, Buffett criticizes the hedge fund industry, stating that many investors are unable to beat the stock market due to high fees and poor investment performance. He advises investors to opt for low-cost S&P 500 index funds instead, but notes that many wealthy individuals continue to pay high fees for underperformance. Buffett believes that human behavior will not change, and wealthy individuals will continue to seek "extra" investment advice, allowing fee-charging advisers to profit.

site_title: Singapore shares rise 14 points ahead of Trump's address
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 14.03 points to 3,110.64 ahead of US President Donald Trump's address to Congress. The key index was boosted by 69 million shares worth S$242 million. Asian markets are expected to react to Trump's address, with analysts predicting a "flood of leads." Despite Wall Street's pullback overnight, US stocks edged down from records amid tariff threats.

site_title: In China, 12.4m people brought above poverty line in 2016: Xinhua
summary: China reported a significant reduction in poverty in 2016, with 12.4 million people lifted above the poverty line. The move is attributed to 230 billion yuan allocated to fight poverty. The country aims to reduce poverty by at least 10 million annually and eradicate it by 2020. Chinese President Xi Jinping has prioritized the fight against poverty, labeling it the nation's most important task.

site_title: Cars racing to become 'mobile phones on wheels'
summary: Connected cars, or "mobile phones on wheels," are being developed to enable features such as direct payment for fuel and parking, traffic alerts, and onboard digital assistants. However, the industry faces significant challenges, including cybersecurity risks, reliability issues, and moral and legal dilemmas. Hacking of connected cars has already occurred, and experts warn that a hacker could take control of a car's network and disable critical systems. The development of 5G networks is expected to enable faster and more reliable connectivity, but commercialization is not expected until 2020. The industry is struggling to address these issues and ensure the safe and responsible deployment of connected cars.

images.alt_text: Prototypes, fitted with the next generation 5G wireless communications network, turned heads at the Mobile World Congress (MWC) in Barcelona.

site_title: Carbon reduction in shipping: ideals v reality
summary: International Chamber of Shipping (ICS) chairman Esben Poulsson calls for realistic carbon reduction goals for the shipping industry, warning that ambitious targets may be unachievable without alternative marine fuels. ICS proposes a bunker fuel levy as a Market Based Measure (MBM) to reduce CO2 emissions, but notes that the technology to capture CO2 from emissions is still in its infancy. Campaign group Carbon War Room warns that lenders to the shipping industry could lose billions if new buildings are not easily convertible to new technologies, and a new report suggests that climate policies could pose risks to shipping debt.

site_title: Trump looks to reboot in first address to Congress
summary: Donald Trump delivers his first address to the US Congress, seeking to reframe his presidency and boost low approval ratings. He plans to detail an agenda of economic empowerment, health reforms, and increased defense spending. Trump's hawkish message, including immigration bans and border walls, will continue from his first 40 days in office. The speech aims to reframe his presidency and provide a new direction for the country.

site_title: Singapore market cap up four months in a row
summary: The Singapore stock market experienced its fourth consecutive month-on-month gain in February, with a 1.6% increase, lifting its market value to S$930 billion, the highest in 19 months. The Straits Times Index (STI) also posted a 1.5% gain, while the broader market saw gainers beating losers 423 to 258 on a year-on-year basis. Despite uncertainty over US President Donald Trump's policies, investors remain optimistic, with the STI up 33.1% from a year ago.

site_title: Obamas sign book deal with Penguin Random House
summary: Barack and Michelle Obama have signed a book deal with Penguin Random House, worth tens of millions of dollars, for their memoirs. This is the highest paid US presidential memoir deal, topping $60 million. The terms of the deal were not disclosed, but the company will donate one million books to First Book charity. The Obamas will settle into a rented mansion in Washington's Kalorama district until their younger daughter finishes high school.

images.alt_text: Barack and Michelle Obama have signed a deal to publish their memoirs with New York-based Penguin Random House, in a coveted contract reportedly worth tens of millions of dollars.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks up after Trump speech
summary: Tokyo stocks rose after US President Donald Trump's speech to Congress, with the Nikkei 225 index jumping 1.44% to 19,393.54. The broader Topix index gained 1.16% to 1,553.09. Trump's speech offered few new details on his economic growth plans, but traders seemed to brush off his threats. The rally in Tokyo came despite concerns over US-EU trade tensions and the impact of tariffs on global markets.

site_title: Soh denied bail, faces new charges in penny stock case
summary: A Singaporean district court denied bail to Malaysian businessman John Soh Chee Wen, who faces 188 charges related to the 2013 penny stock crash. Prosecutors added seven new charges of witness tampering, alleging Soh manipulated the stock of ISR Capital while under police bail. Soh's lawyer argued that the evidence was unreliable and that his client would be "stupid" to attempt to manipulate stocks in this era. The judge accepted the prosecution's portrayal of Soh as a "protagonist" in the crash and a flight risk, citing Soh's use of a fake Indonesian identity and past attempts to leave Singapore.

site_title: South Korea, US forces begin joint military drills
summary: South Korea and the US have begun their annual joint military exercises, known as Key Resolve and Foal Eagle, amid heightened tensions on the Korean peninsula. North Korean leader Kim Jong-Un has ordered his troops to prepare for a "merciless strike" against enemy forces. The exercises, which involve 3,600 US troops and 300,000 South Korean troops, come after North Korea's recent ballistic missile test and the assassination of Kim's half brother. The drills have sparked protests in Seoul, with demonstrators claiming they will bring the peninsula closer to nuclear war.

site_title: New Trump travel order will aim to short circuit legal challenges
summary: President Trump is set to announce a new travel order aiming to limit legal challenges by shaping it more narrowly, excluding green card holders. The initial order led to over 2 dozen lawsuits, with some states and individuals claiming standing to argue the ban causes harm. Experts say the new order will likely face court challenges, with challengers potentially establishing standing to argue the ban's merits. The administration aims to make it harder for opponents to pursue legal actions by excluding permanent residents, but some experts believe this may not fully eliminate challenges.

site_title: Trump infrastructure plan seen as key to dodging China trade war
summary: US President Donald Trump's infrastructure plan may help avoid a trade war with China by boosting US employment and growth, potentially shifting attention away from trade issues. According to professor Michael Pettis, if the plan is successful, it could reduce unemployment to zero and alleviate the need to address China's trade policies, which Trump has accused of harming the US. The plan's impact on trade tensions is uncertain, but Pettis believes it could be a "best-case scenario" for the world.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks fall as Trump focuses on tax, immigration reforms
summary: Taiwan's stocks fell 0.6% on March 1, 2017, as US President Donald Trump emphasized tax and immigration reforms, potentially affecting the trade-dependent nation. The Taiex index closed at 9,691.12 points, while the electronics subindex fell 0.8% and the financial subindex dropped 0.3%. The Taiwan dollar softened to NT$30.688 to the US dollar. This move is seen as a response to Trump's focus on domestic issues, which may lead to a decline in Taiwan's economy.

site_title: Business confidence in Singapore economy rises in second quarter
summary: Business confidence in Singapore's economy rose in the second quarter, driven by optimism in the services and wholesale trade sectors. The quarterly Business Optimism Index (BOI) increased to 2.66 percentage points, up from -1.22 percentage points in the first quarter. This marks a significant improvement from the previous quarter and a year-on-year increase from 0.89 percentage points in Q2 2016. The construction sector, however, saw a decline in sentiments, while the manufacturing sector showed visible improvements. The surge in optimism is attributed to recovering global demand.

images.alt_text: Business confidence in Singapore's economy for the second quarter of this year has bounced back up, led by rising optimism in the services and wholesale trade sectors from a gloomy outlook in the preceeding quarter, according to a latest quarterly survey.

site_title: Silicon Valley tried to upend banks but now it works with them
summary: Silicon Valley's financial startups, which initially aimed to disrupt banks, now partner with them instead. Despite billions of dollars in investments, few startups have successfully threatened the big banks' business. Venture capitalists have come to realize that working with banks is the most effective way to succeed. The Trump administration's plans to cut back on regulations may further hinder startups' growth. However, basic financial services are changing rapidly, with Americans able to send money instantly and get approved for loans in minutes. The largest banks are also absorbing new ideas and shrinking their operations, potentially reducing the need for startups.

site_title: Stock-price collapse claims board of Aussie baby food maker
summary: Bellamy's Australia Ltd, a baby food maker, faced a shareholder revolt after a disastrous foray into China led to a stock-price collapse. The company's stock has slumped 68% in six months due to overestimated Chinese demand and stockpiles of unsold infant formula. After a one-day meeting, almost all directors were ousted, with two new nominees from Black Prince Private Foundation being voted onto the board. The shakeout leaves investors uncertain about the company's prospects, with analysts describing the situation as "a mess" that needed a changing of the guard.

site_title: Net fair valuation loss dents Centurion Q4 net profit
summary: Centurion Corporation reported a 61% decline in net profit to S$2.9 million for the fourth quarter ended December 31, 2016, due to a net fair valuation loss of S$3.1 million on its investment properties. Revenue grew 23% to S$34.8 million, driven by its accommodation business, which saw a 26% year-on-year increase. The company maintained a healthy balance sheet with S$82.5 million in cash and bank balances, and proposed a final dividend of 1 Singapore cent per share.

site_title: SBF and SPH extend pact on 'Belt & Road' portal
summary: The Singapore Business Federation (SBF) and Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) have signed two agreements to expand their tie-up on the "Belt & Road" Chinese portal, one year after its official launch. The agreements include adding news content, an events calendar, and an English version of the portal, aiming to provide comprehensive information on Singapore and the region. The portal is South-east Asia's first comprehensive website on the topic, offering insights on opportunities and risks for individuals and businesses.

site_title: Critics slam cuts to foreign aid, big boost for Pentagon
summary: US President Donald Trump's proposed $54 billion increase in the Pentagon budget for 2018 has been met with criticism from military spending hawks and senior administration officials, who say it will come at the expense of foreign aid and diplomacy funding. Critics argue that cutting development aid and diplomacy funding could undermine global stability and make it harder to avoid future conflicts. Most senior military leaders believe it is unwise to cut these programs, citing their importance in helping to prevent extremism.

site_title: UK shop prices fall more slowly, food prices rise for first time since April: BRC
summary: UK shop prices declined by 1% in February, the smallest annual decline in over three years, according to the British Retail Consortium. Food prices rose 0.4% for the first time since April 2022, driven by global price increases and the weaker pound. The Bank of England expects inflation to rise to 2.7% by mid-2018, increasing pressure on consumers.

site_title: China plans to cut 500,000 jobs this year in smokestack sectors
summary: China plans to cut 500,000 jobs in smokestack sectors this year, as part of a broader effort to trim 1.8 million employees in steel and coal industries. The government aims to eliminate excess capacity and reduce pollution, while also supporting service sectors and internet-related businesses to create new jobs. A 100 billion yuan subsidy has been allocated for displaced workers, with over 30 billion yuan spent last year. The move is part of a plan to manage the country's massive labor force, with a record 7.95 million college students graduating this year.

site_title: Deutsche Telekom CEO pushes for mergers to ease move to 5G
summary: Deutsche Telekom CEO Tim Hoettges called on European regulators to allow more industry consolidation to ease the transition to 5G, citing the need for investments and growth. Companies including AT&T and Ericsson support the push for standards, aiming for 1.1 billion 5G connections by 2025. Hoettges noted that spectrum availability and common standards are major obstacles, and regulators must "recalibrate their mind" to allow carrier mergers, enabling growth and investment in infrastructure.

site_title: As Olympics loom, China plunges into the ski business
summary: China aims to boost its winter sports culture ahead of the 2022 Olympics in Beijing by developing skiing and other winter sports. Currently, only 5-6 million Chinese ski regularly, but the government plans to increase this to 300 million by 2030. New resorts are sprouting up in northern China, catering to novices, and artificially produced snow is being used to supplement natural snowfall, which is scarce in the region. Despite costs being out of reach for many consumers, interest in skiing is growing, with weekend skiers flocking to slopes outside Beijing.

site_title: New Trump immigration order will remove Iraq from list of banned countries: AP
summary: President Donald Trump's new immigration order will remove Iraq from the list of banned countries, following pressure from the Pentagon and State Department. The decision comes after the US government sought to reconsider Iraq's inclusion given its key role in fighting the Islamic State group. The new order is expected to be signed on Wednesday, reversing an earlier ban that was blocked by federal courts.

site_title: Business, household costs top concerns
summary: Singaporean Members of Parliament highlighted rising business and household costs during the Budget 2017 debate. The impending water tariff hike and diesel tax were major concerns, potentially sending business costs soaring. At least eight backbenchers spoke about these issues, emphasizing the need for government support.

site_title: Robots and immigrants are the enemies in Dutch home of populism
summary: Rotterdam, a major port city in the Netherlands, is experiencing a surge in support for populist leader Geert Wilders, who advocates for a hardline stance against immigration and the European Union. Despite the city's history of openness to trade and immigration, concerns over job losses due to technological change are fueling Wilders' popularity. The city's port, which handles 3.5% of the EU's economic output, is adapting to automation, with 22-year-old women operating cranes, but many workers fear the impact on their jobs. Wilders' party is expected to win the most seats in the Dutch parliament despite polling less than 20%.

site_title: As economy reboots, mindsets need to be rewired
summary: Singapore's economy is undergoing a reboot, requiring a shift in mindsets for workers and employers. Senior Minister Heng Chee How emphasized the need for leaders to add value beyond executing plans, leveraging technology and partnerships to create innovative platforms and services. Job security for mature workers is assured, with close monitoring by labor movement and tripartite partners. MPs discussed the potential of a gig economy for seniors, citing examples like Uber, and the need for entrepreneurship education and skills training to adapt to a rapidly changing job market.

site_title: Lawsuit alleges 5 carmakers knew of deadly Takata airbag defects
summary: A lawsuit alleges that five major carmakers - Honda, Ford, BMW, Toyota, and Nissan - knowingly used defective Takata airbags despite knowing they posed a risk to motorists. Documents claim the companies used the cheaper airbags due to bulk production needs, despite having independent information about the defects. The allegations raise questions about who should be held liable for 11 deaths and 180 injuries caused by the faulty airbags, which were used in millions of vehicles worldwide.

images.alt_text: The new allegations come as Takata entered a guilty plea on Monday as part of an agreement with the Department of Justice to resolve the agency's investigation into the matter.

site_title: Australia home prices jump most in 6 years in Feb, ring policy alarms
summary: Home prices in Australia's major cities surged 1.4% in February, with annual growth reaching 11.7%, the fastest pace in over six years. Sydney saw a 2.6% rise, while Melbourne's prices increased 1.5%. This growth is a concern for the Reserve Bank of Australia, which had hoped the market would cool after regulators imposed tighter lending rules. The rapid price increase has made homes unaffordable for many first-time buyers and is a pressing issue for policymakers.

images.alt_text: Home prices in Australia's major cities surged in February to take annual growth to the fastest in over six years, a headache for policy makers alarmed at the risks of a debt-fuelled bubble in the sector.

site_title: Starwood in talks on raising initial bid for Milestone, say sources
summary: Starwood Capital Group is in talks with Milestone Apartments Real Estate Investment Trust to raise its initial bid of C$1.7 billion (S$1.8 billion) for the Canadian REIT. The move comes after proxy advisory firm ISS recommended that Milestone unitholders vote against the transaction, citing a 9.2% premium above the units' closing price. Milestone's units rose 2.7% to a one-month high, and the company and Starwood could agree on a higher price and make an announcement early this week.

site_title: Mindef's Internet system breached in cyberattack
summary: The Defence Ministry of Singapore's Internet system was breached in a cyberattack in early February, resulting in the theft of personal data of approximately 850 servicemen and employees. The breach, which was carried out remotely, targeted the I-net system, which stores data for account management. Despite the breach, no classified military information was compromised. Mindef has disconnected the affected server and is investigating other government systems, while strengthening cyberdefences to prevent future attacks. The ministry will contact the affected personnel and provide assistance.

site_title: Vard posts Q4 net loss of 67m kroner
summary: Vard Holdings reported a net loss of 67 million Norwegian kroner (S$12.2 million) in Q4 2016, down from 83 million kroner a year ago. Revenue fell 35% to 2.15 billion kroner due to reduced activity at European yards. The company delivered two large offshore subsea construction vessels but saw reduced activity levels at Norwegian yards, partially mitigated by temporary layoffs. A loss per share of 0.06 krone was reported, similar to the previous year's corresponding quarter. Vard's full-year loss was 163 million kroner.

site_title: Trump to promise tough immigration laws, 'historic' tax reform
summary: US President Donald Trump is set to deliver a prime-time speech to Congress, promising tougher immigration enforcement and "historic tax reform." He plans to reduce corporate tax rates, provide massive tax relief for the middle class, and repeal and replace Obamacare. Trump's immigration policies aim to raise wages, help the unemployed, and make communities safer.

site_title: British consumer is still spending, says Primark owner
summary: A British consumer is still spending despite official data showing a slowdown in January, according to Associated British Foods (AB Foods), owner of discount fashion retailer Primark. AB Foods reported a 2% increase in Primark sales at UK stores for the first half, driven by increased retail space and market share. The company maintained its full-year earnings guidance, citing a strong performance in its sugar, grocery, and ingredients businesses. Despite inflation rising to 1.8% in January, AB Foods believes consumers have more disposable income, supporting its growth expectations.

site_title: Business giants to announce creation of new computing system
summary: Big tech companies including Microsoft, JPMorgan Chase, and IBM are joining forces to create a new computing system based on the Ethereum virtual currency network. The Enterprise Ethereum Alliance aims to standardize Ethereum software for businesses worldwide to track data and financial contracts. The alliance will create a private version of Ethereum for specific purposes and open it to certified participants, aiming to provide a foundation for various use cases and reduce infrastructure costs by up to 30%.

site_title: Time to start that old death watch on capitalism
summary: German sociologist Wolfgang Streeck argues that the global capitalist system is facing a crisis, characterized by slowing economic growth, rising indebtedness, and increasing inequality. Streeck, a former reformist, now believes the capitalist wealth machine is spinning out of control. He points to tax cuts for high earners and corporations, as well as reduced institutional protection of the market economy, as key culprits. Streeck's theories, rooted in a tradition that includes Karl Marx and Georg Hegel, suggest that capitalism has gone through repeated revolutions and transformations, and that today's troubles could be a prolonged period of uncertainty, rather than an imminent collapse.

site_title: Samsung's big deals, decisions seen on hold as Lee faces trial
summary: Samsung Group chief Jay Y Lee and four other top executives were charged with bribery and embezzlement, potentially hindering major strategic decisions, including acquisitions and management changes. Lee is accused of directing tens of millions of dollars to a confidante of President Park Geun-hye in exchange for government support of a 2015 merger. Samsung denies the allegations, but the indictment may lead to a more conservative business strategy and delay of major decisions. The company has a strong management team in place, and the market expects stability despite the indictment.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Singapore Reits have outperformed globally, but analysts question the fundamentals. Despite expected physical rental market recovery, modest distribution growth is expected due to increased interest expenses. Key catalysts include acquisitions, fundraising, and mergers. Analysts prefer stable operating DPU growth, recommending Mapletree Commercial Trust, CapitaLand, and City Developments.

site_title: The opportunity of a crisis
summary: Businesses face uncertainty due to the slowing economy and growing protectionism. Specialist centre Royal Healthcare plans to open in Tokyo or Osaka after Japan's Sojitz takes control. Researchers at NUS aim to halve the price of sustainable marine fuel. Tenants of Hao Mart's Taste Orchard lament poor footfall and vacant units. OCBC targets S$5 billion in loans to serial entrepreneurs by 2028. Shatec shuts its Orchard campus and cuts staff, putting the building up for sale. The Chinatown Business Association seeks S$77,700 from Nanyang Old Coffee over outdoor area use.

site_title: Asia fixed income outlook: Confidence is high, so is uncertainty
summary: Asia's fixed income outlook is marked by high confidence and uncertainty. Despite the uncertainty surrounding fiscal stimulus and monetary policy, the market expects global growth to rise for the first time in many years, driven by a pick-up in oil-related investment and stronger US growth. Investors should focus on credit-related securities, particularly in emerging markets, and prioritize shorter maturity securities to reduce interest-rate sensitivity. Despite elevated valuations, technical indicators suggest that spreads remain supportive, and the transition to fiscal policy may change investor perspectives. A diversified portfolio is essential in a rapidly changing market environment.

site_title: Cuban cigar sales rise, defying flat luxury goods market
summary: Cuban cigar sales rose 5% to $445 million in 2016, defying the stagnant luxury goods market. Habanos SA, the country's monopoly cigar manufacturer, expects moderate sales growth this year as it taps new markets. The company attributes its growth to increased tourism, which boosted sales by 13% last year. Despite a US trade embargo, cigar sales have improved due to improved US-Cuban relations, with American enthusiasts having better access to Cuban cigars since former President Barack Obama's policy change in 2015.

site_title: SpaceX to send two tourists around moon in 2018
summary: SpaceX announced on February 28, 2017, that two private citizens had paid to be sent around the moon, marking the farthest humans would have traveled to deep space since the US ended its Apollo missions in the 1970s.

site_title: China targets 'prudent' 12% growth in broad money supply for 2017 to cool credit expansion
summary: China aims to target a broad money supply growth of around 12% in 2017, slightly lower than the previous year's goal, to cool credit expansion and contain debt risks while maintaining economic growth. This is part of the government's "prudent and neutral" policy to address financial risks and asset bubbles. The move follows a review of China's economic targets, including a potential decrease in 2017's economic growth target to around 6.5%.

site_title: Riding on the digital wave
summary: Singaporean small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) are embracing digital marketing solutions, with companies like Hashmeta and Cactoz leading the way. Hashmeta, founded in 2012, offers digital marketing solutions, including social media, content influencer, and search marketing. The company has grown from three people to 29 staff and has achieved notable milestones, such as a viral Facebook campaign for Jurong Point's Mother's Day celebration. Cactoz, started in 2011, provides IT infrastructure and data analytics solutions, focusing on distribution and logistics, retail, and hospitality verticals. Both companies aim to scale regionally, with Cactoz seeking to build a strong partner ecosystem in Asia.

site_title: Straco Q4 net dips 2% as Xiamen revenue hit by typhoons
summary: Straco Corporation reported a near 2% year-on-year decline in net profit to S$6.14 million for Q4 2016, mainly due to lower revenue from Underwater World Xiamen (UWX) and Straco Leisure. Revenue fell 2.5% to S$23.24 million, while overall visits to attractions declined 2.6% to 0.915 million visitors. The company attributed the decline to typhoons affecting UWX's revenue and higher expenses, including staff costs and retail costs.

site_title: Yen inches higher ahead of Trump speech
summary: The Japanese yen rose 0.33% against the US dollar and euro ahead of President Donald Trump's speech to Congress, seeking safe-havens for investors. The dollar recovered from losses on Monday, driven by indications of tax cuts and interest rate hikes. Despite Trump's speech, investors remain uncertain about his ability to deliver legislation, leading to a continued search for safe assets. The yen's rise was seen as a sign of growing market anxiety, particularly in Europe, where politics is becoming increasingly uncertain.

site_title: Abe caught in scandal involving a school promoting hate speech
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe is facing a crisis after a kindergarten in Tokyo sent notes promoting hate speech against Koreans and Chinese, with allegations of a cover-up and involvement in a shady land deal. Abe denies wrongdoing, but his wife Akie has resigned as honorary principal of the school. The scandal has sparked widespread outrage and is seen as a major blow to Abe's tenure.

site_title: Newly registered companies
summary: Singapore's small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) are thriving. Royal Healthcare is set to open a specialist centre in Tokyo or Osaka, following a takeover by Japan's Sojitz. Researchers at NUS have developed a startup to halve the price of sustainable marine fuel. Meanwhile, OCBC aims to provide S$5 billion in loans to serial entrepreneurs by 2028. On the other hand, Shatec has shut down its Orchard campus and training restaurant, cutting 42 staff and putting the building up for sale. Local businesses are also innovating, such as Munchi Pancakes modernizing traditional min jiang kueh.

site_title: Government not in the business of picking winners: Iswaran
summary: Singapore Minister for Industry S Iswaran emphasized that the government's role is to launch support schemes, not pick winners. He stated that SMEs must seize these opportunities, citing the International Financing Scheme for Non-Recourse Financing as an example. The government has set aside S$1.5 billion for capability development in SMEs and expects to catalyse S$600 million in loans for infrastructure projects. Iswaran defended the government's position, saying that it is not about picking winners, but rather enabling SMEs to choose their own path to success.

site_title: Marshall Islands first to ratify global pact to curb use of hydrofluorocarbons
summary: The Marshall Islands became the first nation to ratify a global pact to curb the use of hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs), powerful greenhouse gases used in refrigerants and air conditioning, due to climate change risks. The decision, made by the Marshall Islands' parliament, is a sign of action despite uncertainty over US climate policies under President Trump. The Kigali pact, which will phase down HFC use, entered into force in 2019 and has been ratified by 132 nations, including the US, China, and Pacific island states.

site_title: Lady Gaga steps in for pregnant Beyonce at Coachella
summary: Lady Gaga has stepped in to replace the pregnant Beyoncé as the headliner for Coachella, marking the first time a woman has headlined the festival in over a decade. The change was made due to Beyoncé's doctor's orders to cancel her appearance, and Lady Gaga will perform on April 15 and 22. This move ensures a female headliner at the premier music event. Lady Gaga will also showcase her upcoming world tour and will perform alongside Radiohead and Kendrick Lamar.

images.alt_text: Lady Gaga has stepped in to replace the pregnant Beyonce at Coachella, ensuring that the premier music festival has a woman headliner for the first time in a decade.

site_title: Fed needs to be aware of the Ides of March
summary: US Federal Reserve officials believe interest rates may be raised during the March 14-15 Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) meeting, contrary to recent economic signs. Fed Chair Janet Yellen previously stated that rates would be raised sooner than later, citing a moderately expanding economy and inflation expected to rise to the 2% target. However, some economists argue that a rate hike may not be necessary, citing concerns about the impact of President Trump's proposed infrastructure spending and tax cuts on the economy.

site_title: Market a hive of activity as month ends
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 12.01 points to 3,096.61 on February 28, within expectations ahead of US President Donald Trump's address to Congress. The market saw a surge in volume, indicating month-end portfolio rebalancing, with over 2.7 billion units worth S$2.65 billion traded. The Dow futures initially fell but later remained almost flat for the day. This follows a decline in the US market amid concerns over tariffs and sanctions.

site_title: Hindenburg fears hinder hydrogen fuel cells use
summary: Toyota and Shell are facing challenges in promoting hydrogen fuel cells as a commercial alternative to petrol-powered cars due to lingering perceptions of the technology being hazardous, reminiscent of the 1937 Hindenburg disaster. However, proponents argue that fuel cells have been safely used for generations and have numerous advantages, including being safer and less polluting. Despite this, concerns over the technology's safety and the need for a refuelling network continue to hinder its widespread adoption, with the industry relying on government support to drive growth.

images.alt_text: A driver tanking up a Mirai hydrogen fuel-powered car by Toyota Motor Corp. Shell's most optimistic scenario is to be supplying hundreds of tonnes of hydrogen to the cars by 2030, says Mr Tipper.

site_title: Keeping pace with today's economy
summary: The Singapore government has been actively supporting small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) through various initiatives to help them navigate the challenges of the fourth industrial revolution. The Capability and Development Grant (CDG) provides financial assistance to SMEs to upgrade their capabilities in areas such as human capital development and financial management. The grant covers up to 70% of qualifying project costs, enabling SMEs to invest in training, equipment, and software to improve productivity and innovation. By adopting a global mindset and investing in digital tools, SMEs can capitalize on technology-driven change and attain sustained growth.

site_title: Reclusive icon of far right reaches out to Dutch voters ahead of March 15 elections
summary: Reclusive far-right leader Geert Wilders is campaigning ahead of the March 15 Dutch elections, promising to demand a "Nexit" referendum on leaving the European Union. Wilders, known as the "Dutch Trump," has built a movement despite infrequent public appearances, using social media to reach disillusioned citizens. He has promised to end immigration from Muslim countries, tax headscarves, and ban the Quran, and has been convicted of inciting discrimination and insulting an ethnic group. Wilders' success could signal the rise of far-right and populist forces in Europe, influencing pivotal ballots in France, Germany, and Italy later this year.

site_title: Billionaire investor Wilbur Ross confirmed as Trump's commerce secretary
summary: Billionaire investor Wilbur Ross was confirmed as US Commerce Secretary by the Senate in a 72-27 vote on February 28, 2017. Ross, known as the "king of bankruptcy," has a fortune of $2.5 billion and was chosen by President Donald Trump for trade negotiations.

site_title: GM boosts profit-sapping pickup discounts as rivals gain
summary: General Motors boosted incentives on its pickup models, averaging $6,996 for the Chevrolet Silverado and $5,315 for the GMC Sierra, in response to competitors Fiat Chrysler Automobiles and Ford Motor Co's price cuts. Discounts surged 56% and 82% respectively from last year, as the US car market slows following a seven-year expansion. GM's spending on large pickups is at its highest level since 2012, amid fierce brand loyalty among truck owners.

site_title: YuuZoo drops investment in American movie studio
summary: YuuZoo, a Singapore-based social networking company, has cancelled its planned investment of up to US$150 million in American movie studio Relativity Holdings Media, citing unmet conditions. The decision comes as YuuZoo posts a net loss of S$922,000 for its fourth quarter, with revenue of S$9.4 million, down from S$49 million a year earlier. The company has revised its revenue recognition policy, which had drawn debate from investors, and will continue to liaise with new partners for growth and development.

site_title: DC rates rise to play catch-up with land prices
summary: Singapore's Development Charge (DC) rates have increased by 4% for non-landed residential, 1.3% for commercial, and 2.6% for hotel use, while decreasing by 3.7% for industrial use. The hikes are attributed to strong developer appetite for condo development sites and record land bids, such as the Central Boulevard site. The increases aim to play catch-up with land prices, with the commercial and non-landed residential sectors witnessing significant interest from investors and developers. The changes are expected to have a limited impact on residential collective sales transactions.

images.alt_text: Amid strong developer appetite for condo development sites which has buoyed land prices, the government has upped the average DC (development charge) rate for non-landed residential use by 4 per cent for the March 1-Aug 31, 2017 period.

site_title: Toh Tuck site expected to be hotly contested
summary: The Toh Tuck site, a 18,721.4 sq m plot, is expected to be "hotly contested" in a public tender launched by the Urban Redevelopment Authority. The site can yield about 325 units and is within walking distance to Beauty World MRT station. Property consultants anticipate 8-13 bidders, with top bids ranging from S$680 to S$750 per square foot per plot ratio. The site's location and size are seen as attractive for mid-cap developers, and leasing demand in the area is expected to support the project's success.

site_title: Capgemini opens Singapore innovation centre
summary: Capgemini launched its Applied Innovation Exchange (AIE) in Singapore, its 10th globally and first in South-east Asia. The AIE focuses on data analytics, visualization, artificial intelligence, and cognitive computing, aiming to strengthen Singapore's reputation as an innovation hub and bolster local talent development. The centre will work with partners and academic institutions to create a databank of knowledge and expertise specifically for Singapore, and will also collaborate with existing AIEs globally.

site_title: ERA owners exploring IPO for S'pore's biggest property agency
summary: ERA Realty Network, Singapore's biggest property agency, is exploring an initial public offering (IPO) after a 21.5% increase in transactions in 2016, surpassing the market's 6.7% growth. The move comes four years after ERA's former listed parent, Hersing Corporation, delisted. Private equity firm Northstar Group, which owns ERA, has a 10-year fund lifespan that can be extended, allowing for a potential IPO. The exact timeline remains unclear, but Northstar's co-founder Patrick Walujo says there is still runway before the listing takes off.

site_title: JPMorgan's push towards automation goes into overdrive
summary: JPMorgan Chase & Co has launched a learning machine called Coin, which parses financial deals, reducing the time lawyers spend on commercial-loan agreements by 360,000 hours annually. The software reviews documents in seconds, is less error-prone, and automates mundane tasks. The bank is investing heavily in technology, with a $9.6 billion budget, to stay ahead of competitors and create new tools for bankers and clients. JPMorgan plans to deploy Coin for other complex legal filings and may use it to analyze corporate communications and regulations.

site_title: Diageo moves in on world's biggest whiskey market: India
summary: Diageo, the maker of Johnnie Walker and McDowell's whiskeys, sees opportunities in India's whiskey market, which is the world's largest. The company may increase its stake in United Spirits Ltd, the country's top distiller, after India bans liquor sales near highways. Despite the ban, Diageo expects growth due to rising middle-class incomes and a shift towards premium brands. The company has been the biggest beneficiary of India's growing thirst for whiskey, with consumption expanding 8.9% annually for six years.

site_title: Mobius still bullish on Asian equities despite spectre of Trump
summary: Asian equities have outpaced global markets this year, driven by a rising middle class, lower valuations, and economic growth projections. Top investors, including Mark Mobius, are optimistic about the region's potential, despite concerns about potential protectionist trade measures from the Trump administration. Mobius suggests focusing on Asian companies with manufacturing and sales operations in the US, which could benefit from tariffs. Asian stocks are undervalued compared to other regions, with the MSCI Asia Pacific Index trading at 17 times earnings, and are poised to benefit from US fiscal stimulus and recovering commodity prices.

site_title: Have common platform on supply chain: Olam
summary: Olam International CEO Sunny Verghese suggests that NGOs involved in palm oil industry efforts should create a common platform to trace supply chains from product to mill and plantation, potentially accelerating the process. The company aims to trace its supplies to the mill by 2020, but notes that individual efforts would take decades. Verghese also emphasizes the need for collaboration among industry players, as a common platform could aggregate certified sustainable mills and plantations.

site_title: HK-based CLSA shuts US equity research ops
summary: CLSA Ltd, a Hong Kong-based brokerage owned by Citic Group Corp, shut down its US equity research operations, laying off over half its US-based staff. The move affects 90 US-based staff, including analysts Mike Mayo and Avi Silver, and is attributed to "too many downward pressures" in stock research. The remaining 150 research employees are in Asia and Australia, while the Americas unit will now employ 85 workers to execute US and Asia stock trades.

site_title: Natural Cool flags possible irregularities at paint division
summary: Natural Cool Holdings, a Singapore-based company, has flagged possible irregularities at its paint division subsidiaries. The company also reported a full-year net loss due to impairments. This comes after a separate announcement earlier in the day.

site_title: Ezra unit ECS seeks US Chap 11 protection to ring fence US$90m lifeline
summary: Ezra Holdings' 40% unit, EMAS Chiyoda Subsea (ECS), has filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in the US to secure a US$90 million lifeline for financial and operational restructuring. DBS Bank and OCBC Bank have working capital and contingent claims totaling almost US$100 million against ECS. ECS has accumulated an order book of over US$1 billion, but project commencement dates remain in flux, negatively impacting financial performance. The company's existing shareholders have announced massive writedowns, and ECS faces trade claims and litigation. The Chapter 11 petitions will allow ECS to ringfence the pledged financing and retain control of its business operations.

site_title: Relook your rental needs
summary: Singapore SMEs face changing rental landscape, with favourable tenant's market and ample options available. Royal Healthcare is set to open a specialist centre in Tokyo or Osaka, while NUS researchers aim to halve the price of sustainable marine fuel. Tenants at Hao Mart's Taste Orchard lament poor footfall and vacant units. OCBC targets S$5 billion in loans for serial entrepreneurs by 2028, while Shatec shuts its Orchard campus and puts a building up for sale. Meanwhile, local businesses adapt to changing market trends, such as rebranding heritage and modernising traditional snacks.

site_title: Work whenever, wherever
summary: MyWork Global, a Singaporean tech company, has launched an on-demand job platform connecting workers with businesses in need of last-minute help. Founded by sister duo Rachael and Rebecca Chiu, the app has gained 15,000 downloads in its first five months and allows businesses to post jobs and workers to choose from available gigs. The platform aims to reinvent shift work in the age of digital transformation, providing flexibility and cost savings for both businesses and workers. The Chiu sisters' experience in the food industry led to the idea, and they've secured S$1 million in seed funding.

site_title: LTA and Mastercard launch 'tap & go' pilot for train and bus fares
summary: LTA and Mastercard have launched a pilot "tap & go" system for train and bus fares in Singapore, allowing Mastercard holders to pay for fares using their contactless credit or debit cards. The system, called Account-Based Ticketing (ABT), enables commuters to track their journey and fare payment history through the TransitLink ABT Portal or Mobile Services app. The pilot aims to attract at least 100,000 commuters, making Singapore the first country in Asia and one of the few cities worldwide to implement this system.

site_title: Broad-based policy, Budget 2017 measures can help firms: Iswaran
summary: Singapore's Minister for Industry S Iswaran reiterated the government's commitment to helping companies tackle immediate and medium-term challenges with the introduction of broad-based policy support and new measures in Budget 2017. The government aims to support small and medium enterprises (SMEs) and provide short-term relief where necessary. Iswaran emphasized the importance of collaboration with trade associations and chambers to ensure a thriving SME community and strong economy. Despite concerns over the lack of short-term measures, Iswaran stated that the government's efforts will continue to support businesses, with a focus on SMEs as key change agents.

site_title: Fewer business loans dent January bank lending
summary: Singapore bank lending in January saw a decline in business loans for the first time in four months, with a 0.1% drop from December. However, home loans and building and construction loans remained resilient. Total loans grew 2.8% year-over-year, slightly slower than December's 2.9% growth. Economists attribute the slowdown to the reduced number of working days in January due to the Chinese New Year. Despite this, they note that loan growth is still positive and expect business loans to pick up pace when confidence in the economy grows.

site_title: Oscars mistake threatens reputation of PwC
summary: PricewaterhouseCoopers (PwC), the accounting firm responsible for counting Oscars votes, made a major mistake at the 89th Academy Awards, incorrectly announcing La La Land as the winner of Best Picture when Moonlight was the actual winner. The error occurred when PwC presenters Faye Dunaway and Warren Beatty were handed the wrong envelope, which led to a chaotic scene on stage. PwC has accepted responsibility for the mistake and is investigating how it happened, with the firm's reputation potentially taking a hit. This is the largest mistake in Oscars history.

site_title: CIMB Q4 profit up 3.5%, beating forecasts
summary: CIMB Group Holdings Bhd, Malaysia's second-largest lender, reported a 3.5% rise in fourth-quarter profit, beating forecasts. The bank attributed the increase to improved loan growth and lower costs. CIMB's net profit for the December quarter was RM854.4 million, up from RM825.7 million a year earlier. The bank expressed optimism for 2017, citing sustainable loan growth and cost controls, and its cost-to-income ratio improved to 53.9% in 2016.

site_title: New York's historic Waldorf Astoria closing for facelift
summary: The Waldorf Astoria hotel in New York City is closing for a two-to-three year renovation. The historic hotel, which opened in 1931, has hosted numerous international leaders, celebrities, and power players. Guests have complained about dated rooms and cleanliness issues. The hotel's owner, Anbang Insurance Group, plans to convert many rooms into luxury apartments and reduce the hotel's services. The grand ballroom and other Art Deco features are at risk of being preserved, but the hotel's facade is protected as a landmark. The closure is a significant change for the hotel, which has been a New York institution for over 85 years.

site_title: Record nuclear shutdowns in America seen boosting natural gas
summary: US nuclear reactors plan to shut 34 reactors this spring, or over a third of nuclear generating capacity, to replace fuel rods. This shutdown may boost natural gas, the worst performer in the Bloomberg Commodity Index, as generators run harder to make up for the nuclear shortfall. The closures could provide some enthusiasm for the market, with natural gas prices tumbling 28% this year due to weak demand and unseasonably warm weather.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Singapore property developers GSH Corporation and Wheelock Properties reported losses in the three months ended December 2016, with GSH posting a net loss of S$3.3 million and Wheelock Properties a loss of S$16.4 million. In contrast, Hong Leong Asia reported a net loss of S$71.3 million for the full year ended December 2016, while Yeo Hiap Seng saw its net profit fall to S$10.3 million. Golden Energy and Resources, an international coal miner, returned to profitability with a net profit of US$21.8 million.

site_title: JPMorgan expects 2017 expenses to rise about 3.4%
summary: JPMorgan Chase & Co expects 2017 expenses to rise 3.4% to approximately US$58 billion, driven by increased spending on technology and new credit card accounts. This contradicts expectations of steady expenses, potentially impacting bank profits.

site_title: Super Group's Q4 profit dips on poorer gross margin, write-offs
summary: Super Group Ltd reported a 1% dip in Q4 net profit to S$15.5 million, down from S$15.7 million in the same period last year. The decline was attributed to lower gross profit margin and higher expenses resulting from write-offs. Earnings per share also decreased to 1.39 Singapore cents from 1.41 cents in Q4 FY2015.

site_title: Grain traders prepping to turn canola into fish oil substitutes to feed fish farms, health fads
