Core inflation also increased to 1.5%, led by higher electricity tariffs and services inflation. The data aligns with forecasts, marking a modest increase in inflation.

site_title: Australia Post boss resigns amid outcry over huge salary
summary: Australia Post CEO Ahmed Fahour has resigned amid backlash over his A$5.6 million salary, which politicians deemed excessive given the company's financial struggles. Fahour had led the postal service to a US$131 million half-year profit, despite a recent US$6.7 billion public bailout. He cited saving the company as his priority, stating it's not just a letter service but a parcels and e-commerce delivery giant. Fahour's resignation will take effect in July.

site_title: SBF urges Asean members of WTO to join the Trade Facilitation Agreement
summary: The Singapore Business Federation (SBF) has urged Asean members and all World Trade Organisation (WTO) members to join the Trade Facilitation Agreement (TFA), which came into force on Wednesday. The TFA aims to reduce trade barriers, making it easier for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) to compete globally. SBF CEO Ho Meng Kit hopes all WTO members, particularly Asean partners, will join, citing the agreement's potential to boost global trade flows and GDP growth, with estimated reductions of 12.5-17.5% in worldwide trade costs.

site_title: Magnus Energy subsidiary scraps purchase of Goyes Agri-Food Investment
summary: Magnus Energy's subsidiary APAC Coal scrapped the proposed A$136 million acquisition of Goyes Agri-Food Investment due to concerns it may not meet Australian Securities Exchange (ASX) requirements for admission to the official list. The ASX advised APAC that the transaction's structure and nature pose a significant risk. This decision comes after Magnus initially announced the acquisition in mid-2016.

site_title: Japan's crown prince says will model himself after father as emperor
summary: Japanese Crown Prince Naruhito, 57, has stated he will model himself after his father, Emperor Akihito, as he prepares to become emperor. Akihito, 83, is considering abdication due to health concerns, which could happen as early as next year. The last time an emperor abdicated was in 1817, and current law does not allow it. Prince Naruhito has expressed his willingness to share the pain and joys of the people, following in his father's footsteps in healing Japan's post-World War II wounds.

site_title: Asia: Stocks slump as dovish Fed minutes spur yen
summary: Asian stocks slumped as the US Federal Reserve's dovish minutes sparked a yen rally, with Japan's Topix index declining 0.5% and Australia's S&P/ASX 200 Index sliding 0.2%. The euro remained steady, while US dollar rose against most peers. The yen strengthened for a second day, while the S&P 500 index fell 0.1%. The odds for a March rate hike retreated to 36%, with Allianz chief Mohamed El-Erian saying this seems "too low".

site_title: Australia business investment slips again, outlook uninspiring
summary: Australian business investment declined 2.1% in the fourth quarter to A$27.6 billion, the fourth straight quarter of decline, driven by a 9% fall in the mining sector. New investment in manufacturing climbed 3.1%, but spending plans for 2017/18 fell to A$80.6 billion, the lowest in a decade. Economists are concerned about the lack of recovery in the non-mining economy, which keeps the prospect of another rate cut alive, with the Reserve Bank of Australia expected to set a high hurdle for lowering rates.

site_title: Ascott launches first living lab in Singapore in tie-up with SMU
summary: The Ascott Limited, a serviced residence business unit of CapitaLand, has launched its first living lab in Singapore, lyf@SMU, in partnership with the Singapore Management University (SMU). The lab, opening on Feb 27, will test co-living concepts and community building activities for over 1,200 millennials. The living lab features co-working lounges, communal tables, and recreation areas, and will gather data on user preferences and space usage patterns to inform lyf's design and operations. The goal is to roll out lyf in gateway cities globally by 2020.

site_title: Disrupting the disrupters: Singapore rattles sharing economy with rule
summary: Singapore has introduced tighter rules for sharing economy companies like Airbnb and Uber, aiming to balance encouraging disruptive technologies with keeping them in line. The rules, seen as a warning shot, could disrupt the growth ambitions of these companies in Asia. The move is a sign that even sympathetic governments struggle to strike the right balance between innovation and regulation. This move may impact the livelihoods of gig workers, such as Uber drivers, who may face reduced opportunities for part-time work.

images.alt_text: Singapore, a keen early adopter of the sharing economy, has fired a warning shot across the bow of Airbnb and Uber with tighter rules that could shake up their business models and growth ambitions in Asia.

site_title: Malaysia's Maybank Q4 profit rises 43%, beats estimates
summary: Malaysia's Maybank, the country's largest lender by assets, reported a 43% rise in Q4 profit to 2.36 billion ringgit (US$530.81 million), beating analyst estimates. Loan growth and investment income contributed to the increase. The bank expects stronger loan growth in its core markets of Malaysia and Indonesia, with a forecast of 6-7% loan growth this year. Net impaired loans ratio remained stable at 1.51%. Maybank's stock price fell 2.5% over the past year, making it the worst performer among Malaysia's banking sector stocks.

site_title: ST Electronics joins hands with DSTA to build next-gen earth observation satellite
summary: ST Electronics partners with the Defence Science & Technology Agency (DSTA) to develop the next-generation Earth Observation Satellite, TeLEOS-2. The satellite will have a 750kg mass and a Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) payload providing 1m resolution data. The partnership aims to strengthen Singapore's space industry and enhance ST Electronics' commercial satellite imagery services. The satellite will support government agencies and provide value-added services in urban planning, environmental monitoring, and maritime security. This marks the second successful collaboration between ST Electronics and DSTA, following the successful launch of TeLEOS-1.

site_title: CDL posts lower Q4, FY16 earnings on absence of one-time gain, weak market
summary: City Developments Limited (CDL) posted lower Q4, FY16 earnings due to the absence of a one-time gain from its Profit Participation Securities (PPS) platform. Net profit fell 40.6% to S$243.8 million in Q4 and 15.5% to S$653.2 million for FY16. Despite strong residential sales, the company's earnings were impacted by tough market conditions. CDL has a robust balance sheet and plans to be more acquisitive, focusing on finding in-place income in Singapore and overseas.

images.alt_text: Absence of the substantial profits recognised in the year-ago period from the second Profit Participation Securities (PPS) platform weighed down on City Developments Limited's (CDL) fourth-quarter net profit.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks edge down at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell 0.15% in early trading on Thursday, with the Hang Seng Index dropping 35.49 points to 24,166.47, following a global market rally that showed signs of slowing. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined, with the Shanghai Index falling 0.07% and the Shenzhen Index inching down 0.08 points. The decline was attributed to a Trump-fueled rally across global markets.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's share prices opened higher on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 0.28 points to 1,708.36. The market saw 163 gainers compared to 124 losers, with a total trading volume of 199.78 million lots worth RM86.93 million.

site_title: Seoul: Won set for third day of gains after dovish Fed minutes
summary: The South Korean won rose for a third consecutive session, reaching 1,139.5 against the US dollar, as the US Federal Reserve's January meeting minutes indicated a lower likelihood of a March rate hike. The won's gain was attributed to dollar weakness and reduced political anxieties in France. South Korean shares remained largely unchanged, with the Kospi index near its previous close, while offshore investors began to sell Kospi shares worth 27.5 billion won.

site_title: Australia shares slip as materials falter; New Zealand up
summary: Australian shares fell 0.4% on Thursday, driven by a 2% decline in the materials sector, with Rio Tinto and BHP Billiton experiencing significant losses. New Zealand's benchmark index rose 0.4%, led by gains in healthcare and industrial stocks. Ardent Leisure Group plummeted to a three-year low after reporting a half-year net loss. The decline in Australian shares follows a 0.2% gain in the previous session.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on February 23, 2017, as the yen strengthened against the US dollar. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index slipped 0.13% to 19,354.96, while the Topix index fell 0.13% to 1,554.99. Investors were influenced by the US Federal Reserve's latest meeting minutes.

site_title: Stocks to watch: CDL, Ezion, Singtel
summary: City Developments Limited reported a 40.6% decline in 4Q net profit to S$243.8 million and a 15.5% decline in FY net profit to S$653.2 million. Ezion Holdings sank into the red for 4Q with a net loss of US$66.6 million. Meanwhile, Singtel's subsidiary Amobee acquired Turn, a global digital marketing technology company, for US$310 million.

site_title: Fire breaks out at Tuas View Circuit; SCDF at scene as public advised to avoid area
summary: A fire broke out at the Eco Special Waste Management plant on Tuas View Circuit in Singapore on February 23, 2017. The Singapore Civil Defence Force (SCDF) was at the scene, advising the public to avoid the area. The cause of the fire is not specified.

site_title: Singapore Changi Airport sees 8.2% jump in Jan passenger movements from a year ago
summary: SINGAPORE Changi Airport reported an 8.2% increase in January passenger movements to 5.26 million, driven by air travel demand to Southeast Asia, Northeast Asia, and South Asia. China led the growth, with a 31% increase, followed by India and Indonesia. Aircraft movements rose 4.8% and cargo shipments remained steady. The airport serves over 100 airlines to 380 cities in 90 countries, with 7,000 flights per week and 58.7 million passengers annually.

site_title: Singapore shares open 0.07% lower
summary: Singapore shares opened 0.07% lower at 3,119.98, following a drop in oil prices on Wall Street overnight. The benchmark Straits Times Index (STI) saw 127.4 million units traded at S$132.1 million, with gainers beating losers 96 to 62. Key stocks included Genting Singapore, Sembcorp Marine, and oil and gas related plays.

site_title: Nissan says Ghosn to relinquish CEO role, Saikawa to take helm
summary: Nissan CEO Carlos Ghosn will step down, handing the helm to Hiroto Saikawa, who will become the sole CEO from April 1. Ghosn will remain as chairman, allowing him to focus on the Renault-Nissan-Mitsubishi Alliance. Ghosn cited taking on new responsibilities at Mitsubishi Motors as the reason for his decision. Saikawa, a 40-year Nissan veteran, has served as co-CEO since November and previously headed Japan's auto industry lobby.

site_title: GIC announces joint US$1.05b investment in Washington DC offices
summary: Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC has formed joint ventures to buy over 2.1 million sq feet of office assets in Washington DC for more than US$1.05 billion. The investments include Lafayette Centre and Pentagon Centre, with affiliates of Beacon Capital Partners also involved. This marks one of GIC's largest US investments, alongside existing holdings in New York and international markets. The move expands GIC's global real estate portfolio, now exceeding 350 property-related investments across 40 countries.

site_title: UK car production reaches 9 year high in January
summary: UK car production reached a 9-year high in January, with a 7.5% annual increase, driven by a 10.8% rise in sales to overseas markets. The industry faces concerns over a potential takeover by Peugeot, which could impact competitiveness and tariffs following Brexit. The Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders (SMMT) is seeking guarantees on future output and tariff-free access to the EU market to ensure continued growth.

site_title: Trump meets with corporate CEOs Thursday on economic policies
summary: President Donald Trump will meet with corporate CEOs on Thursday to discuss job creation and economic policies. The meeting will focus on areas such as deregulation, workforce training, infrastructure, taxes, and trade. CEOs from companies like Johnson & Johnson, Emerson Electric, and General Motors will attend, and the White House plans to compile recommendations from the groups. Trump has proposed tax and trade policies, including a border-adjustment tax, but its implementation is uncertain. The meeting aims to stimulate the American economy and address barriers to job creation.

site_title: Protecting Trump Tower cost NY City US$24m from election to inauguration
summary: New York City spent approximately $24 million, or $308,000 per day, to provide security at Trump Tower from Election Day to Inauguration Day. The city is seeking full federal reimbursement for the cost, with Mayor Bill de Blasio requesting $35 million in December. The security costs, including police and fire department expenses, are expected to increase significantly when President Trump is in town, with an average daily cost of $308,000.

images.alt_text: It cost New York City about US$24 million to provide security at Trump Tower, President Donald Trump's skyscraper home in Manhattan, from Election Day to Inauguration Day, or US$308,000 per day, New York's police commissioner said on Wednesday.

site_title: Singtel subsidiary Amobee acquires US firm Turn for US$310m
summary: Singtel subsidiary Amobee acquired US firm Turn for US$310 million, expanding its digital marketing capabilities. Turn's data and analytics solutions, as well as demand-side platform, will enhance Amobee's existing programmatic and data management capabilities. The acquisition is expected to accelerate Amobee's growth into a significant global digital marketing player, with Singtel CEO Samba Natarajan stating it will prime Amobee for expansion into the Asia-Pacific market. The deal strengthens Amobee's technological edge in the rapidly evolving digital advertising market.

site_title: US dollar edges lower on Fed minutes, French politics
summary: The US dollar fell against the euro and yen on Wednesday after Federal Reserve meeting minutes disappointed expectations for a hawkish tone, showing policymakers may not raise interest rates soon. The minutes also suggested a "modest risk" of inflation and ample time for the Fed to respond. French presidential candidate Marine Le Pen's perceived chances of winning fell, supporting the euro. The US dollar index was last down 0.2% at 101.220, while the euro reached a session high of $1.0572.

site_title: BOJ's Kiuchi says changing 10-year bond target 'not easy'
summary: Bank of Japan board member Takahide Kiuchi expressed concerns about changing the central bank's 10-year government bond yield target, citing potential erosion of credibility. Kiuchi, a former market economist, has been opposing the BOJ's asset-buying program and proposed tapering asset purchases. He also voted against the BOJ's decision to guide short-term interest rates at minus 0.1% and 10-year bond yields around zero percent. Kiuchi's comments suggest that changing the target may not be feasible in the near future due to low inflation rates.

images.alt_text: Bank of Japan board member Takahide Kiuchi said on Thursday changing the central bank's 10-year government bond yield target would not be easy as doing so frequently could erode its credibility.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks edge lower, tracking regional markets
summary: Taiwan's stocks edged lower on Thursday, tracking weak regional markets, after US Federal Reserve minutes indicated caution on further interest rate hikes. The main Taiex index fell 0.1% to 9,773.62 points, with the financials subindex losing 0.4% and the electronics subindex rising 0.1%. The decline followed weak regional markets, with US stocks reaching fresh records despite tariff concerns and US-EU trade talks in focus.

site_title: Ezion reports losses, completes talks with bankers and cuts rig orders as well as capex
summary: Ezion Holdings reported a net loss of US$66.6 million for the fourth quarter of 2016, down from US$63.5 million in the same period last year. The company canceled the delivery of 4 service rigs and cut capital expenditure by US$270 million to conserve cash. Impairment losses of US$70.9 million were attributed to projects committed at higher oil prices and uncertain market conditions. Ezion has completed talks with bankers and renewed its working capital facilities to improve liquidity and financing cash flows.

site_title: MVN Asset Management increases stake in Vard Holdings
summary: MVN Asset Management increased its stake in Vard Holdings to 6.0388% after acquiring 317,900 shares at S$0.27 apiece, boosting its holdings to 1.62 million shares. This comes after a previous purchase of 806,000 shares, fueling speculation about MVN's intentions regarding Fincantieri's offer to delist Vard's Singapore-listed subsidiary. The move may impact Fincantieri's offer, which was deemed fair and reasonable by KPMG but lower than Vard's net asset value per share.

site_title: Australia's Crown profit up but high-roller revenue falls
summary: Crown Resorts, Australia's largest casino operator, reported a 75% increase in second-half net profit to A$359 million due to scaling down a Macau joint venture and offsetting weaker high-roller revenue. The company's CEO, Rowen Craigie, is stepping down, and Crown has shelved plans for a Las Vegas casino. A 13.4% stake in Melco Crown Entertainment was sold for US$1.6 billion, reducing Crown's Macau holdings. The firm's Australian operations will remain a focus under the new management structure.

images.alt_text: Australian mogul James Packer's Crown Resorts reported a sharply higher second-half net profit on Thursday after scaling down a Macau joint venture which offset weaker turnover from high rollers.

site_title: Addvalue Innovation partners Institute for Infocomm Research to boost competitiveness
summary: Addvalue Technologies' subsidiary, Addvalue Innovation, partners the Institute for Infocomm Research (I²R) to boost competitiveness in the satellite communications industry. The Joint-lab Collaboration Agreement, signed in 2017, aims to leverage I²R's expertise in antenna and efficient power amplification for satellite communication. This collaboration will help Addvalue innovate and develop new business models, with the goal of maximizing value for their businesses. The partnership builds on existing ties between the two entities, which have worked together for nearly two decades.

site_title: Apple 'spaceship' headquarters readies for boarding
summary: Apple's new "spaceship" campus in Silicon Valley is set to begin boarding over 12,000 employees in April, fulfilling a vision by late founder Steve Jobs. The campus, named Apple Park, features a theater in honor of Jobs, who would have turned 62 on February 24. The move is expected to continue into the year, with the new campus serving as a "centre for creativity and collaboration."

site_title: Princess Diana's iconic dresses on show for anniversary
summary: A new exhibition, "Diana: Her Fashion Story," opens at Kensington Palace in London, marking the 20th anniversary of Princess Diana's death. The show features iconic dresses, suits, and mini-dresses worn by Diana, showcasing her evolution from formal royal attire to more informal, expressive styles. The exhibition highlights how Diana used fashion to convey her personality and express her charitable causes, with pieces including the "Travolta" dress and the "Gold Falcon Gown." The show also features personal touches, such as tiny fingerprints believed to belong to Prince William and Prince Harry.

site_title: Air New Zealand posts 24% fall in half-year profit as competition heats up
summary: Air New Zealand posted a 24% decline in half-year profit to NZ$256 million due to increased competition from rival airlines, such as Emirates, Tianjin Airways, and China Southern. Despite record profits last year, low oil prices and double-digit growth tourism are expected to continue. The airline forecast full-year earnings between NZ$475-525 million and plans to pay an interim dividend of NZ$0.10 per share. Higher oil prices and potential headwinds on US routes are expected to affect the airline's performance in the second half.

site_title: KrisEnergy widens FY16 losses on higher expenses, impairment on Thai assets, write-off of assets
summary: KrisEnergy reported a net loss of $235.3 million for FY16, more than doubling from $41.6 million in FY15, due to higher expenses and impairments on Thai assets and write-offs of exploration assets. Revenue rose to $142.8 million, driven by increased crude oil and gas sales, but operating costs more than doubled to $81.8 million. The company also issued senior secured notes and detachable equity warrants to raise $139.5 million and repaid outstanding debts. Loss per share grew to 15.7 US cents, up from 3.4 US cents in FY15.

site_title: Telstra sells 6.5% stake in Autohome to Chinese insurer Ping An
summary: Telstra has sold its 6.5% stake in Chinese online business Autohome to Ping An Insurance Group for US$217 million, with the sale price of US$29.30 per share in line with Autohome's recent trading levels. This divestment reflects Ping An's established strategic partnership with Autohome, and the sale price is expected to be retained by Telstra. As a result, Telstra's nominee director to the Autohome board has resigned.

site_title: Bowie wins as Brit Awards pay tribute to George Michael
summary: David Bowie won two posthumous Brit Awards, taking home the British male solo artist and best album for Blackstar, beating Skepta and Michael Kiwanuka. Emeli Sande was named British female solo artist, and The 1975 won the British group statuette. The ceremony paid tribute to late artists George Michael and Leonard Cohen, with Coldplay performing Michael's A Different Corner. Other winners included Drake, Beyonce, and A Tribe Called Quest, but the event was criticized for a lack of diversity in some categories, with Bowie's wins sparking controversy.

site_title: Trump to unveil first budget 'mid-March'
summary: US President Donald Trump plans to unveil his first government budget in mid-March, a nearly $4 trillion annual federal budget that outlines his policy goals. Trump has promised to cut waste and renegotiate federal contracts, but faces a national debt of $20 trillion and a rising deficit. His campaign promises, including building a border wall and deporting undocumented immigrants, carry an estimated price tag of $5.3 trillion. Trump has downplayed criticism of the upcoming plan, citing his limited time in office and the need to address a "mess" in the country's finances.

site_title: US Fed officials say they may need to raise rates 'fairly soon'
summary: US Federal Reserve officials may need to raise interest rates "fairly soon" due to the uncertainty surrounding President Donald Trump's tax and spending policies. The minutes of the Fed's January meeting revealed a split among central bankers on the timing of a rate hike, with some concerned about rising inflation and others warning of the risk of raising rates prematurely. The Fed has not changed its outlook for the economy and interest rates since December, but the March meeting is expected to be a key decision point.

site_title: Qantas first-half underlying profit falls 7.5%, defers Airbus deliveries
summary: Qantas Airways reported a 7.5% decline in first-half underlying profit to A$852 million, deferring Airbus deliveries due to intense international competition and weak domestic market conditions. The airline attributed the decline to lower fares on international routes, impacting all major airlines. Qantas also announced an interim 50% franked dividend and a share buyback. The company expects revenue to moderate in the second half of the year, but unit revenue declined 5% in the first half.

site_title: Embark on tax policies that change behaviour
summary: Singapore's finance minister Heng Swee Keat's budget has been criticized for its ineffective use of tax policies to drive economic and social behavior. The government's reliance on funding rather than policy changes has led to low tax rates and unintended outcomes. Key measures, such as the Special Employment Credit and income tax rebate, are deemed insufficient to influence behavior. The government should focus on refining policies to target specific behaviors and not burden low-income consumers. Additionally, future funding may take the form of additional tariffs, emphasizing the need for targeted taxation.

site_title: Europe: Flat shares helped by positive earnings updates
summary: European shares remained at 14-month highs on Wednesday, supported by strong earnings updates from companies such as Lloyds, Telefonica Deutschland, and Scor. Lloyds rose 3.3% on a ten-year high in profits, while Telefonica Deutschland and Scor also saw gains. Unilever rose 5.7% after reviewing options to drive shareholder value, and ThyssenKrupp gained 4.6% after selling a Brazilian steel mill. The STOXX 600 index ended flat, but Germany's DAX rose 0.3%.

site_title: IMF chief 'reassured' after talks with Trump's team
summary: IMF chief Christine Lagarde expressed reassurance after her meetings with US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin, describing the discussions as "positive" and "reassuring." Lagarde stated that Mnuchin's desire to work with the IMF on financial stability is "clear" and that he expects a candid assessment of exchange-rate policies. The meetings come amid global jitters over Trump's economic program, which has raised concerns about protectionist policies and their potential impact on the US economy and global growth.

images.alt_text: IMF chief Christine Lagarde said on Wednesday that she had been reassured by her first meetings with members of the new administration of US President Donald Trump, whose economic programme has caused global jitters.

site_title: First drug-resistant malaria parasite detected in Africa
summary: Researchers have detected a malaria parasite in Africa that is partially resistant to the top anti-malaria drug, artemisinin. The discovery, published in the New England Journal of Medicine, is a major concern as it means Africa joins southeast Asia in hosting drug-resistant forms of the disease. Malaria infected 200 million people and killed 438,000 in 2015, mostly in Africa. The parasite, carrying a Kelch13 mutation, was found in a Chinese patient who had traveled from Equatorial Guinea. The finding highlights the need to regularly monitor artemisinin resistance worldwide.

site_title: Oil drops on worries of swelling US stockpiles
summary: Oil prices fell 1.5% on Wednesday due to expectations of increased US inventories, but traded near multi-week highs after OPEC expressed optimism over its production deal. Analysts estimated a 3.3 million barrel increase in crude stocks last week, and the US Energy Information Administration's data is due Thursday. Despite this, OPEC's Secretary General stated the group and other producers will boost output curb compliance to clear a supply glut. Goldman Sachs expects oil prices to recover in the second quarter, with WTI rising to $57.50 and Brent reaching $59.

site_title: Singapore readies new leveraged and inverse ETFs to catch rivals
summary: Singapore is set to launch its first new leveraged and inverse exchange-traded funds (ETFs) in almost eight years, aiming to capture a bigger share of the expanding global market. The move follows revised guidelines from the Monetary Authority of Singapore and is part of a strategy to expand its presence in the Asia-Pacific region. The new listings are expected to be structured as open-end funds, offering a form of passive collective investment schemes similar to existing ETFs in Japan, Taiwan, and Korea.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Analysts from DBS Group Research and OCBC Investment Research have provided mixed views on PACC Offshore Services Holdings. DBS Research upgraded PACC to a buy target, citing an inflexion point in oil majors' capex plans and a gradual earnings recovery in 2018. OCBC Investment Research downgraded PACC to a sell target, citing impairments and a significant year-on-year drop in revenue. Meanwhile, Auric Pacific Group upgraded its target price to S$1.96, citing a strong FY16 core net profit and a 42% net cash position.

site_title: Donald Tsang jailed 20 months for misconduct
summary: Former Hong Kong leader Donald Tsang was sentenced to 20 months in prison for misconduct, making him the most senior city official ever convicted in a criminal trial. He was found guilty of failing to disclose his plans to lease a luxury flat from a major investor, which was later granted a government licence. Tsang's breach of trust was deemed "significant" by the judge, who described him as having "deliberately concealed" his dealings.

site_title: US: Dow hits fresh record as S&P 500, Nasdaq retreat
summary: US stocks closed at records, with the Dow reaching a new high for the ninth straight day, despite a retreat in the S&P 500 and Nasdaq. The Dow's record streak is attributed to anticipation of major tax cuts under President Trump, but analysts suggest the market may be due for a breather. The US Federal Reserve also expects another rate hike "fairly soon." European markets finished slightly higher, with a boost from the French presidential election, while Japan's Nikkei soared on hopes of Toshiba's chip business being sold.

site_title: Shining more light on non-ED remuneration
summary: Singaporean companies often fail to disclose non-executive director (NED) remuneration, potentially compromising their independence. Some companies, such as GKE Corporation and Vicplas International, paid "bonuses" to NEDs without clear justification, sparking concerns about governance and independence. The Singapore Code recommends that NEDs be remunerated differently from executive directors and that their remuneration be disclosed in full. Companies should disclose all remuneration paid to NEDs, including those paid for serving on other entities within the group, and obtain shareholder approval for all "emoluments" paid to NEDs.

site_title: Push to keep fiscal system sustainable is sensible, timely (Amended)
summary: Singapore's Budget 2017 emphasizes maintaining a sustainable fiscal system to drive tax changes, as the country faces rising domestic spending and global tax rule changes. Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat announced a new carbon tax from 2019, diesel tax changes, and a hike in water prices to promote environmental sustainability. The government is also studying options to raise revenues through new taxes or tax rate hikes, and exploring GST changes on digital supplies from abroad. The goal is to maintain a broad-based, progressive, and fair tax system while staying competitive and pro-growth.

site_title: Lower revenue, absence of fair value gain hit Fragrance full-year profit
summary: Fragrance Group reported a 89% drop in net profit to S$7.5 million for its full financial year due to lower property development revenue and an absence of substantial fair value gain on investment properties.

site_title: IMF chief says Greek debt needs to be restructured, not forgiven
summary: IMF chief Christine Lagarde stated that Greece's debt needs restructuring, not forgiveness, during a meeting with German Chancellor Angela Merkel. This contradicts the idea of debt forgiveness by creditors, which Lagarde said is not needed at present. Greece faces a July deadline to pay 7 billion euros in new debt payments, and the IMF wants to see more guarantees before releasing the latest bailout cash. The IMF has been at odds with European creditors over debt relief and budget targets, but Lagarde expressed increased confidence in resolving the debt crisis.

images.alt_text: "The amount (of debt) will have to be restructured," Christine Lagarde (right), the International Monetary Fund's managing director, told German television channel ARD after meeting Chancellor Angela Merkel in Berlin.

site_title: AccorHotels beats 2016 forecasts; Sarkozy to head int'l strategy
summary: AccorHotels, Europe's largest hotelier, posted a record operating profit of 696 million euros in 2016, beating forecasts. The company's restructuring efforts and robust demand in Germany and Britain offset weakness in France. AccorHotels plans to sell its HotelInvest property business for 6.6 billion euros, with former French president Nicolas Sarkozy leading its international strategy. The sale is expected to raise cash for expansion and compete with rising challenges from companies like Airbnb. However, shares lost ground due to concerns over cash use and lack of 2017 guidance.

site_title: Slowing economy not a blip for fresh grads in job market
summary: A joint graduate employment survey in Singapore found that nearly 90% of fresh graduates from top universities such as NUS, NTU, and SMU secured jobs within six months of completing their final exams, with higher starting salaries. The mean gross monthly salary increased to S$3,515, up from S$3,468 in 2015. SMU graduates took home the highest pay, with a mean gross monthly salary of S$3,722, and a median salary of S$3,500.

site_title: Australia central bank sees danger in high household debt
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia's governor, Philip Lowe, signaled that further interest rate cuts would not be in the national interest due to high household debt. Lowe warned that a debt-fueled boom and bust could harm the economy, citing a record 180% ratio of household debt to disposable income. Despite low inflation, Lowe expressed concern about spurring more debt, which could lead to a sharp cutback in consumption and hurt the economy and employment.

site_title: EU risks collapse if irreconcilable differences not tackled
summary: The European Union is at risk of collapse due to irreconcilable differences among its member states, particularly Greece and Germany. Greece's debt crisis continues to worsen, with creditors demanding repayment and the EU unwilling to offer sufficient debt relief. The EU's economic and monetary union is in crisis, and a breakdown is possible if the issues are not addressed. The UK's Brexit vote has set a precedent, and other EU countries are re-examining their relationship with the EU, leading to concerns about the EU's long-term viability.

site_title: Hedge funds lose bid to quash Fannie, Freddie profit grab
summary: Hedge funds' bid to quash Fannie and Freddie's profit grab fails, causing shares to plummet. A federal appeals court rejected the challenge to the "net-worth sweep" policy, which forces the mortgage guarantors to send profits to the US Treasury. Shares of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac dropped 35% and 38% respectively, while some preferred shares fell over 30%. The hedge funds can still pursue contract-based claims, and may appeal to the US Supreme Court.

site_title: S Korea firm plans solar plant for Aussie smelter
summary: Sun Metals, an Australian zinc refinery, plans to invest A$183 million to build a massive solar farm to power its zinc refinery, addressing Australia's electricity price surges and power failures. The move comes as the country grapples with a 20% renewable energy target by 2020, disrupting smelting and refining businesses. The solar farm, set to be Australia's largest, will generate electricity at a lower cost than current wholesale prices, benefiting the smelter and potentially others in the industry.

site_title: PSA chief assures Merkel, German unions over GM deal
summary: PSA Group has assured German Chancellor Angela Merkel and top labour representatives that it will uphold job guarantees for Opel and Vauxhall employees if it buys General Motors' European arm. This comes after a charm offensive, where PSA chief Carlos Tavares discussed plans with Merkel and sought reassurance from German labour unions and Opel's European works council. Despite this, some analysts predict thousands of job losses will occur in the long run.

site_title: Ex-forex traders in Singapore get jail time for cheating banks
summary: Two former currency traders, Ivan Chng and Toh Hway Khuan, were sentenced to up to 15 weeks in jail for cheating their banks by making false trades in 2009 to gain preferential US dollar rates. Chng was sentenced to 15 weeks and Toh to 8 weeks, with neither receiving a fine. The men were convicted of using their accounts to gain substantial six-figure gains through deceitful means and deliberate deception. The sentences aim to deter those in the financial industry from making personal gains through deceitful means.

site_title: TravelersBox sees big business in small change
summary: TravelersBox, a fintech company, sees significant business in converting leftover foreign currency at airports, particularly in Asia. Since mid-December, its kiosks at Changi Airport have processed four times more transactions than the next best performing airport. The company, which accepts nine currencies, generates a 7% fee per transaction and is working with over 80 brands. TravelersBox plans to expand to Hong Kong, Thailand, Russia, Dubai, and China, and expects to break even by the end of the year, with over one million transactions processed globally so far.

site_title: Analysts say HK's Budget is short on ideas and details
summary: Hong Kong's new Financial Secretary, Paul Chan, delivered a budget with few high notes, lacking concrete details on key issues such as innovation and technology development. Analysts welcomed the move to overhaul the tax regime and introduce a tax policy unit to examine Hong Kong's international competitiveness. The budget allocates HK$61 billion for medium- to long-term initiatives, and fiscal policy-making may become more flexible, according to Chan's estimates for fiscal deficits.

site_title: Sad ongoing saga of Japan's electronics industry collapse
summary: Japan's electronics industry continues to face a collapse, with Toshiba's massive writedown on its nuclear power operation being the latest in a long line of failures. Other companies, such as Sony, Olympus, and Sharp, have also struggled, with a lack of management skills, financial incompetence, and a "cover-up" culture contributing to their downfall. Despite corporate governance reforms, the industry's inward-looking attitude and failure to adapt to international markets have hindered its growth. Asian rivals, such as China and Taiwan, are now taking advantage of the situation, with Toshiba potentially selling its core memory chip business.

site_title: SembMarine back in the black with S$34.29m Q4 profit (Amended)
summary: Sembcorp Marine, a Singapore-listed yard group, reported a net profit of S$34.29 million for the fourth quarter, reversing a net loss of S$536.88 million in the same period last year. The company's turnover decreased 37.5% due to a decline in rig and floaters contracts, but gross profit increased to S$34.72 million. Full-year net profit for FY16 was S$78.78 million, and the company declared a final cash dividend of one Singapore cent per share. Despite challenging market conditions, SembMarine's order book remained robust at S$7.8 billion.

images.alt_text: Singapore-listed yard group Sembcorp Marine is back in the black for the fourth quarter with a net profit of S$34.29 million, a reversal from a net loss of S$536.88 million, mainly on the absence of impairment and provisions for its rig building projects.

site_title: Qingjian Realty ropes in Singtel for its Internet-ready EC
summary: Qingjian Realty has partnered with Singtel and lifestyle app hiLife to develop iNz Residence, Singapore's first Internet-ready executive condominium (EC). The project will feature fibre broadband and smart home capabilities, with units expected to be priced around S$730 per square foot. The developer has set an e-application deadline of Feb 24, and experts predict strong demand for the project due to its low land cost and realistic pricing. This follows the success of nearby EC project Wandervale, which was sold at S$760 per square foot in 2016.

site_title: Genting Singapore reverses loss with earnings of S$159 million in Q4
summary: Genting Singapore reported a net profit of S$159.19 million for the fourth quarter of 2016, reversing a net loss of S$7.75 million in the same period last year. The company's gaming revenue rose 7% to S$398.63 million, while non-gaming revenue fell 8% to S$158.51 million. The group's adjusted EBITDA grew 29% to S$233.7 million, driven by improved margins in the VIP gaming business. Genting's full-year net profit rose to S$266.35 million, and the company expects to record a gain on disposal of S$96.3 million in the first quarter of 2017.

site_title: Hard Rock seeks up to 60% stake in Japanese casino
summary: Hard Rock International is seeking up to a 60% stake in a Japanese casino resort, aiming to enter the world's second-largest casino market. The company, known for its music-themed restaurants, plans to partner with Japanese companies in a consortium. Japan's regulation of casinos is expected to be laid out in law by December, with potential operating rights up for grabs. The move could generate $10 billion in annual revenue, with analysts predicting Japan could become the second-largest casino market, rivaling the US.

site_title: Melco pledges to spend 'whatever it takes' on Japan casino
summary: Melco Crown Entertainment Ltd has pledged to spend "whatever it takes" to win a casino resort in Japan, with CEO Lawrence Ho stating that his top choice is Osaka. The company, which operates the US$3.2 billion Studio City resort in Macau, aims to invest a significant amount, depending on the host city, with a focus on entertainment and tourism expansion. This move follows Japan's legalization of casinos in December, with the market predicted to be worth up to US$25 billion.

site_title: Verizon still buying Yahoo despite that epic security breach
summary: Verizon has agreed to a $350 million discount from its initial $4.8 billion deal to acquire Yahoo, despite the company's historic security breaches affecting hundreds of millions of users. The discount, or 7% of the original price, is attributed to a "minimal" loss of active Yahoo users, with Verizon's internal investigation finding that only a few users abandoned the company. The deal still allows Verizon to control Yahoo's core properties, including Tumblr and news sites, to sell advertising to millions of users and gather behavioral data.

site_title: US judge dismisses most of Euribor-rigging lawsuit
summary: A US judge dismissed most of a lawsuit accusing several major banks of conspiring to manipulate the European Interbank Offered Rate (Euribor) and related derivatives. The judge ruled that only two plaintiffs, California State Teachers' Retirement System and FrontPoint Australian Opportunities Trust, had sufficient antitrust standing. The remaining defendants, including Citigroup and JPMorgan Chase, may face one antitrust claim and two common law claims. The decision followed a 100-page ruling that the defendants did not conspire to restrain trade or involve foreign conduct.

site_title: HSBC Singapore gets new CEO
summary: HSBC Singapore has appointed Tony Cripps, former CEO of HSBC Australia, as its new CEO, effective April 3, 2017. Cripps will lead the bank through its next phase of growth and investment in Singapore, following a year of declining profits. HSBC Singapore's customer accounts fell to US$39.1 billion in 2016, down from US$41.3 billion in 2015. Cripps will oversee the bank's retail banking and wealth management business, which was incorporated locally in May 2016.

images.alt_text: Mr Cripps was also appointed a non-executive director of HSBC Bank (Singapore) in 2016.

site_title: JPMorgan, Morgan Stanley, HSBC to underwrite Saudi Aramco IPO
summary: Saudi Aramco has selected JPMorgan Chase & Co, Morgan Stanley, and HSBC Holdings plc as lead underwriters for its planned initial public share offering (IPO), expected to be the world's biggest IPO, raising up to $100 billion. The listing is part of Saudi Arabia's Vision 2030 plan to diversify the economy beyond oil. Aramco will list 5% of its shares on the Saudi stock exchange and potentially on international markets, with the IPO centrepiece of the ambitious plan to restructure the economy.

site_title: China selfie-app leader Meitu gaining traction abroad
summary: China's selfie-app leader Meitu is gaining traction abroad, with over 450 million active China users and 430 million overseas users, challenging Instagram and Snapchat. The app's popularity is driven by its advanced features and its appeal to China's powerful consumer force, particularly women. Meitu's virtual makeovers, which digitally alter facial features, have become a key aspect of Chinese online beauty culture, with the company valuing the global potential of Chinese apps. Despite consistently posting losses, Meitu's shares have risen 16% since its Hong Kong IPO.

site_title: IPF scheme in right direction, but SMEs must not be passed over: industry watchers
summary: Singapore's International Partnership Fund (IPF) aims to support companies in scaling up and internationalizing with up to S$600 million in government capital. However, industry watchers express concerns that larger enterprises may be prioritized over smaller enterprises, which could limit the fund's benefits for smaller companies. The Ministry of Finance has stated that the fund will not focus on specific sectors and will be launched at the end of the year. Experts suggest that a more flexible approach and caps on investment amounts could help balance the benefits for both large and small companies.

site_title: SpiceJet says India's US$85b plane orders still not enough
summary: India's airlines have ordered about 850 planes valued at US$85 billion, but SpiceJet Ltd, a budget carrier, believes this is not enough to meet demand. Chairman Ajay Singh attributes the surge in demand to economic growth in smaller towns, fueling an increase in Indians flying. SpiceJet has ordered 205 Boeing jets worth US$22 billion in the past month, but Singh believes more purchases are needed to keep up with demand.

site_title: Cult Japanese film director Seijun Suzuki dead at 93
summary: Japanese film director Seijun Suzuki, known for his influential B-movies, has died at 93. Suzuki's prolific output, spanning five decades, influenced international filmmakers including Quentin Tarantino and Jim Jarmusch. His unique style, characterized by vivid color and surrealism, was praised by director Damien Chazelle, who cited Suzuki's films as an inspiration. Suzuki's work was not widely known outside Japan, but had a significant impact on the film industry.

site_title: Nominations open for Business China Awards
summary: The Business China Awards (BCA) 2017 nominations are now open until March 10, honoring individuals and organizations for their contributions to Singapore-China relations in three categories: Business China Excellence Award, Business China Enterprise Award, and Business China Young Achiever Award. Last year's winners include Prof Wang Gungwu, the Bank of China, and Jenny Lee. This year's 10-member judging panel will select winners, with results announced at the awards ceremony in July. The awards celebrate exceptional vision and leadership, business growth, and innovation in the Singapore-China market.

site_title: French politics pushes euro below US$1.05
summary: The euro fell below US$1.05 for the first time in six weeks due to concerns over France's presidential election campaign and expectations for a rise in US interest rates. Investors shifted their focus to the US dollar and the yen, with the yen rising half a percent against the greenback and 0.8 percent against the euro.

site_title: Immigrant crackdown could cost US$5t via squeeze on US job market
summary: US President Donald Trump's crackdown on undocumented immigrants could cost the US economy $5 trillion over 10 years, according to a study by the National Bureau of Economic Research. Removing these workers would strain the already tight US job market, with industries like agriculture, construction, and hospitality already facing worker shortages. The study estimates that undocumented immigrants contribute 3% to private-sector GDP, equivalent to the output of Massachusetts.

site_title: China home price growth eases for 4th straight month
summary: China's home price growth slowed for the fourth consecutive month, with average new home prices increasing 0.2% month-on-month, according to January data. The slowdown suggests regulators are making progress in keeping speculative investors out of the market. Despite this, the country's debt to GDP ratio rose to 277% at the end of 2016, prompting concerns of a banking crisis and potential economic slowdown.

site_title: Carmakers in US seek withdrawal of decision to lock in emission rules
summary: US carmakers, including General Motors and Toyota, are urging Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) chief Scott Pruitt to withdraw a decision to lock in vehicle emission rules through 2025, citing job losses and increased costs. The rules, finalized by former EPA administrator Gina McCarthy, aim to maintain a key climate legacy. The Alliance of Automobile Manufacturers argues that the rules could result in up to one million job losses due to higher prices, while environmentalists say the rules are working, saving drivers thousands in fuel costs.

site_title: Bailed-out Lloyds Banking posts surge in 2016 profit
summary: Lloyds Banking Group (LBG) posted a surge in annual profits, more than quadrupling to £2 billion in 2016, driven by lower charges linked to an insurance scandal. The bank took a £1 billion hit to compensate customers mis-sold insurance, but this is a significant reduction from a £4 billion bill in 2015. LBG awaits a full return to the private sector after a state bailout, with the UK government selling down its stake to below 5%. The bank's shares jumped 3.5% following the announcement.

site_title: Uber CEO apologises for failings after harassment claims
summary: Uber CEO Travis Kalanick apologized for cultural failings and lack of diversity at the company after a former employee alleged she was harassed and discriminated against. Kalanick spoke at an internal meeting alongside board member Arianna Huffington, acknowledging mistakes and vowing to build a better Uber. The apology comes amid a tumultuous year for the company, marked by controversy over its handling of a New York taxi drivers' strike and allegations of sexual harassment by former employee Susan Fowler. Kalanick aims to improve employee morale and contribute to industry-wide improvements.

site_title: FEHT posts weaker Q4 DPS of 1.12 cents on soft sector
summary: Far East Hospitality Trust (FEHT) reported a weaker fourth-quarter income available for distribution (DPS) of 1.12 cents, down 4.3% year-over-year, due to reduced revenue from hotels and serviced residences. Revenue dropped 4.6% to S$27.5 million, mainly attributed to soft corporate travel demand and increased competition. The hotel portfolio's revenue per available room (RevPAR) fell 7.3% year-over-year to S$136. Despite this, the trust plans to refurbish guest rooms at Orchard Parade Hotel to improve competitiveness.

site_title: US existing home sales march higher in January
summary: US existing home sales rose 3.3% in January to 5.69 million units, the fastest pace in nearly a decade, according to the National Association of Realtors. Sales were driven by consumer confidence and robust job gains, with all regions except the Midwest experiencing gains. The median home price rose 7.1% to $228,900, marking 59 consecutive months of year-over-year gains. Analysts expect sales growth to continue, but at a slower pace, and warn of potential corrections due to rising mortgage rates and inventory levels.

site_title: S Korean women may live past 90 by 2030, say researchers
summary: South Korea is predicted to have women living past 90 by 2030, with an average lifespan of nearly nine decades, surpassing other developed countries such as France and Japan. The country's success is attributed to broad economic gains, improved child nutrition, and universal access to healthcare. In contrast, the US life expectancy is expected to fall behind, with a predicted lifespan of 81-83 years for women and 76-79 years for men, mainly due to high mortality from chronic diseases and violence, and insufficient healthcare.

site_title: Indonesia's big banks told to submit plans for coping with crisis
summary: Indonesia's banking regulator, the Financial Services Authority (OJK), has ordered the country's largest banks to submit internal recovery plans by year-end to ensure they can recover from potential insolvency without government bailouts. The measure aims to prevent the use of state budget to support troubled banks. The regulator, Muliaman Hadad, requires bank executives to sign the plans, which must include a recovery task force. The move comes as Indonesia's parliament has passed a law outlining a step-by-step protocol for handling financial crises, including limiting state support.

site_title: Wenger must stick to his Gunners
summary: Arsenal manager Arsene Wenger faces uncertainty over his future, but fans are largely supportive of his 20-year tenure. Despite recent misfires, including a 5-1 loss to Bayern Munich, fans appreciate Wenger's contributions, including developing young players and achieving domestic doubles. Many see him as a knowledgeable coach and fighter who can still turn things around, and a departure would be a huge risk without a clear plan in place. Wenger has unfinished business at the club and is determined to stay, saying "success is accidental at some clubs, but compulsory at Arsenal."

site_title: Hudson River tunnel project to take seven years to complete
summary: A new tunnel project under the Hudson River in New York City will take seven years to complete, starting in 2019, and will cause temporary disruptions in a part of Manhattan. The $24 billion Gateway Program aims to repair and expand Amtrak's US north-east transportation corridor. Construction will involve digging up part of 30th Street, boring through a historic bulkhead, and creating a permanent ventilation shaft that may block views of the river from the High Line. The project is expected to have minimal impact on the West Side Highway.

site_title: Australia's Fairfax Media to demerge real estate arm
summary: Fairfax Media has confirmed plans to demerge its real estate arm, Domain Group, despite the property division posting its first-ever drop in earnings due to falling property listings. The demerger plan has cheered investors, with Fairfax shares surging up to 10.3% and valued at A$2 billion. Fairfax CEO Greg Hywood stated that the weakness in listings is cyclical, and Domain will be listed as a separate entity with a 60-70% stake held by Fairfax.

site_title: Mobile order-ahead buzz catches Starbucks off guard
summary: Starbucks was caught off guard by the popularity of mobile order-ahead technology, with the coffee chain struggling to manage overcrowding that scared off walk-in customers. Similar issues were seen at TGI Friday's Inc, where mixed orders occurred. The technology's success is expected to continue, potentially changing the way customers interact with restaurant chains. As mobile order-ahead options become more widespread, businesses will need to adapt to manage demand and maintain customer satisfaction.

images.alt_text: Last quarter, mobile orders represented at least 20 per cent of sales during peak traffic times at nearly 1,200 Starbucks stores.

site_title: Two new tech headquarters open in Singapore
summary: Two tech headquarters were inaugurated in Singapore, bolstering the city-state's reputation as a launchpad for global innovation. Zendesk expanded its Singapore office, doubling its size to 1,390 sq m, while The Trendlines Group opened its first incubator outside Israel, Trendlines Medical Singapore. The incubator will support Singaporean start-ups developing medical devices and technologies. Both companies aim to nurture skills in the digital sector and foster innovation, with Zendesk growing its Chat research and development team and Trendlines investing in start-ups in the coming months.

site_title: Olam to pause forest clearing in Gabon in truce with Mighty Earth
summary: Olam International has reached a one-year truce with environmental group Mighty Earth, suspending forest clearing in Gabon in exchange for Mighty Earth's suspension of its campaign targeting Olam's operations. The truce aims to promote responsible agricultural development, poverty reduction, and job creation in Gabon, while also strengthening incentives for suppliers to avoid deforestation and exploitation of workers. Olam will also boost sustainability efforts in its palm oil supply chain and revise its procedures for handling complaints.

site_title: Not time to take a shine to Singapore banks
summary: Singapore banks face a challenging 2017, with rising rates and oil prices offering little relief. Despite hopes for a rate boost, the banks' loan books remain under pressure, with weaker net interest margins and higher specific provisions for oil and gas loans. The industry's recovery is uncertain, with analysts warning of underinvestment and a potential gap between operating cash flows and capital expenditures. The banks' focus will shift to cost-cutting and diversification, with a growing emphasis on expanding in ASEAN and adapting to structural shifts in key sectors.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: BreadTalk Group posted a nearly fourfold growth in fourth-quarter net profit to S$4.43 million, driven by a 1.1% fall in revenue. Cache Logistics Trust acquired a warehouse in Melbourne for S$24.27 million. Vallianz Holdings received 380.6 million new shares from trade creditors in exchange for debt. Best World International saw a 231% increase in fourth-quarter net profit to S$12.3 million. In contrast, Soilbuild Construction Group's net profit fell 37.6% to S$3.5 million.

site_title: London-based asset manager MVN ups Vard stake to 6.01%
summary: MVN Asset Management has acquired 806,000 shares of Vard Holdings, boosting its stake to 6.0119% in the Singapore-listed yard group. The London-based asset manager's stake first rose to 5.0188% after buying over 1.19 million shares in January. The move has fueled speculation about MVN's intentions regarding Fincantieri's offer to delist Vard's Singapore-listed subsidiary. The pressure on Fincantieri to raise its offer has increased, following calls from investor watchdog SIAS and concerns about the offer's value compared to Vard's net asset value.

site_title: Banks push STI up 0.9%
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.91% to 3,122.20 points on Wednesday, driven by the Dow Jones Industrial Average's eighth consecutive all-time high. The big three banks surged, contributing to the market's advance. Economists attribute the gains to Asia-Pacific's watchful eye on US President Trump's policies. The overall market volume was 2.6 billion units worth S$1.47 billion.

site_title: Myanmar makes record seizures of illegal timber
summary: Myanmar seized a record 40,000 tonnes of illegal timber since April 2016 as part of a government crackdown on the rapidly disappearing forests. The confiscation occurred months before the newly elected government issued a nationwide ban on logging. Forest Ministry Director Tin Tun attributed the seizures to the ongoing illegal trade in timber that has persisted since the junta era.

site_title: Shell partners Toyota to build hydrogen fuelling stations in California
summary: Royal Dutch Shell partners with Toyota to build seven hydrogen fuelling stations in California, aiming to support the state's goal of 100 retail sites by 2024. The stations, valued at $27.8 million, will be funded by a $16.4 million grant from the California Energy Commission and $11.4 million from Shell and Toyota. This partnership marks Shell's latest investment in the hydrogen fuel-cell vehicle market, as the company bets on the demise of the internal combustion engine.

site_title: Major League Baseball may soon stream on Facebook
summary: Facebook is in talks to stream one Major League Baseball game per week in the upcoming season, a move to reach viewers in the era of declining traditional TV sports ratings. The deal, pending approval from MLB owners, would be the latest partnership between a sports league and a social media platform, following the NFL's deal with Twitter last year. This agreement would be part of Facebook's growing sports partnerships division, which also recently struck a deal with Univision to stream Mexican professional football games.

site_title: UPS mulls raising prices, tests drone deliveries
summary: UPS considers raising prices to offset declining margins due to e-commerce growth, which increases costs per delivery. The company tested drone deliveries in Florida, aiming to reduce costs in rural areas. UPS also plans to expand US pickup and delivery services and offer Saturday delivery in major metropolitan areas. The company expects 4-6% revenue growth and 5-10% adjusted earnings per share over 2018 and 2019.

site_title: Evidence mounts that speculation is behind Toronto's property bubble
summary: Toronto's housing market has seen a 20% surge in prices over the past year, the fastest pace in three decades, with speculation believed to be the main driver. Builders cite regulations, taxes, and land restrictions as obstacles to supply, but evidence suggests that demand is not the primary cause. Instead, speculation by investors, particularly in condominiums, is contributing to the price increases. The federal government's primary tool to intervene, mortgage insurance rules, is less effective against speculators, making it challenging to curb the market.

site_title: Kuroda dismisses talk of further rate cuts
summary: Bank of Japan governor Haruhiko Kuroda stated that the likelihood of further rate cuts is slim, but the central bank is prepared to ease monetary policy if necessary to achieve its 2% inflation target. This comes as the BOJ's ultra-loose monetary policy diverges from other leading central banks.

site_title: Likely Trump tweets on six flashpoints that could rattle markets
summary: US President Donald Trump's tweets on international financial issues could significantly impact markets. Trump's views on Germany's trade surplus, quantitative easing, Greece's bailout, France's presidential elections, Italy's banking system, and China's currency could lead to volatile market fluctuations. His comments could weaken the euro, depress interest rates, and destabilize the global economy. Trump's protectionist stance against China and his criticism of European countries' currency manipulation could escalate tensions in the trans-Pacific debate.

site_title: Germany satisfied with PSA commitments on Opel: German government spokesman
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel is satisfied with PSA Group's commitments on jobs, investment, and plants in talks to buy General Motors' Opel unit. A telephone call between Merkel and PSA Chief Executive Carlos Tavares on Tuesday was "encouraging," with the German government supporting the preservation of Opel as a strong brand. The talks are ongoing, with the government to accompany them positively.

site_title: 11 million in crosshairs of US deportation orders
summary: The Trump administration has issued new deportation orders targeting nearly all of the US' 11 million undocumented immigrants, with the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) citing a problem that has "overwhelmed" government resources. The orders, issued by DHS Secretary John Kelly, make it easier for border patrol and immigration officers to quickly deport illegal immigrants, with limited exceptions. Rights groups have labeled the move a "witch hunt," warning that mass deportations would damage families and hurt the economy, while the administration claims the move is necessary to address a national security vulnerability.

images.alt_text: In the memos, Homeland Security Secretary John Kelly ordered immediate action to begin planning the wall along the US-Mexico frontier. He also ordered the hiring of 15,000 more officers for the Customs and Border Protection and Immigration and Customs Enforcement agencies.

site_title: Henderson fund manager buys Unilever shares after Kraft's exit
summary: Henderson Group's fund manager, John Bennett, has started buying Unilever shares after Kraft Heinz withdrew its US$143 billion offer. Bennett sees this as an opportunity for Unilever's management to reassess its portfolio, particularly with the expiration of UK takeover rules in six months. This move suggests investors still expect a deal, despite Unilever's 6.6% decline in shares. Bennett is not a fan of mergers and acquisitions, but believes Kraft Heinz's unsolicited bid indicates the rally for consumer staple companies is nearing its peak.

site_title: NYK offloading Emas Chiyoda Subsea stake: sources
summary: NYK Line is considering offloading its 25% stake in Emas Chiyoda Subsea (ECS), a joint venture with Ezra Holdings, due to a significant loss provision. The move raises questions over Ezra's role in the subsea joint venture. Subsea 7 and China's Offshore Engineering Co Ltd (COOEC) are in contention for NYK's stake, which includes a large order book worth billions of dollars. A divestment could signify NYK's loss of confidence in the business model, and the new JV partner may need to inject funds through a shareholder loan or equity injection.

site_title: Singdollar bond scene sizzles with latest issue raking in S$4b of orders
summary: Commerzbank AG successfully sold a S$500 million Singapore dollar-denominated bond, receiving orders of approximately S$4 billion, with a final price of 4.875% compared to an initial guidance of 5.25%. The strong demand is attributed to yield-hungry investors seeking higher yields amidst expected US interest rate hikes, as well as companies looking to refinance and tap cash-flush investors. This follows a series of successful bond sales by other high-quality issuers in the market.

images.alt_text: The Singapore dollar bond market is sizzling - Wednesday's S$500 million bond sale by Commerzbank AG is said to have taken orders approaching S$4 billion as investors clamour for yield

site_title: UK said to put-off retail tax reform as May pledges relief
summary: UK Chancellor Philip Hammond is unlikely to offer significant concessions for retailers in his upcoming budget due to the scale of reform needed. Despite Prime Minister Theresa May's promise of relief for high street traders hit by increased taxes, retailers will have to wait until the autumn budget for potential changes. The business rates system, a £26 billion-per-year tax on commercial properties, is seen as out of line with other developed countries and is expected to increase dramatically due to a revaluation in April. A cross-party Treasury Committee will make recommendations for reform in its scrutiny of the March Budget.

site_title: Latest Earnings
summary: Oil prices surged over 2% as investors weighed market outlook, tariffs, and sanctions. US stocks edged down from records amid tariff threats, while Europe's stocks fell due to bank and healthcare sector concerns. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer received 9.8 times oversubscription. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall in H2, with similar operating losses as in H1. London's Heathrow Airport plans to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case.

site_title: Unilever reviewing options for change after Kraft bid fails
summary: Unilever is conducting a strategic review of its operations after a failed $143 billion takeover proposal from Kraft Heinz. The company aims to accelerate value delivery for shareholders, boosting its core operating margin forecast to the upper end of its 2017 guidance. Options under consideration include selling its spreads subsidiary, splitting the business, or raising the dividend. Unilever expects the review to be completed by early April, with shares rising 2.9% following the announcement.

site_title: Volkswagen said to renew India push with Tata alliance talks
summary: Volkswagen AG is in advanced talks to team up with Tata Motors Ltd to develop vehicles for emerging markets, including India, where the country's booming middle-class demand for cars is intensifying competition among global manufacturers. A potential deal to jointly develop vehicles may be announced at the Geneva auto show in early March. The partnership would give Tata Motors access to Volkswagen's expertise and help both companies cut costs. This is Volkswagen's second attempt to enter India's market, following a previous partnership with Suzuki Motor Corp that ended in a dispute two years ago.

site_title: Time for ECB to address repo crunch roiling markets: ICMA
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) should reassure investors that it is addressing the repo crunch, a shortage of short-term funding markets that has driven bond prices to unprecedented levels. ICMA chairman Godfried de Vidts said a public statement would provide comfort to the market, but a statement from the ECB is needed to ease investor angst. The ECB's asset-purchase scheme is contributing to the repo market squeeze, which affects banks and big business relying on repo markets to raise cash. A statement from the ECB is expected before its next meeting on March 9.

site_title: WTO chief does not foresee "unmanageable" US trade policy
summary: World Trade Organization (WTO) chief Roberto Azevedo expressed confidence that the organization can cope with any new US trade policy, despite concerns raised by President Donald Trump about "unfair trade" and potential withdrawal from the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA) and the WTO. Azevedo stated that he had not discussed trade issues with the new administration, but was optimistic about finding a path forward. The WTO offers tools to address concerns, and Azevedo believes that other member countries want to find a solution.

site_title: BAE Systems CEO King retires, replaced by chief operating officer
summary: BAE Systems CEO Ian King retires after 40 years in the defence industry, effective July 1. He will be replaced by Chief Operating Officer Charles Woodburn. Chairman Roger Carr praised King's leadership, citing disciplined performance, ethical behavior, and delivering shareholder value.

site_title: Centurion launches student housing brand
summary: Centurion Corp, a Singapore-listed accommodation provider, launched a new student accommodation brand called "dwell Student Living" to grow its business more quickly and cost-effectively. The company, which entered the student accommodation space about 2.5 years ago, has primarily focused on purchasing existing assets and refurbishing them. This new brand aims to expand its presence in the market and diversify its offerings.

site_title: Nude Christ by Michelangelo, long incognito, to be shown in London
summary: A nearly 7-foot-tall statue of Christ by Michelangelo, "Nude Christ," will be displayed in London as part of an exhibition on Michelangelo and Sebastiano del Piombo at the National Gallery, starting March 15. The statue, which was commissioned in 1514 but abandoned by Michelangelo, fell into obscurity after its creator's death in 1554. It was rediscovered in 1997 and has since been shown in Rome, Berlin, and Mexico City. The statue's transfer to the San Vincenzo Monastery in Italy in 1644 helped preserve it, and its recent attribution to Michelangelo has allowed it to be showcased internationally, generating revenue for the monastery.

site_title: Airbus seeks new talks with European nations over A400M costs
summary: Airbus is seeking new talks with European nations over the costs of its A400M military aircraft, which have been impacted by delays and problems with engine gearboxes. The company has taken a 1.2 billion euro charge and is facing a total writedown of 7 billion euros. Airbus CEO Tom Enders said the company cannot continue with the current penalties and is calling for a new deal to ease the burden. European governments have been critical of the project, with one official stating that the problems are "entirely Airbus' own doing."

site_title: EU says Germany should do more to help economy
summary: The European Commission has urged Germany to do more to help its EU partners economically, citing Germany's enormous trade surpluses and "excessive imbalances" in France's public finances. Germany has been pressed to invest more at home to boost consumption and imports, which would benefit weaker economies. The Commission's call comes after the Trump administration criticized Berlin for using the EU to boost exports unfairly.

images.alt_text: Europe's top economy Germany should help its EU partners out, the European Commission said Wednesday, after the Trump administration attacked Berlin for using the bloc to boost exports unfairly.

site_title: Fu Yu Q4 earnings rise despite lower turnover
summary: Fu Yu Corp reported a 44.4% increase in fourth-quarter net profit to S$5.6 million, despite a 3.5% decline in revenue to S$48.5 million. Earnings per share rose to 0.74 Singapore cents, while the dividend per share remained flat at one Singapore cent. The company's shares finished unchanged at S$0.22.

site_title: WTO ratifies first multilateral trade deal
summary: The World Trade Organization (WTO) has ratified the first multilateral trade deal, the Trade Facilitation Agreement (TFA), which has been ratified by 112 of its 164 members. The agreement aims to simplify and standardize customs procedures, reducing global trade costs by over 14% and boosting global growth by half a percentage point per year. The deal is seen as a major reform of global trade, particularly benefiting poorer countries through improved access to richer markets. However, the agreement faces uncertainty with the US pulling out of the WTO under the new administration of Donald Trump.

site_title: Oil slips on US dollar strength but cushioned by Opec optimism
summary: Global oil prices slipped on Wednesday due to the US dollar's rise, but remained at multi-week highs following Opec's optimism over its output-cutting deal. The US West Texas Intermediate April crude contract fell 0.7% to $53.96 a barrel, while Brent crude declined 0.6% to $56.83. Opec's signal of confidence in its deal to curb production helped to support prices.

site_title: Political noise, Fed pushes euro below US$1.05
summary: The euro fell below US$1.05 for the first time in six weeks due to concerns over France's presidential election campaign and growing expectations for a US interest rate hike. Implied volatility for the euro increased, and three-month risk reversals reached their most negative in over a year, reflecting investors' anticipation of a potential rate hike by the US Federal Reserve. The US dollar strengthened against other currencies, with the Fed meeting minutes to be released later in the day potentially influencing market sentiment.

site_title: AccorHotels beats profit expectations, ex-president Sarkozy joins board
summary: AccorHotels, Europe's largest hotelier, posted a record operating profit for 2016, beating expectations, as restructuring efforts paid off and robust demand in Germany and Britain offset weakness in France. The company also announced a planned sale of its HotelInvest property business worth 6.6 billion euros by mid-July. Former French President Nicolas Sarkozy has joined the company's board, and shares initially lost ground due to concerns over future cash use and lack of guidance for 2017.

site_title: US: Wall Street slips on weak oil prices; Fed minutes in focus
summary: US stocks declined on Wednesday as oil prices fell 1.2% to $55.99, weighing on the energy sector. The S&P 500 energy sector was the top drag, slipping 0.64%. Investors await the Federal Reserve's policy meeting minutes, with slim chances of a rate hike until June. The odds of a rate hike stand at 22% for March, 47% for May, and 69% for June. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 0.21%, while the Nasdaq Composite dropped 0.25%.

site_title: Bundesbank considers exit cost from ECB's unconventional policy
summary: The Bundesbank is considering setting aside funds to cover potential losses from the European Central Bank's exit from unconventional stimulus, including its bond-buying program and interest rate hikes. The German central bank's President Jens Weidmann has signaled that "potentially considerable" funds may be needed to absorb the costs. The Bundesbank is particularly exposed to losses from buying negative-yielding bonds, which are guaranteed to lose money. While officials are acting prudently, the move could fuel criticism of the ECB and its unconventional policies.

site_title: UK to set out proposed government role in foreign takeovers in next few weeks
summary: Britain's business minister Greg Clark plans to outline proposed government role in foreign takeovers, particularly in critical sectors like nuclear power, in the coming weeks. This comes after Prime Minister Theresa May intervened in a deal to build a new nuclear plant, straining relations with China and France. The move aims to protect British firms from foreign takeovers and maintain national interests.

images.alt_text: Britain's business minister said on Wednesday he will set out proposals over the government's stance towards the possible foreign takeover of British firms, particularly in critically important areas such as nuclear power, in the coming weeks.

site_title: Total CEO says Opec needs to prolong cuts to eliminate glut
summary: Total SA CEO Patrick Pouyanne stated that Opec and Russia's six-month oil output cut deal should be extended beyond May to trim the global inventory glut and have a significant impact on the market. Pouyanne expressed confidence that the deal will be prolonged, saying, "If they want really to have an impact on the market, it will have to be extended beyond May."

site_title: Delfi's Q4 profit soars 356.8%; gross profit margin hits record 38.4%
summary: Delfi Limited reported a 356.8% surge in net profit to US$3.7 million for Q4 2016, driven by a 38.4% record gross profit margin. Revenue rose 5.6% to US$105.6 million, primarily due to increased sales of premium Own Brands products and cost-containment initiatives. The company proposes a final dividend payout of 1.35 S cents per share, totaling 3.18 S cents for the year.
