site_title: South Korea end-Q4 household credit grows most in over a decade
summary: South Korea's household credit grew 11.7% in the fourth quarter of 2016, the fastest pace in over a decade, as borrowers took advantage of record-low interest rates. Household debt reached 1,344.3 trillion won ($1.17 trillion), up from a year earlier. Housing mortgage loans led the growth, with outstanding loans rising 11.7% on-year to 1,271.6 trillion won. The Bank of Korea is set to review policy on Thursday, with analysts predicting no changes amid global uncertainties and rising household debt.

site_title: Brazil's Meirelles says states to get 3-year reprieve in debt deal
summary: Brazilian Finance Minister Henrique Meirelles announced a 3-year debt relief program for cash-strapped states, requiring them to implement drastic spending curbs, including freezing wage hikes and stopping new hiring. States would also be allowed to privatize public companies. The bill, set to be sent to Congress on Tuesday, aims to help Rio de Janeiro state overcome its fiscal crisis.

site_title: Australia's Fairfax considers demerger of real estate arm: source
summary: Fairfax Media Ltd, Australia's largest newspaper group, is considering a partial demerger of its real estate advertising arm, Domain Group, to unlock its value. Domain is the company's highest-earning division, valued at about A$2 billion. A demerger would make Fairfax more reliant on newspapers, which are in structural decline due to online advertising migration. The company will release its half-year results on Wednesday, and a demerger plan is expected to be announced later this year. Fairfax would retain a 60-70% stake in Domain.

site_title: Australia: Shares down on earnings woes, BHP results awaited; NZ steady
summary: Australian shares fell 0.2% to 5,784.8 points, as earnings season disappointment weighed on investors, with Oil Search's annual profit drop and losses in financial stocks contributing to the decline. Investors are also awaiting data on wages growth, construction and capex, as well as appearances by central bank chief Philip Lowe.

site_title: China's Ant to invest US$200m in Korea's Kakao Pay amid global push
summary: China's Ant Financial will invest $200 million in Kakao Pay, a South Korean mobile payment platform, as part of a strategic partnership to expand its global network of financial assets. Ant, valued at $60 billion, has been aggressively expanding at home and overseas ahead of a potential initial public offering. This investment follows a $880 million deal for US money-transfer firm MoneyGram International and existing investments in Indian and Thai financial technology firms. Ant aims to become a global payments leader, competing with domestic rival Tencent Holdings' Wechat Pay.

site_title: Singapore shares open slightly higher on Tuesday
summary: Singapore shares opened 0.14% higher on Tuesday at 3,101.09, driven by anticipation of US markets reopening. Turnover was 48.9 million worth S$52.5 million, with gainers beating losers 71-37. This marks the 5th consecutive day of gains ahead of GDP data.

site_title: PBOC to inject 100 billion yuan via reverse repos: traders
summary: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China (PBOC), will inject 100 billion yuan into money markets on Tuesday through reverse repos. The injection includes 40 billion yuan through seven-day repos, 30 billion yuan through 14-day repos, and 30 billion yuan through 28-day repos. This move follows the draining of a net 150 billion yuan from money markets last week. The seven-day repo rate is at 2.35%, down 35.18 basis points from the previous closing average.

site_title: AusNet Services agrees to pay A$5m in Mickleham Road bushfire class action
summary: AusNet Services has agreed to pay A$5 million as part of a class action settlement over the 2014 Mickleham Road bushfire. The settlement, subject to court approval, totals A$16 million, with AusNet contributing A$5 million, the Home City Council A$6 million, and Homewood Consulting A$5 million. AusNet maintains it was not negligent and the settlement does not admit liability. The liability insurers will cover AusNet's contribution and outstanding costs.

site_title: Chinese investors find their cash is losing its cachet
summary: Chinese investors, known for their abundant cash, are facing increasing challenges in securing deals abroad due to the country's capital controls. Authorities have tightened restrictions on outbound investments, making it difficult for Chinese firms to secure official permission to transfer yuan into foreign exchange. This has led to a decline in overseas direct investment by Chinese companies, with December's ODI falling 40% from last year. Chinese conglomerates, such as Dalian Wanda, have seen proposed deals collapse due to regulatory hurdles. While regulators will approve deals that make economic sense, the uncertainty has led some fund managers to shift their focus to offshore markets.

site_title: Hot stock: Natural Cool's shares actively traded
summary: Natural Cool Holdings' shares rose 0.7 Singapore cents to S$0.158 after more than 27 million shares changed hands in the first hour of trading, following an extraordinary general meeting that ousted most of the board. The move came amid controversy over a proposed divestment of HMK Energy. The company's stock has been actively traded since the ouster of its chairman.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open higher as yen stabilises
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Tuesday, with the Nikkei 225 index rising 0.07% to 19,264.56, while the Topix index gained 0.02% to 1,547.28. The dollar held firm against the yen, contributing to the market's stability. This follows subdued trading, with investors focusing on the US-EU trade talks and tariffs.

site_title: Turnbull backs IMF call for more Aussie infrastructure spending
summary: Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull has agreed with the International Monetary Fund's call for increased infrastructure spending, citing its ability to boost productivity and stimulate the economy. Despite a forecasted budget deficit of $36.5 billion, Turnbull's government aims to balance the budget by 2021 and has proposed reducing the company tax rate to 25% over 10 years. However, the plan faces opposition from the Senate, and Turnbull is battling to gain momentum for his Liberal-National coalition ahead of the next election.

site_title: Britons say economy their top concern, overtaking immigration: poll
summary: A UK survey found that 28% of Britons named the economy as a top concern, surpassing terrorism and immigration, as the country prepares to leave the European Union. This increase in economic concern comes despite a recent drop in consumer spending. The result reflects growing worries about job security and the impact of Brexit on the economy.

site_title: Mercurius Capital Investment in primary talks on possible joint venture, disposal
summary: Mercurius Capital Investment Limited is in preliminary discussions with unrelated parties about a potential joint venture and disposal transaction. The company has not assured any conclusive transactions will materialize, advising shareholders to exercise caution and refrain from taking any action that may be prejudicial to their interests. The stock closed up 1.2 cents at S$0.045 following the trading query issued by the Singapore Exchange.

site_title: HK seen posting budget surplus of up to HK$75b
summary: Hong Kong's government is expected to report a budget surplus of HK$70 billion to HK$75 billion in the fiscal year 2016-2017, surpassing official estimates of HK$11.4 billion. The surplus is attributed to higher revenues from land sales and stamp duties.

images.alt_text: Analysts have forecast that the Hong Kong government, in its upcoming budget this Wednesday, will report a surplus in the range of HK$70 billion (S$12.8 billion) to HK$75 billion for the fiscal year of 2016-2017, far outstripping the government's HK$11.4 billion estimate.

site_title: Light plane crashes near Melbourne in Australia
summary: A small plane crashed into a shopping centre near Essendon Airport outside Melbourne, Australia, on Tuesday. The aircraft, a five-seater, showed burning wreckage and fire crews were hosing down debris. The incident occurred at the small airfield, which is mainly used by light planes. There is no information on possible casualties at this stage.

site_title: Toshiba wants to raise at least US$8.8b from sale of chip unit majority stake: source
summary: Toshiba plans to sell a majority stake in its NAND flash memory business for at least $8.8 billion to address financial issues stemming from a $6.3 billion writedown of its US nuclear unit. The sale, expected to be completed by March 2026, will help the Japanese conglomerate cope with potential financial problems, as it has been unable to issue new shares due to a Tokyo Stock Exchange watchlist. This move comes after Toshiba initially planned to sell less than 20% of the chip unit, and the company may sell all of the prized business.

site_title: Singapore introduces IP Development Incentive to encourage innovation
summary: Singapore has introduced the Intellectual Property Development Incentive (IDI), a new tax regime aimed at encouraging innovation and retaining high-tech industries. Under the IDI, qualifying income related to intellectual property (IP) will be taxed at a lower rate, potentially as low as 0%, 5%, or 10%. The regime focuses on the "back-end" of the IP life cycle and incorporates the OECD's "modified nexus approach," ensuring that profits are taxed where substantial activities are present and value is created in-country. The IDI aims to stimulate R&D investment and innovation, and its implementation is expected to add complexity to Singapore's existing incentive regime.

site_title: Thousands of anti-Trump protesters say 'not my president'
summary: Thousands of anti-Trump protesters gathered in New York and cities across the US on Presidents Day, with over 10,000 in New York, chanting "not my president." The protests aim to show opposition to President Trump's policies, amid controversies over his ties with Russia and his approach to running the country. Trump has been working on filling his administration's top spots and revising immigration restrictions, following a historically low 40% job approval rating.

site_title: GLP secures new leases with third party logistics firms in China
summary: GLP, a logistics facilities provider, has secured 106,000 sq m of new leases in China with third-party logistics companies. The leases cater to domestic distribution demand from express delivery and less-than-truckload sectors. This marks a new customer relationship with Yimidida and extended partnerships with existing customers, including Best Logistics. GLP's modern logistics facilities aim to enhance operational efficiencies and create value for customers, driven by China's strong logistics market fundamentals.

site_title: UOB plans to issue S$750m notes at 3.5%
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) plans to issue S$750 million 3.5% subordinated notes due 2029, callable in 2024, under its S$15 billion Euro Medium Term Note Programme. The notes will be jointly managed by UOB, Credit Suisse, and The Hongkong and Shanghai Banking Corporation. The issue date is expected to be on February 27, 2017.

site_title: Big emitters face carbon tax from 2019
summary: Singapore to impose a carbon tax of S$10 to S$20 on each tonne of greenhouse gas emitted by power generation plants and large emitters from 2019, aiming to reduce emissions efficiently and at low economic cost. Revenue will fund emissions reduction measures and support industries in transitioning to green growth. The tax will be applied to 30-40 large emitters, with an estimated increase in electricity prices of 0.43-0.86 cents per kilowatt hour for households. Industry consultations have begun, with public consultations to follow in March, and the government will consider lessons from other countries and economic conditions in implementation.

site_title: Five teenagers arrested in London on terrorism charges
summary: Five teenagers were arrested in London on terrorism charges following a series of raids, with the suspects ranging in age from 15 to 19. They were held on suspicion of preparing acts of terrorism, specifically planning to join a proscribed organisation. The arrests were made in connection with plans to travel abroad, but no further details have been released.

site_title: Australia's Westpac reports Q1 fall in stressed assets
summary: Westpac Banking Corp reported a slight decrease in stressed assets in the first quarter of its financial year, with exposures as a percentage of total loans falling to 1.15% from 1.20%. Bad debt charges remained steady, while mortgage delinquencies were unchanged overall, except for a rise in Western Australia.

site_title: Greece agrees to bailout reforms compromise
summary: Greece agreed to discuss new bailout reforms with EU-IMF creditors, aiming to break a deadlock that has sparked fears of a return to the eurozone crisis. Officials will return to Athens for talks, with the IMF expressing that more work is needed. The reforms will include structural changes to the tax system, pension system, and labor market regulation, but will not include additional austerity measures. The deal must still be approved by the Greek parliament, with elections in Europe adding to the pressure.

site_title: China wins big with stakes in US$22b Abu Dhabi oil deal
summary: China has emerged as a major player in Abu Dhabi's oil industry, securing a combined 20% stake in the US$22 billion deal through state-run China National Petroleum Corp and Shanghai-based CEFC China Energy. The deal marks China's debut as a major shareholder in the UAE's oilfield operator, Opec's fourth-largest member. Abu Dhabi plans to retain a 60% stake, with the remaining 40% split between China and other international investors, including Japan's Inpex Corp and South Korea's GS Energy Corp.

site_title: Trump names HR McMaster as national security adviser
summary: US President Donald Trump named Army Lieutenant General HR McMaster as his national security adviser, replacing Michael Flynn who resigned due to questionable contacts with the Russian government. This move comes after a one-week search. McMaster, a counterinsurgency strategist, is expected to help course correct the administration's national security approach. The appointment aims to address concerns following Flynn's resignation and potential contacts with the Russian government.

site_title: Budget takes firm aim at Singapore's future economy
summary: Singapore's Budget 2017 aims to realign the economy with medium-term restructuring plans, focusing on future challenges. The S$2.4 billion allocation is part of a multi-year scheme to implement proposals from the Committee on the Future Economy. The budget also includes measures to support firms, workers, and families, with a focus on targeted interventions and self-reliance. The government aims to drive the Singapore economy forward, while ensuring fiscal sustainability and addressing demographic challenges.

site_title: Singapore to raise water price by 30% over two years (Amended)
summary: Singapore plans to raise water prices by 30% over two years, with the first increase taking effect on July 1, 2017. The price hike, totaling less than S$25 a month for most businesses, aims to reflect the costs of desalination and NEWater production. The government agency PUB will also impose a 50% Water Conservation Tax on NEWater. Domestic users consuming up to 40 cubic meters a month will see a water tariff increase from S$1.17 to S$1.21 per cubic meter.

site_title: Europe: Shares supported by miners, telecoms; Unilever slump weighs
summary: European shares rose 0.2% on Monday, supported by telecoms and mining stocks, but Unilever plummeted 6.9% after Kraft Heinz withdrew its $143 billion takeover bid. This weighed on the broader market, with the STOXX 600 index nearing its highest level since December 2015.

site_title: Alibaba deepens retail foray with new Chinese supermarket tie-up
summary: Alibaba is partnering with Shanghai Bailian Group Co, China's largest supermarket and department store chain, to upgrade 4,700 stores across the country. The collaboration aims to integrate technology in customer relations, payment, and logistics. This move is part of Alibaba's effort to employ technology to shake up traditional retail, as led by Jack Ma. The partnership is similar to Alibaba's existing collaborations with other players, such as Suning Commerce Group Co.

images.alt_text: With Bailian, Alibaba will be tapping a network of 4,700 stores across 25 Chinese provinces.

site_title: Preparing Singapore for a world of uncertainty (Amended)
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat presented a budget that prepares the country for a world of uncertainty and potential strife. The budget aims to bolster the economy through key infrastructure initiatives, industry transformation maps, and support for small and medium-sized enterprises. The government also introduced measures to reduce the regressive quality of the Goods and Services Tax and to address environmental challenges. The budget is mildly expansionary, with the "basic" deficit expected to increase to 1.9% of GDP. This will support real GDP growth of over 3% in 2017.

site_title: Hundreds of EU citizens rally for Brexit rights
summary: Hundreds of EU citizens protested outside the UK Parliament on February 20, 2017, as the House of Lords debated a bill empowering Prime Minister Theresa May to start Brexit negotiations. The protesters, holding signs and flags, demanded guarantees on their post-Brexit status and chanted "Stop Brexit, Brexit is Racist!" Some entered the parliament building to make their point to MPs. The rally came as the UK began its exit from the EU, with the protesters seeking to raise awareness about their concerns and rights.

site_title: Gold prices jump despite interest-rate hikes, Trump uncertainties
summary: Gold prices have jumped 7% since the Federal Reserve's interest-rate hike in December, defying expectations. The metal's price increase can be attributed to uncertainties surrounding Donald Trump's presidency and market concerns ahead of future rate hikes. Despite initial expectations that Trump's infrastructure spending would curb interest in gold, his administration's focus on other matters has reversed the trend. Investors have been buying gold, with the largest ETF backed by gold seeing a 4% price boost to around $1,240 an ounce.

site_title: Malaysia summons N Korea envoy as diplomatic row deepens
summary: Malaysia summoned the North Korean ambassador on February 20, 2017, over Pyongyang's attack on its investigation into the assassination of Kim Jong Un's brother. The move deepens a diplomatic row, with North Korea accusing Kuala Lumpur of conspiring with "hostile forces" to damage its reputation. Five North Koreans are under investigation for the airport killing.

site_title: China adjusts yuan midpoint mechanism: sources
summary: China adjusted its yuan midpoint mechanism, reducing the reference period for trading against its trade-weighted basket from 24 hours to 15 hours, in an effort to curb speculative trading. The change is seen as a technical move to better reflect market changes, with traders believing its impact on the foreign exchange rate will be limited. The People's Bank of China aims to make the yuan more market-driven and transparent, following recent changes to the currency basket composition.

images.alt_text: Traders said the change would make the yuan midpoint more "reasonable", but believed its impact on the foreign exchange rate would be very limited.

site_title: UK banks have low bar to leap over this earnings season
summary: UK banks are expected to underperform this earnings season, with forecasters predicting a 14% decline in earnings for the FTSE 100 Index's second-largest industry group in 2016.

site_title: Yield chase pushes investors to EM infrastructure
summary: Institutional investors are increasing exposure to emerging markets infrastructure, driven by fierce competition in developed markets. A survey found 41% of respondents were invested in or interested in the Asia-Pacific, up from 28% in 2016. Investors are drawn to steady cashflows and predictability in assets like toll roads, airports, and ports. However, concerns around currency risk and rule of law in emerging markets have limited demand, with Africa remaining a niche market. Despite this, sophisticated investors are becoming more confident in managing these risks, leading to increased appetite for emerging markets infrastructure.

site_title: Beijing can nip threat to 'One China' policy by wooing Taiwan
summary: Taiwan's status as a potential threat to China's "One China" policy could be mitigated by Beijing's wider international recognition of the island. US President Donald Trump's recent phone call with Taiwan's President Tsai Ing-wen and his subsequent tweet questioning the policy presented a dilemma for Taiwan, which has campaigned for a distinct identity since 1986. China's maritime disputes with Taiwan could escalate into a full-blown conflict, but Beijing could ease tensions by accelerating its recognition of Taiwan. This could lead to a more stable relationship between Taiwan and China, and potentially take the issue off the table for the US.

images.alt_text: A night market in Taipei. Taiwan's Democratic Progressive Party, currently in power, has campaigned for distinct Taiwanese identity since its inception in 1986, drawing back from demand for full recognition. Anything moving towards independence represents a flaming red line on national sovereignty that Beijing vows to never accept.

site_title: A smaller budget surplus of S$1.91b likely for FY17
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat expects a smaller budget surplus of S$1.91 billion for fiscal year 2017, largely due to increased expenditure. Estimated operating revenue is expected to climb to S$69.45 billion, with motor vehicle taxes contributing the largest dollar increase. The budget remains expansionary, with total expenditure expected to reach S$75.07 billion, driven by increases in national development, healthcare, and home affairs spending.

site_title: Breathing life into CFE strategies
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat has announced a S$2.4 billion budget to implement the Committee on the Future Economy's (CFE) strategies over the next four years. The plans include a Global Innovation Alliance to provide Singaporeans with opportunities to gain experience and build networks overseas, as well as a SkillsFuture Leadership Development Initiative to develop capable leaders. The government also aims to boost training and make it more accessible through targeted and shorter courses. The initiatives are part of the government's efforts to deepen and diversify Singapore's international links and support the key recommendation to get the country more plugged into the global economy.

site_title: Ezion shares hit by warning of Q4, full-year loss
summary: Ezion Holdings, a Singapore-based offshore and marine group, saw its shares plummet 7.9% on Monday after warning of a net loss for both the quarter and full year of 2016 due to impairments of assets. The company's associate, Charisma Energy Services, also warned of an expected net loss for Q4. Analysts predict further impairments may arise from the acquisition of a joint venture and the utilization of service rigs. Ezion is set to release its results on February 23.

site_title: Wall St closure leaves market bereft of direction
summary: The Singapore stock market closed 10.96 points lower at 3,096.69 on Monday, largely due to losses in Jardine Matheson and the three major banks. The Straits Times Index (STI) slipped into the red for most of the session, with turnover amounting to S$1.05 billion. Oil and gas stock Ezion Holdings issued a profit warning, causing a 8% drop in its stock price. Analysts attribute the market's subdued trading to the Wall Street closure and uncertainty surrounding the Singapore government's Budget 2017, as well as the ongoing impact of US President Donald Trump's presidency on global markets.

site_title: GM to build, test thousands of self-driving electric cars in 2018
summary: General Motors plans to deploy thousands of self-driving electric cars in test fleets with Lyft Inc in 2018, the largest test of fully autonomous vehicles by any major carmaker before 2020. This partnership aims to assess the feasibility of autonomous vehicles in real-world settings. GM's move comes as several companies, including Tesla and Nissan, are also investing in autonomous vehicle technology. The partnership is expected to provide valuable insights into the safety and efficiency of self-driving cars, paving the way for wider deployment in the future.

site_title: China consumers shrug off bird flu outbreak, unaware of severity
summary: China consumers appear to be unfazed by the ongoing bird flu outbreak, with over 100 deaths reported this winter, despite a 2013 outbreak that killed at least three dozen people and prompted mass poultry culling. The lack of consumer reaction suggests a reduced awareness of the severity of the outbreak, with few masks on the streets and no significant impact on the economy.

site_title: Future engineering
summary: US President Trump announced tariffs on Vietnam, affecting the Asian garment industry. Malaysia plans to seize RM3 billion of Daim Zainuddin's assets. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers. Citigroup forecasts a 1,150 target for MSCI's global equity index by mid-2026. Thai Prime Minister Thaksin is confident his daughter's suspension in an ethics case will be cleared by the court.

site_title: When a small sip is a taste of anxiety
summary: A sommelier at a high-end restaurant in London has eliminated the traditional ritual of tasting a bottle of wine before serving it to guests, citing the anxiety and pressure it can cause. The sommelier, Erica O'Neal, believes this practice is no longer necessary, as modern wine service relies on her expertise to detect flaws. Guests can now use the tasting moment to determine if they like the wine, and the restaurant will happily take back an offending bottle. This change aims to improve the guest experience and reduce unnecessary anxiety.

site_title: China's property investment to grow less rapidly this year: report
summary: China's property investment is expected to grow at a slower pace in 2017 as Beijing aims to curb speculation, according to a government adviser. Infrastructure spending is forecast to maintain a double-digit growth. China's exports are expected to resume positive growth this year, driven by stabilizing commodity prices and the absorption of the US dollar's appreciation. Consumer spending and infrastructure spending are also expected to extend double-digit growth, while the government prioritizes risk management in the financial sector. The country's economy expanded 6.7% in 2016.

site_title: Malaysia developer Eco World Int'l begins IPO process, may list in April
summary: Malaysia's Eco World International Bhd begins its initial public offering (IPO) process, targeting to raise over RM2 billion. The company has signed agreements with GuocoLand and will list on Bursa Malaysia's mainboard in April. This IPO is expected to be the largest in Malaysia this year, attracting participation from local banks.

site_title: S Korea won resilient amid uncertainties
summary: South Korea's won has remained resilient despite uncertainties, with a 5.3% year-to-date rise against the dollar. The currency's volatility is 11% for the past year, making it a sensitive proxy for investors betting on the region's reaction to US President Donald Trump's policies. Despite concerns over Trump's protectionist policies and the impeachment of President Park Geun-hye, inflows of $5.7 billion into the nation's bonds and equities have supported the currency. The won is considered the most liquid currency in Asia's emerging markets, with a deeper financial market.

site_title: Govt to launch third Enabling Masterplan
summary: Singapore's government will launch a third Enabling Masterplan, a five-year roadmap to integrate people with disabilities into the workforce. The plan includes training programs for special education students, a caregiver support center, and additional funding for mental health care and community-based teams. The government will also provide extra resources to voluntary welfare organizations and set up dementia-friendly communities. Additionally, the government will boost sports participation, allocate $50 million for community sports, and provide grants for aspiring athletes. The overall goal is to foster a caring and inclusive society in Singapore.

site_title: Wilmar Q4 earnings up 70% at US$560.8m
summary: Wilmar International reported a 70% surge in Q4 net profit to US$560.8 million, driven by strong commodity prices and stable crushing margins. Revenue rose 27% to US$11.95 billion, and earnings per share increased to 8.9 US cents. The company recognized a US$23.3 million income tax benefit from deferred tax assets in its Indonesian operations. Net profit for the full year fell 5% to US$972.2 million, while revenue grew 6.8% to US$41.4 billion.

site_title: Budget surplus for FY16 revised upwards due to slower spending
summary: Singapore's budget surplus for FY16 is revised upwards to S$5.18 billion, 50% higher than the previous estimate, due to slower-than-expected expenditure growth. This translates to 1.3% of GDP. Operating revenue is expected to reach S$68.67 billion, driven by higher contributions from vehicle quota premiums and stamp duty. Total expenditure is revised downwards to S$71.39 billion, with reduced spending on healthcare and housing.

site_title: Opec cuts prompt record bets on oil price rise
summary: OPEC's supply cuts have led to record bets on oil price rise, with hedge funds boosting their net-long position on West Texas Intermediate (WTI) by 8.6% in the week to Feb 14. The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries has achieved a record 90% initial compliance with production cuts, and the US benchmark has traded between $50.71 and $54.34 since Jan 10. Analysts expect a balanced market and increased oil demand growth, with world oil inventories projected to fall by 600,000 barrels a day during the first half of the year.

images.alt_text: Opec has never taken supply cuts so seriously, and hedge funds are loving it.

site_title: Hedge fund Oasis pushes for a better Panasonic-PanaHome deal
summary: Hedge fund Oasis Management Co. is pressuring Panasonic Corp. to revise its offer for listed subsidiary PanaHome Corp., citing the deal undervalues the home builder by over 50%. Oasis will petition the courts to rule on the fairness of the price if shareholders approve the deal on current terms. The fund's chief investment officer, Seth Fischer, wants either a bigger share-exchange ratio or a special dividend to compensate minority shareholders. Panasonic has maintained the deal is fair, but PanaHome's minority shareholders are expected to reject it, bolstering Oasis's case in the courts.

site_title: Big jump in share of foreigners setting up Singapore firms
summary: Singapore saw a flat year for company formation in 2016, with 64,748 businesses set up, a 0.1% decrease from the previous year. Foreigners accounted for 44% of company formations, with significant increases from China, Malaysia, and India. The majority of businesses formed in the fourth quarter had foreign ownership, and the number of foreign companies registering branch offices locally rose 63.3%. Experts attribute the lower proportion of local companies to economic sentiments, leading to caution among local entrepreneurs.

site_title: German property market surging, with homes in big cities 15-30% overpriced, Bundesbank says
summary: Germany's housing market is experiencing significant price increases, with homes in major cities 15-30% overpriced, according to the Bundesbank. This surge in residential property prices, driven by low interest rates and high demand, is a concern for the European Central Bank, which may be forced to reconsider its monetary stimulus. Despite a strong economy, the Bundesbank warns that the price overshoots could fuel inflation and lead to a general rise in prices globally.

site_title: Budget 2017: A clear shift towards targeted measures
summary: Singapore's Budget 2017 introduces targeted measures to support specific activities and businesses, following a trend established in the previous year's budget. Key initiatives include a patent box regime, the SMEs Go Digital Programme, and the Tech Access Initiative, aimed at promoting intellectual property, digitalization, and innovation. The government has also enhanced efforts to support businesses in internationalizing, with a new International Partnership Fund and the Internationalisation Finance Scheme. The budget also includes modest tax rebates for corporate and personal income taxes, but no broad-based tax incentives.

site_title: Music school aims to hit the right notes in hiring and data mining
summary: Aureus Academy, a music school in Singapore, aims to provide high-quality music education and control to its students and parents. Founded by Lawrence and Julius Holmefjord-Sarabi, the school has grown from five teachers and 100 students to eight branches, 100 employees, and 2,100 students over the past three years. To achieve this, the brothers implemented a customer service-focused approach, hiring only full-time music teachers with bachelor's or master's degrees. The school also uses data and technology to streamline operations, including a live scheduling system and a billing system that allows customers to pay fees directly to their credit cards.

site_title: Cuba is open but Americans aren't going
summary: US airlines have significantly reduced flights to Cuba due to low demand, with American Airlines cutting daily flights by 25% and JetBlue downsizing its planes. Despite a surge in interest following the US embargo's relaxation, Cuba's unique problems, including high prices and limited hotel availability, have deterred American tourists. The average round-trip airfare from the US to Cuba has dropped, but concerns about US law and travel regulations remain. Experts predict that fewer than 2016's 2016 traveler count, citing a lack of federal government support for the destination.

site_title: Uber investigating sexual harassment claims by ex-employee
summary: Uber's CEO Travis Kalanick is investigating claims of sexual harassment by former engineer Susan Fowler, who reported her supervisor's behavior to HR, which was ignored. Fowler left Uber in December to join Stripe and detailed her experience in a blog post. Kalanick has instructed HR chief Liane Hornsey to conduct an urgent investigation, calling the behavior "abhorrent" and promising to fire anyone who engages in such behavior. The incident highlights Uber's reputation for an intense workplace culture with high turnover and comes amid the company's ongoing struggles with diversity and women's issues.

site_title: Carbon tax is no solution for climate change, huge debts
summary: A proposed US carbon tax, initially set at $40 per tonne of emitted carbon dioxide, could reduce US emissions by 26-28% below 2005 levels. However, its effectiveness is hindered by opposition from most Americans, who see it as a costly solution with uncertain long-term benefits. To address this, the Republican plan includes a rebate system, where the poor would receive a quarterly "carbon dividend" starting at $2,000 annually. Despite its potential, a carbon tax faces significant challenges, including the need for substantial increases in revenue and the uncertainty of technological breakthroughs.

site_title: No wealth taxes yet; govt looking at new or higher taxes
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat announced no wealth taxes in the latest budget, but hinted at new or higher taxes to compensate for rising healthcare and infrastructure costs. Experts predict higher tax rates on personal income, property, and goods and services tax (GST), with potential increases to the GST rate to 10% and a new personal tax top rate of 22%. The government is studying options, with some speculating that property tax hikes could be a more straightforward approach.

images.alt_text: There were no wealth taxes announced in Monday's Budget, but observers say it's likely to come, just a matter of when, as Singapore spends more on healthcare and infrastructure.

site_title: Discretion is top order at Casa Cruz
summary: Casa Cruz, a London-based Art Deco-inspired restaurant, has become a hotspot for London Fashion Week's elite, including celebrities and designers. The restaurant, owned by financier Juan Santa Cruz, offers discretion and exclusivity, with customers signing nondisclosure agreements and photographers not allowed inside. Santa Cruz, who has drawn inspiration from designers like Dries Van Noten and Tom Ford, has attracted high-profile clients such as Karl Lagerfeld and John Galliano. The restaurant's popularity stems from its unique blend of style and craftsmanship, reflecting Santa Cruz's own eclectic fashion sense, which has evolved through his years of living in different cities.

site_title: London house prices post biggest yearly drop in 6 years
summary: London house prices saw their largest annual drop in almost six years, falling 0.4% to £641,116 in February, according to Rightmove Plc. This marks the first annual decline since 2011. The decline is attributed to high asking prices deterring buyers, with a 2.6% monthly gain in January being the weakest February increase since 2009.

site_title: Apple's upcoming iPhone boosts Foxconn
summary: Apple's upcoming iPhone has boosted Foxconn, the main assembler of the company's smartphones, with shares rising 29% in the past year. This growth is attributed to optimism about the 10th anniversary iPhone. The company's founder is re-tooling for the future by installing robots throughout its facilities spanning China to South-east Asia.

site_title: An eye on 5 'I's of Budget 2017 (Amended)
summary: Singapore's Budget 2017, announced on February 20, 2017, focused on five "I"s: Innovation, Industry, Internationalisation, Inclusiveness, and Infrastructure. The budget recognized the pivotal role of small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in the economy and proposed measures to support innovation, internationalization, and industry development. However, critics noted a lack of clear innovation strategies and entrepreneurship measures. The budget also introduced a Global Innovation Alliance and a Carbon Tax to promote energy efficiency and encourage innovation. Overall, the budget aimed to build skills and capacity to bring the economy to the next frontier, with a focus on adaptability and quick change.

site_title: Higher grants for first-time buyers of HDB resale flats
summary: Singapore has introduced higher subsidies for first-time buyers of HDB resale flats, with couples eligible for up to S$110,000 in government assistance. The increased CPF Housing Grant, ranging from S$50,000 to S$110,000, aims to support families and encourage homeownership. The government has also announced additional support for childcare and post-secondary education, as well as a one-off GST voucher of S$280 million to help lower-income households with expenses.

site_title: China saddled with an unwieldy debt load
summary: China's debt load has surpassed 270% of its GDP, driven by easy credit and the growth of the unregulated "shadow finance" sector. The country's economy expanded by 6.7% last year, but analysts warn that this growth is unsustainable. The People's Bank of China has raised short-term rates, but experts say this may not be enough to control the debt crisis, which poses a risk of a hard landing for the economy. The government is struggling to balance growth with the need to curb speculation and corporate defaults.

site_title: Kraft drops US$143b bid for Unilever after negative response
summary: Kraft Heinz Co dropped its $143 billion bid for Unilever NV after the Anglo-Dutch company rejected the offer, citing it as "fundamentally undervaluing" the household-products maker. The decision was made after Unilever's negative response and concerns that a protracted war of words would risk future deal opportunities. The bid, which would have created a $84.8 billion packaged-food giant, was seen as a strategic move to increase profitability in a tough industry. Unilever's rejection was likely influenced by concerns over Kraft's cost-cutting model and lack of vision for cultivating brands.

site_title: Lowering budget cap for ministries to ensure prudent spending
summary: Singapore's government will apply a permanent 2% downward adjustment to the budget caps of all ministries and organs of state from FY2017 to emphasize prudent spending. Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat emphasized the need to drive innovation and value for money, stating "We can do better - and more - with less." This move could lead to delays or cancellations of projects, freezing of pay, or a slow-down in hiring.

images.alt_text: Finance minister Heng Swee Keat said: "With our spending needs increasing, the government will continue to spend judiciously, emphasise value for money and drive innovation in delivery. "We can do better - and more - with less," he said.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Vard Holdings has confirmed the value of a krill fishing vessel contract with Aker BioMarine at approximately S$128 million. International Healthway Corp's convertible loan facilities were terminated by Oxley Holdings and its executives following the takeover offer from OUE. Saizen Reit's proposed reverse takeover by Sime Darby Property Singapore remains uncertain. Global Logistic Properties acquired a Chinese firm for S$72 million, and Noble Group successfully completed a US$1 billion revolving borrowing base facility for its subsidiary.

site_title: Thai economy up 3.2% in 2016 but growth below junta's target
summary: Thailand's economy grew 3.2% in 2016, below the junta's target, following a two-decade period of strong growth. The nation's financial fortunes have stuttered in recent years. The country's economy has struggled to revive after the generals' efforts to revive it. The growth rate is a slight increase from the previous year but still below expectations.

site_title: London Fashion Week serves up fresh Youthquake
summary: London Fashion Week kicked off with a display of youthful ingenuity, showcasing the city's talent and creativity. Donatella Versace praised London's youth culture, citing its fearlessness and courage. Designers such as Matty Bovan and Supriya Lele impressed with their collections, which blended traditional and modern elements. JW Anderson's show featured a "style odyssey" with mixed fabrics and unexpected combinations. Simone Rocha's presentation, meanwhile, emphasized strength and femininity through tailored garments and bold accessories. The week's events marked a shift towards a more youthful and rebellious London fashion scene.

site_title: Building capacities for the future (Amended)
summary: Singapore's 2017 budget aims to build economic capacities and supports small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in transforming and growing in a changing economy. The budget includes measures to help workers adapt to structural changes and get trained in industries with good growth prospects, as well as initiatives to formalize the gig economy and extend social benefits to informal workers. The government also offers support for companies to go digital, innovate, and scale up, and provides incentives for firms to hire older workers. However, the government's finances are expected to strain due to ageing and rising social needs, and measures to strengthen its revenue base will be needed in the future.

site_title: Temasek invests in China's bike-sharing startup Mobike
summary: Temasek Holdings has invested in China's bike-sharing startup Mobike, raising over US$300 million since the start of 2017. Mobike plans to launch in Singapore by March and is also in the running for a tender for Singapore's first large-scale bicycle-sharing pilot scheme. The company has seen rapid expansion to 21 cities in China and has 5.85 million weekly active users. Mobike aims to enhance its technology, increase production capacity, and promote its innovative model internationally.

site_title: Enhanced grants expected to lift resale HDB market
summary: The Singapore government has announced enhancements to the CPF Housing Grant for first-time buyers of resale HDB flats, aiming to boost the resale market and stabilize prices. The grants will increase to up to S$110,000 for first-time families and up to S$55,000 for first-time singles, helping to address the oversupply of new HDB units and stabilize resale prices. The move is expected to lift resale transactions and support the recovery of the resale market.

site_title: Over S$80m set aside to help SMEs go digital
summary: Singapore's government has set aside over S$80 million to help small and medium enterprises (SMEs) go digital and adapt to a tech-driven world. The "SMEs Go Digital Programme" will launch three initiatives: sectoral Industry Digital Plans, SME Centres, and an SME Technology Hub. The programme aims to provide advice, funding support, and access to ICT vendors and consultants to help SMEs build digital capabilities. The government believes this will level up whole sectors and boost capabilities in data and cybersecurity.

images.alt_text: For starters, the government will launch the "SMEs Go Digital Programme" to help these companies build digital capabilities. The programme, to be led by public sector agencies such as Spring Singapore and the IMDA, has three broad initiatives.

site_title: OKP's Q4 earnings quadruple to S$8m
summary: OKP Holdings' fourth-quarter net profit more than quadrupled to S$8.02 million, driven by higher revenue, gross profit margin, and contributions from associated firms and joint ventures. Revenue surged 40.6% to S$34.45 million, with the construction segment increasing 33% and the maintenance segment rising 71.8%. Gross profit margin doubled to 31.3%. The company's year-end net profit more than doubled to S$14.3 million.

site_title: Quasi-Reits in China spread beyond equity markets
summary: China's central bank has authorized the first sale of a "quasi" real estate investment trust (Reit) in the interbank bond market, expanding the investor base for the new asset class amid rising commercial property values. State-owned Anhui Xinhua Media launched a 553.5 million yuan quasi-Reit, which may be a precursor to a listed Reit market in China.

site_title: Businesses to get S$1.4b boost, CIT rebate extended to YA2018
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat announced a S$1.4 billion boost for businesses, including a S$25,000 corporate income tax (CIT) rebate cap for YA2017 and an extension to YA2018 with a reduced cap of S$10,000. Existing measures, such as the Wage Credit Scheme and SME Working Capital Loan, will continue. The government expects to pay out S$600 million to businesses next month, with 70% going to small and medium enterprises.

site_title: Where the money will go
summary: Singapore is establishing a centre to advance sustainable aviation in Asia-Pacific, while also providing support for businesses hit by tariffs. The government is offering a new grant of up to SGD 100,000 to affected businesses. Additionally, the country is being considered as a potential global hub for advanced chip packaging, according to a study. The government is also advising graduates to "stay calm" with better employment rates, citing early data.

site_title: Q4 domestic wholesale trade stays flat
summary: Singapore's domestic wholesale trade index remained flat in Q4 2016, with a 3.7% decline when petroleum is stripped out. Overall, domestic wholesale trade declined 7.4% year-on-year after adjusting for price changes. Foreign wholesale trade index rose 9.1% in Q4 2016, with a 10.4% increase when petroleum is removed. Five categories showed double-digit growth year-on-year, while five declined, including telecommunications & computers and transport equipment.

site_title: Additional S$26m a year to support workers' training
summary: The Singapore government has committed an additional S$26 million annually to support workers' training, starting July 1. The re-employment age will be raised to 67 years from 65 years, allowing workers younger than 65 on that day to also qualify. This move aims to encourage firms to hire older workers and provide more incentives for potential growth sectors through the Attach and Train initiative.

site_title: AVJennings' H1 FY2017 earnings drop 14.4%; revenue down 16.6%
summary: AVJennings, an Australian residential property developer, reported a 14.4% drop in net profit to A$14.1 million for the six months ended Dec 31, 2016, due to a 16.6% decline in revenue. The net profit included a release of A$3.5 million impairment provision, primarily driven by projects in NSW and South Australia.

site_title: Singapore builders could be the next cause for bank pain
summary: Singapore builders' contractors are facing financial strain due to five years of real-estate curbs, with 60% of suppliers expecting delayed payments. This could lead to a 5% increase in construction sector insolvencies. Singapore banks, including DBS, OCBC, and UOB, have reported S$146.4 billion in exposure to the industry, with S$685 million in soured construction debt at the end of December. The situation could worsen if business failures occur, posing a risk to the banks' financial stability.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Ezion Holdings is expected to report a net loss for Q4 FY16 and full-year FY16 due to possible impairments of US$45-50 million. United Overseas Bank (UOB) has been upgraded to "buy" by BS Group Research, citing asset quality prospects and lower credit costs. Phillip Securities Research has reduced its target price for UOB to S$18.92, citing a missed quarterly profit estimate.

site_title: Lotte gets China warning over US missile system
summary: China has warned South Korea's Lotte Group that severe consequences will follow if it allows the US anti-missile system to be deployed on land owned by the company, which is currently part of a golf course. This comes after China halted work on a multi-billion-dollar real estate project in response to South Korea's plans to host the system. Lotte had stated that China's actions were a retaliation for South Korea's plans. The warning from China's state-run Xinhua news agency is a response to South Korea's decision to deploy the US missile system.

site_title: UK keen to strengthen trading ties with South-east Asia nations
summary: The UK aims to strengthen its trading ties with South-east Asian nations, particularly in Singapore, its largest trading partner. The UK government's ambition is to become the world's natural business partner and create a "Global Britain" through international trade and investment. The country has identified over 50 countries where British expertise can meet local needs, with a focus on sectors such as defence, healthcare, and financial technology. The UK seeks to make the case for free trade, despite global challenges, and is committed to working with its trading partners to overcome barriers and ensure globalization benefits all.

site_title: Cash-rich Japanese companies come into focus for global funds
summary: Japan's cash-rich companies are shifting focus towards higher dividend payouts and buybacks, driven by Abenomics' emphasis on return on equity. The government's pension fund, GPIF, has been pushing asset managers to engage in more active cash deployment. Companies like Bridgestone Corp have recently announced significant buyback programs, with stock prices of companies that have done so outperforming the benchmark index by over 39% since 2012. This trend is expected to continue, with revisions to Japan's stewardship code and corporate governance code in the works, signaling a "quiet revolution" in the Japanese stock market.

site_title: Registration tax hikes for big motorcycles
summary: Singapore is introducing progressive taxes for big motorcycles, similar to cars. The government is also encouraging the use of cleaner vehicles through incentive schemes and taxes. Notably, motorcycles no longer need to give up COEs for the open category quota. This change aims to promote more environmentally friendly transportation options.

site_title: Bright spots ahead for insurer Great Eastern
summary: Composite insurer Great Eastern posted an 11% fall in fourth-quarter net profit to S$195.2 million and a 25% drop in full-year earnings to S$589.3 million in 2016. However, total weighted new sales and new business embedded value indicate a brighter picture for the longer term, with 13% and 11% growth in Q4 2016 and FY2016 respectively. Steeper medical claims and new business strain contributed to the decline, but the insurer's fundamentals remain positive, with robust growth rates and a strong agency and bancassurance channel.

site_title: New co-investment fund to help businesses go overseas
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat announced the International Partnership Fund (IPF), a new co-investment fund that will invest up to S$600 million in government capital to help Singapore-based enterprises scale up and internationalise. The fund, managed by Heliconia Capital Management, will focus on Asian markets and enable local firms to partner with other Asian companies. Eligible firms must be headquartered in Singapore and have annual revenues of no higher than S$800 million. The fund aims to support larger companies with established brands, but smaller firms may also benefit from existing schemes.

site_title: Trump trademark: breaking the rules
summary: US President Donald Trump's administration is facing chaos and in-fighting, with top aides constantly at odds and domestic and foreign policy steps mismanaged. Trump's executive orders, such as a travel ban from Muslim countries, have sparked public outcry and court challenges. The White House is accused of covering up alleged ties between Trump's campaign officials and Russian spies. Trump's behavior, including insulting journalists and accusing intelligence agencies of leaking, has raised concerns about his ability to govern effectively. Despite this, Trump's core supporters believe his unconventional approach will help him push through economic initiatives, such as tax cuts and infrastructure programs.

site_title: Shell says new LNG buyers want shorter, smaller contracts
summary: Royal Dutch Shell reports that new LNG buyers are seeking shorter and smaller contracts due to uncertainty over demand evolution. The company sold LNG into six new markets in 2016, compared to a typical annual rate of 2-3 new national buyers. Shell expects much of new LNG demand to come from countries looking to replace declining domestic gas production and those seeking to complement pipeline and domestically produced gas. LNG sales rose 45% last year to 57.11 million tonnes.

site_title: Pence emerges as influential point man in domestic, global issues
summary: US Vice President Mike Pence concluded his first international trip as vice-president with meetings in Brussels, promising "unwavering US support" for NATO and holding Russia accountable for its actions. Pence's mainstream Atlanticist stance on EU and NATO issues contrasts with President Donald Trump's criticisms, indicating Pence aims to assume significant influence on US international policy. This marks a pattern where the last three vice-presidents have enjoyed substantial influence in US foreign policy, following Pence's recent role in ousting National Security Advisor Mike Flynn.

site_title: US: Markets closed for public holiday
summary: US financial markets are closed on Monday, February 20, 2017, for President's Day. Trading will resume on Tuesday.

site_title: Tritech unit wins S$3m wastewater treatment system contract in China
summary: A Tritech Group subsidiary, Anhui Clean Environment Biotechnology Co, has won a contract worth 14.86 million yuan (S$3.06 million) to design and install a wastewater treatment system for a plant in Wuhan, China. The contract, awarded on Feb 15, is expected to be completed by July 5 this year and will not impact Tritech's consolidated earnings per share or net tangible assets per share for the current financial year.

images.alt_text: A SUBSIDIARY of Tritech Group has been awarded a 14.86 million yuan (S$3.06 million) contract to design and install a wastewater treatment system for a plant in Wuhan, China.

site_title: Govt looks into levying 'Netflix tax' on digital buys
summary: Singapore is considering a "Netflix tax" to collect Goods and Services Tax (GST) from digital transactions, including e-services like music and video downloads. The move aims to create a level playing field for local businesses and foreign-based ones. Australia has already introduced a similar tax, and Singapore may lower the S$400 threshold or require overseas vendors to register for GST. The government is studying both options, but the impact on consumers could be significant, potentially increasing the cost of digital purchases.

images.alt_text: The government is looking to collect Goods and Services Tax (GST), currently at seven per cent, from digital transactions.

site_title: North Korea, Malaysia row as Kim killing film emerges
summary: North Korea and Malaysia are locked in a diplomatic confrontation over the investigation into the killing of Kim Jong Un's brother, Kim Jong Nam, at Kuala Lumpur airport. The Malaysian probe has implicated five North Koreans, but Pyongyang claims the investigation is biased and lacks evidence. Malaysia has recalled its envoy to North Korea and summoned Pyongyang's ambassador, while the North Korean ambassador has accused Malaysia of "delusions, lies and half-truths". The incident has raised tensions between the two countries and highlighted the ongoing power struggle within the North Korean regime.

site_title: GLP buys Shanghai firm for 350m yuan
summary: Global Logistic Properties (GLP) has acquired Shanghai Jingxi Business Consulting Co for 350 million yuan (S$72 million) in cash. The acquisition gives GLP a 45.6% stake in Beijing Capital Farm. GLP's indirect subsidiary purchased 100% of Shanghai Jingxi, but the company did not provide details on what Shanghai Jingxi and Beijing Capital Farm are.

site_title: 'Green' push for diesel leaves London choking amid record air pollution
summary: London is experiencing record air pollution, largely due to diesel cars and trucks, with hourly mean levels of PM2.5 exceeding those in Beijing. The city's air pollution is linked to 23,500 deaths annually in Britain, and the European Union has ordered five member countries, including Britain, to reduce car pollution levels or face financial penalties. The British government's previous efforts to aid the environment by incentivizing diesel engines have contributed to the problem, as diesel cars emit five times more emissions in real-world driving conditions. To address the issue, London's Mayor, Sadiq Khan, plans to introduce a toxicity charge and expand low-emission zones, including a planned £500 million national fund to help drivers switch to cleaner vehicles.

images.alt_text: Central London buildings shrouded in smog on Jan 24, 2017, when Britain's Met Office forecasters placed a "severe" warning over all of England, a day after London issued its "very high" pollution alert.

site_title: Sponsors shying away from Fifa as Russia World Cup draws near
summary: FIFA is struggling to attract top-tier sponsors for the 2018 World Cup in Russia, with only one new partner, China's Wanda Group, and one regional sponsor, Alfa Bank, signed since the last tournament in Brazil. The US$150 million cost of the most expensive deal and fallout from the 2015 corruption scandal may be deterring companies. FIFA has just nine companies on its roster, down from 20 by the time the Brazil World Cup started, and its target of 14 tier-one and tier-two backers seems ambitious.

site_title: Utah startup brings virtual reality's potential for magic closer
summary: A Utah startup, the Void, is developing virtual reality attractions that aim to revolutionize entertainment and potentially revitalize struggling shopping malls. The company's first location, featuring a Ghostbusters-themed experience, has sold over 43,000 tickets and generated nearly $900,000 in revenue. The Void plans to open 20 more locations this year, with a focus on social, wireless experiences that could solve the nausea problem associated with VR gear. With backing from influential investors and partnerships with major film companies, the Void is positioning itself as a potential game-changer in the virtual reality industry.

site_title: Goldman unit launches up to US$82m block deal in Max Financial
summary: A unit of Goldman Sachs has launched a block deal to sell up to US$82.1 million worth of shares in Max Financial Services Ltd, with an option to upsizing by US$41.1 million. The deal involves selling up to 10 million shares at a floor price of 550 rupees per share, a 7.52% discount to Max Financial's Monday closing share price.

images.alt_text: A unit of Goldman Sachs has launched a block deal to sell up to US$82.1 million worth of shares in Max Financial Services Ltd with an upsize option of $41.1 million, a deal term sheet showed on Monday.

site_title: EU and IMF in 'common position' on Greece
summary: Eurozone ministers reached a "common position" on Greece's bailout, aiming to resolve a deadlock with the IMF over debt relief and budget targets. Germany's finance minister Wolfgang Schaeuble expressed confidence that the IMF will continue to participate in the bailout. The Eurogroup plans to discuss the progress, with a possible return to Athens' mission expected soon. However, Greece's leftist premier Alexis Tsipras has refused to accept further tightening of budget targets, and the IMF has demanded debt relief. The negotiations come ahead of European elections, which could delay matters and impact the bailout.

site_title: Undeterred by Brexit, Vattenfall eyes growth in Britain
summary: Vattenfall, a Swedish utility, remains committed to its British operations despite the country's decision to leave the EU. The company plans to expand its business in the UK, investing 4 billion Swedish crowns this year and next, and sees no threats to its operations. Britain aims to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and decrease its energy dependency on foreign suppliers, which Vattenfall believes will benefit its renewable energy business. The company's wind power capacity in the UK accounts for 28% of its total capacity.

site_title: How will Trump's tax plan succeed when Bush's in 2004 failed?
summary: US President Donald Trump's proposed tax plan aims to incentivize companies to repatriate profits by offering a 5% tax rate, similar to the 2004 American Jobs Creation Act. However, a 2004 investigation found that this repatriation led to companies returning $312 billion in profits, but with little to no increase in domestic jobs or investment. The money was instead used for share buybacks, executive salaries, and increased dividends. If Trump's plan is successful, it could repeat the same pattern, potentially leading to a loss for the US Treasury and no appreciable job growth.

site_title: Expedia, Amazon bet on UK with more staff, office space
summary: Online travel booking company Expedia has expanded its London office by 138,000 square feet, doubling its existing space, and signed a new lease until 2030. This move comes as the UK navigates potential changes to border controls. Amazon is also investing in the UK, with its AI-focused innovation hub for edtech research set up in Singapore. Other companies, including BHP, Oracle, and Grab, have established AI hubs in Singapore. These investments signal a continued focus on AI and digital innovation in the UK and Asia.

site_title: Oxley CEO and deputy CEO terminate loan agreement with IHC
summary: Oxley Holdings' CEO and deputy CEO have terminated their loan agreement with International Healthway Corporation (IHC) following the sale of their stakes to developer OUE. IHC had entered into convertible loan facilities with Oxley, totaling up to S$55 million, but drew only S$1.51 million, which is repayable on demand with interest. OUE has acquired 35.77% of IHC and now holds 57.6%, launching a mandatory cash offer for IHC shares. The move comes after Oxley sold its stakes to OUE.

site_title: UK manufacturing picks up more pace in Feb, but so do price pressures: CBI
summary: UK manufacturing saw its order books grow at the strongest pace in two years in February, with a +8 balance, surpassing expectations. However, the weaker pound is pushing up input costs, leading to higher output price inflation expectations. Export orders remained stable, while manufacturers expect to raise prices over the next three months to their highest level since April 2011. The post-Brexit economic growth continues, despite inflation challenges emerging.

site_title: Texas oil fields rebound from lull, but jobs are left behind
summary: Texas oil fields have rebounded from a 2015-2016 slump, but the industry is struggling to replace jobs lost due to automation. Over 163,000 oil jobs were lost nationally, with 98,000 in Texas, and many workers have migrated to construction or renewable energy. Powerful computers and software have replaced manual labor, and companies are investing in high-tech workers, such as data analysts and robotic design engineers, to develop complex algorithms and supervise drilling operations remotely. Despite improved production and safety, the industry's workforce is shrinking, with some companies aiming to hire fewer people through automation.

site_title: Indonesia watchdog says Yamaha, Honda distributors guilty of price-fixing
summary: Indonesia's anti-monopoly agency has ruled that PT Yamaha Indonesia Motor Manufacturing and PT Astra Honda Motor, distributors of Yamaha and Honda motorbikes, guilty of price-fixing for automatic scooters with an engine capacity of 110-125 cubic centimeters. Yamaha Indonesia was fined 25 billion rupiah ($2.698 million) and Astra Honda 22.5 billion rupiah. Both companies denied the allegations, with Yamaha Indonesia reserving the right to appeal.

site_title: Euro inches up against US$ and yen
summary: The euro rose 0.1% to US$1.0616 and 0.3% to 120.06 yen, holding onto minimal gains despite concerns over far-right French presidential candidate Marine Le Pen. French bond yields showed the biggest gap to German equivalents since 2012, but investors believe a potential tie-up between Socialist Benoit Hamon and hard-left Jean-Luc Melenchon would weaken the euro. Market anxiety persists due to US President Donald Trump's fiscal and tax policies, with the start of 2017 dominated by disappointment and a potential impact on currency trades.

site_title: Oil rises, but faces prospect of growing US output
summary: Oil prices rose on Monday, with Brent futures up 33 US cents to US$56.14 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude up 23 US cents to US$53.63. Despite OPEC's commitment to cut production, rising US drilling rigs and record stockpiles tempered gains, with US oil production expected to increase by 405,000 barrels per day. The 90% compliance rate with OPEC's production cuts is being offset by growing US shale production, making it challenging for prices to surpass US$55 a barrel.

site_title: London office workers trust BOE more than government on Brexit
summary: A survey by FTI Consulting found that London office workers trust the Bank of England more than the UK government on Brexit, with 36% considering the BOE's communications as "informative and believable" compared to 25% for the government. The survey also showed that workers are uncertain about the impact of Brexit on their jobs, with 80% stating they'll remain with their current employers in the UK. The findings suggest that office workers may not be as confident in the government's ability to navigate the Brexit process as they are in the BOE's expertise.

site_title: Gold isn't behaving in practice the way it should in theory
summary: Gold prices have defied expectations, rising 7% since the US Federal Reserve's interest rate increase in December, despite the theory that higher rates should negatively impact the metal. The metal's price jump is attributed to uncertainties surrounding the Trump administration, as well as other global economic and political factors, including elections in Germany and the Netherlands. Investors are seeking a haven from uncertainty, driving up gold prices to $1,236.86 an ounce.

site_title: National Arts Council to appoint new CEO
summary: The National Arts Council (NAC) announced the appointment of Rosa Huey Daniel as its new CEO, effective March 1, 2017. Daniel, currently deputy secretary (culture) at the Ministry of Culture, Community and Youth, will oversee policy formulation and implementation in the arts and culture sector. She will also continue as CEO of the National Heritage Board until a new CEO is appointed. Daniel brings over 30 years of experience in the public sector, including key postings in various ministries.

site_title: Raffles Medical Group's FY2016 earnings edge up to S$70.2m
summary: Raffles Medical Group's FY2016 earnings rose 1.3% to S$70.2 million, driven by a 15.4% increase in revenue from its expanding clinic network and contributions from its Medical Clinics Holdings (MCH) acquisition. Higher expenses, mainly due to inventory and consumable consumption, weighed down the profit. Despite this, revenue growth was driven by increased sales of medical supplies and services.

site_title: JPMorgan says panda bond sales to grow as China opens market
summary: JPMorgan Chase & Co and BNP Paribas SA plan to increase yuan bond sales in China as the government opens the market to foreign underwriters. The two banks received approval to underwrite corporate bonds regulated by the central bank last month, allowing them to help global clients tap China's bond market. Foreign underwriters have an advantage in helping foreign companies sell panda bonds in China due to their knowledge of overseas clients. Demand for panda note issuance is strong, with European, US, and Taiwanese clients expressing interest in selling them.

site_title: Gasoline glut in New York has traders sending cargo abroad
summary: The US East Coast is experiencing a gasoline glut, with traders exporting cargo from New York Harbour to abroad. Record-high inventories have led to low prices, reversing typical trade flow. At least six shipments originally bound for Europe were diverted to the Caribbean or US Gulf Coast in January and February. This oversupply is causing concern among traders, who are now shipping gasoline and diesel abroad.

images.alt_text: The biggest gasoline market in the US is bursting at the seams.

site_title: SG Budget Reactions: SICC sees a raft of measures to help Singapore companies, SMEs
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat delivered the Budget 2017 speech, outlining plans to strengthen corporate capabilities and promote digitalization, innovation, and overseas expansion. The government announced measures to assist SMEs, including the SME Go Digital Programme, and provided targeted relief for sectors facing headwinds. The Singapore International Chamber of Commerce welcomed these measures, calling for companies to take advantage of schemes to innovate, learn, and grow. The budget also aims to reduce carbon footprint and promote a caring and inclusive society.

site_title: Top aide latest Thai palace official to fall from grace
summary: A senior Thai palace official, Air Vice Marshal Chitpong Thongkum, has been fired and stripped of his titles after being accused of improperly using his connections to King Maha Vajiralongkorn. This is the latest in a string of officials to fall from grace, following the removal of Princess Srirasmi Suwadee's titles in 2015 and the purging of others accused of improperly claiming connections to the king. The move comes as King Vajiralongkorn continues to consolidate power and shield the royal family from scrutiny.

site_title: Opec wins investors back as cuts prompt record bets on oil
summary: OPEC has achieved a record 90% initial compliance with its oil production cuts, boosting investor confidence and driving record bets on oil prices. The US benchmark oil price has traded between $50.71 and $54.34 since January 10, with hedge funds increasing their net-long position on West Texas Intermediate oil by 8.6% in the week ended February 14. This optimism is attributed to OPEC's commitment to reducing supply and the expectation of a balanced market.

images.alt_text: Opec has never taken supply cuts so seriously, and hedge funds are loving it.

site_title: SG Budget Reactions: SMF says Singapore factories must aspire to go global
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat delivered his Budget speech, outlining plans to strengthen corporate capabilities, promote digitalization, innovation, and overseas expansion. The Singapore Manufacturing Federation (SMF) welcomed the measures, citing opportunities for businesses to transform and grow in the face of global economic challenges. SMF expressed gratitude for government recognition of the role of Trade Associations and Chambers and looks forward to Committee of Supply reports to help businesses innovate and scale up globally.

site_title: Sovereign funds pulled US$38b from global markets in 2016
summary: Sovereign funds pulled US$38 billion from global markets in 2016, marking their third year of net selling. Oil-backed funds were under pressure due to falling oil prices, but redemptions from third-party fund managers slowed year-on-year. The rate of selling decreased in the fourth quarter, partly due to a rebound in oil prices to around US$57 a barrel. This trend suggests that decisions to redeem assets were not short-term, according to eVestment's global head of research.

site_title: Economy good, but homes in German cities overpriced, Bundesbank says
summary: The German economy is expected to remain strong, driven by high industrial and construction activity, despite concerns about the side effects of monetary stimulus. Homes in large German cities are overpriced by 15-30% due to high demand and limited supply, with residential property prices rising by 8% last year. The Bundesbank warns that this could lead to inflation and fuel concerns about a property bubble. The European Central Bank will consider its next steps on March 9, with some economists expecting no changes amid a recent price increase mainly due to higher oil prices.

images.alt_text: Homes in large German cities are between 15 and 30 per cent overpriced, the Bundesbank said on Monday, in a message that is likely to stoke further fears in Europe's strongest economy about the side-effects of monetary stimulus.

site_title: Pence vows Trump committed to nervous EU
summary: US Vice President Mike Pence reassured European leaders of President Trump's commitment to transatlantic ties during a Brussels meeting, amid concerns of a potential US abandonment. Pence expressed the US strong commitment to continued cooperation and partnership with the European Union. The meeting came as anti-Trump protests took place in Brussels, but Pence's visit aimed to comfort allies fearful of a shift in US policy.

site_title: SG Budget Reactions: On carbon and diesel tax
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat announced a carbon tax of S$10 to S$20 per tonne of greenhouse gas emissions, starting from 2019. A volume-based duty on automotive diesel and industrial diesel will also be introduced to encourage users to reduce diesel consumption. Industry experts welcome the move, citing its potential to transform the economy by promoting energy efficiency and clean energy sources. The revenue generated by the carbon tax may be channeled into promoting innovation and sustainability.

site_title: Euro inches higher in face of France political noise
summary: The euro rose 0.1% to US$1.0616 and 0.3% to 120.06 yen, defying signs of gains for far-right French presidential candidate Marine Le Pen. French bond yields widened to their largest gap to German equivalents since 2012 after a poll showed Emmanuel Macron's lead over Le Pen narrowing. The euro held onto its gains despite a lack of US investors in the market due to a holiday.

site_title: OKP Holdings' Q4 earnings soar 315% (Amended)
summary: OKP Holdings reported a 314.7% increase in net profit to S$8 million for the fourth quarter ended Dec 31, 2016, driven by revenue and joint venture increases. Earnings per share rose to 2.6 cents from 0.63 cents in the previous year. Full-year net profit rose 104.7% to S$14.3 million. Revenue for Q4 increased by 40.6% to S$34.5 million.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's Budget 2017 addresses global shifts, including trade and economic changes. Domestic wholesale trade expanded 10.3% in Q4 2016, but remained flat year-on-year. Noble Group completed a $1 billion revolving borrowing base facility and Vard Holdings valued its Aker BioMarine contract at $127.4 million. Meanwhile, Takeda Pharmaceutical transferred its Japan consumer healthcare business to a subsidiary. The Singapore stock market closed weaker due to Wall Street's closure and anticipation of the government's Budget 2017.

site_title: Wilmar posts 70% rise in Q4 profit
summary: Wilmar International reported a 69.9% year-on-year increase in Q4 net profit to US$560.8 million, driven by stronger commodity prices and higher sales volume. Revenue rose 26.7% to US$11.95 billion. Earnings per share increased to 8.9 US cents from 5.2 US cents. The company declared interim and final dividends, and its stock slipped 1.01% to S$3.90.

images.alt_text: WILMAR International on Monday posted a 69.9 per cent year-on-year increase in net profit for the fourth quarter ended Dec 31, 2016, to US$560.8 million, led by stronger performance across all segments.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks advanced on Monday, with the Hang Seng Index rising 0.47% to close at 24,146.08. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also increased, with gains of 1.18% and 0.90% respectively. The positive lead from Wall Street contributed to the gains, as investors remained optimistic despite ongoing US-EU trade tensions.

site_title: SG Budget Reactions: On corporate tax
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat announced an extra S$310 million for the Corporate Income Tax rebate, increasing the cap from S$20,000 to S$25,000 for YA2017 and extending it to YA2018 at 50% and 20% of tax payable, respectively. Experts welcomed the move, but noted it may not be enough for businesses grappling with rising costs. The government's focus on helping local enterprises grow and expand overseas was also highlighted.
