summary: James Dyson, the 70-year-old founder of the Dyson brand, emphasizes the importance of innovation and taking risks to create better products. He believes that engineers should strive to see beyond existing technology and ask if there's a better way. The company has invested £330 million in its Singapore facility, which has led to the creation of 1,100 jobs, with plans to grow the engineering staff by 50%. Dyson's products are known for their unique design, which is driven by technology rather than aesthetics. He believes that patents encourage innovation and that failure and rejection should be seen as opportunities to learn and improve. The company is currently working on new technologies, including artificial intelligence and robotics.

images.alt_text: Mr Dyson with various digital motors which will be used in future applications using robotic technology. Above right: The Dyson V8 Cord-Free Vacuum is the brand's most powerful cordless vacuum cleaner. It can also transform into a hand-held machine.

Above left: Dyson Pure Cool Link purifying fan uses a HEPA filter to trap ultrafine particles. It automatically monitors and reacts to the air-pollution level in your home, while simultaneously reporting live indoor and outdoor air quality to a smartphone, via the Dyson Link App. Above right: Dyson spent four years and £50 million to develop the Dyson Supersonic hair dryer that is quiet, fast, light and intelligent.

site_title: Fiat's jump contrasts with GM chief signalling desire to exit Europe
summary: Fiat Chrysler Automobiles (FCA) shares have surged following speculation about a potential combination with General Motors (GM), amid GM's proposed sale of its European business. Analysts see this as an opportunity for FCA to revive its long-standing effort to merge with GM, eliminating overlap in Europe and replacing money-losing operations with FCA's profitable brands. However, GM CEO Mary Barra has expressed no interest in a combination, contradicting FCA's jump in shares.

site_title: 'Variety is the spice of life' rings true in collecting wines
summary: A wine collector's experience highlights the importance of evaluating vintage evaluations critically, considering biases and personal preferences. Initially, relying on printed evaluations and scoring was sufficient, but as knowledge grew, the importance of multiple sources and neutral recommendations became apparent. Focusing solely on top vintages, known as "100-pointers," can be limiting, as lesser vintages often offer unique characteristics and flavors. Collecting and drinking lesser vintages can provide a valuable learning experience, and it's recommended to wait at least six years before opening top vintages to allow them to mature.

site_title: ST Engineering's Q4 earnings rise 21% to S$170.4m
summary: ST Engineering reported a 21% net profit growth in Q4 2016 to S$170.4 million, driven by revenue growth in its aerospace sector. Revenue for the full year was 6% higher at S$6.68 billion, despite a 8% decline in net profit to S$484.5 million. The company attributed lower profits to a one-off charge for asset impairment and closure costs. ST Engg proposed a final dividend of 10 Singapore cents per share, with a total dividend yield of 4.81%.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Hock Lian Seng Holdings, a 47-year-old Singaporean company, has a record high orderbook with three to five years' earnings visibility. The company boasts a robust 2017 forecast net cash of S$209.9 million, or 80% of its market capitalization. Analysts from UOB Kay Hian Research initiate coverage with a "buy" and target price of S$0.69, citing a 7.6 times ex-net cash price earnings ratio. The company offers a 4.9% dividend yield and potential for further growth.

site_title: Pay of Credit Suisse's senior Asia-Pac investment bankers up 15%: sources
summary: Credit Suisse raised senior Asia-Pacific investment bankers' pay by 15% in 2016, with average total compensation ranging from $1 million to $1.5 million. The bank's Asia-Pacific underwriting and advisory business saw a 38% increase in net revenue, driven by a surge in merger, equity, and debt-capital market transactions. The move aims to boost profitability, which was impacted by a 2.4 billion Swiss franc annual loss in 2016. The bank's CEO, Tidjane Thiam, plans to cut up to 6,500 jobs this year to reduce costs.

site_title: US labour secretary nominee withdraws as Republican senators turn against him
summary: US labour secretary nominee Andrew Puzder withdrew his nomination after Republican senators turned against him, dealing a setback to President Donald Trump's Cabinet. Puzder, a fast-food executive, faced attacks from Democrats, unions, and liberal groups over his business record and character. The withdrawal was a victory for these groups, who had been vocal in their opposition to his nomination. Puzder's defeat marks the latest challenge for the White House in its efforts to fill key positions.

site_title: Two PAP wings offer recommendations for Budget debates
summary: The People's Action Party (PAP) youth wing and policy forum have released a position paper offering recommendations for Budget 2017 debates in parliament. The 10-page document suggests enhancing employability and competitiveness for four groups: students, young adults, mid-career professionals, and the silver generation. Recommendations include a dynamic school syllabus for students, expanded industry scholarships, relocation allowances for mid-career professionals, and incentives for companies to re-design jobs for the ageing workforce. The PAP activist-led initiative aims to provide input for the government's Budget 2017 decisions.

images.alt_text: The People's Action Party (PAP) youth wing and the party's policy forum have penned a position paper that aims to generate input for the upcoming Budget 2017 debates in parliament.

site_title: A price on carbon emissions
summary: Singapore aims to sign a carbon credits transfer agreement with its first ASEAN country by the end of 2025, as part of its efforts to combat climate change. The country is also considering introducing legislation for airlines to offset carbon emissions. Temasek's sustainable investments have reached S$46 billion by FY2025, while BYD and other EV battery makers face increased pressure to reduce their emissions. MAS is also evolving its climate investing approach, and it will deepen cooperation with the PBOC in green and transition finance.

site_title: Boycott culture forces CEOs to walk tightrope in era of Trump
summary: US companies face a "damned-if-you-do, damned-if-you-don't" dilemma in today's polarized culture, where advertising on or off certain platforms can lead to boycotts. A Weber Shandwick study found that 57% of top executives believe boycotts can affect a company's bottom line, while 64% of consumers care what they find about a brand on social media. Companies must navigate controversy and decide which groups to risk offending to avoid backlash, with those standing on principle gaining an advantage, according to Micho Spring, head of global corporate practice at Weber Shandwick.

site_title: Opportune time to tweak tax policies to help vulnerable groups
summary: The Committee on the Future Economy recommends tweaks to Singapore's tax policies to help vulnerable groups, including retrenched workers, low-income earners, and senior citizens. The government proposes exempting retrenchment benefits from taxes, introducing a credit system for lifelong learning, increasing earned income relief for seniors, and introducing a new tax bracket for high-income earners. Additionally, a one-off 50% personal income tax rebate will be offered to individual taxpayers. These measures aim to promote inclusivity and address the challenges of the future economy.

site_title: Regulate, not ban, lower risk tobacco products
summary: Singapore's health authorities should reconsider their stance on regulating lower-risk tobacco products, such as e-cigarettes and heated tobacco products. These products are significantly less harmful than traditional cigarettes, with the Royal College of Physicians estimating a 5% harm reduction. Allowing these products could "crowd out" traditional cigarettes and help smokers quit, with the US Surgeon General's report finding e-cigarettes to be "the most successful product at helping people to quit smoking". Regulating these products instead of banning them could lead to a more effective reduction in smoking-related deaths and diseases.

site_title: Remaining TPP members should resurrect ambitious pact
summary: The Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) was thrown into disarray when the US withdrew, leaving remaining members to revive the pact as TPP11. A simulation model suggests that countries with existing FTAs with the US, such as Canada and Australia, will benefit economically under TPP11. Countries excluded from the original deal, like China and India, will also gain. However, the US will be the largest loser, with a 0.2% GDP contraction. The remaining TPP countries should proceed with TPP11, keeping the original agreement intact, and leave the option open for the US to rejoin.

site_title: IE S'pore: Internationalisation 'core' to sustaining country's growth
summary: Singapore's International Enterprise (IE) Singapore says internationalisation is "core" to sustaining the country's growth, with a survey of 700 businesses finding that overseas revenue grew 4.2% year-on-year, outpacing total revenue growth of 1.3%. The survey also found that small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) derived 53% of their revenue from overseas activities, and that companies are increasingly interested in expanding into emerging markets such as Vietnam, Myanmar, and India. IE Singapore facilitated over 450 projects globally last year, with a focus on South-east Asia, China, and India.

site_title: India taps newcomers to unlock oil and gas assets
summary: India has awarded rights to develop 31 small oil and gas fields, entrusting most of the 15 new entrants, including Sun Petrochemicals and Megha Engineering & Infrastructure Ltd, to boost local production. The development of these fields is crucial for Prime Minister Narendra Modi's plan to reduce oil imports by 10% by 2022, which could increase oil output by 15,000 barrels a day and gas production by 2 million cubic meters a day. The awarded fields hold potential for investments and job creation over the next decade.

site_title: Where a city sees decay, a fight to save a community
summary: In Charlestown, Indiana, a city of 8,000, residents of Pleasant Ridge, a neighborhood of prefabricated WWII-era homes, face a code violation crackdown that many believe is intended to drive out low-income residents. The city claims the homes are unsafe and prone to crime, but residents say the fees are meant to target those who cannot afford to pay. A group of residents has filed a request for a preliminary injunction to stop the city, arguing that the crackdown is a form of eminent domain. The city disputes this, saying the goal is to improve safety and quality of life.

site_title: Mapletree Investments acquires Oakwood Worldwide
summary: Mapletree Investments has acquired US-based Oakwood Worldwide for an undisclosed sum, aiming to expand its corporate housing and serviced apartment business across the US, Europe, and Asia-Pacific. Oakwood's CEO Christopher Ahearn will lead the company, while founder and chairman Howard Ruby will become non-executive chairman emeritus. The acquisition strengthens ties between the two companies, which previously collaborated on a joint venture in 2014.

images.alt_text: MAPLETREE Investments has acquired US-based Oakwood Worldwide for an undisclosed sum as the Singapore real estate company seeks to boost its corporate housing and serviced apartment business.

site_title: Cash-rich Asian conglomerates scour for US fund deals
summary: Asian conglomerates such as SoftBank and HNA Group are investing heavily in US fund deals, seeking expertise and diversifying their portfolios. SoftBank acquired a New York-listed private equity firm, while HNA Group took a stake in a New York hedge fund company and another in a British insurer. The deals are part of a broader trend as Asian firms look to become financial conglomerates, with SoftBank aiming to create a "Berkshire Hathaway of the tech industry." The acquisitions offer access to new distribution networks and information on the US investment industry, but also raise concerns about the buyers' ties to their home countries.

site_title: DBS Q4 profit falls 9% on surge in allowances
summary: DBS Group Holdings, Singapore's largest bank, reported a 9% decline in Q4 earnings to S$913 million due to a surge in allowances related to its oil and gas exposure. CEO Piyush Gupta remains optimistic, expecting single-digit loan growth and double-digit profit growth in 2017. Despite a 1.4% increase in non-performing loans, the bank's other businesses continue to perform well, with consumer banking and wealth management showing strong growth. DBS proposed a final dividend of 30 Singapore cents per share, unchanged from the previous year.

site_title: Finance sector emerges tops in Singapore 1000 rankings
summary: Singapore's largest 1,000 companies saw a 8.3% drop in combined revenue to S$2.8 trillion and a 5.4% decline in combined profits to S$165.4 billion in the 2017 ranking period. However, the finance sector experienced double-digit revenue and profit growth, with a 10.4% increase in revenue to S$118.3 billion and a 12.1% increase in profits to S$27.1 billion. This growth is attributed to the growth of private wealth and Singapore's reputation for stability.

site_title: Brexit's economic ripple effects felt from London to Bangladesh
summary: The economic ripple effects of Brexit are being felt in Bangladesh, where garment makers are struggling with rising import costs due to the pound's 16% slump. Despite concerns, big high street brands such as Primark and Next are squeezing suppliers instead of raising prices for shoppers. Suppliers are under pressure to lower prices, with some reporting a 11% year-on-year increase in sales to Next. Bangladesh's economy is holding up, but the country remains vulnerable to future market access and tariff regimes, with economists warning of potential uncertainty and impact on trade.

site_title: Old-school charm, bespoke luxury in BT Weekend
summary: China's "Karaoke King" is transforming Shanghai's waterfront into a mega museum of contemporary art. The Business Times Weekend magazine also features an interview with Ethan Koh, a luxury bag designer, and a drive with Volkswagen Group Singapore's managing director Ricky Tay. In the main paper, Brunch discusses kaya toast and coffee culture, while the Sass and the City column proposes radical ways to fix Singapore. Additionally, the Cubicle Files offers a guide on delivering tough love to underperforming employees.

site_title: Manila magic
summary: Art Fair Philippines, now in its fifth year, has become a major stop in the Asian art-buying season, attracting international galleries and collectors. The event has evolved from a small, one-floor affair to a four-floor classy event with professionally designed booths and a chic rooftop dining area. The fair has seen a significant increase in galleries, from 24 in its first year to 46 this year, with a focus on showcasing Filipino heavyweights and emerging artists. Despite some foreign galleries reporting weak sales, the event has maintained its momentum, with local support being a key factor in its success.

site_title: Civil penalties of S$100,000 each for two over SFA breaches
summary: Two individuals, John Chionh Teow Hie and Kiew Yoon Seng, have been ordered to pay S$100,000 each in civil penalties for breaching the Securities & Futures Act. They engaged in false and unauthorized trading in Keda Communications shares between June 2008 and November 2009, including 52 cross trades and 6 wash trades that artificially raised the price of the shares. The actions were deemed a breach of the Securities & Futures Act, with MAS stating that the individuals intentionally deceived Phillip Securities Pte Ltd to avoid paying higher brokerage fees.

site_title: A balancing act of near and long-term demands
summary: Singapore's Budget 2017 is expected to address both long-term and near-term demands, providing practical steps to relieve immediate business and worker concerns. Economists anticipate a business-friendly policy response, with targeted moves to ease near-term pressures. The budget will likely outline steps to balance long-term growth with short-term needs, aiming to support businesses and workers amidst global economic challenges.

site_title: UBS says US$9t China bond market to come of age
summary: UBS Asset Management predicts China's $9 trillion bond market will come of age, doubling in size in five years, driven by government reforms and inclusion in global benchmark indexes. Despite a money-market squeeze, capital controls, and shrinking reserves, the market is expected to attract more foreign investors. However, investors remain cautious due to concerns over government control and unclear tax rules. UBS expects tighter financial conditions to lead to slower economic growth and prompt a "looser" monetary policy, ultimately benefiting the market.

site_title: ExxonMobil upgrades Singapore refinery
summary: ExxonMobil is upgrading its Singapore refinery to increase base oil production, a key ingredient in lubricants. Construction is set to begin in Q2 2017 and finish by 2019, with the company declining to disclose investment details. The expansion will strengthen global supply of EHC Group II products, helping to meet stringent specifications and reduce emissions. The move affirms ExxonMobil's confidence in Singapore as a major refining hub, with the company investing in other recent projects in the region.

site_title: Capturing the dark times of Singapore's war years
summary: A new permanent exhibition, Syonan Gallery: War and Its Legacies, opened at the Former Ford Factory in Singapore, marking the 75th anniversary of the Fall of Singapore in 1942. The exhibition features local oral history accounts, memoirs, and everyday objects from the Japanese Occupation years, aiming to capture the dark times of Singapore's war years. Despite controversy over the exhibition's name, which some quarters view as legitimizing the Japanese name for Singapore, the National Library Board stressed that the building is still a National Monument.

site_title: Rickmers Maritime's Q4 loss lower; auditor makes disclaimer
summary: Rickmers Maritime reported a Q4 net loss of US$48.44 million, lower than the previous year's US$129.58 million. The loss was mainly due to a non-cash impairment for a vessel sold to raise cash. The shipping trust's auditor, PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP, issued a disclaimer of opinion due to the non-cash impairment. Noteholders rejected a debt restructuring plan, further impacting the company's financial situation.

site_title: No deal on global bank capital rules expected in early March
summary: Global banking regulators are unlikely to reach an agreement on capital requirements rules in early March due to the US government's delay in appointing a new top financial supervisor at the Federal Reserve. The Basel Committee, comprising nearly 30 countries, met on March 1-2 but was unable to reach a deal on reforms, which would supplement the existing Basel III accord. The US government's executive order to review regulation has raised concerns about a fragmented global approach to banking rules, with some European regulators expecting the US to focus on easing specific rules rather than ditching global standards.

site_title: US jobless claims edge upward in mid-February
summary: US jobless claims rose by 5,000 to 239,000 in the week ending February 11, edging upward but remaining low. This is the 102nd week of jobless claims below 300,000, the longest streak since 1970. Analysts attribute the low claims to employers' reluctance to lay off workers, which may prompt the US Federal Reserve to raise interest rates. This follows Chair Janet Yellen's testimony that conditions indicate more interest rate increases will be appropriate, potentially including a hike as soon as next month.

site_title: Update: Snap seeks to raise as much as US$3.2b in initial offering
summary: Snap Inc is seeking to raise up to $3.2 billion in its initial public offering, offering 200 million Class A shares for $14 to $16 apiece. The company's valuation would be between $16.2 billion and $18.5 billion, lower than its initial target of $20 billion to $25 billion. Snap reported a 6-fold increase in revenue to $404.5 million last year, but net losses widened to $514.6 million. The company's shares have no voting power, and its user growth slowed in the second half of 2016.

site_title: Equity seen as game-changer in Spain
summary: Neinor Homes, a Spanish homebuilder, sees an opportunity to construct more homes due to the current low demand in secondary towns and cities, where millions of empty apartments exist. The company aims to capitalize on this by increasing construction in big cities like Madrid and Barcelona, where the housing stock is running low. With the support of Lone Star Funds, Neinor plans to sell 25-50% of the company this year, valuing it at around €2 billion. This move is expected to make equity the key game-changer in the Spanish construction market.

site_title: Revisiting exhibition in art book
summary: Photographer Ang Song Nian's exhibition, "Hanging Heavy on My Eyes," explored Singapore's haze and was later compiled into an art book. The book features 365 silver gelatin prints based on data from the National Environmental Agency, documenting the highest and lowest PSI readings at noon daily. Ang's work has a personal urgency, as he has experienced retinal detachment surgery and panic due to pollution. The book is a conceptual art object, not just a documentation of the exhibition, and is printed in a limited edition of 401 copies.

site_title: OUE launches takeover offer for IHC
summary: OUE Limited has launched a surprise takeover offer for International Healthway Corporation (IHC), valuing the nursing home owner at approximately S$175.9 million. The offer price is 1.9% above IHC's last-traded price, and OUE aims to expand into healthcare real estate, citing "tremendous" growth potential. The takeover bid comes just a week after OUE increased its stake in IHC to 21.83%, following a series of similar offers by Lippo Group conglomerate.

site_title: US housing starts exceed estimates after a stronger December
summary: US housing starts exceeded estimates in January, reaching 1.25 million annualised pace, driven by a surge in multifamily unit construction. Single-family house construction rose 1.9% to 823,000 annualised rate. Permits increased 4.6% to 1.29 million annualised rate, and builders expect growth despite a shortage of skilled workers and ready-to-build lots. The National Association of Home Builders/Wells Fargo index of homebuilder sentiment fell to 65 in February, still close to an 11-year high, due to hopes for regulatory easing.

site_title: Dual-class shares: issue now is striking the right balance
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) is seeking public feedback on allowing dual-class shares (DCS), which grant certain privileged shareholders more voting rights. Despite concerns over governance, the exchange believes DCS is necessary to attract high-tech companies and startups, which favor this arrangement. The consultation paper proposes safeguards, such as a "sunset clause" to convert multiple-vote shares to one-vote shares after a certain period. The debate now centers on striking a balance between commercial benefits and shareholder protection, with proposals including a minimum market capitalization of S$500 million and restricting DCS companies to the mainboard.

site_title: Trudeau says EU must spread trade's benefits or risk its decline
summary: Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau urged European lawmakers to share the benefits of the newly approved trade pact, Ceta, to prevent its decline, stating that inclusive trade is key to addressing economic anxiety. Trudeau emphasized the pact's potential as a blueprint for future trade deals, but warned that its failure could be one of the last multilateral trade agreements. The agreement's approval comes as protectionist sentiment in North America and Europe grows, with Trudeau seeking to maintain Canada's $540 billion annual trade relationship with the US.

site_title: Groundbreaking ceremony held for Yoma Central in Yangon
summary: A groundbreaking ceremony was held for Yoma Central in downtown Yangon, Myanmar, marking the start of its construction. The integrated real estate development, designed by architect Cecil Balmond, will feature luxury residences, office towers, and a business hotel. The project, which was stalled for years due to red tape, is a collaboration between Yoma Strategic Holdings and First Myanmar Investment. The ceremony included a traditional Burmese ritual to ensure a smooth project, with the development expected to transform Yangon into an international city.

images.alt_text: Yoma Strategic and FMI executive chairman Serge Pun performing a traditional Burmese ritual at the groundbreaking ceremony of Yoma Central, meant to ensure a smooth, trouble-free project.

site_title: OUE launches takeover of International Healthway Corp
summary: PROPERTY group OUE has launched a takeover offer for International Healthway Corporation (IHC) at 10.6 Singapore cents per share. OUE agreed to buy an additional 35.77% stake in IHC from four sellers, bringing its stake to 57.6%. This move comes after OUE acquired a 22.83% stake in IHC in January. The takeover offer is the latest development in OUE's expansion strategy.

site_title: Chinese banking stocks stage surprise rally
summary: Chinese banking stocks have staged a surprise rally, with Agricultural Bank of China Ltd climbing 14% in an eight-day period and Bank of China Ltd soaring to levels last seen in August 2015. Analysts attribute the turnaround to modest monetary tightening, stabilizing bad debt levels, and relatively high dividend yields. Mainland funds are drawn to the banks' cheapness and cheapness, with China's Big Four lenders offering an average dividend yield of 5.2%. However, concerns about the banks' bad debt recognition remain, and some analysts warn that shares may be due for a pullback.

site_title: Germany urges fair business environment for its carmakers in China
summary: Germany's Foreign Minister Sigmar Gabriel urged China to create a fairer business environment for foreign companies, particularly German carmakers, during talks with Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi. The call comes as the EU seeks to promote free trade and counter protectionist pressures from the US. Germany's carmakers face obstacles in China, where the government plays a more interventionist role. China aims to increase plug-in car sales to 5 million by 2020, making it the largest electric car market, and Germany wants to tap into this market.

site_title: Uber gives staff a way to cash out with no IPO in sight
summary: Uber offers a program allowing long-time employees to sell up to 10% of their shares after four years of service, with a capped buyback of under $10 million per employee. This program incentivizes staff to stay, but also limits exits, as Uber has not gone public and instead uses its own funds to purchase and sell shares. Fewer than 200 of the 10,000 Uber employees qualify, and employees must remain at the company while selling shares, which are paid out over months.

site_title: China loses a friend, and leverage, with North Korean murder
summary: China's loss of influence over North Korea's Kim Jong Un's leadership with the murder of his half-brother Kim Jong Nam, 45, has raised concerns about a potential geopolitical miscalculation. The assassination at a Malaysian airport has strained China's relations with North Korea, which Beijing has long seen as a buffer to US forces. China's ties with North Korea have cooled, with total commerce falling for two years to $5.4 billion in 2016, and China rejecting a US$1 million shipment after North Korea's latest missile test.

site_title: US: Cisco helps Wall Street extend streak of record highs
summary: US stocks reached a record intraday high for the sixth straight session, driven by gains in Cisco, which jumped 2.8% to $33.76. The S&P 500 technology index rose 0.29%, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average and Nasdaq Composite also increasing. The rally follows President Donald Trump's vow of a 'phenomenal' tax announcement and robust economic data. Despite concerns about a potential market pause, the S&P 500 index ended higher for the seventh session in a row, its longest winning streak since September 2013.

site_title: Frasers Centrepoint unit to issue inaugural series of securities
summary: FRASERS Centrepoint Limited's subsidiary FCL Treasury plans to issue its inaugural series of securities, S$348 million in fixed-rate notes with a 4.150% interest rate, maturing on Feb 23, 2027. The notes will be used for general corporate purposes, including refinancing existing borrowings and financing investments. OCBC is the sole global coordinator and bookrunner for the Series 1 Notes, under the S$5 billion Multicurrency Debt Issuance Programme established by FCL Treasury in January 2017.

site_title: Looking at unspeakable loss up close
summary: Lee Chandler, a handyman, is forced to confront his tragic past after his older brother's death in the film Manchester by the Sea. Lee's life is consumed by grief, and he's tasked with caring for his 16-year-old nephew Patrick. As Lee returns to his hometown, he must come to terms with his own family's tragedy and reconnect with Patrick, who has grown accustomed to life in Manchester. The film is a powerful human drama exploring loss, grief, and the impact on a small community.

images.alt_text: Uncle (Affleck, at left) and nephew (Hedges) picking up the pieces and trying to renew their once-close relationship in Manchester by the Sea.

site_title: Trump tax cuts could boost profit US$12b at big US banks
summary: US President Donald Trump's proposed corporate tax cut could boost annual profits of the six largest US banks by an average 14% and save them a combined $12 billion annually. The banks, which have higher effective tax rates, would benefit more from the cut, with Wells Fargo and JPMorgan Chase expected to see significant increases in earnings. However, some banks, including Citigroup and Bank of America, may face one-time losses due to reduced deferred-tax assets. Tax reform could happen faster than regulation changes, and its impact could be greater, with some experts arguing that eliminating interest expense deductions could be too disruptive for banks.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 2.20 points to close at 1,707.59 on Thursday, marking a lower day for shares. A total of 2.11 billion lots valued at RM2.11 billion were traded, with 367 gainers and 502 losers.

site_title: Oil rises after news Opec could extend output cuts
summary: Oil prices rose after Opec sources indicated the group could extend its supply-reduction pact with non-members, potentially leading to deeper cuts if global inventories don't drop to target levels. Benchmark Brent crude rose 40 US cents to $56.15 a barrel, while US light crude gained 30 US cents to $53.41 a barrel. The pact, which began on January 1, aims to reduce a price-sapping glut and is set to be extended by May if major producers show effective cooperation. Global inventories remain high, particularly in the US.

site_title: Latest Earnings
summary: Oil prices rose over 2% amid market uncertainty and ongoing trade tensions. US stocks edged down from record highs due to tariff threats, while European stocks declined due to bank and healthcare sector concerns. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and similar operating losses for the second half of the year. London's Heathrow airport is considering higher fees for a £10 billion upgrade, and Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case involving 285 trillion rupiah.

site_title: Looking for a story behind all the static
summary: Bacchanalia's new chef, Luke Armstrong, has taken over the kitchen after Ivan Brehm and Mark Ebbels left. Armstrong, a former chef at Gordon Ramsay's Maze in London, brings a new, more energetic approach to the restaurant. His dishes are intricately composed, featuring local ingredients like chilli crab and foie gras. While the food is technically sound, it sometimes feels overly ambitious, with too many components clashing. The meal is pricey at S$125 for a lunch tasting menu, but the food is good to very good, with standout dishes like crispy lentil falafel and a well-balanced battle of artichokes. The kitchen's new DNA is a departure from the previous, more understated approach, leaving the future of Bacchanalia's Michelin stars uncertain.

site_title: ECB minutes suggest little appetite to curb stimulus
summary: European Central Bank policymakers have expressed little appetite to curb stimulus, citing a temporary inflation surge and ongoing growth threats. The ECB's rate-setting meeting showed "wide" support for maintaining a steady policy stance, despite concerns about rising prices and potential policy tightening. Policymakers dismissed concerns about inflation, citing weak underlying inflation and slow second-round effects, and warned of growth constraints and downside risks. The ECB is expected to keep policy unchanged until autumn, when it will review its stance.

site_title: China outbound investment plunges under new curbs
summary: China's direct overseas investment plummeted 35.7% in January, falling to 53.3 billion yuan, amid tightened restrictions on foreign acquisitions. The government aimed to curb "irrational" spending and capital flight. This marks a significant shift after authorities had encouraged Chinese firms to invest abroad in search of better returns. The decline in overseas investment follows a record-breaking 44% surge in 2016, with Chinese firms making major acquisitions, including Wanda Group's purchase of Legendary Studios for $3.5 billion.

site_title: JPMorgan to HSBC face fines in South African rand-rigging probe
summary: South Africa's antitrust investigators have referred a dozen banks, including JPMorgan and HSBC, to an antitrust tribunal for colluding and manipulating trades in the rand currency since at least 2007. The Competition Commission recommended fines of 10% of the banks' turnover, but the tribunal will determine a penalty based on "affected revenue." The probe comes amid pressure to break the dominance of the country's four largest lenders and force them to lend more to black clients.

site_title: Silver Creek Capital's aggregate shareholding of Auric Pacific stands at 80.04%
summary: Silver Creek Capital, owned by Stephen Riady and Andy Adhiwana, has acquired 3.32% of Auric Pacific shares, increasing its aggregate shareholding to 80.04%. The buyout offer of S$1.65 per share is final and won't be revised. This move may limit dissenting minority shareholders' ability to "put" their shares and potentially unlock their investment in case of delisting.

site_title: British blue chips snub investor calls to reveal CEO pay ratios
summary: British blue chips are resisting calls to reveal CEO pay ratios, sparking a rift with major investors who aim to combat wage inequality. Four FTSE 100 companies, including GlaxoSmithKline and AstraZeneca, refused to disclose how much more their CEOs earn than the average worker. The move is seen as a challenge to the government's efforts to address record wealth divisions and rising anti-globalization sentiment.

site_title: Football: English FA posts record £370m turnover despite England flop
summary: The English Football Association (FA) has reported a record £370 million turnover for the 2015/16 season, despite England's Euro 2016 defeat. The FA made a profit of £7 million after tax, up from a £9 million loss in 2015. The increased revenue allowed the FA to invest £125 million in the domestic game. The record turnover surpasses previous records and demonstrates the FA's financial stability.

site_title: Consultancy files complaints with Chinese government over McDonald's China sale
summary: A Chinese consultancy has filed a complaint with the Chinese government regarding McDonald's sale of its China and Hong Kong business to Citic Ltd and Carlyle Group LP for up to $2.1 billion. The complaint alleges the deal may harm workers and consumers, potentially leading to poorer pay and conditions for McDonald's 120,000 workers in China. Regulatory approval for the deal may be delayed due to the complaint.

site_title: European car market gets off to good start in 2017
summary: The European car market started 2017 with a positive trend, with new car sales jumping 10.2% to 1.17 million units in the European Union in January. Major markets such as Spain, France, Germany, and Italy saw double-digit percentage gains. German carmaker Volkswagen's combined sales rose 10.3%, despite the ongoing "dieselgate" scandal. The market growth is attributed to extra working days during the month, and other carmakers such as PSA Peugeot Citroen and Renault also saw significant sales increases.

site_title: Wall Street's trading revival risks relapse as volatility ebbs
summary: Low volatility has returned to financial markets, contradicting Wall Street's initial hopes for a "durable" trading revival following Donald Trump's presidential victory. The Bank of America Merrill Lynch's MOVE index and the CBOE Volatility Index for S&P 500 are near record lows, indicating a lack of market uncertainty. Analysts attribute the decline to a lack of concrete budget plans from the Trump administration and unchanged economic data. While some asset classes, such as currencies, remain volatile, the overall market outlook remains uncertain, raising concerns about a potential relapse in trading activity.

site_title: Disney plans midnight 'Star Wars' event to unveil 'Last Jedi' toys
summary: Disney is hosting a midnight "Force Friday II" event on September 1 to unveil toys and merchandise for the upcoming film "The Last Jedi." The event, a sequel to the 2015 "Force Friday," will feature new products, including Lego, Hasbro, and apparel, and will be available online and in stores at major retailers. The move aims to build buzz and expand the "Star Wars" audience, with Disney citing strong sales from previous films in the series, including "The Force Awakens."

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's median household income from work rose 2.6% in real terms to S$8,846 in 2016, according to the Department of Statistics. Internationalisation is driving growth for local firms, while a joint development partner has been awarded for the Kuala Lumpur-Singapore High Speed Rail project. DBS CEO signals the bank has overcome worst of energy-loan issues, and ExxonMobil is expanding its Singapore refinery to increase base oil output. Senior Counsel Hri Kumar Nair has been appointed as deputy Attorney-General.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Stocks track Wall Street higher
summary: Hong Kong shares rose on Thursday, following a fifth consecutive record close on Wall Street, driven by growing optimism over the US economy. The Hang Seng Index gained 0.47%, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index rose 0.52% and 0.57%, respectively. The gains were fueled by investor confidence in the US economy, despite recent tariff threats between the US and EU.

site_title: SMBC head says will give Toshiba as much support as possible
summary: Toshiba, a Japanese conglomerate, is struggling financially due to a multi-billion-dollar hole in its nuclear business. SMBC, one of its main lenders, will provide as much support as possible to the firm. Toshiba is considering selling its prized flash-memory chips business, which could help keep its net worth positive. The company may delay the sale and has asked its creditors for an extension of a loan waiver until the end of March. Toshiba's financial woes could see its shares demoted to the second section of the Tokyo Stock Exchange if it remains in negative net worth.

site_title: Protests call for US immigrants to stay home from work, school
summary: US immigrants are being urged to protest President Donald Trump's stance on immigration by staying home from work or school on Thursday, dubbed "A Day Without Immigrants." The action, driven by word of mouth on social media, aims to highlight the vital role immigrants play in US society. Dozens of restaurants and businesses in cities across the US have vowed to close in solidarity with no-show workers, while some, like celebrity chef Jose Andres, are supporting the cause. The protest follows a series of federal raids and Trump's executive order on immigration.

site_title: Singapore shares finish higher, STI pushed up by gains in DBS, Thai Beverage
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 8.21 points to 3,096.69, finishing higher after trading sideways for most of the day. DBS and Thai Beverage contributed to the gains, with DBS rising S$0.31 to S$18.54 despite a 9% decline in Q4 profit and Thai Beverage's S$0.02 rise to S$0.96. Turnover remained high at 3.3 billion units worth S$1.37 billion, with 274 rises versus 215 falls.

site_title: G-20 digesting US warning to Nato and shift in Israel
summary: US Defense Secretary James Mattis warned NATO allies to increase military spending or face a reduced defense commitment, shifting the US stance on its long-held support for Israel. President Donald Trump also departed from previous US foreign policy by suggesting a "one-state" solution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, rather than a two-state solution. These moves are seen as significant shifts in US policy, potentially destabilizing the Middle East and re-evaluating US commitments to its allies and regional conflicts.

site_title: India's Tata Motors, Microsoft ink technology collaboration deal
summary: Tata Motors Ltd and Microsoft India announced a strategic technology collaboration to enhance driving experiences for customers. The partnership will utilize IoT, AI, and machine learning technologies, and the first vehicle showcasing this vision will be unveiled at the Geneva International Motor Show on March 7. This collaboration aims to provide a safe, productive, and fun driving experience for vehicle owners in India and worldwide, creating new revenue opportunities for Tata Motors.

site_title: Trump says market rally due to confidence in his administration
summary: US President Donald Trump credited the recent stock market highs to high confidence and optimism in his administration, despite low approval ratings. He suggested the market will continue to favorably react once the White House and congressional Republicans unveil a new tax cut blueprint. The Dow Jones experienced its longest winning streak in decades, with the president tweeting, "Stock market hits new high with longest winning streak in decades. Great level of confidence and optimism - even before the tax plan rollout!"

images.alt_text: President Donald Trump credited high confidence and optimism in the early weeks of his administration for new stock market highs, despite his low approval ratings, and suggested markets will act even more favorably once the White House and congressional Republicans roll out a new blueprint for tax cuts in the coming weeks.

site_title: Hong Kong stock exchange to launch renminbi currency options on March 20
summary: The Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing Limited (HKEX) plans to launch renminbi currency options on March 20, marking the first time the USD/CNH options will be traded at the exchange. The initial eight contract months will cover various periods in 2017 and 2018.

site_title: Iran gets set for Internet of Things launch
summary: Iran is set to launch the Internet of Things (IoT) nationwide by June 2017, thanks to a deal between French startup Sigfox and local internet provider Parsnet. The IoT applications will allow users to monitor and control devices such as intelligent transportation and gas meters remotely. This move aims to bring the IoT services to Iran, enabling users to access and control various devices connected to computers, mobile phones, and smart watches.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets sag at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets fell at the open on Thursday, with London's FTSE 100 down 0.2% to 7,288.84 points, Frankfurt's DAX 30 down 0.1% to 11,778.99 points, and Paris's CAC 40 flat at 4,925.54 points. The decline came despite another record performance on Wall Street, as investors brushed off concerns over US-EU trade tensions. The lacklustre session in Asia also contributed to the downturn, with European markets struggling to build on the previous day's gains.

site_title: South Korea court plans to end impeachment hearings on Feb 24: Yonhap
summary: South Korea's Constitutional Court plans to wrap up impeachment hearings of President Park Geun Hye on February 24, aiming to minimize the country's leadership gap. The court will make a swift decision, with a verdict expected after closing arguments. If the court upholds the impeachment, a presidential election will be held two months later, stripping President Park of her powers pending the ruling.

site_title: Chip Eng Seng Q4 net profit up 52.5% to S$14.9m
summary: Chip Eng Seng, a construction and property development group, reported a 52.5% increase in Q4 net profit to S$14.9m, driven by a net fair value gain on investment properties and lower administrative expenses. Revenue rose 62.5% to S$250m, primarily due to higher progressive revenue from the High Park Residences project.

site_title: Indonesia's central bank holds key rate at 4.75%
summary: Indonesia's central bank, Bank Indonesia, left its benchmark policy rate at 4.75% for a fourth consecutive meeting, as expected. This decision was made to support economic growth, following six rate cuts last year totaling 150 basis points. The bank also maintained its two other rates, the 7-day reverse repurchase rate at 4.75%, the floor rate at 4%, and the ceiling rate at 5.50%. The decision aims to keep the economy growing while controlling inflation.

images.alt_text: Indonesia's central bank on Thursday left its benchmark policy rate unchanged for a fourth consecutive policy meeting, as expected, saying the current level still supports economic growth.

site_title: Apple vowed to revolutionise TV. An inside look at why it hasn't
summary: Apple has been criticized for its inability to revolutionize the TV industry despite significant investments and efforts. The company has poached Amazon's Fire TV chief, Timothy Twerdhal, to lead its television operations. A new, fifth-generation Apple TV is being tested, which will offer 4K streaming and more vivid colors, but may not be enough to surpass competitors. Apple's vision of replacing cable boxes and providing a seamless viewing experience has been compromised, and the company's focus on fat margins has hindered innovation. The Apple TV's failure to disrupt the market has led to concerns about its long-term viability.

site_title: Nestle sees slower sales as new CEO plans restructuring
summary: Nestle, the world's largest food company, has forecast slower sales and profitability in 2017 under new CEO Mark Schneider's restructuring efforts. Revenue is expected to increase 2-4% organically, with cost savings anticipated by 2020. Schneider has modified the company's long-term guidance, citing challenges such as deflation in Europe, slowing infant formula sales in China, and increasing competition in the US chocolate market. Nestle expects restructuring costs to rise to 500 million francs and plans significant cost savings to drive future profitability.

site_title: Deutsche Boerse CEO says insider trading allegations will prove unfounded
summary: Deutsche Boerse CEO Carsten Kengeter denies insider trading allegations, stating he had no role in determining the timing of his share purchases ahead of merger plans with the London Stock Exchange. Kengeter claims the shares were purchased within a time-frame fixed by the Supervisory board and were subject to a holding period until the end of 2019. The company is cooperating with the public prosecutor, and Kengeter is confident the allegations will be unfounded following a detailed investigation.

site_title: SGX launches consultation on dual-class shares
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has launched a public consultation on introducing dual-class shares (DCS) to its listing rules. The exchange aims to improve market vibrancy through regulatory innovation, with potential safeguards such as a "compelling reason" hurdle and mandatory sunset clauses. If consensus is reached, SGX may propose changes as early as the third quarter of 2023. The consultation seeks feedback on the feasibility and necessary safeguards for DCS structures.

site_title: Editor's note
summary: Wealth expert Keith Magnus of Evercore Asia emphasizes the importance of creating value exceeding costs in investment deals. He advises clients to walk away if the cost of creating value surpasses the value being created. Evercore has successfully executed billion-dollar deals since establishing its Asia office, and Magnus expects bright dealmaking prospects in Asia despite muted economic growth.

site_title: San Miguel's Ang offers 700b peso to airport in tycoon battle
summary: Philippine tycoon San Miguel Corp has proposed a 700 billion-peso ($19.9 billion) airport project in Bulacan province, rivaling billionaire Henry Sy's $20 billion plan for an airport and seaport near Manila. The project, which will be built without government guarantee or subsidy, aims to serve 100 million passengers annually and eventually expand to 150 million. The plan is part of President Rodrigo Duterte's infrastructure spending boost, which aims to upgrade facilities to cope with rising flight traffic and road congestion.

images.alt_text: The battle of Philippine tycoons to build a new airport to serve the nation's capital is heating up as San Miguel Corp proposed a 700 billion-peso (S$19.9 billion) facility, rivalling an offer from a group led by billionaire Henry Sy. San Miguel shares rose to the highest in more than three years.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks end lower as automakers hit by strong yen
summary: Tokyo stocks fell 0.47% on February 16, 2017, as a strong yen dragged down key indexes, despite a record close on Wall Street. The Nikkei 225 index ended at 19,347.53, while the Topix index closed at 1,551.07. A yen rally and profit-taking contributed to the decline.

site_title: Malaysia pledges to return Kim body after autopsy
summary: Malaysia has pledged to return the body of North Korea's half-brother, Kim Jong-Nam, after an autopsy. The country's deputy prime minister, Ahmad Zahid Hamidi, said Malaysia will comply with North Korea's request to claim the body, despite initial objections from the North Korean embassy. The assassination of Kim Jong-Nam, who was poisoned with a liquid at Kuala Lumpur International Airport, has raised tensions between the two countries. Malaysian police have arrested two women, Doan Thi Huong and Siti Aishah, in connection with the killing, and several more arrests are expected.

site_title: Fund managers target tech deals as key trend for 2017
summary: Global tech investors are expected to see a surge in deal-making in 2017, driven by the potential repatriation of offshore cash by US companies under the new tax regime proposed by President Donald Trump. Tech companies such as Netflix, Microsoft, and Alphabet are likely to be major targets for mergers and acquisitions, with software sector deal-making already experiencing a surge in 2016. Fund managers are optimistic about the sector's growth and potential for M&A, with some predicting a "deluge" of tech deals this year.

site_title: Update: Debutant Pacific Star Development up 15% from pre-trading price
summary: Pacific Star Development, a Singapore-based property developer, made its debut on the Catalist board, rising 15% from its pre-trading price of 26.5 cents to 33 cents. The company's transfer follows a reverse takeover by LH Group, allowing for a backdoor listing. Pacific Star Development has several ongoing projects, including Puteri Cove Residences and The Posh Twelve, targeting young and affluent home buyers. CEO Glen Chan aims to expand the brand in the ASEAN region and validate investment support from the community.

site_title: Senior Counsel Hri Kumar Nair appointed as deputy Attorney-General
summary: The Prime Minister's Office announced the appointment of Senior Counsel Hri Kumar Nair as deputy Attorney-General, effective March 1 for a three-year term. He will be the third deputy Attorney-General at the Attorney-General's Chambers. Currently, Senior Counsel Tan Siong Thye will be appointed as a Judge of the High Court on April 1.

site_title: Brexit puts UK's Vauxhall in crosshairs after Peugeot-GM deal
summary: The UK's Vauxhall car brand is uncertain after General Motors considers selling its unprofitable European arm to France's Peugeot, potentially due to the Brexit vote. Vauxhall, Britain's No 2 car brand, employs 4,500 people and supports 17,000 jobs in its supply chain. A sale could lead to plant closures, with Ellesmere Port or Luton's second plant at risk. The consequences of a "hard Brexit" may leave Vauxhall more vulnerable, with 85% of its annual output going to mainland Europe and 25% of its components sourced in Britain.

site_title: ExxonMobil expands Singapore refinery to raise base oil output
summary: ExxonMobil is expanding its Singapore refinery to increase base oil production, with construction starting in Q2 2017 and completion by 2019. The expansion aims to strengthen the global supply of Group II base stocks, used in automotive engine oil and lubricants. The project will also improve energy efficiency and reduce emissions through a previously announced cogeneration project. The expansion is expected to enable customers to blend lubricants that meet more stringent specifications, reducing emissions and improving fuel economy and low-temperature performance.

images.alt_text: EXXONMOBIL, which owns the largest refinery in Singapore, is expanding the facility to increase the production of base oil, which is used to manufacture lubricants.

site_title: China's record global buying spree wanes amid capital flow curbs
summary: China's outbound investment declined 35.7% in January from a year earlier, with foreign direct investment dropping 9.2%. The decline is attributed to measures by the foreign exchange regulator to examine overseas deals and new rules aimed at keeping money in the country. Officials say the January data does not represent a full-year trend, but the fall raises questions about China's appeal to investors.

images.alt_text: China's record outbound investment slumped last month as authorities stepped up scrutiny of acquisitions overseas and other deals to keep money from flowing out of the country.

site_title: Hong Kong: Mainland demand drives stocks to 5-month highs; China rebounds
summary: Hong Kong stocks reached a 5-month high on Thursday, driven by mainland China's demand and a Wall Street rally. China's stocks rebounded, led by coal miners and metal firms, after regional governments' investment targets were published. Hong Kong's Hang Seng index rose 0.4% to 24,092.26 points, but later gave back gains on profit-taking.

site_title: Taking a lower-risk route
summary: A low-volatility equity investment strategy is gaining traction in 2017, as investors seek lower-risk options amid volatile market conditions. According to Ben Dunn, Eastspring Investments Head of Quantitative Solutions Group, Asia ex-Japan equities are undervalued and offer attractive growth opportunities. Low-volatility strategies have outperformed broader markets in Asia over the last decade, typically delivering higher returns during periods of elevated volatility and market drawdowns. By leveraging a systematic approach and excluding expensive stocks, Eastspring's Asia Low Volatility Fund aims to minimize volatility and offer a low-volatility solution for investors in the region.

site_title: In a class of its own (Amended)
summary: Singapore's Good Class Bungalows (GCBs), a highly sought-after and exclusive type of landed property, have seen a slight increase in transactions despite a decrease in the overall landed property market. In 2016, a total of 25 GCB caveats were recorded, marking the highest number of transactions since 2011. The increase in transactions can be attributed to lower price expectations of sellers, reflected in the decline of average transacted prices for a second consecutive year. The scarcity of GCBs and their prestige status in the Singapore property market are expected to support the market's stability.

site_title: London restaurants face a world of pain in 2017
summary: London's restaurant industry faces significant challenges in 2017 due to Brexit. High property taxes, increased costs for imported food and wine, and potential restrictions on the right to work in the UK are among the concerns. Restaurant owners, including Russell Norman and Chris Yates, expect higher costs and potential staffing issues. Some, like Leonid Shutov, remain optimistic about the UK-EU agreement, but many, including Jeremy King, warn that the absence of free movement across Europe will be disastrous for the hospitality industry.

site_title: 2017's big picture
summary:
Global growth appears to be on the mend, with inflation expected to pick up. However, challenges include political risk and potential hurdles to free trade. Experts predict a trend towards combining monetary policy with fiscal expansion to boost growth. Key themes include:

- Global equities: benefiting from infrastructure investments and US fiscal expansion under President Trump
- Rising rate environment: US bond yields expected to drift higher, but with a shallow anticipated trajectory for rate hikes
- China equities: improving macroeconomic data and cheap valuations
- Political uncertainty and policy divergence: monetary policy divergence between the US and other central banks, and potential trade policy changes
- Volatility: intermittent theme throughout 2017, with investors advised to take a longer-term view

Asset allocation calls include:

- US equities: overweight due to expected growth and fiscal expansion
- China equities: constructive due to robust macroeconomic data and policy support
- Fixed income: overweight convertible bonds and investment-grade corporate bonds
- Commodities and real estate: neutral or mildly overweight
- Hedge funds: mildly overweight
- Asia FX: temporary consolidation, with renewed weakness expected in Asia hard currency bonds

site_title: Sydney Airport says new airport terms unviable, sows doubt on involvement
summary: Sydney Airport's CEO, Kerrie Mather, stated that building a new A$5 billion airport in the western outskirts of Sydney is economically unviable without government aid. The proposed project aims to boost inbound air passenger numbers by 10 million people per year. Mather suggested that the government might play a role in the project, citing the potential for decades before seeing reasonable cash flows. Sydney Airport has a first right of refusal to build the airport, but Mather's comments raise doubts about its involvement.

site_title: Seoul: Won gives up gains on finance minister comments, stocks weaken
summary: The South Korean won rose 0.1% to 1,141.5 to the US dollar and 10.0090 against the yen on Thursday, but later gave up gains after finance minister Yoo Il-ho stated the ministry was monitoring currency volatility. The won's gains were offset by flat South Korean shares, with the Kospi index closing down 0.1% at 2,081.84 points. Foreign investors bought Kospi shares worth 162.6 billion won, while local institutions sold 261.7 billion won.

site_title: Seeking the bright spot
summary: Emerging markets (EM) are expected to benefit from a cyclical recovery in key economies and improving earnings growth, driven by Brazil and Russia's economic recovery and China's stable growth. Valuations are considered reasonably attractive, with the MSCI Emerging Markets index trading at 12x forward P/E and 1.57x price-to-book. However, uncertain global politics and the US dollar's strength pose risks, with potential changes to US trade policy carrying asymmetric risk. Despite subdued global growth, intra-EM trade has grown, and improving EM fundamentals could drive earnings.

site_title: Good yield hunting
summary: US markets face uncertainty as Donald Trump's policies take center stage, with fiscal policy and deregulation potentially boosting markets or leading to higher uncertainty. Inflation is expected to rise, affecting bonds, particularly long-dated ones, and high-yield bonds may also benefit from reduced recession risk. Leveraged loans and EM bonds offer diversification and yield enhancement opportunities, but investors must be selective and position defensively due to the unpredictable economic environment.

site_title: India revives passenger plane project as China, Japan race ahead
summary: India is reviving its 14-year-old plan to build a 14-seat twin-turboprop passenger aircraft, called Saras, after a setback in 2009. The aircraft is undergoing preliminary tests and India's air force plans to purchase 15 planes. The development aims to boost air links in remote areas, with the country needing hundreds of small planes to meet this goal. India joins a select few Asian nations that have successfully developed their own home-made jets, with China and Japan leading the way.

site_title: North Korea female agents are regime's weapon of choice: defector
summary: North Korea has shifted from using male agents to female assassins, who are trained with good looks and poison tools, according to defector An Chan-Il. The regime's new approach allows female agents to strike fear into the hearts of enemies without being detected, with a focus on using mini poison injectors disguised as cosmetics or clothing. The change comes after the apparent assassination of North Korea's half-brother Kim Jong-Un, with two female agents suspected of involvement.

site_title: Joint development partner for KL-Singapore high speed rail project awarded
summary: Malaysia's MyHSR Corporation and Singapore's Land Transport Authority have awarded the joint development partner contract for the Kuala Lumpur-Singapore High Speed Rail project to WSP Engineering Malaysia, Mott MacDonald Malaysia, and Ernst & Young Advisory Services. The consortium will provide management support and technical advice on high-speed rail systems and operations. The tender was called on August 22, 2016, and received eight bids, with the contract awarded after a competitive process. The joint development partner will assist with document preparation for the project. The project aims to enhance connectivity between Kuala Lumpur and Singapore.

site_title: Indonesia Jan exports surge more than expected on rising commodity prices
summary: Indonesia's exports surged 27.71% in January to $13.38 billion, exceeding expectations, driven by increased shipments of palm oil and coal. The country recorded a $1.40 billion surplus for the month. Imports rose 14.54% to $11.99 billion, also beating expectations. The strong export performance was attributed to rising commodity prices.

site_title: Doing well, doing good
summary: Veteran lawyer Rajan Menon founded RHTLaw Taylor Wessing in 2011, but it wasn't until he retired from KhattarWong that the firm's true potential emerged. Nearly 100 employees, including 49 lawyers, resigned to join the new firm, which broke even within its first month. Menon's firm emphasized the importance of giving back to society, leading to the establishment of the RHT Rajan Menon Foundation in 2015. The foundation aims to promote philanthropy and provide grants to deserving causes, with a focus on the corporate and legal community.

images.alt_text: Genevieve Cua

site_title: Australia shares end higher on financials; NZ falls most in 3 months
summary: Australia's S&P/ASX 200 index closed 0.1% higher at 5,816.3, its highest close since May 2015, driven by gains in financial and material stocks. The telecom sector fell 6.4% after Telstra Corp's half-year profit plunge. New Zealand's S&P/NZX 50 index dropped 1.1%, its sharpest single-day drop since November 2016, as consumer confidence slipped. US market indexes pushed into record-high territory, boosting Australian shares.

site_title: Lux-cious dining (Amended)
summary: Luxurious dining options are available in Singapore and abroad, with top-rated restaurants like Restaurant Andre and Cé La Vi offering exclusive experiences. In Japan, Michelin-starred restaurants like Ryugin and Narisawa offer seasonal and sustainable ingredients, while Osteria Francescana in Italy offers an a la carte menu alongside tasting menus. Noma, a two-Michelin-starred restaurant, is relocating to Mexico but will reopen in Denmark in the second half of the year, with a waiting list available for its US$750 menu package.

site_title: Lenovo's profit misses estimates after PC rivals erode lead
summary: Lenovo's quarterly earnings missed estimates, with net income falling 67% to $98 million and revenue down 6% to $12.2 billion. The company's PC business remained stable, but its smartphone division turned in an operating loss of $112 million due to declining market share and rising component prices. Lenovo is negotiating a deal with Fujitsu to shore up its position and is cutting jobs, selling assets, and pushing into higher-end devices to weather the shrinking demand and competition in PCs.

site_title: In pursuit of growth
summary: Singapore Reits face challenges in 2017 due to rising interest rates, slowing growth, and higher costs of capital. The US economy's recovery and expected four Fed rate hikes are expected to increase the Singapore 10-year yield to 3.0% by the end of the year. This may constrain growth plans for Reits, with a slowing distribution per unit (DPU) growth profile of 1.1%. Investors are now focusing on the pace of interest rates, making it a challenging year for Reits.

site_title: Rio Tinto said to seek bank pitches on US$1.5b coal sale
summary: Rio Tinto is seeking bank pitches for the sale of its last remaining coal operations in Australia, valued at around A$2 billion. The company has decided to divest its Hail Creek and Kestrel mines after receiving unsolicited approaches from potential buyers. This sale is part of Rio's efforts to reshape its portfolio, focusing on iron ore, copper, and aluminum. The move comes after the company has already sold US$2.45 billion of Australian mines to a Chinese company and US$7.7 billion of assets since 2013.

images.alt_text: Rio Tinto Group has asked banks to pitch for a role advising on the divestment of its last remaining coal operations in Australia, people with knowledge of the matter said.

site_title: DBS CEO signals bank may be past worst of energy-loan issues
summary: DBS Group Holdings Ltd CEO Piyush Gupta signaled that the bank may have passed the worst of its energy-loan issues, citing significantly lower formation of nonperforming assets and bad-loan charges for the industry in 2017. Despite a weaker-than-expected earnings report, DBS shares rose 0.6% due to Gupta's optimistic outlook. The bank reported a 1.4% bad-loan ratio and S$462 million in allowances for credit and other losses, primarily due to the energy-services sector. DBS expects total loan allowances for 2017 to be similar to last year, excluding Swiber Holdings Ltd.

site_title: Gold rises as US dollar gives up gains; US rates in focus
summary: Gold prices rose 0.3-0.4% to $1,235.71/oz and $1,237.3/oz, respectively, amid upbeat US economic data, which boosted prospects of a US interest rate hike in March. The US dollar index fell 0.3% due to traders booking profits. Analysts expect gold to approach a turning point and potentially end its upward trend, with rising US interest rates increasing the opportunity cost of holding gold.

images.alt_text: Gold prices rose on Thursday as the US dollar drifted down from one-month highs hit in the previous session on upbeat US economic data.

site_title: China outbound investment retreats as capital controls bite
summary: China's non-financial outbound direct investment (ODI) decreased 35.7% year-over-year, with overseas property investment plummeting 84.3% in January, according to the commerce ministry. This slowdown is attributed to Beijing's efforts to curb capital flight, which is putting downward pressure on the yuan and threatening to deplete China's foreign currency reserves. The data highlights the challenges facing China's economic policies as the country seeks to manage capital outflows and stabilize its currency.

site_title: BOJ's Kuroda warns low rates may sow seeds of new financial crisis
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda warned that low profitability at financial institutions could sow the seeds of a new financial crisis, citing the need for bolder steps to address Japan's over-crowded regional banking sector. He attributed the issue to aggressive monetary easing, which has hurt profits at financial institutions and created a new challenge for the global banking environment. Kuroda emphasized the importance of considering responses to low profitability to ensure future stability of the financial system.

site_title: With grit and integrity
summary: Keith Magnus, CEO of Evercore Asia, attributes his success to grit, integrity, and determination. He recounts his early experience in 1998 when he walked into a Chase bank interview while recovering from a hospital stay, demonstrating his fierce determination. Magnus, who has helmed billion-dollar deals, emphasizes the importance of grit and integrity in investment banking. He credits his father, a retired senior district judge, as his mentor and values instilled in him. With a track record of advising on over 100 transactions and $50 billion worth of deals, Magnus believes Singapore will remain a hub for investment banking deal flow, and expects active intra-Asian deal flow and M&A activity despite muted global growth.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks down on profit-taking after five-session rally
summary: Taiwan's stocks fell 0.3% to 9,767.98 points, ending a five-session rally that lifted the main index to its highest level since mid-2015. The decline came after the government raised its growth outlook for the trade-dependent economy, prompting profit-taking. The electronics subindex dropped 0.4%, while the financials subindex gained 0.2%. The Taiwan dollar softened to NT$30.837 per US dollar, its weakest level since May 2015.

site_title: Median household income from work in Singapore up 2.6% in real terms in 2016
summary: The median household income from work in Singapore rose 2.6% in real terms in 2016, reaching S$8,846, up from S$8,666 in 2015. This is a decrease from the 4.9% increase in 2015. The median monthly household income per household member grew 3.8% in real terms, lower than 2015's 5.4% growth. Income inequality, measured by the Gini coefficient, fell to 0.458 in 2016 from 0.463 in 2015.

site_title: Internationalisation key engine of growth for local firms: IE Singapore
summary: Singapore companies have become the key engine of growth and transformation through internationalisation, with 4.2% year-on-year growth in overseas revenue, outpacing total revenue growth of 1.3%. Over 50% of firms have a presence in China and Malaysia, with interest in Vietnam, Myanmar, and India. Internationalisation-focused jobs predominantly went to PMETs, and IE Singapore will continue to support companies venturing abroad, particularly in South-east Asia, China, and India.

site_title: Jury out in corruption trial of Hong Kong ex-leader Donald Tsang
summary: A Hong Kong jury has begun deliberating on the corruption trial of former leader Donald Tsang, who is accused of misconduct and bribery while in office. Tsang, 72, faces three charges carrying a maximum seven-year jail sentence. He is alleged to have approved a licence application for a broadcaster and failed to disclose his plans to lease a luxury flat in Shenzhen from a major investor. The trial comes amid public suspicions of cosy links between authorities and business leaders in Hong Kong.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong's former leader Donald Tsang will soon learn his fate as the jury in his high-profile corruption trial began deliberating Thursday.

site_title: Many Singapore firms still have not started looking at adopting new revenue standard: EY
summary: Many Singapore firms have not started adopting the new revenue standard, FRS 115, with less than a year to the January 1, 2018 implementation deadline. A poll of 53 finance executives found that 62% have not started identifying the key impact of the standard, while 6% have completed this process. Only 2% of respondents said their company was ready for adoption. The main challenges include deciding on the approach (full retrospective or modified retrospective) and implementing the standard. EY's survey suggests that firms are struggling to meet the deadline.

site_title: China's yuan edges up to 3-week high, money rates down
summary: China's yuan rose to a three-week high against the US dollar, reaching 6.8629 per US dollar, due to corporate dollar sales and a central bank injection of funds into the banking system. Interbank money rates fell, with the benchmark seven-day repo rate trading at 2.5796% at midday. The People's Bank of China injected 393.5 billion yuan into financial institutions through its medium-term lending facility, and 250 billion yuan through reverse repurchase agreements.

site_title: Fed aims to hike rates, based on more growth and fiscal stimulus: Dudley
summary: The Federal Reserve aims to raise US interest rates as long as the economy grows above its trend and fiscal policies provide a boost, according to New York Fed President William Dudley. Dudley stated that the Fed will gradually remove monetary policy accommodation and snug up interest rates further if the US economy runs above 2% growth, inflation rises, and unemployment remains low. The Fed expects three rate hikes this year, with possible consideration of trimming its $4.5-trillion bond portfolio, but Dudley wants to delay this until he is more confident of not needing rate cuts.

site_title: Australian dollar hits multi-year highs vs euro, yen, Swiss franc
summary: The Australian dollar surged to multi-year highs against the euro, yen, and Swiss franc, reaching 88.17 yen and 2-year peaks against the Swiss franc, due to investors borrowing low-yielding currencies to buy higher-yielding assets. The Aussie rose after a surprise dip in Australia's unemployment rate, but failed to sustain gains. The currency's strength was also influenced by market jitters over European elections.

site_title: Seoul: Won climbs to 3-month high, stocks edge down
summary: South Korea's won surged to a three-month high against the US dollar, reaching 1,140.5, due to the US dollar's decline and increased speculation that the US may add the won to its list of manipulated currencies. The won has risen 1.9% this month, near one-year highs against the yen. However, South Korean shares edged down, with the Korea Composite Stock Price Index falling 0.1%, amid investor sentiment and concerns over the won's value.

site_title: Wildfire razes homes in New Zealand
summary: A wildfire in Christchurch, New Zealand, destroyed at least 11 homes and forced hundreds of residents to evacuate. The fire, which merged two smoldering blazes, burned over 1,800 hectares of land in the Port Hills area. A state of emergency was declared by civil defence officials, and residents were advised to evacuate due to the rugged terrain and difficulty in accessing the area. The cause of the fire is unknown.

site_title: Malaysia detains second suspect in connection with murder of Kim Jong Nam
summary: Malaysia has detained a second suspect in connection with the murder of Kim Jong Nam, the half brother of North Korean leader Kim Jong Un. The suspect, identified as a woman with Vietnam travel papers, was apprehended on Wednesday. Malaysian police are still searching for a "few" other foreign suspects. The inspector general of police stated that an official statement on the arrest would be issued later.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open slightly lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened 2.180 points lower at 1707.610 on Thursday, with 361.9 million lots traded worth RM173.3 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 204 to 200.

site_title: Ski diplomacy boosts Swiss-Iran ties
summary: A team of elite Swiss ski instructors has embarked on a two-week mission to scout for the best skiers in Iran, aiming to establish a new generation of instructors and boost ties between Switzerland and Iran. The team has been inundated with participants, with some days reaching 140 skiers, despite initial concerns about the country's ski infrastructure. The mission is part of a broader effort to rekindle business ties between Switzerland and Iran, which have been strengthened by the 2015 nuclear deal. The goal is to attract more skiers and ultimately more business interest, while also promoting cultural exchange and cooperation between the two countries.

site_title: Malaysia's economy grows 4.5% y-o-y in Q4, matches forecasts
summary: Malaysia's economy grew 4.5% in the fourth quarter, matching forecasts, ending a year of tepid growth on a stronger note due to solid exports. This brings the full-year 2016 growth rate to 4.2%, down from 5% in 2015.

images.alt_text: Malaysia's economy grew 4.5 per cent in the fourth quarter from a year earlier, central bank data showed on Thursday, as a year of tepid growth ended on a stronger note helped by solid exports.

site_title: Asia: Markets dip as Trump rally takes a break
summary: Asian markets declined as investors cashed in profits, despite a record US Wall Street close and positive US economic data. The US dollar also dipped. A rally in Asian markets ended after a week of gains, with investors brushing off President Trump's reassurances on tax reform and US interest rates. The US inflation rate hit a four-year high, fueling bets on an interest rate hike.

site_title: New Facebook job-hunting features challenge LinkedIn
summary: Facebook has launched a new job-hunting feature, allowing businesses in the US or Canada to post jobs and take applications directly on the platform, challenging LinkedIn. Users can find job postings on business pages or a new 'jobs' bookmark on the mobile app. The feature includes an online form filled out with relevant information from a person's Facebook profile, and companies can review and contact applicants through the Messenger service. The feature is currently available in the US and Canada, with plans for a broader rollout.

site_title: Building bridges
