summary: Hong Kong's M+ Museum, set to open in 2019, aims to bridge cultural divides and promote understanding between Hong Kong and China. The museum's lead curator, Aric Chen, emphasizes curatorial independence, stating that the institution's focus is on content rather than politics. The museum's collection, including works by Ai Weiwei and other Chinese artists, has sparked some scrutiny, but Chen notes that the M+ team has "passed" the test. The museum's design and location, a giant laptop-shaped building in the West Kowloon Cultural District, are seen as a symbol of unity and a platform for showcasing Hong Kong's rich cultural heritage.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks extend gains at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.59% at open, tracking a record close on Wall Street, with the Hang Seng Index reaching 24,136.86. This follows Janet Yellen's statement that the US economy is strengthening. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index dipped 0.08%.

site_title: All eyes on Tillerson at G20 in diplomatic debut
summary: US Secretary of State Rex Tillerson is set to make his diplomatic debut at a G20 gathering in Germany, where he will discuss global challenges with counterparts and address concerns about President Donald Trump's foreign policy. Tillerson's maiden trip to Europe comes amid controversy over Trump's ties to Russia and his "America First" policy. He will also meet with Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov and Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi, sparking scrutiny for potential hints of a rapprochement. The G20 gathering aims to provide clarity on the Trump administration's intentions to a wary international community.

images.alt_text: US Secretary of State Rex Tillerson on Thursday will make his diplomatic debut at a G20 gathering in Germany, where his counterparts hope to find out what "America First" means for the rest of the world.

site_title: Suspect in North Korea killing to appear in Malaysia court
summary: A 28-year-old woman, suspected of being one of two female assassins, is set to appear in court in Malaysia over the killing of North Korea's half-brother Kim Jong Nam. The assassination, which analysts say could have been ordered by North Korea, occurred at Kuala Lumpur International Airport on Monday. CCTV images show one of the suspects wearing a "LOL" t-shirt. Malaysian police are searching for more suspects, and North Korea has requested the body, but it remains in the morgue until claimed. This would be the highest-profile death under North Korea's leader Kim Jong Un.

site_title: Samsung chief arrives at prosecutor's office before arrest hearing
summary: Samsung Group chief Jay Y Lee appeared at South Korea's special prosecutor's office before a court hearing to decide on an arrest warrant for his alleged role in a corruption scandal involving President Park Geun-hye. Lee faces expanded charges, including bribery, embezzlement, and perjury, related to a 43 billion won pledge to Park's friend's business. Lee, 48, did not comment on the charges, and prosecutors seek an arrest warrant for the second time in a month. A court decision is expected Thursday or Friday.

site_title: Aussie unemployment rate falls despite full-time jobs plunge
summary: Australia's unemployment rate unexpectedly fell to 5.7% in January, despite a decline in full-time jobs, with a rise in part-time employment. Employment increased 13,500, but full-time jobs plummeted by 44,800. The Reserve Bank of Australia had predicted a 5.8% unemployment rate. Economists attribute the fall to discouraged job-seekers giving up the hunt, highlighting spare capacity in the labor market.

site_title: Stocks to watch: DBS, ST Engineering, LMIRT
summary: Singaporean banks DBS, OCBC, and ST Engineering reported mixed earnings results, with DBS and OCBC citing provisions for bad loans and lower net interest income. ST Engineering posted a 21% jump in net profit due to stronger contributions from aerospace and land systems segments. Meanwhile, Lippo Malls Indonesia Retail Trust saw an increase in distribution per unit and net property income. Healthway Medical Corporation issued a profit warning, and Singapore Medical Group halted trading pending an announcement.

site_title: Hanjin saga reveals South Korea corporate governance flaws
summary: Hanjin Shipping, South Korea's once-top sea transport company, will declare bankruptcy, with billions of dollars in debt. The company's demise highlights South Korea's corporate governance flaws, particularly in family-run "chaebol" firms. The owner's widow, Choi Eun Young, took the helm in 2007 despite lacking experience, leading to a flawed succession process. The case underscores the dangers of prioritizing family ties over competence and the need for better corporate governance practices.

images.alt_text: Hanjin Shipping will declare bankruptcy on Friday, with the former titan of the global shipping industry and one of South Korea's powerful family-run "chaebol" finally sinking under billions of dollars of debt.

site_title: Credit Suisse said to boost Asia banker pay by up to 15%
summary: Credit Suisse boosted pay for senior Asia-Pacific investment bankers by up to 15% in 2016, with managing directors receiving between $1 million to $1.5 million in total compensation, including bonuses. The bank's Asia-Pacific underwriting and advisory business saw a 38% increase in net revenue, driven by a surge in merger, equity- and debt-capital market transactions. The move may help insulate the business from planned job cuts by CEO Tidjane Thiam, who aims to lower costs by 8% this year.

site_title: DBS Group posts 9% drop in Q4 profit to S$913m
summary: DBS Group reported a 9% drop in Q4 net profit to S$913 million, despite improved operating performance. Total allowances doubled to S$462 million, offsetting the gain. Net interest income fell 2% and non-interest income rose 19%. For the full year, net profit was 2% below the previous year due to higher allowances. Strong operating performance provided headroom for higher specific allowances, driven by a rise in non-performing loan rates.

site_title: ADHD a 'brain disorder', not just bad behaviour: study
summary: A study published in The Lancet Psychiatry found that people with ADHD have slightly smaller brains than those without the condition, with structural differences and delayed brain development compared to non-sufferers. The study, involving 1,713 people with ADHD and 1,529 without, confirmed that ADHD is a brain disorder, not just bad behavior. The differences in brain volume were small, but the study's large sample size helped identify these differences, which were also seen in other psychiatric disorders.

site_title: Jokowi pick loses momentum as Jakarta vote goes to second round
summary: Jakarta's governor election is headed to a second round after an unofficial "quick count" showed incumbent Basuki Tjahaja Purnama leading with 43% of the vote, followed closely by Anies Baswedan with 40%. The election was marked by a blasphemy case against Ahok, a Christian governor, and will likely focus on religion in the run-off campaign. The outcome could impact President Joko Widodo's administration, with Baswedan potentially gaining support and Prabowo Subianto's bid for presidency in 2019.

site_title: PBOC official says yuan faces "no big adjustment": China Securities Journal
summary: China's yuan faces no major adjustments due to sustained current account surplus, according to Zhu Jun, director of the international division of the People's Bank of China. The country's international payment imbalances are not "serious," and no significant foreign exchange controls are needed. Despite a 6.6% slide in the yuan last year, China's currency policy has seen the yuan rise 1.1% against the US dollar this year. The comments aim to soothe market concerns over further yuan devaluation amid US interest rate increases and capital outflows.

site_title: Smoke and mirrors: Beijing battles to control smog message
summary: China battles to control smog message amid concerns over unauthorised data from mobile apps and handheld detectors. Despite improvements in data collection and transparency, Beijing worries that too much bad news could stoke public unrest. The government's approach reflects a broader debate about China's appetite for political reform, with the Ministry of Environmental Protection pushing for a modern regulatory system based on independent monitoring and the rule of law. This could potentially clash with the ruling Communist Party's priority for stability.

site_title: Yahoo notifies users of sophisticated breach methods
summary: Yahoo notified users of a sophisticated breach method where hackers forged "cookies" to authenticate users, affecting an estimated one billion users. The breach, disclosed late last year, involved forging of cookies to gain access to accounts without stealing passwords. The investigation into the attacks is nearing its final stage, with messages sent to a "reasonably final list" of affected users.

site_title: China bears in Hong Kong abandon ETF shorts on improving economy
summary: China's economy has defied naysayers, with equity markets rallying and short interest on Hong Kong-listed ETFs declining to a one-year low. The FTSE China A shares ETF, tracked by China Asset Management Co, saw short interest drop to 3.5% and 3.99% respectively. Fears of a hard landing have subsided as authorities stem capital outflows and shore up markets with cash injections. The MSCI China Index has rallied nearly 30% from last year, and some analysts believe the A-share market may experience a rebound due to high liquidity in mainland China.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Thursday
summary: Singapore shares opened 2.6 points lower at 3,085.88 on Thursday, following weak retail sales data. Despite a seven-session winning streak on Wall Street, driven by robust economic data and corporate tax optimism, the Singapore market was affected. Gainers outpaced losers 76 to 60, with 137.3 million shares changing hands for S$99.4 million.

site_title: Trump drops US commitment to 'two-state' Mideast deal
summary: US President Donald Trump has halted the US commitment to a two-state solution for the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, instead supporting a single state if it leads to peace. Trump welcomed Israel's Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu to the White House and expressed willingness to accept either a two-state or one-state solution. Netanyahu urged Trump to support a single state with Israel retaining security control over the West Bank. The decision has sparked international dismay, with Palestinians and international leaders condemning the change in US stance, which contradicts the international consensus on a two-state solution.

site_title: Lisbon to get second airport, as tourism soars
summary: Portugal has unveiled plans to build a second international airport in Lisbon to cope with record tourism numbers. The new airport, to be built at the Montijo military air base, is expected to be operational by 2021. The move comes as Lisbon's main airport, Humberto Delgado, reached a record 22.4 million passengers last year, an 11.7% increase from 2015. The new airport aims to alleviate pressure on Humberto Delgado, which welcomed a record number of visitors.

site_title: Trump's contested pick for labour secretary withdraws
summary: US President Donald Trump's pick for labour secretary, Andrew Puzder, withdrew from consideration on Wednesday after facing intense scrutiny over his business record and personal past. Puzder, a 66-year-old fast-food executive, had been the first of Trump's cabinet nominees to withdraw. He cited "careful consideration and discussions with my family" and expressed support for the president. Puzder's withdrawal comes after a contentious confirmation hearing and amid criticism of his labour practices and tax record. The move is seen as a blow to Trump's administration, following the resignation of national security chief Michael Flynn.

images.alt_text: US President Donald Trump's pick for labour secretary Andrew Puzder withdrew from consideration Wednesday, after facing intense scrutiny for his business record and controversies about his personal past.

site_title: ST Engineering posts 21% jump in Q4 profit
summary: ST Engineering reported a 21% increase in Q4 net profit to S$170.4 million, driven by stronger contributions from aerospace, land systems, and "others" business segments. However, the full-year net profit dropped 8.4% to S$484.5 million due to weaker land systems, marine, and "others" segments. Revenue grew 5.5% to S$6.68 billion. The company expects FY2017 revenue to be comparable, but profit before tax to be higher than FY2016. A final dividend of 10 cents per share is proposed.

site_title: Temasek cuts Alibaba stake, buys Antero Resources shares
summary: Temasek Holdings sold 4.1 million American depository receipts in Alibaba Group Holding Ltd, reducing its stake to 35.5 million, making Alibaba its second largest US stock holding at 25%. Meanwhile, Temasek acquired 4.2 million shares of Antero Resources Corp, emerging as a shareholder of the oil and gas producer.

site_title: Lou Gehrig's fixer-upper awaits a buyer
summary: Lou Gehrig's former home, a 3-bedroom structure in New Rochelle, New York, is awaiting a buyer. The house, where Gehrig lived with his parents from 1927 to 1933, features original fixtures and furnishings, including brass fixtures, galvanized steel wiring, and parquet floors. A local preservationist, Arthur Scinta, hopes to restore the property to its original style and potentially turn it into a Lou Gehrig museum. The house was foreclosed upon in 1937, while Gehrig's parents still owned it, due to missed mortgage payments. The current owner plans to sell the property for $449,000.

site_title: Australians well able to service mortgage debt overall: RBA
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia's Assistant Governor Luci Ellis stated that most Australians are capable of servicing their mortgage debt, despite the country holding a relatively large amount of debt compared to other developed nations. Higher-income households tend to own their homes and have other properties, making them more able to service debt. However, lower-income households often have a high debt-to-income ratio, indicating potential stress. This finding suggests that while overall debt levels are a concern, pockets of vulnerability exist.

site_title: US: Wall Street rises further into uncharted territory
summary: Wall Street continued its upward trend, with the S&P 500 reaching an all-time high and recording its fifth consecutive record close. The index rose 0.50% to 2,349.25, driven by robust economic data and optimism about President Donald Trump's tax plan. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and Nasdaq Composite also reached new highs. Despite concerns about the lack of details in Trump's tax plan, investors remained confident, and the Federal Reserve signaled a possible interest rate hike, boosting financial stocks.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open flat despite rise on Wall Street
summary: Tokyo stocks opened flat on February 16, 2017, despite a rise on Wall Street, as investors remained optimistic about US economic prospects. The Nikkei 225 index slipped 0.12% to 19,415.41, while the Topix index edged up 0.07 point at 1,553.76. The yen strengthened against the US dollar.

site_title: US dollar retreats from one-month peak tied to upbeat US data
summary: The US dollar retreated from a one-month high after US data showed robust growth in retail sales and consumer prices in January, with investors taking profits. Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen offered no additional insight on the timing of the central bank's next rate hike, contradicting earlier hints of more rate increases. The US dollar index was flat at 101.21, while the euro rebounded against the greenback. Investors have priced in only a 27% chance of a rate increase at the Fed's March meeting, according to the CME Group's FedWatch program.

site_title: Strike to disrupt Berlin airports
summary: A strike by the Verdi union at Berlin's two airports is set to disrupt air travel on Thursday, causing flight delays and cancellations. The strike, lasting from 3 pm to 10 pm GMT, affects Lufthansa and Air Berlin, with up to 30 flights potentially cancelled. The union is seeking a 1 euro per hour pay increase, following a similar strike last week that forced airlines to cancel up to 100 flights. Passengers are advised to expect long delays and cancellations.

images.alt_text: Passengers should expect flight delays and cancellations at Berlin's two airports Thursday due to a ground crew strike strike over pay, union officials announced.

site_title: Trump dodges questions as Russia scandal deepens
summary: US President Donald Trump dodged questions about Russia ties, firing national security advisor Michael Flynn amid revelations of repeated contact between Trump aides and Russian intelligence officials. Trump accused intelligence leaks and pointed fingers at the NSA and FBI, while calling for tougher media scrutiny. The White House defended Flynn's firing, citing a "trust issue," but Democrats and Republicans have called for an investigation into Trump's campaign and administration dealings with Russia. The controversy has shaken the administration, with another high-profile withdrawal, Andrew Puzder's pick for labor secretary, and the ongoing investigation into Russian meddling in the 2016 US election.

site_title: Fed's Tarullo says progress on too-big-to-fail will be 'durable'
summary: Federal Reserve Governor Daniel Tarullo expressed confidence that progress made in addressing the "too-big-to-fail" issue will be durable despite potential changes under the Trump administration. Despite regulatory strides, vulnerabilities remain, and regulators need to adapt to new risks created by changing bank business models. Tarullo, who steps down in April, praised the Dodd-Frank Act overhaul but warned that anti-regulation rhetoric could undermine efforts. Annual stress tests remain a key development in bank supervision, but some rules have been too tough on smaller banks.

site_title: Europe: Bank shares climb to three-week high in earnings-driven trade
summary: European shares rose 0.3% on Wednesday, driven by earnings from banks, particularly Credit Agricole, which jumped 4.7% after beating forecasts. Banking stocks, led by Credit Agricole, reached a three-week high. US Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen's hawkish rhetoric also supported the rally. However, analysts remain cautious, citing ongoing concerns about sustained improvement in European banks and the impact of interest rates. Other sectors, such as Finnish packaging maker Huhtamaki and brewer Heineken, also saw gains, while Temenos and Akzo Nobel fell after reporting results.

site_title: Fed's Yellen spars with lawmakers on regulation, economy
summary: Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen defended the Fed's role in the US economic recovery, citing solid job creation and growing incomes. She also addressed concerns over bank regulations and international participation, stating that the Fed participates in regulatory bodies to promote financial stability and US competitiveness. However, Yellen acknowledged that the Fed does not have the tools to address all economic issues, and called on Congress to implement policies that would boost productivity and growth.

site_title: Oil prices hold ground after US stockpiles soar to record
summary: US oil prices held steady despite record high US crude and gasoline inventories, which fueled concerns about a global glut. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC) and other producers have been complying with agreed-upon supply cuts, supporting prices. US crude stocks rose 9.5 million barrels, while gasoline inventories reached a record 259.1 million barrels. Despite bearish data, US gasoline futures ended slightly higher, and prices recouped some losses. OPEC's compliance rate remains high, but concerns about demand and market rebalancing persist.

site_title: American Air's pilots vote no-confidence in CEO, executives
summary: American Airlines pilots have voted no-confidence in CEO Doug Parker, citing pay and scheduling problems, delays in implementing their contract, and a "toxic" company culture. The vote, which is largely symbolic but reflects growing disaffection, comes after the airline's refusal to consider a pay raise following Delta's compensation increases. The no-confidence vote follows a series of grievances, including incorrect pilot paychecks and a lack of response to employee concerns.

site_title: S'pore must speak up for free trade, deepen and widen global links
summary: Singapore must prioritize free trade, talent, and ideas to stay open to international connections and promote economic growth. The Committee on the Future Economy's report highlights the importance of resisting protectionism and connecting with overseas partners, particularly in Asia. Despite the US's withdrawal from the Trans-Pacific Partnership, Singapore can leverage its global reputation and economic influence to push for free trade. The country should focus on bilateral free-trade agreements, regional trade initiatives, and strengthening its ties with China and other fast-growing economies to counter protectionism and promote openness in trade and investments.

site_title: Deals and exits needed to draw VC and PE funds
summary: Singapore aims to attract venture capitalists (VCs) and private equity (PE) funds by simplifying rules and incentives, but a steady stream of attractive deals and lucrative exits is crucial. VCs want less compliance, more funding sources, and attractive exits, while PE funds seek greater clarity on tax and a vibrant local equity market. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has introduced initiatives to strengthen financing channels and build technological infrastructure. However, exits remain a challenge, and local players want to improve the environment for VCs, including cutting compliance and encouraging government institutions to invest in VC funds.

site_title: Trump's trade threats an ominous omen for global business
summary: US President Donald Trump's trade threats have left global business markets remarkably unfazed, but a closer look reveals damage to foreign direct investment (FDI) in emerging markets, with a decline from $526 billion in 2015 to $410 billion in 2016. The Institute of International Finance (IIF) terms this a "disturbing" trend, citing US policy initiatives such as import taxes and discouraging offshoring. This could lead to further pressure on FDI flows and pose a challenge to the World Trade Organization (WTO).

site_title: China warns US against fresh naval patrols in South China Sea
summary: China's Foreign Ministry warned the US against planning fresh naval patrols in the disputed South China Sea, urging respect for China's sovereignty and security. The warning comes after reports of US Navy and Pacific Command leaders considering freedom of navigation patrols by the Carl Vinson carrier strike group. The US last conducted a similar operation in October, and China claims almost all of the South China Sea, through which $5 trillion worth of trade passes annually. China's tension in the area is currently stabilised, according to the ministry.

site_title: Fed harps on growing risk in US commercial real estate
summary: The Federal Reserve has expressed growing concerns over the US commercial real estate market, citing rising property prices and decreasing capitalization rates as a "growing concern" for financial stability. Despite modest commercial property debt and tightened lending standards, the Fed warns that smaller banks may be vulnerable to a significant decline in CRE prices, which have more than doubled from their post-crisis low.

site_title: Finance companies' shares soar on new relaxed rules
summary: Singapore's three finance companies, Hong Leong Finance, Sing Investments & Finance, and Singapura Finance, saw their shares surge 32% over two days following the Monetary Authority of Singapore's relaxation of rules to spur innovation and increase loans to small and medium enterprises. The regulator allowed foreign takeovers on condition that the new partner introduces new business models to boost lending to SMEs. The companies' prices rose 18-32% as investors reacted to the news, with potential for re-rating and growth.

site_title: Shareholders raise storm over valuation of Sabana acquisition
summary: Shareholders of Sabana Reit, a Singapore-listed Real Estate Investment Trust (REIT), have raised concerns over the valuation of a property acquisition, citing objectivity issues with the valuation firms involved. Unitholders, including Jerry Low and associate professor Koh Yee Kan, have lodged a complaint with Singapore's white-collar crime buster against Colliers, Savills, and Knight Frank, alleging that the valuations were too coincidental. The dispute has led to a split among unitholders, with some calling for the removal of the Reit manager, while others aim to replace only the CEO, Kevin Xayaraj.

site_title: Berkshire takes huge bite of Apple, boosts airline stakes
summary: Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway Inc significantly increased its stakes in Apple Inc and US airlines during the fourth quarter of last year. Berkshire nearly quadrupled its Apple stake, now worth $7.74 billion, and increased its airline stake sevenfold. The company also disclosed new stakes in satellite radio company Sirius XM and seed company Monsanto.

images.alt_text: Berkshire's initial investment in Apple got attention last year, given Mr Buffett's usual aversion to technology companies - apart from IBM - which he considers outside his zone of competence.

site_title: Washington reels amid the turmoil of Trump's first month
summary: President Donald Trump's first month in office has been marred by turmoil, scandal, and personnel drama, with National Security Adviser Michael Flynn's resignation being the latest in a series of high-profile exits. The administration has faced criticism for its handling of issues such as travel bans, executive orders, and interactions with world leaders, with many questioning Trump's temperament and ability to lead. Despite this, Trump's allies argue that the president has made progress in areas such as Supreme Court nominations and executive orders, and that the chaos is a necessary part of his efforts to fundamentally reorient the government.

site_title: World leaders wait to see who speaks for Trump
summary: World leaders are awaiting clarity on who will represent US President Donald Trump at international meetings. Secretary of State Rex Tillerson, Defense Secretary James Mattis, and Vice-President Mike Pence are set to attend the G-20 meeting and Munich Security Conference, potentially contradicting Trump's statements. National Security Adviser Michael Flynn's resignation due to Russia contacts controversy has added to the uncertainty. As Trump's foreign policy team navigates its first major international trips, the world waits to see who will speak for the President on foreign affairs.

site_title: Lone Ranger without even a Tonto
summary: US President Donald Trump's management style is being described as "obsessive micromanagement" due to his mistrust of the bureaucracy. This has led to chaotic and disorganized decision-making, including the creation of the Muslim travel ban without input from other government agencies. Experts warn that this style undermines authority and loyalty among Cabinet members, who are being kept out of the loop on major decisions. Trump's behavior is compared to that of past presidents, including Jimmy Carter and Richard Nixon, who were also known for their micromanaging and paranoia.

site_title: Cautious rebound ahead of bank results
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rebounded 16.01 points to 3,088.48 on Wednesday, driven by a positive reaction to Federal Reserve chair Janet Yellen's comments on the need to raise interest rates soon. US banks pushed Wall Street to a new high overnight, with Dow futures rising 29 points. Local bank counters, however, performed quietly. Analysts expect banks to benefit from higher interest rates, with Macquarie Equities Research maintaining an "outperform" rating on OCBC.

site_title: Connectivity a catalyst for growth
summary: Singapore must continue to develop its connectivity, including physical, trade, financial, information, and people flows, to remain competitive and attract global talent. The city-state's economy is witnessing the rise of protectionism and trade barriers in the US and Europe, but there are opportunities for companies and individuals to capitalize on growth in emerging markets. To succeed, companies must adopt three key business imperatives: "Go to the ground," "Be nimble," and "Partner." This includes developing specialist market research capabilities, implementing nimble development processes, and fostering trust and reciprocity among partners and stakeholders.

site_title: Strategy and execution finesse have to work hand in hand to achieve our desired outcomes
summary: Singtel CEO shares experience on adapting to a digital economy. As CEO of Group Enterprise at Singtel, the company has been grappling with challenges of staying relevant in a rapidly changing world. Despite facing competition and disruptions since the 1990s, Singtel has grown its Singapore market and expanded into higher-growth developing markets. The company has re-engineered its infrastructure, invested in digital marketing, data analytics, and cyber security, and is now a key player in global connectivity and digital space. With over 640 million mobile subscribers, Singtel has navigated technological disruptions to maintain its economic foothold.

site_title: LMIRT's Q4 DPU 7.4% higher; net property income up 10.9%
summary: LIPPO Malls Indonesia Retail Trust (LMIRT) reported a 7.4% increase in distribution per unit for Q4 2016, with net property income rising 10.9% to S$44.6 million and gross rental income up 8.9% to S$39.9 million. The trust's gross rental revenue increased by S$3.6 million year-on-year due to positive rental reversion. For the full year, LMIRT's net property income rose 8.4% to S$171.9 million and gross rental income grew 7.2% to S$152.9 million.

site_title: Five keywords for the future economy
summary: The Committee on the Future Economy (CFE) has released a report outlining seven core objectives for Singapore's future economy, focusing on deepening international connections, building new skills, and fostering innovation. Key areas include enhancing ties with Asia, acquiring diverse skills, and creating digital infrastructure. The report also emphasizes the need for supportive social policies to address the impact of automation and digitalization on employment. Additionally, partnerships among companies, universities, and trade associations are crucial for success in the future economy.

site_title: Manufacturers jostle for slice of China's 'premiumisation' pie
summary: China's affluent consumers are driving demand for premium goods, with 11 million households crossing the income threshold each year. As incomes rise, consumers are spending more on healthier, higher-quality products, such as yogurt and baijiu, and are willing to pay up to 40% more for SUVs. The trend is also evident in the demand for premium brands in clothing, entertainment, travel, and dining out, with 56% of consumers showing off their success through luxury purchases. This shift is prompting companies to invest in premium products and acquisitions, and is expected to continue as China's economic slowdown impedes household spending.

site_title: Swiss ski resort's bet on summer tourists, hikers and non-skiers pays off
summary: Swiss ski resort Titlisbahnen's summer tourism strategy has paid off, with the company generating more revenue in July than in December. Despite three snowless Christmases, the resort has seen a surge in summer tourists, hikers, and non-skiers, contributing to a 28% average annual return since 2009. Investing in snow-making technology and embracing four-season tourism has helped compensate for unreliable early-season snow. The company's stock has tripled, with a value of about 23 million Swiss francs, outperforming US peer Vail Resorts and European rival Compagnie des Alpes.

site_title: Heineken banking on Tiger beer sales in Asia to spur 2017 earnings growth
summary: Heineken, the world's second-largest brewer, forecasts 2017 earnings growth driven by a 13% increase in Asian revenue, particularly in Vietnam. The company's adjusted operating profit rose 9.9% to 3.54 billion euros. Growth in Asia offsets slowing shipments in Europe and Africa. Heineken expects margin expansion, excluding major unforeseen developments, to meet its target of 40 basis points. The company's stock rose 4.6% following the earnings report.

site_title: Government to take facilitator role
summary: The Singapore government is urged to take a facilitator role in nurturing a more flexible and nimble economy by plugging gaps in the business ecosystem and adopting forward-looking regulations. The Committee on the Future Economy (CFE) recommends that the government issue public-sector challenges, set aside resources for innovation procurement, and expand accreditation schemes for promising startups and SMEs. This approach aims to support the development of promising industries, especially where they align with the country's strategic needs, and encourage innovation and risk-taking.

site_title: A 'Global Innovation Alliance' to spark new ideas
summary: Singapore aims to boost innovation through a 'Global Innovation Alliance', linking educational institutions with businesses and overseas hubs. The Committee on the Future Economy (CFE) envisions the alliance, which will foster connections to global innovation networks and tap into new ideas. The initiative is expected to expand existing efforts to boost regional ties and engage more universities and polytechnics. By connecting with global partners, Singapore hopes to spark new innovation activity and build a more alert mindset to seize opportunities worldwide.

site_title: Faster, cheaper access to Singapore market soon for VC funds
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has proposed relaxing rules for venture capital (VC) managers, allowing for a simplified authorisation process and reduced capital requirements. The changes, expected to take effect by July this year, will enable VC managers to obtain approval in a matter of weeks and without capital requirements. The move aims to attract more VC managers and support entrepreneurship and innovation in Singapore, potentially leading to a more nurturing environment for local start-ups.

site_title: What will you, your business, and Singapore be great at?
summary: The Committee on the Future Economy report highlights Singapore's need for change and growth over the next 50 years. The seven key strategies include understanding core capabilities, analyzing opportunities, identifying gaps, and creating a plan for execution. Singapore's strong base and history of resilience are assets, but the report notes that this new cycle of change will be harder due to global and local competition. To succeed, Singapore must convince its citizens of the need for change and ensure everyone benefits. As individuals, businesses, and professionals, it's essential to challenge oneself to drive change and stay relevant in a rapidly changing world.

site_title: CapitaLand's Q4 profit surges on strong operating income
summary: CapitaLand, a Singaporean property developer, reported a 73.8% surge in Q4 net profit to S$430.5 million, driven by residential unit sales in China and fair value gains on investment properties. The company's full-year net profit increased 11.7% to S$1.19 billion, with a record 12,789 homes sold last year. CapitaLand expects a busy year in 2017, with the opening of new retail space and serviced apartment units. Analysts predict continued growth in residential sales in China, with the company poised to expand its presence in the market.

site_title: Malaysia police arrest woman over North Korean killing
summary: Malaysian police arrested 28-year-old Doan Thi Huong, a Vietnamese woman, on Wednesday over the killing of Kim Jong-nam, half-brother of North Korea's leader, at Kuala Lumpur International Airport. The assassination, believed to be orchestrated by Pyongyang's agents, has echoes of Soviet-era spycraft. Doan was positively identified from CCTV footage and was alone at the time of arrest. The case has raised concerns of a Cold War-style assassination, with analysts suggesting it may have been ordered due to Kim Jong-nam's reported plans to defect.

site_title: Case Study: A breath of fresh air for Orchard Road
summary: Orchard Road, a congested and dated shopping street in Singapore, is in need of a refresh. Experts suggest transforming it into a high-tech, socially inclusive space that celebrates homegrown design. Proposed changes include installing more bridges, underground links between malls, and pedestrian-only zones. Additionally, there are ideas for sidewalk bazaars with solar-powered pop-up stalls, streetside food joints, and monthly closures to the road. These changes aim to revitalize the street and provide a more welcoming and modern experience for shoppers.

site_title: CapBridge unveils world's first rules-based trust
summary: Singapore venture capitalist Steven Fang has launched the world's first rules-based trust, CapBridge Investment Trust (CIT), a US$100 million pre-IPO fund that invests in private securities. CIT aims to automate the selection criteria, reducing the fund's expense load. The trust will develop sub-trust funds, including a US$40 million seed-stage fund in Los Angeles, backed by prominent Singapore conglomerates and entrepreneurs. CIT is expected to expedite pre-IPO capital raising and give investors access to venture-backed securities, traditionally a limited asset class.

site_title: From the factory to the lab, manufacturing will need to change gears
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector needs a significant transformation to reach its goal of 20% of GDP, according to economists and industry players. The sector must shift from mass production to technology-driven innovation, focusing on intellectual property and research and development. This change will require workers to move from factory floors to R&D labs and may lead to a decrease in the sector's share of employment. To achieve this, the government may need to provide incentives for adopting cutting-edge technology and developing homegrown companies.

site_title: Apple tiptoes into producing original video
summary: Apple is expanding into original video content with two television-style series, Carpool Karaoke and Planet of the Apps, set to debut on Apple Music in the spring. The company aims to build Apple Music into a cultural platform, with plans for more scripted dramas and interactive content in the next year. Apple Music has attracted over 20 million subscribers, and the company plans to use original video to differentiate itself from competitors like Netflix and Spotify. The move marks a significant shift for Apple, which has historically focused on music.

site_title: Greece's economy contracts ahead of yet another bailout
summary: Greece's economy contracted by 0.4% in the fourth quarter of 2016, reducing annual growth to 0.3%, ahead of a looming bailout deal. The country's creditors, the EU and IMF, are seeking debt repayment of over 6 billion euros, despite Greece's total gross domestic product remaining largely unchanged since 2008. Unemployment is 23%, with youth unemployment at 46%, and the IMF has called for austerity measures to achieve a budget surplus of 1.8%. Greece's creditors are expected to roll over debt, allowing the country to remain in the eurozone.

site_title: Suu Kyi pushes for investment in Myanmar as Rohingya crisis deepens
summary: Myanmar's Aung San Suu Kyi government is pushing for foreign investment as the Rohingya refugee crisis deepens. Two laws set to take effect by June will make it easier for foreign companies to invest, aiming to revamp the country's image among investors. The move comes after a surge in global interest following Myanmar's transition to democracy. Suu Kyi's efforts are part of a broader strategy to attract investment and boost the country's growth rate, which is one of South-east Asia's highest. The laws are expected to increase foreign investment in the country.

images.alt_text: Buddhist monks and other people protesting while a Malaysian NGO's aid ship carrying food and emergency supplies for Rohingya Muslims arrives at the port in Yangon, Myanmar on Feb 9. The United Nations' refugee agency said that more than 60,000 Rohingya are believed to have sought safety in Bangladesh since October 2016.

site_title: Staying relevant to the world
summary: Singapore's Economic Review Committee (ERC) has released a comprehensive report, the Committee for the Future Economy (CFE), to guide the country's economic development in the medium term. The report highlights the need for Singapore to stay open and connected to the world, build deep and relevant capabilities, and work together in new ways. Key strategies include building a Global Innovation Alliance, strengthening industry-education links, and fostering a culture of collaboration among government, private sector, and unions. The report aims to position Singapore for success in a rapidly changing global environment, with a focus on creating opportunities for its people and companies.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: TT International reported a net loss of S$9.63 million in the third quarter, down from S$6.71 million a year ago, due to non-cash expenses. Revenue declined 18.3% to S$88.5 million. Hyflux signed an agreement with Changi General Hospital for clinical trials of its ELO Water product. EuroSports Global entered into a non-binding MOU to acquire SS Ventures, a Hong Kong-based company. The companies are exploring funding options to support their restructuring efforts.

site_title: Case study: Going back to school has never gone out of fashion for her
summary: Singaporean nurse Pauline Tan, 56, heads the 428-bed Yishun Community Hospital, becoming the first nurse in Singapore to attain CEO status. Tan, who has 39 years of nursing experience, has pursued multiple degrees, including a Bachelor of Nursing, Graduate Diploma in Nursing Administration, Master of Science in Asia-Pacific Human Resource Management, and Master of Public Administration. She has also received an honorary Doctor of Nursing from La Trobe University for her contributions to nursing. Tan's career highlights her dedication to empowering nurses and improving patient care, and she aims to change the public's perception of nurses as merely caregivers.

site_title: Connectivity, capabilities and collaboration in the future economy
summary: Singapore aims to maintain its openness to trade, investments, and talent in a rapidly changing global economy. The country will focus on harnessing the benefits of economic and digital connectivity, including building on trade and investment agreements and promoting internationalisation to create jobs and opportunities for its people. To achieve this, Singapore will nurture a vibrant enterprise ecosystem through capability development, collaboration with multinational corporations, and the development of a strong cohort of local enterprises. The government will also work with key stakeholders to implement strategies and achieve desired outcomes, requiring a shift in mindset and resilience in the face of adversity.

site_title: Data science and cybersecurity could boost Singapore's appeal
summary: Singapore can boost its appeal as a safe and attractive place for businesses to operate by developing capabilities in data science and cybersecurity. The Committee on the Future Economy's proposal to build advanced data analytics and cybersecurity capabilities will strengthen the country's economic infrastructure. Experts say embracing a mindset of curiosity and acceptance of failure, and being collaborative and open, is crucial for successfully building strong expertise in these areas. The government's efforts to develop talent, build a vibrant ecosystem, and prepare for AI-driven advancements will be key to cementing Singapore's position in the digital economy.

site_title: Tough year ahead for Singapore telcos
summary: Singapore's telecoms industry is set for an interesting period with the upcoming spectrum auction and potential entry of a fourth telco, TPG Telecom. The existing three incumbents, Singtel, StarHub, and M1, are facing declining revenue from traditional businesses due to changing user habits. TPG, which has 60 MHz of spectrum, is expected to bid for more spectrum, potentially leading to a price war. M1 and StarHub are under pressure, with M1's net profit falling 16.1% and StarHub's revenue dropping 1.9%. Singtel is in the best position, with a diversified business and deep pockets, and may benefit from the impending IPO.

site_title: Gearing up for success in the digital world
summary: The financial services sector is undergoing significant disruption due to the rise of fintech and digital technologies. Established players must adapt to changing consumer expectations and invest in innovation, digital capabilities, and agile business models. To succeed, financial institutions need to enable an ecosystem of collaboration among companies, banks, fintech startups, and governments, develop effective cyber security programs, and foster talent with new skills such as data analysis and human-centered design. Those that fail to adapt will be left behind, and the industry will transform with new technologies, leading to improved products and services for consumers and new job opportunities.

site_title: Challenger's Q4 profit tumbles on weak retail sales, impairment charge
summary: Challenger Technologies reported a 46% decline in net profit to S$4.2 million for Q4 2016, due to weak retail sales and an impairment provision of S$1.1 million. Revenue fell 13% to S$83.4 million, mainly attributed to lower IT product sales. For the full year, revenue dropped 4% to S$339.4 million. Despite this, the company expects to improve its bottom line in FY2017 through omni-channel sales and store closures, and proposed a dividend of 2.7 Singapore cents per share.

site_title: GM weighs selling Opel to France's PSA
summary: General Motors (GM) is considering selling its European unit, Opel, to PSA Group in France, potentially creating Europe's second-largest carmaker. The deal would free GM from persistent losses in Europe and help improve overall profit margins. Opel's financial situation has improved under new leadership, but its future is clouded by Brexit and a surplus of production capacity. The deal faces challenges, including opposition from Opel's labour representatives and the need to address the company's lack of competitiveness in the European market. A sale could also help GM invest in more lucrative regions, such as China and North America.

site_title: Developers in Singapore off to good start in housing sales
summary: Singapore developers started 2017 on a positive note, with 381 private homes sold in January, a 17.6% year-over-year increase. This contrasts with a 13.8% drop in January 2016. Several new projects are set to launch, including The Clement Canopy and Grandeur Park Residences, with developers expecting strong demand and sales bookings to reach around 500 private homes in February and 1,000 in March. Analysts predict a more active first quarter, with total private home sales estimated at 8,000 to 9,000 units for 2017.

site_title: Canada home resales down in January, prices still climbing
summary: Canada's home resales fell 1.3% in January, with prices rising 15% from last year, driven by 10 of 13 housing markets. Despite a decline in sales in Toronto, Vancouver, and Montreal, home prices continue to climb, driven by low inventory and supply shortages in these markets. Experts warn that sales activity must drop dramatically for prices to stabilize, and the outlook for home prices remains strong in areas with supply shortages.

site_title: Enabling the right mix of elements
summary: Singapore's Committee on the Future Economy (CFE) aims to create a vibrant and sustainable city by aligning public and private interests. To achieve this, the government plans to offer extra gross floor area to property owners for building public spaces and connectivity infrastructure. Analysts suggest introducing lower development charge rates for underground developments, which can improve the financial feasibility of adding new underground spaces. The CFE also recommends creating an urban logistics system to reduce congestion and utilize land more efficiently. However, stakeholders must buy into the idea, and the government needs to play a key role in implementing these plans.

site_title: All eyes on the race for the post of Jakarta governor
summary: Jakarta's gubernatorial election has become a referendum on the role of religion in politics, with Christian candidate Basuki Purnama, known as Ahok, facing trial for allegedly insulting the Quran. Despite his success as governor, Ahok is fighting for survival, and his nearest rival, Anies Baswedan, has gained support from Islamic conservatives. The election marks a milestone for the city's ethnic Chinese community, which was affected by the 1998 race riots. With millions of Indonesians casting their votes, the outcome is uncertain, and Ahok's victory is by no means assured, potentially paving the way for his ouster if convicted of the crime.

images.alt_text: A woman takes the chance to snap a selfie with Jakarta's Christian governor Basuki Tjahaja Purnama, better known as Ahok, as he arrives to cast his vote in Jakarta on Wednesday.

site_title: Case study: P&G - A company of leaders
summary: Procter & Gamble (P&G) has established a strong learning and development culture, investing in leadership training programs that foster a "built from within" approach. The company's Asia-Pacific headquarters in Singapore plays a key role in developing regional leaders, with over 80 trainers delivering corporate training programs annually. P&G's Leadership Academy provides customized training modules, and the company has also partnered with local universities and organizations to nurture talent from a young age, including through its annual Dream P&G Internship program. This approach has contributed to P&G's success as a top employer, with the company ranking as the top spot on Fortune magazine's list of Global Top Companies for Leaders in 2011.

site_title: Asia eyeing bilateral trade pacts with US after Trump ditches TPP
summary: The US has abandoned the 12-nation Pacific trade pact, the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP), after President Donald Trump's "America First" policy on jobs. Several countries, including Japan and New Zealand, are interested in negotiating bilateral trade agreements with the US, but experts warn that these deals may be difficult to achieve due to Trump's attacks on trade and his demands for major concessions. The US has Free Trade Agreements (FTAs) in the region, but multilateral agreements offer more benefits, such as access to multiple markets. The US's trade negotiators will need to convince partners that the reward of a deal with the US is worth the time and concessions required.

site_title: Melania Trump reopens White House for tours
summary: Melania Trump announced the White House will reopen to the public on March 7, nearly seven weeks after her husband Donald Trump's inauguration. The decision comes after lawmakers complained about the long delay in restarting tours. First Lady Melania Trump expressed her dedication to the White House's restoration and preservation, despite planning to continue living at the Trump Tower in New York. The reopening is seen as a positive step for the public, who were unhappy about the lack of access to the historic site.

site_title: Boosting Singapore's links is critical for its continuing relevance
summary: Singapore's growth and relevance are threatened by its small size and limited natural resources, prompting the Committee on the Future Economy (CFE) to develop a strategy to make the city a vibrant and connected hub of opportunity. This involves enhancing physical connectivity through infrastructure development, fostering social connectivity by creating a great place to live and work, and promoting intellectual and digital connectivity to spur innovation and growth. By embracing various forms of connectivity, Singapore can improve its agility to change and remain competitive in the global economy.

site_title: US teenage students showing a level of civic engagement not seen in years
summary: US teenage students are showing increased civic engagement, with discussions on topics like the North American Free Trade Agreement (Nafta) and social issues replacing celebrity gossip. This trend is observed in various schools, including a New York high school, where students are actively participating in class discussions and expressing their opinions. The increase in civic engagement is attributed to the changing social landscape and the influence of current events on younger generations.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Croesus Retail Trust's move to be internally managed may close the discount to its target price, according to DBS Group Research. The trust's high yield and potential takeover by a J-Reit could be removed with an internal manager. OCBC Bank maintains a neutral call, citing rising provisions and a weak earnings outlook. Jumbo Group holds Croesus Retail Trust, citing a 24 times price-earnings ratio, and reduces its FY17 forecast due to a delayed new outlet opening.

site_title: Singapore land-use policies should be more responsive to market changes
summary: Singapore's government is reviewing existing land-use policies and planning guidelines, a move aimed at making the country's industrial sector more responsive to market changes. The review follows recommendations by the Committee on the Future Economy to increase flexibility in land use, allowing complementary commercial activities to be co-located. The government aims to refresh existing definitions of allowable uses for industrial sites, particularly in light of the evolving manufacturing sector, which now encompasses design, R&D, logistics, marketing, and after-sales services. The review is seen as a step in the right direction, but industry players expect clearer guidelines to support the growth of Industry 4.0, which requires high-specification and flexible spaces.

site_title: Rents rise for condos, but ease for HDB flats in January: SRX
summary: Singapore's non-landed private home rents rose 1.3% in January 2017, but HDB flat rents eased 0.6% over the same period. The rental index for private apartments and condos has contracted 5.0% year-on-year, while HDB flat rents have shed 4.8% over the same period. New unit completions are expected to ease in 2017, with 14,826 private homes anticipated to be completed this year, down from 20,803 in 2016.

site_title: Emerging nations seize bigger role in clean energy race
summary: Developing countries, including China, India, Vietnam, South Africa, Brazil, Mexico, and Turkey, are emerging as leaders in the global clean energy transition by adopting policies to boost energy efficiency and promote renewable energy. The World Bank's survey found that 40% of 111 countries surveyed have strong policies to improve access to reliable and affordable energy. However, richer countries need to do more to promote energy efficiency, as the World Bank warns that failing to do so will prolong global warming and have serious consequences.

images.alt_text: A wind farm in China. The country is among those that are working to improve people's access to reliable and affordable energy and increase the use of renewable energy.

site_title: Trump campaign aides had repeated contact with Russian intelligence officials
summary: US law enforcement and intelligence agencies have intercepted phone records and calls showing repeated contact between Donald Trump's 2016 presidential campaign and Russian intelligence officials. The communications occurred around the same time as efforts to disrupt the presidential election and include other associates of Trump, such as Paul Manafort, who worked as a consultant in Ukraine. The FBI is investigating links between Trump's associates and the Russian government, as well as the hacking of the Democratic National Committee. While no evidence of collusion has been found, the intercepted calls have raised concerns among US officials.

site_title: Hotels pull out all the stops for Westminster show dogs
summary: Hotels near the Westminster Kennel Club dog show in Manhattan are catering to the needs of the nearly 3,000 show dogs, offering amenities such as dog-friendly facilities, grooming services, and special diets. The Hotel Pennsylvania, which hosts about 500 dogs this year, has even hired a full-time employee, the "doggie concierge," to welcome the canine crowd. Hotels are charging extra for dog stays and services, but the event has become a lucrative business, with many hotels recognizing the value of pet-friendly accommodations.

site_title: Ezra shares hit another bad patch
summary: Ezra Holdings' shares plummeted to a record low of S$0.021 after the offshore and marine group announced a winding-up petition against a subsidiary of its subsea joint venture, Emas Chiyoda Subsea (ECS). The petition, filed by Necotrans Singapore Pte Ltd, has been fixed for hearing on March 3, 2017. Ezra is seeking advice on the application and assessing its impact on the group. The company's shares have repeatedly tested new lows since news of a massive writedown tied to ECS.

site_title: Electric car boom spurs investor scramble for cobalt
summary: Investors are buying up physical cobalt in anticipation of a surge in prices due to increasing demand from electric vehicles, particularly in China. Prices for cobalt have climbed 50% since September to a 5-year peak of $19 a pound, with demand expected to reach 130,000 tonnes by 2021. The Democratic Republic of Congo, where 60% of the world's cobalt is produced, faces geopolitical risks, leading to concerns about supply chain insecurity. Investors are buying cobalt to sit on until prices rise to $25 a pound or more, with some funds also looking to invest in cobalt mining projects in stable countries.

site_title: Bankia probe may boost Spain's pitch to Brexit banks
summary: Spain's National Court has summoned former and current central bankers, including former Bank of Spain governor Miguel Angel Fernandez Ordonez, over their roles in propping up Bankia during the 2008-2013 financial crisis. The investigation may boost Spain's bid to attract financial firms fleeing Brexit Britain, with the Bank of Spain and market regulator CNMV denying wrongdoing. The clean-up efforts are seen as a positive step towards Spain leaving behind its painful past and demonstrating its commitment to financial stability, making it a more attractive location for financial firms.

site_title: Vital to secure working people's will, leadership and support
summary: The Committee on the Future Economy (CFE) has been convened to address uncertainty and present opportunities for Singapore's working people and economy. The CFE's seven strategies aim to enhance competitiveness, with a focus on workers' learning and upgrading, adapting to internationalization, and addressing demographic changes. The labour movement and government will work together to convey challenges, create job opportunities, and provide training. Outcomes sought include good career growth, sustainable wages, and innovative companies. Ultimately, the goal is for all stakeholders to grow together, embracing changes and facing challenges as one Singapore.

site_title: Blueprints for building capabilities
summary: Singapore has developed Industry Transformation Maps (ITMs) to drive productivity and growth in 23 industries, accounting for 80% of the economy. The ITMs, launched in 2017, are tailored development plans that aim to strengthen industries through collaboration and innovation. The maps will be used to drive growth, innovation, and nimbleness in the face of future challenges. The government will act as a facilitator and enabler of industry transformation, while trade associations and stakeholders will act as multipliers.

images.alt_text: The ITM for the logistics industry can help the firms better understand emerging trends.

site_title: Engine maker Rolls-Royce logs record £4b loss
summary: Rolls-Royce, a British engine maker, reported a record annual net loss of £4 billion in 2016 due to a Brexit-fueled collapse in the pound and a corruption fine. The company's underlying pre-tax profits nearly halved to £813 million. Rolls-Royce attributed the loss to a £4.4 billion hit from the weak pound and a £671 million penalty for bribery allegations. Despite the loss, the company expects a "modest" performance improvement in 2017 and is on track to slash costs.

site_title: Charting a course for Singapore's future
summary: Singapore unveils a plan to chart its future economic course, following a year-long review by the Committee on the Future Economy. The plan aims to maintain the country's economic momentum despite changing global conditions. It includes strategies to enhance innovation, improve productivity, and attract foreign talent. The move is seen as a response to the challenges posed by trade tensions and shifting economic landscapes. The plan's implementation is expected to support Singapore's long-term economic growth and competitiveness.

site_title: CFE pushes for collaborations that seed innovation and growth
summary: The Committee on the Future Economy (CFE) in Singapore has highlighted the role of trade associations and chambers (TACs) in supporting the internationalisation of local firms. The EEN Singapore Centre, established by the Singapore Manufacturing Federation, Enterprise Europe Network, International Enterprise Singapore, and Intellectual Property Intermediary, has facilitated over 200 meetings and eight partnership agreements with local manufacturers. The CFE encourages other TACs to lead initiatives in industry upgrading, internationalisation, and skills development, citing the success of existing schemes such as the Local Enterprise and Association Development (Lead) programme.

site_title: Siberian oil field that bankrolled Soviets may gush cash again
summary: Russia's largest oil field, Samotlor, could see a surge in profits if proposals to encourage investment in the field are implemented. The 25 billion-barrel field, which now produces almost 20 times more water than crude, could add 90 billion roubles (S$2.2 billion) to Rosneft's earnings annually by cutting the extraction tax in half for fields producing a lot of water with the oil. This proposal could benefit Samotlor, which bankrolled the Soviet Union for decades and is now considered past its prime.

site_title: Eviction looms for 'well-off' tenants in HK public rental homes
summary: Hong Kong's Housing Authority has finalized plans to evict wealthier public housing tenants, known as "well-off tenants," from subsidized public rental homes (PRH) starting this October. The measure aims to reallocate resources to those with more pressing housing needs. Tenants with incomes exceeding five times the monthly limit or net assets exceeding 100 times the limit will be forced to vacate. Those with temporary housing needs can apply for a license to stay for up to a year, paying a fee equivalent to double net rent or market rent.

site_title: International Energy Group to start crude oil trading
summary: Singapore-based trading startup International Energy Group (IEG) plans to expand its portfolio to crude oil trading, tapping into growing Chinese demand. IEG aims to import crude and light components from the US, following China's record crude import growth in 2016. The company, a subsidiary of New Silkroutes Group, started trading oil products in 2015 and is working on energy infrastructure investment to support its oil trading. IEG's move is driven by the need for control and infrastructure investments to sustain business models in a transparent oil market.

site_title: Reviewing the tax regime to help realise the CFE vision
summary: Singapore's Committee on the Future Economy (CFE) has called for a review of the country's tax regime to ensure it remains competitive, sustainable, and pro-growth. The CFE aims to create a vibrant economy, but a broad-based, progressive, and fair tax system is needed to support its plans. The government must refine its tax policies to address concerns such as an ageing population and increased international pressures, including the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development's Base Erosion and Profit Shifting (BEPS) project.

site_title: Case study: Pioneering cybersecurity solutions for mobile
summary: V-Key, a Singapore-based startup, is pioneering cybersecurity solutions for mobile applications. Founded in 2011 by Benjamin Mah, the company aims to ensure secure transactions on mobile devices. Its core offering, V-OS, is a virtual secure element that integrates into mobile apps, providing threat-aware and self-defending multi-layered protections. The company's solutions are increasingly relevant due to the rise of mobile transactions and the need for secure digital identities. V-Key is expanding globally, with plans to grow its team and presence in South-east Asia and beyond.

site_title: The next breakthrough
summary: The Committee on the Future Economy (CFE) has released a strategy to help Singapore adapt and upgrade in the face of a rapidly changing global economy. The plan focuses on harnessing data-related innovations and leveraging Asia's growth to drive Singapore's economy forward. Key recommendations include developing expertise in key markets, creating a dedicated data programme office, and fostering a vibrant city of opportunity. If implemented successfully, the plan aims to achieve annual GDP growth of 2-3% over the next decade, keeping Singapore ahead of other developed economies.

site_title: US health insurers Aetna, Humana drop merger; Cigna seeks to end Anthem deal
summary: US health insurers Aetna and Humana have dropped their planned $34 billion merger, while Cigna has sought to end its deal with Anthem. The moves come as the Trump administration vows to repeal and replace the Affordable Care Act. Humana will exit the Obamacare individual insurance market after this year, citing high medical costs. Aetna will pay Humana a $1 billion breakup fee and Cigna will pay Anthem a $1.85 billion fee. The cancellations are a setback for industry consolidation efforts to address the ACA.

site_title: China considering making foreign submersibles travel on surface
summary: China is considering revisions to its maritime safety law, which would require foreign submersibles to travel on the surface and report their movements to authorities when in China's waters. The draft revisions, based on the UN Convention on the Law of the Sea and Chinese laws, also allow Chinese authorities to stop foreign ships if they pose a threat to navigational safety. The move comes amid ongoing disputes with the US and other countries over the South China Sea, a region rich in resources and strategically important for sea lanes.

site_title: Toshiba puts prized chips unit up for sale to salvage business
summary: Toshiba is considering selling a majority stake in its prized memory chip business, valued at up to $14 billion, to salvage its struggling business. The move comes after a chaotic earnings day, with the company forecasting a $6.2 billion loss for the year and potential asset-stripping. South Korea's SK Hynix and Chinese chipmakers are among potential buyers. Toshiba's nuclear business is also facing uncertainty, with the company considering selling its US unit or pulling out of nuclear plant construction. The move has sent the company's stock to 10-month lows.

site_title: Deepening knowledge of regional markets is vital
summary: Singapore's Committee on the Future Economy recommends seven strategies to achieve 2-3% yearly growth, including staying connected with the world through overseas assignments. Despite progress, parents' concerns about children's education while working abroad remain a challenge. The committee suggests extending the Student Learning Space to overseas students, setting up a one-stop portal for families, and making it easy for overseas students to enroll in the International Baccalaureate Diploma Programme. The report emphasizes the need for deep knowledge of regional markets to form effective strategies, which can be acquired through quality overseas assignments and internships.

site_title: Apple weighing Chinese supplier for next-gen iPhone screens
summary: Apple is in discussions with Chinese screen maker BOE Technology Group to supply next-generation Amoled displays for future iPhones. BOE is spending nearly 100 billion yuan to build two Amoled plants in Sichuan, hoping to secure a deal. If selected, BOE would become Apple's first supplier outside of South Korea and Japan. The move comes as Apple explores alternatives to address a global shortage of Oled displays, with the company potentially adopting the technology in 2018 or later.

site_title: Market may be guilty of gambler's fallacy on Fed rate hikes
summary: Financial markets are at risk of the "gambler's fallacy" when it comes to Federal Reserve interest-rate hikes, some investors warn. Despite the Fed's record of being less hawkish than expected, investors are discounting just two hikes this year, while a rapid pick-up in inflation due to the Trump administration's fiscal stimulus could prompt the Fed to move faster. Fed Chief Janet Yellen has signaled that the Fed should avoid waiting too long to remove policy accommodation, but market expectations are still underpriced.

site_title: UK law making landlords check passports "racist"
summary: A UK law requiring landlords to check the immigration status of prospective tenants has been deemed discriminatory by a migrant and refugee charity group. The Right to Rent scheme, introduced in 2016, aims to prevent illegal immigration but has been found to disproportionately affect foreign nationals and Britons from ethnic minorities. A survey revealed 51% of landlords would be less likely to rent to foreign nationals, with 58% turning down an applicant from an ethnic minority. Charities and politicians have called for the scheme to be halted, citing a lack of evidence of its effectiveness.

site_title: Healthway Medical expects loss for Q4 and FY 2016 due to impairments
summary: Healthway Medical Corporation expects a loss for its Q4 and FY 2016 due to significant impairment of certain receivables and goodwill. The impairment mainly affected the company's financial performance. More details on the impairment will be disclosed when the Q4 results are announced on or before March 1.

site_title: Troika must find Greek answer this week
summary: Greece's debt resolution is becoming increasingly urgent due to heightened market uncertainty. The European Commission's forecasts show the economy accelerating, but fundamentals remain weak. Mario Draghi stated that Greece won't be considered for the ECB's quantitative easing until a political accord is reached on debt resolution. The Troika, consisting of the European Commission, the European Central Bank, and the International Monetary Fund, must find a solution by the end of the week.

site_title: EU parliament backs landmark Canada trade deal
summary: The European Parliament voted in favor of the EU-Canada free trade deal, known as Ceta, despite protests and calls for protectionism from some. The agreement, seen as a rare victory for global trade, has been hailed as Europe's most modern trade deal and a potential model for post-Brexit relations. MEPs praised the accord as a defense against US President Trump's opposition to far-reaching trade deals, and it is expected to have a significant impact on the global trade system.

site_title: Dubai plans taxi that skips the driver, and the roads
summary: Dubai plans to launch automated flying taxis, called passenger drones, as early as July. The Ehang 184 drone, capable of carrying a single rider and a small suitcase, has flown test runs past Dubai's Burj Al Arab. The drone can fly up to 31 miles and has a top speed of 160 kph. It will operate at 100 kph and has a fail-safe technology to ensure safety in case of a malfunction. Dubai aims to have 25% of its journeys conducted by driverless vehicles by 2030, building on its existing driverless subway system.

site_title: US$ up for eleventh straight session
summary: The US dollar has recorded its 11th consecutive daily rise, driven by investors' anticipation of a potential interest rate hike by the Federal Reserve next month. European currencies, such as the Swedish krona and British sterling, fell due to cautious economic outlooks from the Riksbank and UK labour market report.

images.alt_text: The US dollar chalked up its 11th straight daily rise on Wednesday, as investors' focus moved to inflation data in the United States for more support for the idea of a rise in Federal Reserve interest rates next month.

site_title: Case study: Driving business through talent
summary: Yang Kee Logistics, a local player in the logistics industry, is differentiating itself by focusing on people development. The sector is often perceived as unattractive and demanding, making it challenging to attract fresh talent. By prioritizing talent development, Yang Kee Logistics aims to stand out from its competitors. This approach may help to revitalize the industry and improve its reputation.

site_title: Tunisian fashion designers look to past for inspiration
summary: Tunisian fashion designers are drawing inspiration from the country's rich heritage, incorporating traditional embroidery and styles into modern outfits. Designers like Zeineb Chiboub and Faouzia Frad are reworking traditional clothing, such as the kachabiya robe and the Maryoul Fadhila top, to create stylish and modern pieces. The trend is seen as a way to celebrate Tunisian identity and counter religious extremism, with designers hoping to showcase the country's unique cultural heritage on the international stage.

site_title: Case study: A firm believer in automation to level up
summary: Singapore-based laundry company Orchid Laundry is investing heavily in automation and technology to boost productivity amid a labor shortage. Director Harry Toh aims to hire experienced workers like business-excellence manager Anthony Loh, who joined at 58, and leverage technology to increase efficiency. Toh believes automation will enable workers to develop new skills and reduce labor costs. He plans to expand the business overseas, starting with the South-east Asian market, and is taking advantage of government aid schemes, including the Wage Credit Scheme and Productivity and Innovation Credit Scheme.

images.alt_text: Orchid Laundry is a family business run by director Harry Toh (second from left). With him are his father Toh Kun Hai and other members of the family.

site_title: Hope emerges against tide of populist politicians
summary: The 2017 Munich security conference highlights the growing concern of an "illiberal moment" in Western democracies, with populist parties making significant gains in government in around a dozen countries. The conference focuses on the debate between liberal cosmopolitans and populist authoritarian forces, with key figures such as Marine Le Pen and Emmanuel Macron vying for power. Despite the rise of populists, Macron's centrist movement appears to be gaining momentum, potentially providing a counterbalance to far-right forces. The conference's theme underscores the need for a liberal vision to tackle complex policy challenges and build public consensus, a message that resonates with centrist politicians worldwide.

site_title: Using intellectual property to drive innovation
summary: Singapore's Committee on the Future Economy recommends strengthening the country's intellectual property (IP) ecosystem to drive innovation and technology adoption in enterprises. Industry players welcome the move, citing the need to build capabilities to commercialise IP, grow the IP expert community, and develop standardised IP protocols. The report also proposes reviewing Singapore's copyright regime to support the growth of creative industries. Experts highlight the importance of providing subsidies, incentives, and support for individuals and entities to join the IP commercialisation community.

site_title: Trump immigration storm buffets Los Angeles' Olympics bid
summary: US President Donald Trump's support for Los Angeles' 2024 Olympics bid has been undermined by his administration's immigration policies, sparking concerns among analysts that domestic politics could impact the city's chances. The LA 2024 campaign, led by Mayor Eric Garcetti, has faced criticism from Trump, who has also been embroiled in controversy over a travel ban on refugees and migrants. As the International Olympic Committee (IOC) prepares to choose the 2024 host city in September, Los Angeles, Paris, and Budapest are seen as front-runners, but domestic politics could give an unwanted kick to all three bids.

site_title: Accountant General Dept's mobile app wins global prize
summary: The Accountant-General's Department of Singapore won the "best mobile government service award" at the World Government Summit in Dubai for its Vendors@Gov mobile app, which enables vendors to submit electronic invoices, check payment status, and track cash flows. The app, launched in June, has been downloaded over 4,000 times and aims to strengthen the "last-mile delivery" of government services to businesses. This is Singapore's first international award for a government service, following previous wins in 2015 and 2016.

site_title: Google faces setback in premium content plans without big YouTube star
summary: Google's YouTube removed PewDiePie's channel from its premium advertising service and cancelled his YouTube series after he published videos with anti-Semitic messages. The move is a setback for YouTube's strategy of promoting premium content that attracts top advertising rates, and may put other creators on notice about the importance of adhering to standards. Despite this, analysts say YouTube is still stronger than any one creator and will not be significantly impacted by the move.

site_title: Yang Kee sponsored his EMBA
summary: Yang Kee Logistics sponsored Chan Hsien Hung's two-year part-time executive MBA course at the National University of Singapore in 2013. Hung, general manager of the management office, felt he had reached a professional ceiling and wanted to grow with the company. The sponsorship allowed him to gain new perspectives, interact with executives from different backgrounds, and learn best practices and trends.
