The team is doubling in size since 2014 and is now supporting bankers in equity underwriting, leveraged buyouts, and real estate deals. While Goldman executives say the technology aims to reduce grunt work and make junior bankers more efficient, some employees are concerned that automation could lead to job losses and limit career advancement opportunities. The bank's revenue fell 9% last year, and the industry has cut client-facing investment bankers by 15% since 2010, raising worries about the impact of technology on staffing levels.

site_title: Hong Kong police guilty over attack on democracy protester
summary: Hong Kong police officers were found guilty of assaulting a protester, Civic Party activist Ken Tsang, during pro-democracy rallies in 2014. Seven officers were convicted of assault causing actual bodily harm, but acquitted of a more serious charge. The attack, captured on video, showed Tsang being beaten and kicked by police. The verdict was seen as a blow to the police force's reputation, which had faced criticism for its treatment of protesters seeking fully free elections for Hong Kong's future leaders.

site_title: Australia: Shares upbeat on rally in commodities, NZ up
summary: Australian shares rose 0.4% on Tuesday, driven by a rally in commodities, particularly iron ore futures, which surged over US$90. The S&P/ASX 200 index is heading for its sixth day of gains, its longest winning streak in over six months. Analysts attribute the positive sentiment to the mining sector's strong moves, including copper.

site_title: Hot stock: Noble surges on rumours of stake interest from Sinochem
summary: Noble Group's shares surged 14.2% to 22.5 cents after reports that China's state-owned Sinochem is in talks to buy an equity stake in the commodity trader. Reuters cited sources saying Sinochem is interested in Noble's global supply chain. Noble has confirmed it is in discussions with Sinochem but no binding arrangements have been made. The news comes after Noble met with Sinochem executives and its US regional hub in recent months.

site_title: Credit Suisse posts quarterly loss of 2.35b francs on litigation
summary: Credit Suisse posted a 2.35 billion franc quarterly loss, its second consecutive annual loss, due to a settlement with the US Justice Department over mortgage securities. The bank set aside 2.17 billion francs to top up legal provisions. CEO Tidjane Thiam attributed the loss to the implementation of the bank's new strategy and cost cuts, which will continue in 2017. Despite the setback, Thiam expressed confidence in the bank's progress and its target of a 13% common equity Tier 1 ratio by 2018.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close down, Toshiba dives
summary: Tokyo stocks closed lower on Tuesday, with the Nikkei 225 index falling 1.13% to 19,238.98. Toshiba plummeted 8% after requesting a delay in filing its earnings report. The yen strengthened, contributing to the market's decline.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open lower after rally
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened lower on Tuesday, ending a four-day rally, with the Hang Seng Index slipping 0.32% to 23,636.17. The benchmark Shanghai Composite Index remained flat, while the Shenzhen Composite Index ticked up slightly. Investors took a breather after a surge in previous sessions, with some attributing the decline to concerns over US-EU trade tensions.

site_title: HDB launches 4,056 flats for sale in February BTO exercise
summary: The Housing & Development Board (HDB) launched 4,056 flats for sale under the February 2017 Build-To-Order (BTO) exercise, offering units in Punggol, Clementi, and Tampines. A project in Woodlands has been deferred due to site conditions. Families on the Fresh Start Housing Scheme can apply for a two-room Flexi flat with a 45- to 65-year lease, with priority allocation of up to 10% of units. The HDB plans to launch 17,000 flats this year, with another 4,600 units available in May.

images.alt_text: THE Housing & Development Board (HDB) on Tuesday launched 4,056 flats for sale under the February 2017 Build-To-Order (BTO) exercise.

site_title: China Jan consumer inflation quickens to 2.5%, beating forecasts
summary: China's consumer inflation rate rose to 2.5% in January, beating forecasts and the highest since May 2014. Producer price inflation accelerated to 6.9%, the fastest since August 2011. Despite rising inflation expectations globally, China's consumer inflation remains within the central bank's comfort zone, sparking debate about tighter monetary policy.

site_title: With vacancies, Trump gains chance to reshape Fed
summary: US President Donald Trump's influence over the Federal Reserve may increase following the resignation of Governor Daniel Tarullo, who helped regulate banks after the 2008 financial crisis. Tarullo's departure leaves three vacancies on the Fed's board of governors and gives Trump the chance to name a new Fed chair. Trump is expected to appoint someone more sympathetic to industry interests, potentially leading to a shift in financial regulatory policies. This could have implications for monetary policy and interest rates, with some economists warning that Trump's views may favor lower regulation and higher lending rates.

site_title: Australia struggles to improve lives of indigenous population
summary: Australia's government report, "Closing the Gap," reveals the country is failing to meet almost every target for improving the lives of its indigenous population. Despite making up 3% of the population, Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders have disproportionately high rates of suicide and incarceration, ranking near the bottom in economic and social indicators. The report marks 50 years since Australia's constitution change, aiming to improve welfare and living standards for indigenous communities.

site_title: MAS relaxes rules on finance firms to help fund SMEs, including allowing foreign M&As
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) announced it will relax rules to strengthen finance companies' ability to fund small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). The regulator will allow foreign mergers and acquisitions, raise loan limits, and permit finance companies to offer current accounts and join electronic payment networks. These changes aim to provide more comprehensive credit and deposit services to SMEs, with restrictions on foreign currency exposures and derivatives trading remaining in place to limit business risks. The move is expected to enable finance companies to serve SME customers more effectively.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Noble, OCBC, CRT, Manulife US Reit
summary: Singapore Inc. reported mixed earnings results, with Noble Group potentially seeing trading interest due to talks with Sinochem to buy an equity stake. OCBC Group's net profit dropped 18% to S$789 million, while Croesus Retail Trust (CRT) rose 5.2% in distribution per unit. Manulife US Reit beat its forecast by 3.6% with a fourth-quarter distribution per unit of 1.54 US cents. Two companies, Ezra Holdings and The Stratech Group, requested trading halts before market opening.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened 1.19 points lower at 1,709.05, with 118.95 million lots traded worth RM45.64 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 150 to 78.

site_title: Trump immigration order blocked by US judge in Virginia
summary: A US judge in Virginia has blocked President Donald Trump's 90-day ban on people from seven predominantly Muslim countries from entering the US. The ruling, issued by US District Judge Leonie Brinkema, moves the issue closer to possible Supreme Court review. Trump may issue a revised order to address issues raised in the cases. The ruling bolsters a delay in a separate case and increases hurdles for Trump to fulfill his campaign promise to shut US borders to countries with ties to terrorism.

site_title: New York City mayor says 'affordability crisis' threatens city
summary: New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio warned of an "affordability crisis" due to rising housing prices outpacing wage growth, affecting residents' ability to pay rent. In his state of the city address, de Blasio discussed recent proposals, including adding 10,000 affordable apartments and a "mansion tax" to generate $336 million for rent assistance, aiming to create 100,000 higher-paying jobs. The proposals are part of his efforts to address homelessness, opioid addiction, and economic inequality, ahead of his reelection in November.

site_title: Prime region leads private-home resale price rise in January: SRX Property
summary: The Core Central Region (CCR) saw a 1.9% rise in resale prices in January, with the overall resale index for the private residential market increasing 1.1% month-on-month. Resale prices in the city-fringe and suburban areas rose 1.5% and 0.4% respectively, while those in the Outside Central Region fell 0.1% and 1.1%. Resale volumes increased 9.1% from December and 29.9% from a year ago, with 526 non-landed resale units sold.

site_title: South Korea sues Nissan over mileage claims, probes BMW, Porsche
summary: South Korea has sued Nissan's South Korean unit for allegedly manipulating fuel economy test results of its Infiniti Q50 sedan. The Seoul Central District Prosecutors' Office is also investigating BMW and Porsche on similar allegations. The probe follows a ban on 10 models of the three car makers for fabricating emissions and noise-level test documents. Nissan is accused of overstating the Q50's fuel economy by 3.4%, while the company claims it reported errors in certification documents due to a manager's misconduct. The investigation adds to Nissan's emissions cheating scandal in South Korea.

images.alt_text: South Korea has sued Nissan Motor's South Korean unit alleging that the Japanese car maker manipulated the fuel economy test results of its Infiniti Q50 sedan, a government official said on Tuesday.

site_title: Oil rises on Opec-led cuts, but market remains range-bound
summary: Oil prices rose on Tuesday, supported by an Opec-led effort to cut output, but remained within a narrow $5-per-barrel trading range. Brent crude futures rose 17 US cents to $55.76 per barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures gained 14 US cents to $53.07 per barrel. Opec and other producers agreed to cut output by 1.8 million barrels per day to rein in global fuel supply, but rising US production undermined efforts. Despite a 90% compliance rate, market skepticism remains, with some analysts predicting a possible temporary dip to $45 per barrel.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Tuesday
summary: Singapore shares opened lower on Tuesday, down 0.5% at 3,095.25, despite a strong US market. The Straits Times Index fell 16.38 points, with 93 gainers outpacing 48 losers in trading volume. The extended Wall Street rally earlier in the day saw four major US equity benchmarks reach fresh records.

site_title: Lance Armstrong to head to court in US lawsuit
summary: US District Judge Christopher Cooper cleared the way for Lance Armstrong to go to court in a US$100 million lawsuit against him, alleging he cheated the government by doping during his cycling career. The US Justice Department claims Armstrong cheated when the US Postal Service sponsored his team. A jury will decide the issue of injury suffered by the US, with Armstrong claiming the lawsuits were unfounded. Armstrong was stripped of his Tour de France victories in 2012 after being accused of a sophisticated doping program. He has since acknowledged doping, but denies the government's allegations of misleading the federal government.

site_title: Banks eyeing Dublin hub post Brexit face shortage of top traders
summary: Banks are considering Dublin as a post-Brexit hub due to its similar laws and regulations to the UK, but face a talent shortage, with more people working in finance in Edinburgh than in Ireland. Dublin's lack of top traders, with some recruiters saying it's hard to hire front-office traders, poses a concern for global banks. Despite this, Irish officials are confident in attracting workers from other EU cities, with IDA Ireland estimating Dublin could gain up to 15,000 financial jobs from Brexit.

site_title: Toshiba to unveil nuclear writedown as it scrambles for cash
summary: Toshiba Corp is set to unveil a potential $8.77 billion writedown related to cost overruns at its US nuclear arm, which could wipe out shareholder equity. The company may also sell a stake in its British nuclear venture NuGeneration Ltd to Korea Electric Power Corp. Toshiba's shares fell 4% in early trade as the company scrambles for cash, with Chief Executive Satoshi Tsunakawa expected to outline the nuclear arm's prospects and efforts to raise capital. The writedown and potential sale are part of Toshiba's efforts to recover from a $1.3 billion accounting scandal in 2016.

site_title: Trump national security adviser Flynn resigns in controversy over Russian contacts
summary: US President Donald Trump's national security adviser, Michael Flynn, resigned on February 14, 2017, amid controversy over his contacts with Russian officials before Trump took office. Retired General Keith Kellogg was named acting national security adviser. The resignation came after Flynn admitted to lying about his interactions with Russian Ambassador Sergei Kislyak. The controversy raised concerns about Flynn's loyalty and ability to serve as national security adviser.

site_title: Beijing bans high-emission vehicles in anti-smog move
summary: Beijing has banned high-emission vehicles from entering the city's main districts on weekdays, effective Wednesday, as part of efforts to combat pollution. The ban applies to vehicles failing to meet China's Emission Standard III and drivers will be fined if they fail to comply. The move follows a pledge by the municipal government to take "extraordinary" measures to curb emissions from coal consumption and cars. This is part of China's broader efforts to reduce air pollution, with new rules requiring all light vehicles to adhere to the China VI emission standards by 2020.

site_title: China's Xi says officials should prevent abuse of power
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping emphasized the need for senior officials to practice self-discipline and "build a fence" to prevent abuse of power. He stated that officials must eliminate special privileges and use their power impartially and legally. This comes as China continues its anti-corruption campaign, with dozens of senior officials jailed for corruption and abuse of power since Xi took office four years ago. Xi's message is aimed at strengthening the party's grip on power and combating graft, which has been a persistent issue in China.

site_title: Hot stocks: Banks slide after OCBC's Q4 results disappoint
summary: The share prices of Singaporean banks DBS, UOB, and OCBC fell after OCBC reported disappointing Q4 results, with net income down 18% and provisions for bad loans surging. DBS fell 1.85% and UOB 0.57%, while OCBC's share price dropped 2.26%. Analysts had expected an average profit of S$864 million. The banks are scheduled to report their earnings in the coming days, with DBS on Feb 16 and UOB on Feb 17.

site_title: It's the current account stupid: Korea, Thailand lure flows
summary: Foreign investors are pouring into South Korean and Thai sovereign bonds, with the two nations attracting the largest flows in developing-nation Asia. South Korea and Thailand have 10-year yields under 3% and large current-account surpluses, making them well-positioned to cope with potential US interest-rate increases. The nations' strong economic indicators, including low inflation rates and large foreign-reserve stockpiles, are also attracting investors. This trend is seen as a response to the unwinding of the "Trump trade" and the concerns of regional authorities about being named currency manipulators.

site_title: AusGroup inks A$1.1m profit for Q2, sees return to profitability continuing
summary: AusGroup reported a net profit of A$1.09 million for the fiscal second quarter ended Dec 31, 2016, compared to a net loss of A$69.77 million in the same period last year. The 13.5% year-on-year decline in revenue was offset by lower costs. The company expects a return to profitability to continue through the next half of FY2017 and into FY2018 and FY2019 as core projects grow in scale and complexity. This marks an improvement of A$5.8 million in the half-year net loss.

site_title: Playboy turns back to nudity
summary: Playboy, under new chief creative officer Cooper Hefner, is reviving its tradition of featuring nudity in its magazine, 1 year after stopping. The decision comes as the magazine seeks to reclaim its identity and broaden its audience. The March/April edition will feature nude photos and an essay by actress Scarlett Byrne on female sexuality and double standards. The move marks a rebranding for the magazine, which will shift focus from "Entertainment for Men" to a lifestyle brand. Cooper Hefner says nudity is not the problem, but rather a dated approach to sex.

site_title: Australia dollar edges up on positive data, kiwi near 3-1/2 wk low
summary: The Australian dollar rose 0.35% to US$0.7665 after a business conditions survey jumped to near decade highs, indicating a pick-up in sales and employment. The currency has struggled to break through the 77 US cent barrier, with technical analysts expecting chart support at 76 US cents. The US dollar index is near a 3-1/2 week high, driven by speculation of economic stimulus under President Trump. The New Zealand dollar held at US$0.7179 after hitting a 3-1/2 week low.

site_title: Top dogs vie for blue ribbon at New York show
summary: Over 2,800 dogs from 200 breeds, representing 49 states and 16 foreign countries, gathered in New York City for the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show. The competition, the second-oldest sporting event in the US, concluded with the "Best in Show" award to be announced on Tuesday evening. Dogs from various groups, including sporting, herding, and toy breeds, competed for the top prize, with the golden retriever being the most popular breed in this year's show.

site_title: Hopes of US tax cuts lift US dollar index to 3-week high
summary: The US dollar rose to a near three-week high against a basket of currencies, reaching 101.11, following US President Donald Trump's promise of a "phenomenal" tax plan that includes tax cuts for businesses and individuals. Investors are optimistic about the fiscal policy outlook, which they believe will promote economic growth and lead to higher interest rates. The euro slipped to its lowest level against the US dollar since January 19, while the yen advanced to a two-week peak against the US dollar.

site_title: Steven Mnuchin is confirmed by Senate to be Treasury secretary
summary: Steven Mnuchin was confirmed as US Treasury secretary in a 53-47 Senate vote, filling the role of chief spokesman for the dollar and steward for the Trump administration's economic priorities. Mnuchin, a former Goldman Sachs banker, will push ahead with top administration goals, including dismantling financial regulations and slashing taxes. He will play a leading role in preparing for the expiration of the debt limit suspension and his first meeting of G-20 finance ministers and central bank governors in Germany. Mnuchin's confirmation comes after several delays in the Senate vetting process.

site_title: Valentine's Day gets chilly reception in parts of Asia
summary: A Pakistani court banned public celebrations of Valentine's Day in Islamabad, while Indonesian students and some cities in Malaysia and Indonesia also rejected the festival. Grumpy protesters in Japan called for an end to public displays of love. Authorities in Malaysia, Australia, and Singapore warned of growing online love scams targeting lonely people. The court cited "immorality, nudity, and indecency" as reasons for the ban, while protesters in Japan claimed it hurt their feelings.

site_title: Queen to unveil Britain's new cyber security centre
summary: Queen Elizabeth II is set to unveil Britain's National Cyber Security Centre in London, marking the country's efforts to combat growing cyber attacks, primarily from Russia. The centre, part of a £1.9 billion government strategy, aims to implement preventative measures such as securing state websites and email accounts. The centre has already responded to 188 cyber attacks and is preparing for a major "category 1" attack. The move comes amid concerns about Russian aggression in cyber-space and US intelligence agencies' accusations of Moscow's involvement in cyber attacks on government departments and companies.

site_title: Australian business conditions surge to highest level since 2007
summary: Australian business conditions surged to the highest level since 2007, with a National Australia Bank survey showing a 16 from 10 in January, and a gauge of employment rising to its highest level since 2011. Business confidence climbed to 10 from 6, and interest-rate cuts are now less likely, according to NAB chief economist Alan Oster. This improvement is attributed to a "degree of caution" due to seasonal influences, but suggests an overall improvement in the domestic economy.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Tuesday, with the Nikkei 225 index rising 0.15% to 19,488.27. This follows Wall Street's fresh records and an improved eurozone economic forecast. The Topix index also increased 0.26% to 1,558.19. The gains come amid a backdrop of US-EU trade talks and amid rising US tariffs.

site_title: CRT's Q2 DPU up 5.2% from year-ago restated DPU thanks to acquisitions
summary: CROESUS Retail Trust (CRT) reported a 5.2% rise in distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.81 Singapore cents for Q2 2016, driven by acquisitions and a larger portfolio of income-producing properties. Gross revenue jumped 30.7% to 3.18 billion yen, while net property income rose 23.2%. The company's CEO attributed the financial performance to enhancement initiatives and tenant renewal exercises, with plans to grow CRT's income base through asset enhancement initiatives and tenant replacement exercises.

site_title: Dallas Fed's Kaplan calls for gradual interest rate rise soon
summary: Dallas Federal Reserve Bank President Robert Kaplan urged the US central bank to raise interest rates soon to avoid having to make rapid removals of monetary accommodation. He emphasized the need for a gradual approach to rate hikes to avoid distorting investment and hiring. Kaplan's call comes ahead of Fed Chair Janet Yellen's testimony and may reflect growing sentiment among policymakers for a rate rise sooner than expected. The Fed is currently targeting short-term rates below 3%, and Kaplan suggested discussing how to reduce the massive balance sheet once rates are raised.

site_title: Oil down 2% as US dollar firms, Opec compliance rate shrugged off
summary: Oil prices declined 2% on Monday, the largest drop since mid-January, due to a stronger US dollar and rising US crude output. Despite an Opec report showing high compliance with production-cut deals, oil prices remained under pressure. Brent futures fell to $55.59 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude declined to $52.93 per barrel. Analysts attribute the decline to increased US rig count and productivity in shale basins, as well as hopes of US tax cuts.

images.alt_text: Oil prices declined on Monday by about 2 per cent, the most since mid-January, pressured by a stronger US dollar and signs of rising US crude output.

site_title: White House 'considering and pursuing all options' on new immigration measures
summary: US President Donald Trump's administration is considering new immigration measures to keep Americans safe, amid a federal appeals court's freeze on his travel ban. The White House is exploring options, including an emergency appeal to the Supreme Court or a new executive order, after a top aide, Stephen Miller, said the judges' decision took away power from the president. Meanwhile, hundreds of undocumented migrants were deported under a separate executive order, sparking protests and concerns about the impact on Latin Americans.

site_title: Beijing eyeing radical steps against metals, coal in war on smog
summary: China is considering radical measures to tackle smog, including cutting steel and aluminium output by at least half and 30% respectively, banning coal in one port, and shutting fertiliser and drug plants. The plan, proposed by the Ministry of Environmental Protection, aims to reduce pollution in 28 cities across five regions. The measures would have a significant impact on industries and prices, with potential price volatility and supply chain disruptions.

site_title: US: Stocks end at record highs, extending 'Trump effect' rally
summary: US stocks closed at record highs, extending a rally driven by President Donald Trump's promise of a tax cut plan. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.7%, the S&P 500 gained 0.5%, and the Nasdaq Composite Index also increased 0.5%. Banks and technology shares, including Amazon and Tesla, surged, while mobile phone companies declined after Verizon's announcement of unlimited data packages. The market's optimism is attributed to investors giving Trump the benefit of the doubt, with the rally extending for the third straight session.

site_title: OCBC posts 18% drop in Q4 profit
summary: OCBC Group reported an 18% drop in Q4 net profit to S$789 million, primarily due to lower net interest income and non-interest income, as well as increased allowances for loans and impairment. The decline in net interest income was attributed to lower net interest margin from customer loan yields. For the full year, OCBC's net profit decreased 11% to S$3.47 billion due to higher allowances and lower trading and insurance income. Despite this, the bank's liquidity and capital positions remain strong.

images.alt_text: OCBC Group on Tuesday reported an 18 per cent drop in net profit to S$789 million for the fourth quarter ended Dec 31, 2016, dragged down by both net interest income and non-interest income, as well as higher allowances for loans and impairment.

site_title: Trump, Trudeau grapple with differences on refugees, trade
summary: US President Donald Trump and Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau failed to reconcile their differences on refugee treatment during a White House meeting. Trump defended his immigration decree, labeling it "common sense," while Trudeau's open door policies were seen as a threat. The leaders avoided direct criticism, but the tone was tense, particularly on trade. Trump's harsh rhetoric on trade was toned down, but the underlying differences remained. The meeting marked a rare instance of the two leaders not publicly disagreeing.

images.alt_text: US President Donald Trump and Canada's Prime Minister Justin Trudeau failed to paper over differences on the treatment of refugees during a joint public appearance Monday, but appeared to tone down harsh trade rhetoric.

site_title: 32 dead in Taiwan's worst highway accident for decades
summary: A Taiwan bus carrying 44 elderly tourists crashed off a highway in Taipei, killing 32 people, the island's worst road accident in decades. The bus veered off the motorway while traveling back from a trip to a farm in Taichung. Police are investigating whether the bus was speeding at the time of the crash. The victims were mostly older Taiwanese citizens, and 12 are still being treated in hospital with serious injuries. Authorities have condemned the incident, with Taiwan President Tsai Ing-Wen vowing to "make all efforts to save the injured people and properly handle the aftermath."

site_title: Hitler doppelganger arrested in Austria
summary: Austrian police arrested a 25-year-old man, self-identifying as "Harald Hitler", in Braunau am Inn, the birth town of Adolf Hitler, for promoting Nazi ideology. The suspect was detained under a 1947 Austrian law and offered no resistance. Authorities became aware of him after photos emerged on social media showing him posing outside Hitler's birth house and in traditional garb. The arrest highlights Braunau's historical ties to Hitler and the ongoing controversy surrounding the town's dilapidated birth house, which was recently expropriated by the government.

site_title: FotoGraft evolves to stay in race
summary: Fotograph (FotoGraft) has evolved from a sports event photo analysis tool to an end-to-end service, including a race pack vending machine, after its initial business in Facebook analytics declined. The company's founder, Mr. Huang, had created FotoGraft's initial module to identify runners in photos via their bibs, but it faced resistance from event organizers. After securing funding, FotoGraft expanded its services, but failed to gain traction. Now, the company is launching a new, more comprehensive service, which includes a race pack vending machine, after six years of development.

site_title: Four dead in massive French Alps avalanche
summary: A devastating avalanche in the French Alps claimed the lives of four people, including a father and son, their half-brother, and a guide, while snowboarding in the popular resort of Tignes. The accident occurred at an altitude of 2,100 meters, with witnesses reporting a 400-meter-wide wall of snow and ice ripping down the mountain. The incident was the deadliest in the French Alps since the start of the winter season, with a total of seven lives lost this winter.

images.alt_text: A French father and son, as well as his half-brother and their guide died Monday in the French Alps after being swept away by a giant avalanche while snowboarding in the popular resort of Tignes, officials said.

site_title: China's pain, Italy's gain: high costs push textile buyers west
summary: China's textile industry is facing increased competition from Western suppliers, particularly Italy, due to rising labor, raw material, and energy costs. China's labor costs have risen 12% annually, outpacing the economy, making it less competitive on price. Italy's proximity to European markets and better technology are advantages, with some international brands switching to Italian wool fabrics. China's textile exports to the EU have dropped 4.1% in October, and buyers are turning to Turkey and other countries for fabrics due to quality and price.

images.alt_text: International textiles buyers are increasingly switching away from China, and back to Western suppliers, as rising labour, raw material and energy costs make the world's dominant producer more expensive.

site_title: Europe: Shares rise to 13-month high on miners strength, M&A news
summary: European shares rose 0.8% to a 13-month high, driven by mining stocks reaching a 2-1/2-year high due to rising copper prices. Mergers and acquisitions also fueled gains, with German drugmaker Stada reaching a record high after receiving takeover offers. Steel and mining company ArcelorMittal and Anglo American were top gainers, while Renault and Peugeot benefited from upgrades. The CAC 40 outperformed peers, closing up 1.2% despite concerns over an upcoming French election.

site_title: Bafta names La La Land best film
summary: La La Land won five British Bafta movie awards, including best film, best director, and best actress, Emma Stone. The film also took home awards for cinematography and original music. Despite losing in six categories, the win solidifies its Oscar success later this month. The ceremony featured several political messages, with winners praising the power of film to speak out against social issues.

site_title: The real Dodd-Frank scandal
summary: Treasury Secretary Timothy Geithner argues that much of the public's understanding of the Dodd-Frank Act, enacted in response to the 2008 financial crisis, is incorrect. He suggests that the US banking system has become stronger, with banks holding more capital and a more stable base of funds. However, Geithner also warns that a financial crisis is "certain at some point" and that the system is not self-correcting. He criticizes Dodd-Frank for crippling the government's ability to intervene in future crises, restricting the Federal Reserve's power to lend to individual institutions. Geithner's essay argues that the law's restrictions will lead to a future, self-inflicted wound if not revised.

site_title: UN Security Council unanimously condemns North Korea missile launch
summary: The UN Security Council unanimously condemned North Korea's ballistic missile launch, describing it as a "grave violation" of UN resolutions. The US, Japan, and South Korea requested the meeting after North Korea tested a new missile on Sunday, the first launch since President Trump took office. Council members, including China, agreed to take "further significant measures" against Pyongyang.

site_title: Great Eastern's profits hit by steeper medical claims, new business strain
summary: Great Eastern Holdings reported a 25% decline in full-year profit to S$589.3 million due to steeper medical claims and increased new business strain. The insurance arm of OCBC Bank saw a 11% year-on-year drop in net profit to S$195.2 million in the fourth quarter. The decline was attributed to higher new sales volume and increased claims.

site_title: Yellen unlikely to rule out March hike in US Congress testimony
summary: Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen is expected to testify before Congress, defending post-crisis banking rules amid potential changes favored by the Trump administration. Yellen is unlikely to rule out a March interest-rate hike, despite few investors anticipating a move, and will instead keep the possibility open. The hearings also focus on Yellen's stance on proposed changes to the central bank's authority and structure, as well as her response to the Trump administration's fiscal policies.

site_title: Trump looks like a net negative on economic growth: Goldman
summary: Goldman Sachs' chief economist Jan Hatzius and Jari Stehn have expressed concerns that President Donald Trump's agenda will hinder economic growth. They anticipate a delayed boost from increased government spending due to a possible bill not passing until late 2017 or early 2018. The economists also note that the more adverse parts of the Trump agenda remain substantial, posing a net negative impact on economic growth.

site_title: US Senate expected to confirm Mnuchin as Treasury secretary
summary: The US Senate is expected to confirm former Goldman Sachs banker Steven Mnuchin as Treasury secretary on Monday, with a likely party-line 52-48 vote. Mnuchin's appointment signals the Trump administration's trust in bankers and senior business executives, reversing a trend under former President Barack Obama. Mnuchin's focus will shift to tax reform, financial services deregulation, and international economic diplomacy, with a Group of 20 finance ministers meeting in March.

site_title: New York subway's slide in service leaves commuters fuming
summary: New York City subway riders are frustrated with the declining service quality, with delays more than doubling over the last five years. According to data from the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, the system's reliability has dropped significantly. This marks a reversal of the improvements seen in the past, leaving commuters angry and concerned about the impact on the city's transportation infrastructure.

site_title: Feel-good factor sends STI up 11 points
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 11.24 points or 0.4% to a 52-week high, driven by rosy economic data and Wall Street's strong showing after President Trump hinted at tax cuts and infrastructure spending. Other regional markets also gained, with Japan's Nikkei 225 and Hong Kong's Hang Seng up 0.4% and 0.6%, respectively. The gains were fueled by a positive start to the week, despite geopolitical concerns sparked by North Korea's weekend ballistic missile test.

site_title: CFE report could have included long-term macroeconomic issues
summary: The Committee on the Future Economy (CFE) report failed to address long-term macroeconomic issues, focusing instead on industry-specific initiatives. The report missed opportunities to discuss the viability of the current growth model, fiscal policy reform, and adapting to the sharing economy. Key concerns include the reliance on export-led growth, foreign capital, and labor, which may have reached a point of diminishing returns. The report also lacked specific ideas on fiscal policy reform, particularly in addressing income inequality and the impact of technological disruptions on the workforce.

site_title: Singapore remains a top FDI destination globally
summary: Singapore remains a top foreign direct investment (FDI) destination globally, ranking fifth in the world in 2016, despite a 23% drop in FDI inflows to US$50 billion. The decline was part of a global 13% drop in FDI flows to US$1.52 trillion. The United Nations Conference on Trade and Development (UNCTAD) predicts global FDI flows will recover by 10% in 2017, benefiting Singapore.

site_title: CEOs of major carmakers urge Trump to order review of 2025 fuel rules
summary: US CEOs of 18 major carmakers urge President Trump to review 2025 fuel efficiency rules, warning that thousands of jobs could be at risk. The rules, set by the Obama administration, require vehicles to achieve an average fleet-wide efficiency of over 50 miles per gallon through 2025. The CEOs, including those from General Motors, Ford, and Fiat Chrysler, have asked Trump to reopen the mid-term review process, citing significant costs and out-of-step consumer preferences. Environmentalists argue the rules are working, saving drivers thousands in fuel costs and should not be changed.

site_title: Treasury power vacuum leaves US open to policy mix-ups
summary: A leadership vacuum at the US Treasury Department, created by President Donald Trump's delayed confirmation of Steven Mnuchin as Secretary, is causing uncertainty in key areas of economic policy, including currency and sanctions. The lack of a confirmed Treasury chief has led to misinterpretation of recent policy moves, such as a brief rise in the Russian ruble due to unclear sanctions amendments. The delay also impacts the US$14 trillion Treasuries market and the debt ceiling, with Mnuchin expected to start planning how to address the debt ceiling by March 16.

site_title: China's Sinochem in early talks to buy stake in Noble: sources
summary: China's state-owned Sinochem is in early talks to buy a stake in Noble Group, a commodity trader, to gain access to its global supply chain. The discussions come as Noble seeks to restructure its business units, cut debt, and boost liquidity amid a long-term downtrend in commodity prices. A deal would help Sinochem expand its energy trading ambitions and support China's plans to develop its gas industry. The talks have not been completed, and there is no assurance that a deal will be finalized.

site_title: Billionaire Christo Wiese faces hurdles in attempt to combine assets
summary: South African billionaire Christo Wiese is attempting to combine the African operations of Shoprite Holdings Ltd and Steinhoff International Holdings NV, creating the continent's largest retailer. The proposal involves Shoprite buying Steinhoff's African retail assets in exchange for a significant equity interest. The deal would help Wiese consolidate his stake and potentially bring both companies under Steinhoff CEO Markus Jooste's control. However, the transaction faces opposition from minority shareholders and antitrust authorities, who may require the combined entity to sell assets or ensure job protection.

site_title: Canada firms nervous as Trudeau, Trump shake hands
summary: Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau is set to meet US President Donald Trump in Washington, sparking concerns among Canadian companies about a potential trade war. The two nations have a highly integrated economy, with trade in goods such as fertiliser and oil since signing free trade agreements 30 years ago. Trudeau's meeting with Trump has raised worries among Canadian businesses, who fear the US may impose tariffs on Canadian goods. The meeting takes place as the US has recently announced tariffs on Vietnam and other countries, highlighting the uncertainty surrounding global trade.

site_title: Singapore cargo volume and bunker sales up for January
summary: The Port of Singapore saw a surge in cargo volume and bunker sales in January, with total cargo throughput exceeding 50.5 million tonnes and bunker sales volume rising to 4.4 million tonnes. Containerized cargo volume increased to 2.62 million TEUs, while oil and non-oil bulk cargoes also saw significant growth. The port's bunker sales set a new world record for the calendar year 2016. The increase is attributed to the long-term agreement between CMA CGM and PSA, as well as the arrival of cargo ships ahead of the Chinese New Year holidays.

site_title: RBS said to plan US$1b cost cuts by trimming jobs, closing branches
summary: RBS is planning to cut £1 billion (S$1.78 billion) of annual operating costs by eliminating jobs and closing branches as it seeks to bolster profitability. Senior executives have determined the bank has more staff than required, and further job cuts are planned. The exact number of job reductions is not disclosed, but the move is aimed at reducing costs and improving the bank's financial health.

site_title: Don't assume new board will lead to good corporate governance
summary: A shareholder expressed concerns about the newly appointed directors of Natural Cool Holdings, questioning the independence of the independent directors and the process by which they were identified. The proposed directors claimed their questions were irrelevant, but the chairman intervened, allowing them to respond. The shareholder urged shareholders to attend the company's next annual general meeting to scrutinize the new board's decisions and strategies, citing the need for transparency and accountability in corporate governance.

site_title: Accordia Golf Trust Q3 DPU down 3.2%
summary: Accordia Golf Trust reported a 3.2% decline in its distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.09 Singapore cents in the third quarter, driven by lower operating income and distributable income. Operating income dropped 2.5% to 14.6 billion yen due to poor golf course performance and higher expenses. Net profit attributable to unitholders fell 11% to 2.95 billion yen. The trust manager expects Japan's economy to recover gradually, but notes downside risks such as yen appreciation and a potential world economic slowdown.

site_title: A*Star to undergo major restructuring
summary: A*STAR, Singapore's lead public sector agency for research and development, will undergo a major restructuring to keep up with the rapidly evolving biomedical industry and meet the Committee on the Future Economy's objectives. The restructuring aims to create an entire ecosystem connecting industry, knowledge base, and deployable solutions, ultimately driving economic value and jobs for Singaporeans. A*STAR will also establish new centers, such as the Experimental Biologics Centre, to advance small-molecule and large-molecule drug discovery, and adopt domain-based and multi-disciplinary approaches to foster impactful research.

site_title: Committee to review wages, training in lift industry
summary: The Building and Construction Authority (BCA) announced a new committee to review wages and training in the lift and escalator industry in Singapore. The committee, comprising representatives from the government, trade unions, and industry associations, aims to attract and retain locals in the sector. The move comes after the sector experienced a spate of incidents involving lift malfunctions, leading to new regulations requiring monthly maintenance contracts and annual permits. The committee will set minimum qualifications and explore career progression pathways, with an estimated 1,000 additional technicians needed in the next three years.

site_title: Local start-up launches vending machines that can dispense race packs
summary: A local start-up, GenieAgent, has launched a vending machine, FotoGraft, that can dispense race packs to participants. The machine, which was launched in Singapore, can reduce costs by at least 50% compared to traditional methods. Participants can collect their race packs by scanning their identification card or verification slip. The machine also prints race bibs and allocates RFID chips, which can help organisers manage event logistics. GenieAgent plans to expand the service overseas, targeting Asian cities with high manpower costs, and is seeking venture capital to support its growth.

site_title: Aussie banks narrow focus of Apple Pay dispute to tech access
summary: Australia's four major banks have narrowed their dispute with Apple over mobile payment system Apple Pay to focus solely on access to iPhone's near-field communications (NFC) antenna. The banks, which include Commonwealth Bank, National Australia Bank, Westpac, and Bendigo & Adelaide Bank, had initially sought permission to negotiate together to boost their bargaining power with Apple. The Australian Competition & Consumer Commission (ACCC) had previously refused permission, but the banks claim Apple's restrictions on NFC access would give the company a stranglehold on the market.

site_title: House of Commons endorses May's vision of 'hard' Brexit
summary: The UK House of Commons has endorsed Prime Minister Theresa May's vision of a 'hard' Brexit, approving the Article 50 legislation needed to trigger formal exit talks with the European Union. The chamber's majority approved the legislation unamended, paving the way for a possible trigger of Article 50 at the EU Summit on March 9. The outcome also aligns with May's previously stated schedule, and the government has confirmed that Parliament will have votes on the future terms of the UK's relationship with the EU.

site_title: Vallianz faces pressure on gross profit margin
summary: Vallianz Holdings reported a 13.2% increase in fourth-quarter profit to US$4.66 million, but its gross profit margin decreased to 26.7% due to lower charter rates. Revenue fell 11.9% to US$41.38 million, and the company's focus on expanding vessel chartering and brokerage business led to a 20% decline in vessel management revenue. Full-year profit decreased 20.9% to US$13.81 million. The company is reviewing rightsizing initiatives and assessing asset value amid market conditions.

site_title: America's checks and balances in action
summary: US President Donald Trump's executive order banning visitors from seven mainly Muslim countries has sparked controversy and legal challenges. The order, which was made in January, was challenged in court by several states and ultimately blocked by a federal judge in Seattle. However, the US Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit upheld the ruling, allowing immigrants and travellers to enter the US. The ruling highlights the system of checks and balances in the US government, where the executive, legislative, and judicial branches work together to ensure that power is not concentrated in one branch.

images.alt_text: Although most legal specialists agree that Mr Trump was within his right to order the immigration ban, there is also a general consensus that the execution of the order was chaotic, opening the door for the legal challenges.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Yoma Strategic Holdings and 800 Super Holdings are analyzed by DBS Group Research and Phillip Capital Research, respectively. Yoma's improved operating outlook post Myanmar's new government is a key factor, with the company set to meet FY17 forecast targets. 800 Super Holdings is expected to benefit from its non-real estate segments, with the company taking on more debt to fund the construction of its sludge treatment facility. Both companies are expected to deliver upside to earnings and target prices.

site_title: NTU and CleanTech Park to serve as urban mobility testbed
summary: NTU and the CleanTech Park in Singapore are set to become a live testbed for alternative urban mobility options, including e-bikes and autonomous driverless vehicles. The Mobility-as-a-Service (MaaS) Lab was launched with a memorandum of understanding between SMRT, JTC Corporation, and NTU. The testbed aims to address the "last mile" commute issue, with plans to introduce alternative transport options and a mobile application for commuters to plan journeys and select preferred transport choices. The testbed is expected to be set up within 12 months, with full application to follow in the next few years.

site_title: Samsung scion summoned again by prosecutors over corruption scandal
summary: Prosecutors in South Korea have summoned Lee Jae Yong, vice-chairman of Samsung Electronics, for questioning in connection with a corruption scandal that led to the impeachment of President Park Geun Hye. This is the latest in a series of probes into the scandal, which has rocked the nation. Lee Jae Yong, the son of Samsung group chairman Lee Kun Hee, has been quizzed multiple times over his alleged role in the scandal. The investigation continues to unfold.

site_title: Adele wins big at Grammys with five awards
summary: Adele won five Grammy Awards, including Album, Record, and Song of the Year, making her the first act to sweep these categories in two different years. She paid tribute to Beyoncé, calling her an idol, and also honored late rock icon David Bowie, who won five awards posthumously. Beyoncé won two awards, including Best Urban Contemporary Album for her album "Lemonade." The ceremony also featured performances by Lady Gaga, Metallica, and Bruno Mars, with a focus on themes of motherhood, empowerment, and social justice.

site_title: Japan GDP stays on growth path in Q4
summary: Japan's economy expanded for a fourth consecutive quarter in Q4 2016, with a 1% real GDP growth, driven by increased exports to the US and China. Private consumption, accounting for 60% of the economy, fell for the first time in four quarters, marking a 0.1% decline. Analysts warn that US protectionist policies, potentially leading to a weaker yen, could harm Japan's exports and end the country's quarterly GDP growth streak.

site_title: Apec still a distance away from goal of free, open trade: Hng Kiang
summary: Singapore's Minister for Trade and Industry Lim Hng Kiang stated that the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (Apec) is still far from achieving its goal of free and open trade, but economic integration should remain a priority. Apec's vision is to promote growth through greater economic cooperation and integration across the Asia-Pacific.

site_title: The Prospex back on the market, with lower price tag
summary: The Prospex, a nine-storey retail and office building in Singapore, is back on the market with an indicative guide price of over S$70 million, significantly lower than its previous asking price of S$80 million. The building is 85% leased and has a 99-year leasehold tenure, with a balance term of approximately 57 years. The sale could attract buyers looking to invest in a newly refurbished income-producing asset, and the building's prime location near Bugis MRT Station may also appeal to owner occupiers.

site_title: Amazon reimagines retail with quirky experiments on Seattle Streets
summary: Amazon is testing various retail experiments in Seattle, including a drive-up grocery store concept where customers order online, schedule a pickup time, and pick up their items in designated stalls. The company is also developing a convenience store concept, Amazon Go, that uses sensors to allow customers to check out without a cashier. Amazon's goal is to capture a bigger share of shopping that may never move entirely online, particularly in the food category. The company is using Seattle as a lab to test new ideas, with over 25,000 employees serving as test cases.

site_title: Germany Inc zones in on risks threatening economy's fortitude
summary: Germany's economy is performing well, with a 0.5% increase in gross domestic product in the fourth quarter, and wholesale prices rising 4% in January. However, some top firms, such as Siemens and Thyssenkrupp, have expressed concerns about global risks, including US President Donald Trump's policies. Industry leaders, including the European Central Bank and Bundesbank, warn of potential economic uncertainty, while the BGA association of exporters predicts "catastrophic" consequences of US trade policies. Despite this, the economy is expected to continue growing, with the European Commission set to update its forecasts on Monday.

site_title: Invest in employees' development
summary: A recent article emphasizes the importance of investing in employees' development for an organization's competitiveness in a slow-growth global economy. The IMF, World Bank, and OECD predict a decade-long productivity growth crisis, with businesses needing to adapt to disruptions from geopolitical tensions and rapid technological changes. To succeed, organizations must prioritize employee development, including self-leadership, coaching culture, and fostering a culture that focuses on employees' growth. By doing so, companies can enhance their business outcomes, achieve strategic objectives, and navigate the increasingly volatile, uncertain, complex, and ambiguous (VUCA) business environment.

site_title: Population trends a fillip for Japan's boutique advisers on micro-M&A
summary: Japan's boutique advisers specializing in micro-M&A are experiencing a boom as the country's shrinking population forces family-run firms to merge or sell to cope with dwindling demand. Boutique advisers like Nihon M&A Center and Strike Co have seen significant growth, brokering a combined 512 deals in the last financial year. This trend is expected to continue, with Yasuhiro Wakebayashi, chairman of Nihon M&A Center, predicting a bigger M&A market as small companies are forced to grow by merging with larger firms.

site_title: Beijing calls for restraint on Pyongyang as UN prepares to meet
summary: China has called for restraint from North Korea ahead of an emergency UN Security Council meeting, amid a recent ballistic missile test. China's foreign ministry opposed the test and urged all parties to avoid escalating tensions. The US and China may find common ground on North Korea's nuclear programme, but no guarantee of progress exists. The UN Security Council will meet to discuss the issue, while the US has deployed a missile-defence system in South Korea, opposed by China.

site_title: Despite diesel scandal, new models coming to US
summary: Ford and General Motors are set to introduce new or revamped diesel vehicles to the US market despite the Volkswagen diesel emissions scandal. Ford will offer a 3.0-litre diesel engine in its F-150 pick-up truck, while GM plans to launch diesel versions of the Chevrolet Equinox and GMC Terrain. Mazda is also introducing a diesel SUV, the CX-5, in the second half of 2017. Diesel engines still offer better mileage than petrol engines, making them an attractive option for meeting US regulatory requirements.

site_title: US$ hits 2-week high against yen
summary: The US dollar reached a two-week high against the yen, driven by expectations of potential interest rate hikes by the Federal Reserve, following testimony by Janet Yellen this week. The dollar's strength was also boosted by President Trump's promise of tax reform and infrastructure spending. The yen weakened, hitting its lowest in a month, while China's yuan also fell due to the dollar's strength. Analysts expect the dollar to continue its upward trend, with some warning of a potential "bull run" for the currency.

site_title: CH2M Hill to be design consultant for Tuas water plant
summary: Singapore's National water agency PUB has appointed US-based CH2M Hill Singapore as the detailed design consultant for the Tuas Water Reclamation Plant (WRP), a S$6.5 billion project. Construction will start in the second half of next year, with multiple construction tenders and an expected completion in 2029. The plant will use membrane bioreactor technology to treat domestic and industrial used water, producing NEWater and reusing industrial water. It will be the largest MBR facility in the world, with an initial capacity of 176 million gallons per day.

site_title: Australia's ruling coalition divided by vote deal with One Nation
summary: Australia's ruling Liberal-National coalition is divided over a vote-sharing deal with far-right party One Nation, following Western Australian state premier Colin Barnett's agreement to swap preference votes. The deal, announced ahead of state elections, has split the centre-right coalition and raised concerns about the influence of One Nation, which advocates protectionism and anti-immigration policies. The move has also weakened embattled Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull, who faces a potential minority government.

site_title: Most prefer Founders' Memorial to be built at Gardens by the Bay
summary: Most Singaporeans (72%) prefer the Founders' Memorial to be built at the Bay East Garden of Gardens by the Bay, citing its spaciousness and visitor-friendly location. The site offers a forward-looking narrative and potential for future development, with the committee noting its accessibility to all groups. The 13-member committee plans a third phase of public engagement, a showcase at Gardens by the Bay, and will present its final report and recommendations to the government in the middle of the year.

images.alt_text: The Founders' Memorial Committee says the Bay East Garden at Gardens by the Bay (above) and the surrounding Marina Bay, having been created from nothing, better brings out Singapore's developmental story since independence.

site_title: UK house prices hit record as shortage worsens
summary: The average UK home price reached a record £300,169 in January, a 0.3% increase, according to a report by Acadata and LSL. This marks an annual growth of 3.1%, with prices now doubling what they were in 2002. The supply-demand imbalance is driving the upward trend, as UK homebuyer demand rebounds to a six-month high.

site_title: Oops, wrong Trump
summary: A Dominican newspaper, El Nacional, apologized for publishing a photo of actor Alec Baldwin in his satirical role as US President Donald Trump, alongside an article about Israeli settlements, instead of the actual Trump. The mix-up was in the Friday edition, which went unnoticed by reviewers. Trump attacked Baldwin and the late-night show on Twitter, while Baldwin received critical praise for his performance. The gaffe might be the highest compliment yet for Baldwin's impersonation.

site_title: Entrepreneurs can drive Singapore's growth if they begin working together
summary: Singapore's small to medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) generate more revenue from exports than any other country, accounting for over half of the nation's GDP. However, these businesses often struggle to secure funding and make the transition to multinational companies. A new model, agglomeration, is proposed to empower entrepreneurs by allowing them to form a collective holding company that goes public, providing access to capital and scale. This approach enables entrepreneurs to retain operational control while benefiting from increased share liquidity and a larger network, ultimately driving business growth and job creation.

site_title: Analysts embrace SingPost's e-commerce goals despite impairment risk
summary: SingPost released its third-quarter results, flagging a risk of "significant" impairment to its US e-commerce business TradeGlobal. Despite analysts' initial optimism, the company's warning led to a 4.4% decline in shares. Analysts, including Deutsche Bank and Nomura Research, remain bullish on SingPost's e-commerce goals, citing the company's scale, infrastructure, and leverage. However, some analysts, such as CIMB Research, have cut their target prices due to the impairment risk. SingPost's net profit dropped 28% to S$31.4 million, while revenue rose 17% to S$369.4 million.

site_title: China tech tycoons' healthcare dreams dashed by reality
summary: China's tech tycoons, including Alibaba's Jack Ma, Baidu's Robin Li, and Tencent's Pony Ma, initially envisioned a lucrative healthcare market with online consultations, pharmacies, and drug tracking. However, regulatory changes and a lack of an insurer willing to work with internet firms have crippled these ventures. Investment in China's digital health industry has declined, and at least 26 startups have shut down. Billionaires are reevaluating their healthcare ambitions, with Baidu focusing on medical AI and Tencent-backed WeDoctor expanding its offline hospital presence. Despite challenges, entrepreneurs remain optimistic about the potential of online health, with Alibaba planning to expand its online pharmacy business.

site_title: Carter makes a stand for solar with power project in his hometown
summary: Former US President Jimmy Carter has launched a small-scale solar power project on his family's farmland in Plains, Georgia, nearly 38 years after installing solar panels at the White House. The 3,852-panel project can power over half the town and has been years in the making. Carter hopes it will demonstrate the economic benefits of renewable energy and provide jobs, contradicting President Trump's skepticism about the costs of such energy sources. The project earns Carter's family less than $7,000 annually.

site_title: UK tech firm Dyson opens R&D centre in Singapore
summary: UK tech firm Dyson opened its new research and development centre in Singapore, bringing its total investment to £330 million. The centre focuses on advanced manufacturing, software development, and robotics, and will add 190 jobs, including 160 research scientist and engineer positions. Dyson, which employs 1,100 people in Singapore, plans to grow its engineering team by 50%. The move is seen as a testament to the strong partnership between Singapore and Dyson, and aims to position Singapore as an innovation-led economy.

site_title: Valentine's chocolate gets cheaper as global cocoa supply swells
summary: Valentine's Day chocolates may be cheaper this year due to a global cocoa supply surge. Latin American and West African growers have collected bigger harvests, pushing cocoa futures to their lowest since 2008. This has cut costs for confection makers like Mondelez International, the maker of Cadbury chocolates and Oreo cookies. As a result, hedge funds are betting on lower prices, with a record net-short position of 24,320 futures and options. The trend is expected to continue, with prices potentially falling further in the coming months, making chocolates more affordable for consumers.

site_title: PCRD up 15% on news of associate's stake sale
summary: PCRD shares rose 14.7% to 39 Singapore cents after its associate PCCW sold its 51.97% stake in HKT Trust & HKT Ltd, Hong Kong's largest telecoms company, for HK$10.15 apiece. PCCW will recognize approximately HK$7.6 billion from the sale. The deal is part of PCCW's strategic shift towards core media and solutions businesses. The sale is expected to have no impact on PCRD's earnings per share for the current financial year.

site_title: Could SingX be a global payments disruptor?
summary: Fintech start-up SingX has launched an online remittance platform backed by former bankers, aiming to disrupt the global payments industry by offering customers a 90% reduction in typical remittance charges. The platform, which has raised $2.5 million, plans to expand to other countries, including Malaysia, Hong Kong, and Australia, and has launched its Singapore-India corridor. SingX's focus on consumers with bank accounts and small and medium enterprises, as well as its rigorous verification process, sets it apart from other fintech start-ups.

site_title: US trial set over bitcoin exchange linked to JPMorgan hack probe
summary: A Florida software engineer, Yuri Lebedev, and a New Jersey pastor, Trevon Gross, are set to face trial in Manhattan federal court over their alleged involvement in a bitcoin exchange linked to a JPMorgan hack probe. Prosecutors claim Lebedev schemed to deceive financial institutions and bribed Gross to gain control over a credit union, facilitating the virtual currency business. Lebedev and Gross have pleaded not guilty, and their trial is expected to begin on Monday.

images.alt_text: A Florida software engineer and a New Jersey pastor are expected on Monday to face trial in a case stemming from an investigation into a bitcoin exchange and a data breach at JPMorgan Chase & Co.

site_title: Tweak our tax policies to lend a hand to SMEs
summary: The Singapore government is urged to tweak its tax policies to support Small and Medium-sized Enterprises (SMEs) amidst uncertainties. The government can consider introducing a condition to the start-up tax exemption scheme to prevent abuse and fine-tune the scheme to allow a 75% tax exemption for the first $100,000 of income. The partial tax exemption scheme can also be increased to $175,000, and the corporate income tax rebate can be extended to YA 2019 and 2020. Additionally, the carry back relief system can be increased to $200,000 with flexibility to claim up to two preceding years.

site_title: China's developers to invest more in land this year
summary: Chinese real estate developers plan to increase their land investments in 2017, despite record prices and government tightening measures. Eight of the top 10 developers surveyed by Reuters said they would boost their budgets by 10-50% to expand market share and counter competition. They focus on Tier 1 cities and Tier 2 cities, while shunning smaller cities. The move is seen as a strategy to gain economies of scale and maintain growth momentum, but may also pose challenges for authorities trying to prevent property price increases.

site_title: Renault CEO: France sale would allow Nissan stake shift
summary: Renault CEO Carlos Ghosn suggests that France's sale of its stake in the company could allow Nissan to increase its involvement, potentially shifting the alliance's imbalanced shareholdings. Nissan currently owns 15% of Renault with no voting rights, while Renault has 45%. The French government's 20% stake has thwarted Nissan's efforts to gain more sway. A sale of the French stake could pave the way for Nissan to increase its influence, but Ghosn notes that "nothing will change" until the French government acts.

site_title: Trump, Brexit elevating economic risks for euro area: European Commission
summary: The European Commission warns of heightened economic risks for the euro area due to Brexit and the election of Donald Trump. The commission forecasts 1.6% GDP growth for 2017, slower than 1.7% last year, and 1.8% for 2018. The UK's economy is expected to grow 1.5% in 2017, while France's economy will grow 1.4%, Italy's 0.9%, and Spain's 2.3%. Inflation is expected to average 1.7% in 2017, below the European Central Bank's goal of 2%. The commission notes that medium-term threats include Brexit, trade disruptions, and rising debt in China.

images.alt_text: The European Commission upgraded its forecast for Germany. Yet, with an increase in GDP of 1.6 per cent, that's still less than the 1.9 per cent growth rate it witnessed in 2016, the commission said.

site_title: ST Telemedia adds to its data centre portfolio
summary: ST Telemedia Global Data Centres (STT GDC) has added three colocation facilities in Singapore, expanding its portfolio to include STT Defu and STT MediaHub. The deal, part of a joint venture with Tata Communications, enhances STT GDC's presence in the data centre business segment in Singapore. With five facilities totaling over 540,000 square feet, STT GDC is now one of the largest and geographically diversified data centre companies in Singapore.

site_title: Metro Q3 net hit by lower contributions from associates
summary: Metro Holdings' Q3FY17 net profit plummeted 63.3% to S$20.49 million due to lower contributions from associates, primarily from the Nanchang project and Top Spring. Revenue fell 9% to S$37.3 million, impacted by the closure of Metro City Square department store and weaker renminbi. Occupancy rate for investment properties remained stable at 91.1%. Earnings per share fell to 2.5 Singapore cents, and general administrative expenses decreased to S$6 million.

site_title: Tycoon eyes StanChart's Indonesia bank stake in march to top
summary: Indonesian business tycoon Tahir's Mayapada Group is seeking to acquire a 90% stake in PT Bank Permata, a rival bank, to merge it with Bank Mayapada International and become the nation's largest non-government bank. Standard Chartered and PT Astra International own 45% each in Permata. Tahir aims to expand Bank Mayapada's footprint and compete with state-run lenders and PT Bank Central Asia. The move is seen as a strategic move to tackle bad loans at Permata and capitalize on Indonesia's growing economy.

site_title: MAS to boost financing options for Asia's growth companies
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is launching a series of initiatives to boost financing options for growth companies in Asia. The initiatives include developing better technology infrastructure, simplifying regulatory frameworks, and promoting innovation. MAS will also study the use of dual-class share structures and assess successful private-market financing platforms to support high-tech companies. Additionally, MAS will simplify authorisation processes for venture capital managers and boost the role of finance companies that provide small and medium-sized enterprise (SME) lending. The moves aim to provide a conducive environment for innovation and support the growth of financial services in Singapore.

site_title: HPH Trust dives on dismal outlook, ratings downgrades
summary: Hutchison Port Holdings Trust (HPH Trust) saw a significant decline in value, falling 6.8% to 41 US cents, after releasing its fourth-quarter results and facing downbeat outlooks from brokerages. The trust cited "high level of uncertainty" in the US administration, weak consumer sentiment, and high unemployment rates as factors impacting its performance. Rating downgrades by DBS, OCBC, and Citi followed, citing a cautious outlook on global trade and lower distribution per unit.

site_title: Trump said to tap David Malpass for international Treasury post
summary: US President Donald Trump plans to nominate David Malpass, a former Bear Stearns economist, as US Treasury undersecretary for international affairs. Malpass, 60, has extensive government experience and will report to the Treasury secretary on international economic relationships, particularly with China. His appointment comes as the administration navigates trade policies and currency manipulation, which may violate a G-20 pact. Malpass's views on the Federal Reserve's asset purchases and his potential to influence US-China relations are expected to shape the economic team.

images.alt_text: If confirmed by the Senate, Mr Malpass, (left) a former Bear Stearns economist, would bring extensive government experience to an economic team that has little background in public service.

site_title: China's monetary toolbox sowing market volatility
summary: China's central bank has introduced a range of new monetary tools, including the Medium-term Lending Facility (MLF) and Temporary Liquidity Facility (TLF), to manage liquidity and tackle economic growth, currency weakness, and swelling debt. However, these tools have sowed market volatility, as investors struggle to interpret policy intentions behind the new instruments. The tools have led to a bond selloff, driving yields to an 11/2-year high, and have sparked concerns about tighter liquidity. Experts say the policy mix is juggling multiple objectives, leading to volatile policy decisions.

site_title: Technology a way to mitigate manpower shortage in healthcare
summary: Singapore is addressing its healthcare manpower shortage through technology, with the Infocomm Media 2025 Masterplan aiming to provide patients with remote access to healthcare services. Smart Health-Assist (SHA) employs wearables and sensors to monitor patients' vital signs and conditions remotely, allowing healthcare providers to intervene early and reducing hospital readmissions. Data analysis and machine learning are key components in improving patient care, and experts like Dr. Eric Wong believe that technology will play a significant role in the next 5-10 years, enabling doctors to predict treatment responses and provide better care.

site_title: VW CEO slams infighting as spat escalates over worker agreement
summary: Volkswagen CEO Matthias Mueller addressed internal conflicts and labor disputes at the company, seeking to calm nerves amid a diesel-cheating scandal. Mueller vowed to resolve conflicts, citing the need for concentration to overcome the crisis. Renewed tensions with labor leaders and allegations from former chairman Ferdinand Piech threatened to disrupt efforts to implement a planned overhaul. Mueller promised to implement the Future Pact, a cost-cutting plan signed in November, and to weigh in more strongly on its implementation. The tension remains unresolved, with a meeting between labor leaders and management adjourned without result.

site_title: Manulife US Reit's Q4 DPU 3.6% above forecast (Amended)
summary: Manulife US Reit reported a 3.6% increase in its fourth-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.54 US cents, surpassing its forecast. The Reit attributed the increase to higher rental and other income, and lower property expenses. CEO Jill Smith attributed the positive outcome to US President Donald Trump's pro-business policies, which she believes will boost the commercial property market. The Reit also expects no impact from the US Federal Reserve interest rate hikes, as its borrowings are at fixed interest rates.

site_title: Alibaba-backed S'pore firm has key to new mobile security lock
summary: A Singaporean company backed by Alibaba, V-Key, is partnering with a government agency to introduce a new mobile security lock based on biometric authentication, replacing traditional 2-factor authentication via SMS. This move comes amid concerns that SMS-based authentication is not secure, as hackers can intercept messages and authoritarian governments can compel telco companies to block SMS messages. V-Key's approach uses biometric information, such as fingerprints, selfies, or retina scans, to verify transactions, and secures it at the application level. The partnership aims to improve mobile transaction security and financial inclusion in Asia.

site_title: Asia's potential trade hot spots escaping Trump's glare for now
summary: US President Donald Trump has largely avoided targeting trade deficits with India, Indonesia, Malaysia, and Vietnam, despite running significant trade deficits with these countries. However, Trump's protectionist policies and threats of tariffs may yet lead to a trade war, potentially harming growth. Countries that run trade deficits with the US, such as Vietnam, are vulnerable to Trump's ire. Despite this, some countries, like Japan and Vietnam, are proactively engaging with the US to ward off potential trade tensions.

site_title: Regulators play vital role in creating environment that fosters innovation
summary: Singapore's regulators play a vital role in fostering innovation in the financial services sector. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has implemented a "regulatory sandbox" environment to support fintech companies and encourage risk-taking. This approach balances innovation with regulatory safeguards, allowing for the development of new products and services. The success of this approach is exemplified by the MAS's efforts to support fintech startups, with venture capital-backed funding in Asian fintechs growing 50% to US$1.2 billion in the third quarter of 2016.

site_title: Tensions and chaos rattle US National Security Council
summary: The US National Security Council is experiencing tensions and chaos, with many staff members disturbed by overt partisanship from President Donald Trump. The council staff struggles to create policy in line with Trump's Twitter posts, and they are often kept in the dark about his phone calls with foreign leaders. This lack of transparency is hindering the council's effectiveness in managing the president's dealings with the world. The situation is causing anxiety among council staff, and it remains to be seen how the administration will navigate these challenges.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Ley Choon Group posted a net profit of S$8.76 million for the third quarter, up from a net loss of S$2.85 million a year ago. Jumbo Group's earnings jumped 26.1% to S$2.6 million, driven by revenue growth from its Shanghai outlets. Hyflux will build three desalination plants in Saudi Arabia, valued at S$260.3 million. Rowsley's executive chairman will step down and take on a non-executive role, while RSP Architects will continue to be led by managing directors Lee and Lai.

site_title: Toshiba's nuclear reactor mess leads back to a Louisiana swamp
summary: Toshiba is set to announce a multibillion-dollar write-down on its nuclear reactor business, potentially as large as $6.1 billion, due to cost overruns at Westinghouse Electric Co, a Toshiba subsidiary. The issue stems from four nuclear reactor projects in Georgia and South Carolina, which were overseen by Westinghouse and involved the Louisiana-based pipe manufacturer Shaw Group Inc. Toshiba's nuclear renaissance bet has failed, and the company may exit the construction business altogether, focusing on design and maintenance. The write-down may force Toshiba to sell off assets and has already led to a decline in the company's stock value.

site_title: Data suggests Swiss National Bank intervention to trim rising franc
summary: The Swiss National Bank (SNB) intervened in currency markets to temper the rising Swiss franc, according to rising sight deposits. The franc rose to 1.067 per euro, its strongest level since June's Brexit vote. Economists believe the SNB likely stepped in to mitigate the franc's rise, with the central bank sticking to its policy of negative interest rates and currency intervention. The franc is expected to remain strong, but at a lower level than previously predicted, around 1.06 francs per euro by year-end. The SNB declined to comment on its activities.

site_title: Canadian support of Nafta grows with Trump vowing renegotiation
summary: Canadian support for the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA) has increased after US President Donald Trump vowed to renegotiate the pact, a poll from the Angus Reid Institute shows. 44% of Canadians now believe NAFTA has benefited the country, up from 25% last June. Canadians are also more open to renegotiation, with 56% expecting the agreement to be renegotiated, but only 10% think Canada will emerge better off. The shift in opinion comes as Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau prepares to meet with Trump to discuss economic ties between the two countries.

site_title: US: Wall Street extends record run as "Trump trade" reignites
summary: US stocks hit record intraday highs on Monday, driven by renewed optimism over the economy and President Donald Trump's potential tax and policy announcements.
