Indian and Chinese banks are looking to dispose of billions of dollars in soured loans, creating huge opportunities for players like Bain and Oaktree Capital Group. The fund, expected to launch in the first half of 2017, will focus on special situations investments.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks at 3-1/2-month high on Trump tax talk and China inflows
summary: Hong Kong stocks reached a 3-1/2-month high on Friday, driven by Wall Street's gains and capital inflows from China. The Hang Seng index rose 0.2% to 23,574.98 points, while the Hong Kong China Enterprises Index gained 0.5%. The market was also supported by rising southbound inflows through the Shanghai-Hong Kong Stock Connect, which used 24% of the daily quota. Investors largely shrugged off China's better-than-expected trade data in January.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets climb at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets rose at the start of trade on Friday, with London's FTSE 100 index up 0.5% to 7,262.54 points, and Frankfurt's DAX 30 and Paris CAC 40 also gaining 0.5% and 0.3% respectively.

site_title: Hundreds of thousands rally in Iran against Trump, chant "Death to America": TV
summary: Hundreds of thousands of Iranians gathered in Tehran's Azadi Square on the anniversary of the 1979 Islamic Revolution, chanting "Death to America" and waving "Death to America" banners and effigies of US President Donald Trump. The rally, called by Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, was in response to Trump's warning that he had put Iran "on notice" over a recent missile test. The demonstration showed strong anti-US sentiment, with many calling for confrontation with any "warmongering policies" and expressing solidarity with the US for opposing Trump's travel ban.

images.alt_text: Hundreds of thousands of Iranians rallied on Friday to swear allegiance to the clerical establishment following US President Donald Trump's warning that he had put the Islamic Republic "on notice", state TV reported.

site_title: China cash crunch test looms as US$151b set to leave system
summary: China is set to face a significant test of its campaign to contain corporate leverage as over US$151 billion in reverse-repurchase agreements and maturing loans are due to mature next week. The central bank will need to manage liquidity to prevent a cash crunch, similar to the one in 2013, which saw benchmark money rates soar to records. Commerzbank AG's senior economist Zhou Hao warns that "deleveraging will be a prolonged process" and could lead to "painful periods" for markets, unless the central bank adopts a sophisticated balancing act to maintain liquidity.

site_title: Gold down on Trump tax pledge, US rate hike expectations
summary: Gold prices fell 0.5% to $1,223.93 per ounce on Friday due to a firmer US dollar and expectations of a US rate hike. US President Donald Trump's promise of a major tax announcement boosted the dollar and led to a selloff in gold. Analysts expect gold to remain supported in the first half of 2017 due to risk aversion and global uncertainties.

site_title: IEA says record OPEC cut compliance helps oil market rebalance
summary: The International Energy Agency (IEA) reported that global oil output plummeted by 1.5 million barrels per day in January, exceeding a 90% compliance rate with OPEC's six-month output-cut deal. This rebalancing is expected to ease record oil stocks overhang by 600,000 barrels per day in the next six months. However, non-OPEC producers' rising output, expected to grow 0.4 million bpd in 2017, may slow market rebalancing, and high oil stocks and market caution are keeping Brent crude oil prices stable.

images.alt_text: Global oil output plunged in January as OPEC and non-OPEC producers curbed supply to accelerate a market rebalancing following one of the largest oil gluts in a generation, the International Energy Agency said on Friday.

site_title: Gucci, YSL shine as Kering profits beat forecast
summary: Kering, the parent company of luxury brands Gucci and Yves Saint Laurent, reported a 14.5% rise in recurring operating income and an 8.1% increase in group revenue in 2016, beating forecasts. Gucci's fourth-quarter sales rose 21.4%, driven by its revamped stores and "geek chic" look, while Yves Saint Laurent sales increased 20.5%. The strong performance was attributed to the successful revival of Gucci and strong sales at Yves Saint Laurent, despite a slowdown in Chinese tourist spending in Japan and Europe affecting Bottega Veneta.

site_title: Obamacare critic confirmed as US health secretary
summary: The US Senate confirmed Tom Price, a fierce Obamacare critic, as President Donald Trump's pick for health secretary, with 52 Republicans voting for and 47 Democrats against. Price, a former orthopedic surgeon and congressman from Georgia, aims to implement a Republican promise to repeal and replace the Affordable Care Act. Critics argue that his confirmation would harm millions of Americans who depend on the law, which has provided health coverage to 20 million Americans. Price was also accused of insider trading, but denied any wrongdoing.

site_title: Euro Disney says visitor numbers up in first quarter
summary: Euro Disney reported a 5% increase in revenues to €354 million (US$377 million) in the first quarter, driven by a 3% rise in park attendance and a 4% growth in hotel occupancy. This comes despite the ongoing state of emergency in France, which impacted the tourism environment. Park revenues rose to €194 million, while hotel revenues grew to €141 million. The company attributes the increase in attendance to French and British visitors, but notes that average spending per guest decreased due to lower ticket rates.

images.alt_text: Euro Disney, which operates Disneyland Paris, said Friday visitor numbers were up in the first quarter, despite the state of emergency that has been in place in France for over a year.

site_title: Seoul: Won weakens as Trump promises tax reform, stocks firmer
summary: South Korea's won dropped to its lowest in a week, closing at 1,150.6 to the dollar, as US President Donald Trump announced plans to lower business tax burdens. The won shed 0.4% on Friday and 0.3% for the week. However, South Korean shares rose 0.5% as Wall Street firmed on Trump's comments. Foreign investors sold Kospi shares worth 105 billion won.

site_title: Oil prices rise on strong Chinese imports, Opec-led production cuts
summary: Oil prices rose on Friday due to strong Chinese crude imports and Opec-led production cuts. Brent crude futures increased 5 US cents to US$55.68 per barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude futures rose 3 US cents to US$53.03 per barrel. Despite ample US fuel inventories, China's January crude imports of 34.03 million tonnes, or 8.01 million barrels per day, supported prices. Opec's production cuts, implemented to rein in global fuel supply, are estimated to be around 80-90% compliant, according to analysts.

site_title: Reckitt Benckiser agrees to buy Mead Johnson for US$16.6b
summary: Reckitt Benckiser has agreed to purchase Mead Johnson Nutrition Co for $16.6 billion, expanding into the baby-food market and increasing its presence in Asia. The deal, which includes paying $90 per share in cash, is expected to add $3.7 billion in annual sales, with half coming from Asia. The acquisition is expected to be "double-digit accretive" to earnings by the third year, with cost savings of $200 million by the end of the third year.

site_title: Australian heatwave causes firms to power down, Sydney braces for blackouts
summary: Australia is experiencing a severe heatwave, with temperatures reaching 40 degrees Celsius in parts of New South Wales and the Australian Capital Territory. To ease demand on strained power supplies, major energy users, including a paper mill and the Tomago aluminium smelter, have shut down operations. Residents are being asked to reduce their energy usage, with NSW Energy Minister Don Harwin advising against cooking or watching TV at home. The heatwave has sparked debate over the country's energy security, with a review of the national electricity market and energy policy underway.

site_title: GIC, Unite Students acquire student village in UK
summary: GIC and Unite Students have jointly acquired Aston Student Village in Birmingham, UK for £227 million (S$403 million) in a 50:50 joint venture. The acquisition, representing the first major on-campus purchase by GIC and Unite Student, comprises 3,067 beds across five properties on Aston University's campus. This marks a significant milestone for both parties, with ASV being their first major London Student Accommodation Joint Venture.

site_title: China yuan down, depreciation fears persist even as Trump sets to improve China-US ties
summary: China's yuan weakened against the US dollar, trading at 6.8777 per dollar, amid concerns about depreciation despite US President Donald Trump's efforts to improve relations with China. Trump agreed to honor the "One China" policy during a phone call with Xi Jinping, but yuan losses persist due to capital outflows and expectations of higher US interest rates. The yuan has fallen 6.6% in 2016 and is expected to decline further this year, with forecasts predicting a near-decade low of 7.18 per dollar.

site_title: Boeing eyes more Indian orders with new business unit
summary: Boeing is establishing a new business unit in India to win more orders and create employment in the country. The unit, which will be a separate legal entity, aims to support Boeing's Indian clients and grow its manufacturing presence. Boeing currently sources $500 million worth of products from India and plans to hire more staff, mostly locals, as it looks to win new deals. The move follows a similar strategy in other countries such as Britain, Australia, and Saudi Arabia, as Boeing seeks to tap into India's growing defence industry, expected to spend $250 billion over the next decade.

site_title: China said to assess impact of possible punitive US tariffs
summary: China is assessing the impact of possible punitive US tariffs, with the government asking companies to estimate the highest duties they can bear. This comes as US President Donald Trump threatens to label China a currency manipulator and impose tariffs, sparking concerns of escalating tensions. China's state-run Global Times newspaper described Trump's cabinet as forming an "iron curtain" of protectionism, further exacerbating the situation. The move is seen as a response to Trump's accusations of unfair trade practices and is likely to have significant implications for China's economy and trade relationships.

site_title: Vancouver's empty mansions highlight middle-class housing woes
summary: Vancouver's multimillion-dollar homes are increasingly out of reach for locals, with over 66,000 vacant or temporarily occupied dwellings as of last year. The city's affordability crisis is undermining its regional economy, with neighbourhoods hollowing out and public schools suffering from declining enrollment. A new tax on empty homes was introduced to boost rentals, but concerns persist over the city's transformation into a luxury real estate playground, pricing out the middle class and squeezing industry and jobs.

site_title: China, US warplanes had 'unsafe' South China Sea encounter
summary: US and Chinese warplanes had an "unsafe" encounter over the South China Sea, with a Chinese KJ-200 surveillance plane and a US Navy P-3C Orion flying within 1,000 feet of each other near the Scarborough Shoal. The incident is the first publicly confirmed since May 2016, amid heightened tensions between the two countries. China claims 80% of the South China Sea, while the US supports the Philippines' claims. The US has denied China access to artificial reefs and has accused China of "shredding the trust" of its neighbors.

site_title: Renault profit surged 38% as new SUVs grab European market share
summary: Renault's profit surged 38% in 2016 to 3.28 billion euros, exceeding analyst estimates. The company gained European market share with new SUVs and upgraded models like the Megane hatchback. Revenue jumped 13% to 51.2 billion euros. Renault plans to expand in India, Africa, and return to Iran, aiming to lift operating margin to 7% by 2022. The company's alliance with Nissan delivered 9.96 million vehicles in 2016, and Renault targets higher operating profit and revenue this year.

site_title: China may increase quota for Hollywood films: state paper
summary: China is expected to increase its quota of imported Hollywood films, potentially adding around a dozen new films to the current annual quota of 34, according to the state-run Global Times newspaper. This move could boost Hollywood producers, who are seeking a share of ticket revenues closer to those in other overseas markets, now at 25% compared to 40%. The news comes ahead of key talks to review the five-year agreement between China and Hollywood, which has been clouded by US President Donald Trump's inauguration and criticism of China.

site_title: China sustains red-hot commodities imports at near-record pace
summary: China maintained a near-record pace of commodities imports in January, with iron ore shipments rising 12% to the second-highest on record. Coal imports reached the highest for January in three years, and crude imports were the third-highest on record. The surge in imports is driven by declining domestic production and higher demand from steel mills. Analysts predict that the trend may continue, despite concerns about underlying demand. China's imports also exceeded expectations, supporting optimism about the health of the global commodities market.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks rally, hit over 20-month high on foreign buying
summary: Taiwan's stocks surged to a 20-month high, closing 0.7% higher at 9,660.18, driven by foreign investors' buying. They account for about a third of all trading. This follows optimism over recent foreign investment.

site_title: Landslides kill 12 in Indonesia's Bali, more rain expected
summary: Twelve people have been killed in three landslides on Indonesia's Bali island, triggered by torrential rain, according to the disaster agency. The landslides destroyed houses in three villages in Kintamani district, killing residents including a one-year-old boy. Several people were injured, and more heavy rain is expected in the area, with the national weather agency predicting continued heavy rain on Saturday and Sunday.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks jump 2.5% after Trump tax cut promise
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index surged 2.5% on Friday, mirroring a Wall Street rally, after US President Donald Trump promised details of a "phenomenal" tax-cut plan. The benchmark index ended the week at 19,378.93, while the Topix index rose 2.18%. The tax-cut announcement boosted investor confidence, sending global stocks higher.

site_title: How low can you go? Deposit rates hit 0.00% at Japan's banks
summary: Japan's two largest banks, Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group Inc and Mizuho Financial Group Inc, have lowered their deposit rates to 0.00% for the first time in nine months, in an effort to minimize a squeeze on interest margins since the Bank of Japan introduced negative rates a year ago. Despite this, deposits continue to swell, growing 4.5% in January, as companies and individuals choose to save rather than invest or spend. Analysts say lenders should boost sales of investment products to support profitability.

site_title: China officials punished for dozing in meeting on motivation
summary: China officials in Hubei province have been punished for dozing off during a meeting on motivating lazy bureaucrats. Six mid-level officials were named and forced to write self-criticisms and make public apologies. The incident occurred amid President Xi Jinping's crackdown on corruption and dereliction of duty. The officials were attending a meeting ironically focused on motivating sluggish officials, highlighting the need for accountability among government officials.

site_title: Singapore banks' sour loans in focus as oil service sector stresses
summary: Singapore's DBS Group Holdings and smaller rival United Overseas Bank are set to report their lowest quarterly profits in at least two years due to bad loans provisions for the battered oil services sector. Nearly a dozen firms in the offshore services sector have restructured their bonds and loans to stay afloat. DBS booked a doubling of soured loans to S$436 million, while OCBC and UOB reported increases in third-quarter charges. Analysts expect further provisions in the fourth quarter and a decline in 2017 loan growth due to weakening regional trade.

site_title: Struggling retailers seek silver bullet in Amazon era
summary: Retailers are seeking innovative ways to boost store traffic and stay competitive in the Amazon era. Stores are testing AI programs, swipe-right games, and personalized services such as coffee shops, restaurants, and interactive dressing rooms. Experts predict some brick-and-mortar stores will survive, but the survivors will be more customer-friendly and experiential. Retailers are also investing in data analytics, hand-held tablets, and mobile apps to enhance the in-store experience. However, the high costs of implementing new technologies may limit their widespread adoption.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open sharply higher on Friday
summary: Japanese stocks opened sharply higher on Friday, with Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index rising 1.58% to 19,206.31, following new records on Wall Street. US President Donald Trump promised to release details of a "phenomenal" tax cut plan, boosting investor confidence.

site_title: Blue cocktails and pheasant meatball soup to fete Kim Jong Il's birthday
summary: North Korea held a national cooking contest to celebrate the 75th birthday of late leader Kim Jong-il, with pheasant meatball soup and blue cocktails being showcased. The competition, which drew over 300 participants, featured traditional Korean dishes and was the seventh of its kind. The event was held at the Pyongyang Noodle House, where cooks prepared and presented various dishes, including pheasant meatball broth and blue cocktails decorated with cherries and pineapple slices. The competition is a national holiday in North Korea, known as the "Day of the Shining Star".

images.alt_text: Pheasant meatball soup and blue cocktails snazzily shaken were two of the more intriguing entries at a national cooking contest held in North Korea on Thursday to mark the 75th birthday anniversary of late leader Kim Jong-il.

site_title: Takata expects full-year loss on air bag recall-related costs
summary: Takata Corp, a Japanese air bag maker, expects a full-year loss of 64.0 billion yen (US$562.74 million) due to costs related to a massive global product recall. This would be the company's third consecutive loss. Takata has been seeking a sponsor for its restructuring and has selected Key Safety Systems as a final bidder. The company faces billions of dollars in additional recall-related costs, leading to a significant decline in its forecasted net profit.

site_title: Maersk says sanity returning to shipping as freight rates gain
summary: Maersk Line's Asia-Pacific chief, Robbert van Trooijen, says the bankruptcy of South Korea's Hanjin Shipping Co. and consolidation in the container shipping industry will bring sanity to the industry, leading to a balanced supply-demand situation in 2017. Freight rates are rebounding, with the Shanghai Containerized Freight Index more than doubling from a record low. Maersk Line expects a 2-4% global container market growth and plans to be profitable in 2017 after a $384 million loss. The company attributes the normalization to the growth side and right-sizing of the industry.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks rally at open on Trump tax promise
summary: Hong Kong shares rose on February 10, 2017, for a third day, driven by investors' optimism over Donald Trump's tax-cut plans, which may boost the US economy. The Hang Seng Index increased 0.51%, adding 120.76 points to 23,645.90.

site_title: Australia shares rise on Trump's tax plans, see best week in 2 mths; NZ falls
summary: Australia's S&P/ASX 200 index rose 1% to 5,720.6, its best week in two months, driven by US President Donald Trump's remarks on tax. The index gained 1.76% for the week, with all major sectors except real estate trading in positive territory. New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index fell 0.2%, while Asia-Pacific stocks were supported by stronger Chinese trade data.

site_title: Hot stock: United Engineers' shares surge amid talk of buyer interest
summary: Shares of United Engineers surged 4.2% to S$2.96 amid speculation of buyer interest, prompting a trading halt request. Speculation began after major shareholders sent preliminary financial information to potential bidders. At least 10 parties, including regional developers and private equity firms, have expressed interest in acquiring the company, valued at S$1.7 billion. United Engineers' largest owners, OCBC Bank and Great Eastern Holdings, had previously stated they were reviewing strategic options for their combined stakes.

site_title: Brussels hit by power outage
summary: A power outage hit several neighborhoods in Brussels, including Schaerbeek, Evere, and Saint-Josse, at 10:40 pm on February 10, 2017, due to an unknown problem with the grid. The electricity distributor, Sibelga, reported that five of the 48 high-voltage stations were affected and that power was gradually being restored. Residents initially contacted the police, but many took the outage in stride, even joking about a potential baby boom. The power outage also affected RTBF radio programs, which broadcast continuous music instead of regular programming.

site_title: Trump tells Xi will respect 'One China' policy: White House
summary: US President Donald Trump has told Chinese President Xi Jinping he will respect the "One China" policy, according to a White House statement. This comes after Trump suggested the policy was up for negotiation. The announcement was welcomed by Xi, who had cast a pall over relations after Trump's previous comments. The two leaders extended invitations to meet in their respective countries, marking a swift resolution to a sensitive issue.

site_title: Developers' association calls for review on property taxes in Budget
summary: The Real Estate Developers' Association of Singapore (Redas) has called for a review of property taxes, improved transparency in property valuation, and reduced business costs and regulatory fees. The association also seeks special training grants for building maintenance engineers and technicians. Redas' president, Augustine Tan, expressed concerns about the impact of property taxes on the market, citing a high vacancy rate of 8.4% for private residential units and a weakened labor market. The association looks forward to participating in the Committee on the Future Economy's recommendations on urban solutions and innovative digital capabilities.

site_title: Iraq's 'cycling girls' ride for freedom
summary: A young Iraqi artist, Marina Jaber, has inspired a movement by riding her red bicycle in the streets of Baghdad, challenging the country's conservative society. The 25-year-old's project, which started as an art project, has become a social media sensation and a civil society movement, with dozens of women gathering to cycle and break ground. Jaber's actions echo global history of cycling as a symbol of women's emancipation, including suffragette Alice Hawkins and Yemeni photographer Bushra al-Fusail, who have also challenged societal norms.

site_title: Panama raids Mossack Fonseca over Odebrecht bribery scandal
summary: Panamanian prosecutors raided Mossack Fonseca, the law firm at the center of the Panama Papers scandal, seeking possible links to Odebrecht in the Odebrecht bribery scandal. Ramon Fonseca, a partner at Mossack Fonseca, denied any connection to Odebrecht, accusing the government of diverting attention. Panamanian President Juan Carlos Varela denied receiving donations from Odebrecht, but Fonseca claimed Varela had accepted money. The raid aims to investigate potential ties between Mossack Fonseca and Odebrecht in the Lava Jato probe.

site_title: Australia shares follow Wall Street's gains; NZ up
summary: Australian shares rose 0.8% on Friday, following Wall Street's gains, as the Reserve Bank of Australia slashed its near-term economic growth forecast but maintained a positive outlook. The S&P/ASX 200 index reached 5708.10 points, with broad-based gains driven by record highs on Wall Street, consumer stocks, and materials sectors. Meanwhile, New Zealand's benchmark index rose 0.1% to 7125.70 points, led by financials and utilities stocks.

site_title: US dollar at 1-1/2-week high vs yen on Trump tax vow, US-Japan summit awaited
summary: The US dollar rose to a 1-1/2-week high versus the yen due to President Trump's comments on a potential ambitious tax reform plan. The dollar index against a basket of major currencies was steady at 100.610, poised to rise 0.8% on the week. The euro was little changed and on track to shed over 1% on the week, while the yen hit a nine-day high of 113.800. The US-Japan summit, which may discuss currency policies, is awaited, with concerns that Trump may reiterate opposition to a strong US dollar.

site_title: Workers strike at world's biggest copper mine
summary: Workers at BHP Billiton's Escondida copper mine in Chile launched a strike, citing a seven-per-cent raise and bonuses of 25 million pesos as unacceptable. The strike, which began on Thursday, has resulted in the suspension of production for at least 15 days and is expected to be the longest since 2006. The strike's impact on global copper supply and prices is being closely watched, with copper prices having rallied in recent weeks. The Escondida mine produces 5% of global copper output, and a prolonged strike could lead to seasonal shortages in China, the world's largest copper consumer.

site_title: News Corp swings to loss on write-downs
summary: News Corp reported a loss of US$290 million in the fiscal quarter ending December 31, due to a write-down of US$310 million for the diminished value of its Australian newspapers. Total revenues dipped 2% to US$2.1 billion, while digital now accounts for 27% of segment revenues. The company's assets include the Wall Street Journal, HarperCollins book publisher, and digital real estate platforms. CEO Robert Thomson cited "strategic reinvestment and digital diversification" as the company adapts to an industry shifting towards online content.

site_title: Seoul: Won buckles under US dollar after Trump vows tax reform, stocks up
summary: South Korea's won fell to a one-week low after US President Donald Trump vowed to announce tax reform plans, expected to reduce taxation for individuals and businesses. The won dropped 0.6% to 1,152.2, its lowest since February 2. Meanwhile, South Korean shares rose 0.5% on Wall Street's gains, with the Kospi index reaching 2,076.77 points. Investors are awaiting Trump's summit with Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe and US Federal Reserve Vice Chair Stanley Fischer's speech for further market direction.

site_title: China January exports rise 7.9%, beating forecasts
summary: China's January exports rose 7.9% from a year earlier, beating forecasts, while imports rose 16.7%, exceeding expectations. The resulting trade surplus was $51.35 billion. Analysts caution that the strong January data may be influenced by the Lunar New Year holidays, which can distort trends. Customs data is expected to be released on February 23. This report contrasts with a dismal 2016, where exports declined 7.7%.

site_title: Ethics review sought after Trump adviser touts Ivanka Trump products
summary: The House Oversight committee is seeking an ethics review of White House adviser Kellyanne Conway's promotion of Ivanka Trump's products, citing potential violation of federal ethics rules. Conway's comments on Fox News appeared to endorse Ivanka's products, which are the daughter of President Donald Trump, and could imply a government endorsement. The review was prompted by a complaint from a member of the committee and follows President Trump's criticism of a retailer for dropping Ivanka's products.

site_title: Sydney braces for blackouts as heatwave stokes Australia energy row
summary: Australia's capital Sydney and New South Wales face power outages amid a heatwave, with the energy market operator warning of potential load shedding. This comes after 40,000 homes and businesses lost electricity in South Australia last week due to tight power supply conditions. The issue has sparked a review of the national electricity market and energy policy, deepening the divide between Liberal conservatives and Labor on the use of green energy to cut carbon emissions. The New South Wales government is considering which customers will face managed power cuts.

site_title: Hong Kong's biggest arbitrage trade gets a boost from China
summary: Mainland Chinese investors are pouring into Hong Kong's stock market, boosting the city's Hang Seng China Enterprises Index, which has seen a 5% rally since February 3. Average daily inflows have reached the highest since September, with the index narrowing its valuation gap with the Shanghai Composite Index. Despite being 33% cheaper on average, dual-listed stocks remain attractive, with funds repositioning to add low-valuation names, according to analysts. The influx of mainland money is seen as a result of tightening capital controls, which make Hong Kong a more attractive destination for offshore investment.

images.alt_text: Cheap Hong Kong equities are suddenly back in vogue with Chinese investors.

site_title: Singapore shares open flat on Friday
summary: Singapore stocks opened 0.4% higher on Friday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) rising 12.4 points to 3,092.36, amid a positive start to the US market, where all three major indices closed at new highs. US President Donald Trump promised to release a tax cut plan soon, boosting investor sentiment. About 119.9 million shares changed hands, with SinoCloud, Noble Group, and Equation being the most actively traded counters.

site_title: US appeals court maintains suspension of Trump travel ban
summary: A US appeals court has upheld a suspension of President Donald Trump's travel ban, ruling that the administration failed to provide evidence of national security concerns justifying its reinstatement. The 9th Circuit Court of Appeals unanimously rejected a request to lift an emergency halt on the ban, which was put in place by a lower court. The court's decision does not resolve the lawsuit but rather relates to whether to lift the emergency halt. The Justice Department will need to present evidence that people from the seven countries pose a domestic threat to ultimately win the case.

site_title: Construction resumes on Dakota pipeline despite tribe's challenge
summary: The Dakota Access Pipeline, a $3.8 billion oil pipeline, has resumed construction despite a last-ditch challenge from the Standing Rock Sioux Tribe. The project, which aims to transport crude oil from the Northern Plains to the Midwest and Gulf of Mexico, was put on hold by former President Barack Obama but resumed under President Donald Trump. The tribe filed a court challenge seeking a temporary restraining order, but experts say the tribe faces long odds in convincing a court to halt construction. The pipeline is expected to be operational by early May.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Friday, rising 12.45 points to 1699.73, following a bank holiday. The market saw 144 gainers and 51 losers, with a total trading volume of 68.48 million lots worth RM31.9 million.

site_title: Apple CEO Cook 'optimistic' about UK's future after Brexit: BBC
summary: Apple CEO Tim Cook expressed optimism about the UK's future after Brexit, stating he believed the country would be "just fine" outside the European Union. Cook met with Prime Minister Theresa May and made the comments during a meeting at Downing Street. This follows Apple's recent investment in its London headquarters at Battersea Power Station, seen as a sign of major firms' continued investment in the UK despite the Brexit vote.

site_title: In call with Putin, Trump denounced Obama-era nuclear arms treaty
summary: US President Donald Trump denounced the 2010 New Start nuclear arms treaty with Russia in his first call with President Vladimir Putin, calling it a "bad deal" that favored Russia. Trump expressed uncertainty about the treaty, asking aides for an opinion during the call. The White House denied that Trump was unaware of the treaty's details. Critics, including national security experts and Democrats, have expressed concern over Trump's handling of foreign policy and lack of knowledge about nuclear policy.

site_title: China punishes hospital staff after patients infected with HIV, hepatitis B
summary: China has punished hospital staff after 14 patients were infected with HIV and hepatitis B due to improper medical procedures. In two separate incidents, staff at hospitals in Zhejiang and Shandong provinces reused medical equipment and operated against regulations, leading to infections. The incidents have raised concerns about public trust in China's healthcare system, which treats 1.4 billion people and is the world's second-largest drugs market. Several hospital staff, including the head and deputy head of a hospital, were sacked and removed from their Communist Party posts.

site_title: Trump to meet Canada's PM amid tensions over trade, immigration
summary: US President Donald Trump is set to meet with Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau on Monday amid tensions over trade, immigration, and NATO spending. The meeting comes as Trump seeks to renegotiate the North American Free Trade Agreement (Nafta) and Canada is concerned about potential protectionist measures. Trudeau's office said the talks will be wide-ranging, covering trade, security, and defence. The meeting follows a charm offensive by senior Canadian government ministers to persuade the Trump team not to single out Canada during the Nafta talks.

site_title: Dry run for Modi as India's most populous state votes
summary: India's most populous state, Uttar Pradesh, is set to vote on Saturday, with Prime Minister Narendra Modi's Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) facing strong competition from Chief Minister Akhilesh Yadav's Congress Party. The vote is seen as a key test of Modi's popularity after a controversial cash ban aimed at combating tax evasion. Polls are staggered over several weeks, with results out on March 11. Analysts say the election will determine the BJP's national prospects and its ability to pass reforms, while Yadav hopes to win the support of Uttar Pradesh's youth.

site_title: South Korea reports second annual budget surplus in 2016, will pay down debt
summary: South Korea reported its second consecutive budget surplus in 2016, with a total gross revenue of 345.0 trillion won and expenditures of 332.2 trillion won, resulting in an 8.0 trillion won surplus. The surplus will be mainly used to pay down debt and other liabilities. Tax revenue, particularly VAT and corporate tax, increased by 12.8% and 15.7% respectively, contributing to the surplus. This marks a significant improvement from the previous year's budget surplus of 2.8 trillion won.

site_title: Yoma Strategic's Q3 profit plunges 98.7%
summary: Yoma Strategic Holdings reported a 98.7% decline in Q3 net profit to S$0.3 million, due to currency translation losses and lower fair value gain. Revenue grew 16.6% to S$27.7 million, driven by a 22.4% increase in non-real estate businesses. Earnings per share fell to 0.02 Singapore cents, down from 1.45 cents last year. No dividends were declared for the period.

site_title: Ex-DBS bankers back fintech remittance startup
summary: Former DBS bankers Rajan Raju and Edwin Khoo are backing fintech remittance startup SingX, which aims to disrupt the trillion-dollar global payments industry. SingX charges a fixed 0.5% upfront, compared to 1-5% by banks and remittance houses. The platform offers live foreign-exchange rates and aims to save customers up to 90% on typical remittance charges. SingX plans to expand to other countries, targeting 7,000 customers this year and has raised US$2.5 million in funding.

site_title: Taiwanese woman sentenced for shark-fin haul in Costa Rica
summary: A Taiwanese business owner, Tseng, has been sentenced to six months in prison for her role in a Costa Rican fishing haul that involved illegally hacking off shark fins. The fins were destined for sale abroad, primarily in Asia, where they are highly valued. This is the first criminal sentence in Costa Rica for shark finning, a practice that harms sharks and is banned by several international treaties. The verdict was handed down by the Puntarenas court in western Costa Rica.

site_title: Oil up after petrol stock draw, but market bloated
summary: Oil prices rose 35 cents a barrel to $55.47 after a US petrol inventory draw suggested higher demand, but crude supplies remained bloated. Benchmark Brent crude was up, while US light crude rose 55 cents to $52.89 a barrel. Analysts say the US petrol stock draw may support prices, but high US crude inventories and rising production may keep markets under pressure.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Yoma Strategic, Singtel
summary: Yoma Strategic Holdings posted a 98.7% fall in net profit for the third quarter to S$0.3 million due to currency translation losses and lower fair value gain. Revenue grew 16.6% to S$27.7 million, driven by a 22.4% increase in non-real estate businesses. Meanwhile, Singtel is preparing to divest over 75% of its 100% shareholding in NetLink Trust, with an initial public offering (IPO) expected, and must divest to less than 25% by April 2108.

site_title: China to take fingerprints of foreigners in security step
summary: China plans to take fingerprints of all foreign visitors aged 14-70 at entry points, starting at Shenzhen airport, to strengthen immigration controls and increase efficiency. The move, similar to requirements in the US, Japan, Taiwan, and Cambodia, aims to enhance security without specifying if other biometric data will be collected. The regulation will be gradually rolled out across the country.

site_title: China, New Zealand pledge to support for free trade
summary: New Zealand Prime Minister Bill English and Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi agreed to support free trade and globalisation, with plans to upgrade their bilateral free trade agreement and cooperate in sectors like infrastructure and tourism. The two countries also discussed China's One Belt, One Road initiative and welcomed increased Chinese investment in New Zealand. China's foreign ministry stated that English praised Chinese President Xi Jinping's speech on globalisation, and the two countries did not discuss the Trans-Pacific Partnership trade pact.

site_title: Singapore advised to be ready to review tax regime
summary: Singapore's government is advised to review its tax regime to ensure sustainable economic growth, according to a report by the Committee on the Future Economy. The report recommends a tax system that is "broad-based, progressive and fair" while remaining "competitive and pro-growth." The government should maintain this tax regime, but also refine it to address domestic and global changes, such as an ageing population and international pressures like the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development's Base Erosion and Profit Shifting project.

site_title: Europe: Shares end at 2-week high, SocGen and Total advance
summary: European shares ended at a two-week high on Thursday, with Societe Generale and Total advancing after their results. Eutelsat surged 8.2% after reporting lower-than-expected revenue but higher Internet and mobile satellite sales. Bank of America Merrill Lynch said there was a strong value case for European equities, with earnings expected to rise relative to the US in 2017. The STOXX 600 index climbed 0.8%, with the German DAX and French CAC 40 also rising, despite some underperforming sectors such as mining.

site_title: Twitter woes deepen as growth sputters; no Trump lift
summary: Twitter's fourth-quarter revenue rose 1% to $717 million, but the company's growth sputtered, with shares plummeting 12% to close at $16.41. Twitter reported a net loss of $167 million and 319 million monthly active users, a 4% gain from last year. Advertising revenue was down 5% from a year ago, and the company's deficit narrowed from 2015. Despite efforts to revamp the platform, analysts say Twitter is moving too slow in the rapidly evolving social media space, and faces tough competition from rivals like Facebook and Google.

site_title: Indonesia hails credit outlook upgrade to 'positive' by Moody's
summary: Indonesia's credit outlook has been upgraded to "positive" by Moody's, following a similar move by Fitch in December. The upgrade reflects the country's improved economic stability, fiscal discipline, and reduced vulnerability to external shocks. Finance Minister Sri Mulyani Indrawati vowed to continue strengthening policies to "rationalize risk perception." However, Chief Economics Minister Darmin Nasution chastised Standard & Poor's for holding back an investment-grade rating, despite Moody's Baa3 rating, which is the lowest notch for investment-grade debt.

site_title: Virtual assistant Cortana holds people to promises
summary: A virtual assistant named Cortana has been criticized for holding people to promises. Meanwhile, several institutions have launched innovation hubs focused on artificial intelligence, including Singapore's NIE and Amazon Web Services. Mining giant BHP and companies like Oracle, Grab, and PwC have also established AI-focused innovation hubs. Additionally, Lazada has invested $100 million in creator commerce, while Synapxe launched a health tech sandbox offering improved data access. OpenAI has also made changes to its business model, dialing back a plan to convert to a for-profit entity and retain control as a nonprofit.

site_title: CFE unveils 7-point roadmap to 2-3% annual growth for Singapore
summary: The Committee on the Future Economy (CFE) has unveiled a 7-point roadmap to achieve a 2-3% annual growth rate in Singapore's economy over the next decade. The plan focuses on building a collaborative economy that is responsive to domestic and external realities, while targeting specific areas for economic restructuring. The CFE emphasizes the importance of looking outwards and avoiding broad-based approaches, instead opting for targeted strategies. The goal is to drive quality, productivity-led growth and ensure Singapore's long-term economic sustainability.

site_title: Don't let tax issues trip up your digital strategy
summary: The digital economy in South-east Asia has significant growth potential, with the Singapore government investing in infrastructure to support businesses. However, the rise of globalisation and digitalisation has raised concerns over outdated tax laws and their impact on multinational enterprises. The Base Erosion and Profit Shifting (BEPS) project aims to address these issues, but uncertainty remains. Businesses can mitigate risks by adopting BEPS-ready measures, such as improving corporate governance, assessing substance, and engaging with tax authorities. A balance must be struck between tax risk management and business operations, with companies adapting to the evolving digital economy.

site_title: Trump loyalist Sessions takes over as US attorney general
summary: US Attorney General Jeff Sessions, a loyalist to President Donald Trump, has taken over the role with a focus on aggressive policing, voter registration laws, and strong immigration curbs. Sessions, 70, is a trusted advisor to Trump and has championed conservative views on law enforcement. Despite his loyalty, Sessions has pledged to follow the law and exercise independent judgment, a promise that has been met with skepticism by Democrats. His appointment has raised concerns about the constitutional separation of powers and the potential for politicization of the Department of Justice.

site_title: The US has (mostly) got it wrong on the euro
summary: The US has largely misjudged Germany's handling of the euro, with the US administration criticizing Germany for allegedly undervaluing the currency. However, data shows the US dollar has appreciated by 10% annually, while Germany's competitiveness has remained relatively stable. The US should examine its own economic situation rather than attacking others. The US has a point in criticizing economic and monetary union in Europe, but the Americans neglect to consider Germany's own issues, such as its current account surplus and imbalances.

site_title: HDB resale volume, prices down in January: SRX
summary: HDB resale prices in Singapore decreased 0.3% in January, with transactions dropping 13.9% to 1,174 flats resold. Consultants attribute the drop to a large supply of build-to-order flats released in November, but believe prices are stabilizing. This marks a blip in the market, with prices expected to continue their downward trend. The drop in transaction volume is also seen as a temporary effect, with the BTO supply expected to impact the market in the short term.

site_title: US investors more willing to place wagers on uncertain Europe
summary: US investors are shifting their focus from the US to European stocks amid uncertainty from upcoming elections in major European countries, including the Netherlands, France, and Germany. Despite concerns over economic growth and inflation, investors are taking a risk on European stocks, with asset managers like BlackRock increasing their exposure. European stocks have a lower price-to-earnings ratio compared to US stocks, making them more attractive to investors seeking value. Fund managers have boosted their bets on European stocks, while pulling back from US stocks, with $709 million invested in European funds in January.

site_title: ARA Asset Management's Q4 net profit falls 28% to S$18.5m; buyout gets regulatory approval
summary: ARA Asset Management's Q4 2016 net profit fell 28% to S$18.5m due to lower acquisition fees and increased costs. The company's privatisation bid, led by founder John Lim, has received regulatory approvals and will proceed with a scheme of arrangement. The consortium values the company at S$1.78 billion and aims to take it private at S$1.78 a share. ARA will hold a shareholders' meeting by March 31, 2017, to obtain shareholder approval and a court order.

site_title: Trump teases tax reform within 'weeks'
summary: US President Donald Trump hinted at corporate tax reform within weeks, promising to "lower the overall tax burden of American businesses." The proposed policy aims to incentivize companies to stay and grow in the US, rather than seeking lower tax rates abroad. However, experts warn that implementing higher import tariffs could spark retaliatory measures from trading partners, potentially disrupting global trade. Trump's plan is part of a package that would be paid for by tariffs, and its implications for trade and the economy remain uncertain.

site_title: US: Stocks hit records as Trump signals action on tax cuts
summary: US stocks reached fresh records on February 9, 2017, as President Donald Trump promised to release a tax cut plan in the next two to three weeks. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.6% to 20,172.40, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also gained 0.6%. Investors were boosted by Trump's comments, which followed a strong day for European equities. Analysts attributed the rally to enthusiasm behind the plan, but noted depressed US volume due to a major snow storm.

site_title: GLP Q3 net profit down 7.3%
summary: Global Logistic Properties (GLP) reported a 7.3% decline in net profit to US$170.7 million for its Q3 2017, primarily due to a one-time syndication gain a year ago and higher non-cash accounting foreign exchange losses. Revenue rose 16.9% to US$232.5 million, driven by growth in operations, development projects in China, and the appreciation of the Japanese yen. GLP's same-property NOI was up 6.9% year-to-date, and the company maintained a strong customer base with a global lease ratio of 92% and customer retention of 73%.

site_title: Number of countries with top debt ratings down in 2016: Fitch
summary: Fitch reported a 13-year low in the number of countries with top-notch sovereign credit ratings in 2016, with 11 countries maintaining 'AAA' status. This includes Australia, Canada, Denmark, Germany, Luxembourg, the Netherlands, Norway, Singapore, Sweden, Switzerland, and the US. The agency expects this level to remain unchanged over the next two years, with no upgrades to 'AAA' anticipated and no downgrades expected in the next 12-24 months. This reflects the long-term impact of the global financial crisis.

site_title: Hudson Theatre rejoins Broadway's performance arts scene after 50 years
summary: The Hudson Theatre in New York rejoined Broadway's performance arts scene after nearly 50 years. The historic theatre, which opened in 1903, was restored through a partnership between Millennium & Copthorne Hotels chairman Kwek Leng Beng and Ambassador Theatre Group founder Howard Panter. The theatre's 10-week run of "Sunday In The Park With George" began on February 11, 2017, marking its return to live performances. Kwek expressed excitement to welcome audiences from around the world to enjoy premier shows and celebrate the theatre's rich history.

site_title: China biotech taps Big Data as next weapon against cancer
summary: China's biotech industry is leveraging big data to develop new treatments for cancer, with companies like WuXi NextCode and iCarbonX offering genetic tests and analyzing vast amounts of health data to identify cancer markers. The country's 13th five-year plan prioritizes precision medicine, and Chinese firms are aiming to dominate the market for complex procedures like liquid biopsy tests. With the cost of DNA sequencing falling, precision medicine is gaining popularity worldwide, with China holding around 4-8% of the global market, valued at $56 billion in 2016.

site_title: Tesla to start pilot production of Model 3 cars on Feb 20: sources
summary: Tesla plans to start pilot production of its Model 3 sedans on February 20, according to sources, potentially meeting its July 2017 target. The company will build a small number of vehicles to test the assembly system and quality of parts. This move aims to alleviate concerns about meeting the ambitious production timeline, which has been questioned by analysts and suppliers. If successful, Tesla's Model 3 could raise the company beyond a niche luxury player in the automotive sector, with a potential annual production target of 500,000 cars by 2018.

site_title: Brexit raises risk for 66,000 nuclear industry workers in UK
summary: The UK's decision to leave the EU raises risks for 66,000 nuclear industry workers in the UK, threatening to disrupt atomic fuel trade and nuclear research projects. Leaving the European Atomic Community (Euratom) would require the UK to replicate rules and international agreements needed to trade radioactive materials with other nations, potentially affecting bilateral nuclear-supply agreements. The UK's departure could also impact funding for research projects and lead to job losses, with experts warning of a "tricky business" for the international uranium trade.

site_title: Maersk voices alarm at Trump's trade war talk
summary: Maersk, the world's largest container shipping line, is warning of a potential trade war between the US and China, citing concerns over tariffs and trade restrictions. CEO Soren Skou states that a trade war would have a negative effect on the company's business, with Goldman Sachs estimating a 25% decline in China's exports to the US. Maersk's shares have already sunk due to a full-year loss, and a trade war could further erode global economic growth. The company is more optimistic about US tax proposals, which could lead to increased imports and boost its business.

site_title: IBM to train 25 million Africans for free to build workforce
summary: IBM plans to train 25 million Africans in digital skills over the next five years, with an initial investment of $99.6 million in South Africa. The program, in partnership with the United Nations, aims to build a digital workforce on the continent and retain digital jobs currently outsourced to India. IBM's country manager for South Africa believes the initiative could move up to 50,000 jobs to Africa, where participants will be equipped with skills from basic computer skills to high-end app development.

site_title: Those who oppose Trump run the gamut
summary: US President Donald Trump is considering skipping the White House Correspondents' Association (WHCA) dinner, a annual event that brings together Washington journalists and Hollywood celebrities. The dinner's guest of honor typically roasts the president, but this year, the WHCA is facing a "dam-if-you-do/damn-if-you-don't" dilemma due to Trump's strained relationship with the media. Many celebrities and film stars have expressed their disdain for Trump, and some have even boycotted the event. The WHCA dinner has become a metaphor for the growing resistance to Trump's presidency, with some activists using the Oscars and other events to criticize his policies, including his travel ban.

site_title: Non-race issues bear watching, too, in Malaysia's election race
summary: Malaysia's upcoming general election is expected to be the country's most rancorous, with politicians resorting to racially-divisive rhetoric to garner votes. The incumbent party, Barisan Nasional, is expected to win, but with a reduced two-thirds majority in Parliament. The election comes amidst "1MDB fatigue" and a desire for substantive discussions on fundamental issues such as the economy and education. Observers warn that the ruling coalition's focus on racial issues could lead to a high price for the nation if it fails to address non-race related concerns.

site_title: Lippo offer doesn't save Healthway shareholders from Cayman loan
summary: Lippo Group has launched a takeover offer for Healthway Medical Corporation, but the offer won't save shareholders from a massive loan agreement with Cayman-based investor Gateway Fund. The loan, worth $70 million, has onerous terms, including a 16.5% interest rate and potential dilution of shareholder holdings. Shareholders face a choice between paying interest or allowing the lender to convert the loan into shares. The loan agreement was made without seeking shareholder approval, raising concerns about good governance. Lippo's offer is seen as a welcome relief, but its ability to rescue the company is unclear.

site_title: Natural Cool board ouster leaves doubts over stake divestment
summary: The board of Natural Cool Holdings, a Singapore-based airconditioning specialist, was ousted in an extraordinary general meeting, with only one director remaining. The new board's decision to potentially freeze a proposed sale of its stake in HMK Energy has raised doubts among shareholders. The move comes amid claims that some members of the new board and shareholders who called for the ouster might be unhappy about the proposed divestment of HMK Energy. The outcome of this decision is uncertain, leaving investors waiting for further clarification.

site_title: NZ$ falls on central bank's dovish signal
summary: The New Zealand dollar plummeted 0.8% against the US dollar after the central bank signaled no rate hikes for at least two years, catching investors off guard. The euro also dipped, with France's upcoming election and the US dollar's potential weakening due to President Trump's meeting with Japan's Prime Minister. The kiwi's dovish steer overshadowed the US dollar's firmer week, with the greenback held in check by falling Treasury yields and concerns over a strong dollar.

site_title: STI, Catalist index rise to 52-week highs
summary: The FTSE ST Catalist Index and Straits Times Index reached 52-week highs, with the former rising 0.6% and the latter gaining 13.43 points. This is due to gains in banks like DBS, Singtel, and Keppel Corp. The Singapore Exchange also queried two companies, Artivision Technologies and SinoCloud, after their shares were actively traded. Analysts, including Nomura and Bank of America-Merrill Lynch, have expressed mixed views on the market outlook, citing concerns over weak net revenue growth and elevated credit costs.

site_title: More private participation wanted in building up future city
summary: Singapore's Committee on the Future Economy recommends increasing private participation in the built sector to rejuvenate Orchard Road, develop future precincts, and create an urban logistics system. The government will incentivize mall owners and involve private logistics companies in the urban logistics system. Private developers will be involved in future precincts, with the government taking a longer-term and holistic view. The plans aim to improve delivery and logistics services, promote innovation, and create a living lab for urban solutions.

site_title: Fans will lap up this slick, empty erotic enterprise
summary: The movie "Fifty Shades Darker" is the sequel to "Fifty Shades of Grey" and follows Anastasia Steele's relationship with Christian Grey after their breakup. Christian returns, and they agree on a vanilla relationship, but Anastasia discovers a taste for BDSM. The film is criticized for tame content, unscintillating dialogue, and a predictable storyline, but will likely appeal to fans of the erotic genre. The movie features a mystery stalker and Christian's disapproving ex, Elena, and concludes with Anastasia asking Christian to spank her, which he happily agrees to.

images.alt_text: Dornan (left) and Johnson in Fifty Shades Darker. It is pretty tame stuff - sort of like Twilight for the S&M set.

site_title: The smartphone way to see a tropical jungle
summary: The ArtScience Museum in Singapore has launched the world's first augmented reality (AR) and virtual reality (VR) exhibition in Asia, "Into The Wild." The exhibition, which uses Google's Tango technology and Lenovo's Phab 2 Pro smartphone, allows viewers to walk through a virtual rainforest experience and even plant a real tree in Central Sumatera. The exhibition, which aims to raise awareness about rainforest conservation, is free for the public and has a minimum donation of S$38 to sponsor a tree. The museum has partnered with WWF to follow up on the growth of the tree and its impact on the environment.

site_title: Pinterest lets phones spy eye-catching items
summary: Pinterest has introduced "Lens" in its online bulletin boards, allowing users to take pictures with smartphones to identify similar items or themes. The visual search feature uses machine smarts to find matching products, pushing into e-commerce. This test version aims to enable users to browse products directly from the Pinterest app.

site_title: Intel to invest US$7b to finish Arizona chip plant
summary: Intel plans to invest $7 billion to complete a chip factory in Arizona, adding 3,000 jobs. The factory, which has been under consideration for years, will complement two existing Intel plants in Chandler, Arizona. The investment is part of a larger effort by the company to reduce corporate taxes and regulations, with CEO Brian Krzanich stating that the company will "lean in" on policies that benefit US manufacturers. The factory is expected to produce ultra-dense chips, which will allow for faster and more energy-efficient processing.

site_title: The S'pore musical boom
summary: Singapore's musical scene has experienced a significant boom over the past two decades, with numerous talented individuals and companies emerging. The industry has become more professional, with trained performers and composers contributing to the growth of musicals. Lasalle College of the Arts, Nanyang Academy of Fine Arts, and School of the Arts have produced many graduates who have gone on to perform in stage musicals, including Elena Wang and Nathan Hartono. The surplus of talent has led to a surge in musical productions, with local theatre companies such as Dream Academy, Pangdemonium, and W!ld Rice staging multiple shows each year. Despite the challenges faced by young performers, the industry continues to thrive, with musicals such as "Detention Katong" and "Tropicana The Musical" receiving critical acclaim and commercial success.

site_title: Philippine central bank keeps rate steady
summary: The Philippine central bank maintained its benchmark interest rate at 3% in a unanimous decision, despite a challenging global economic environment. The Monetary Board cited strong domestic growth and manageable inflation as reasons for the decision. However, it raised inflation forecasts for this year to 3.5% and next year to 3.1%, indicating a possible interest rate hike in the third quarter to control price pressures.

site_title: Wechat shows the way forward for Facebook
summary: Facebook's new "Instant Games" platform, part of its Messenger app, allows users to play games directly through the app without downloading. This move is reminiscent of China's WeChat, which has integrated social media with messaging, free calls, and various app-like services. WeChat has over 800 million monthly active users and has become an indispensable mobile portal for payments, appointments, and more. Despite being an underdog, WeChat Pay has seen mobile transactions surge to $235 billion in China, surpassing the US for the first time. Facebook's success in replicating WeChat's model will be challenging due to core capabilities turning into rigidities, and the company's focus on advertising and data mining.

site_title: Investors show thirst for IPO of tequila maker Jose Cuervo
summary: Jose Cuervo's initial public offering priced at 34 pesos per share, exceeding the expected range of 30-34 pesos. The 476.6 million share offer raised at least 16.2 billion pesos (S$1.1 billion) and could allow the company to draw upwards of US$900 million. The IPO comes amid US protectionist measures against Mexico, which could impact the company's sales. Despite this, investors have expressed strong interest in the IPO, citing Cuervo's strong US dollar-based earnings and demand for tequila not heavily dependent on prices.

site_title: SIA to spend US$13.8b on new Boeing aircraft
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) plans to spend US$13.8 billion on 39 new Boeing aircraft, including 20 777-9 and 19 787-10 planes, due for delivery from 2020 to 2022. The order is the SIA group's first for the new 777-9 model and marks a commitment to modernizing its fleet. The move aims to drive growth and expansion opportunities for the airline, while also addressing increasing competition in the global economy.

site_title: China Construction tops bids for West Coast Vale site
summary: China Construction (South Pacific) Development Co has won a tender for a 1.64-hectare private housing site in Singapore's West Coast Vale, with a bid of S$291.99 million, or S$591.51 per square foot per plot ratio (psf ppr). The bid was 0.7% higher than MCC Land's S$289.9 million, and reflects a more optimistic market outlook compared to August 2015. The site will have a maximum of 520 residential units and must adhere to the Prefabricated Prefinished Volumetric Construction standard.

site_title: Prudential Q4 profit up 22% on surge in pension-risk transfers
summary: Prudential Financial Inc. reported a 22% increase in fourth-quarter operating profit to $1.09 billion, driven by a surge in pension-risk transfers, with account values at its retirement unit rising $17 billion to $386 billion. The company won deals with United Technologies Corp and Owens-Illinois Inc, adding to growth in its pension-risk transfer industry. Despite investment losses and lower expenses, adjusted profit at the retirement segment climbed 89% to $318 million.

site_title: US railroads join fight over biofuel law
summary: US railroads, including BNSF and Union Pacific, are joining the fight against a biofuel law that requires ethanol mandates, citing the costs of compliance and the impact on fuel prices. The American Association of Railroads is pushing back against calls to move the onus of compliance to fuel distributors, arguing it would increase costs and fuel prices for consumers. The Environmental Protection Agency has rejected a petition to change the law, but the Trump administration has ordered a review of environmental regulations, including the Renewable Fuel Standard.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary:
Singapore corporate news: 
- AA REIT reported a 2.8% decrease in distribution per unit to 2.77 Singapore cents for its third quarter, due to lower gross revenue and higher property expenses.
- Neo Group posted a 97.4% fall in net profit to S$0.125 million, but revenue grew 23.4% to S$46.7 million.
- Boustead Projects reported a 22% fall in revenue to S$66.6 million, but a 19% increase in net profit to S$8.5 million.
- PEC Limited secured a seven-year contract for the largest refinery and petrochemical plant in Vietnam, valued in millions of dollars.

site_title: Trump blasts Nordstrom's dropping of Ivanka's clothing line as 'attack' on his policies
summary: US President Donald Trump criticized Nordstrom for dropping his daughter Ivanka's clothing line, calling it an 'attack' on his policies. Critics accuse Trump of misusing public office to benefit his family's business empire. Nordstrom claims the decision was based on declining sales of the Ivanka Trump products, not a response to Trump's criticism.

site_title: Future gazing
summary: Key news highlights include Vietnam's surprise at US tariff announcement, which may affect the Asian garment industry; Malaysia plans to seize approximately RM3 billion in assets from businessman Daim Zainuddin; China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers; Citigroup forecasts a mid-2026 target of 1,150 for the MSCI global equity index; and Thai Prime Minister Thaksin remains confident that a court case involving his daughter will clear her suspension as PM in an ethics case.

site_title: First round of investment to close for Softbank tech fund
summary: SoftBank's $100 billion technology fund, led by CEO Masayoshi Son, is set to close its first round of investment by the end of February, with initial investments totaling over $80 billion from Saudi Arabia, SoftBank, Apple, Qualcomm, and Oracle. The fund aims to capitalize on emerging trends like artificial intelligence and the Internet of Things, and Son plans to use it to make large deals. The fund's closure may lead to announcements of deals, including potential investments in WeWork and OneWeb, a startup providing internet connectivity from satellites.

site_title: SATS' Q3 earnings up 7.4% at S$65.1m (Amended)
summary: SATS, a Singapore-based ground-handling and inflight catering service provider, reported a 7.4% growth in its third-quarter net profit to S$65.1 million. This increase is attributed to the collapse of South Korea's Hanjin Shipping, which boosted the cargo market. Earnings per share rose to 5.8 Singapore cents, up from 5.5 cents the previous year.

site_title: VW's comeback faces roadblock from Trump tax on Mexican Beetles
summary: Volkswagen, the German carmaker, faces a potential roadblock in its US comeback efforts due to President Donald Trump's proposed "big border tax" of up to 35% on Mexican-made vehicles. About 60% of VWs sold in the US last year were made in Mexico, and the company's reliance on Mexican factories makes it vulnerable to the tax. VW's US headquarters is also just 40 kilometers from the White House, but the company's poor past dealings with US authorities, including its diesel-cheating scandal, may limit its ability to negotiate leniency.

site_title: Trump sends letter to thank China's Xi for congratulatory note
summary: US President Donald Trump has sent a letter to Chinese President Xi Jinping, weeks after receiving a congratulatory note, expressing a desire to develop a "constructive relationship" between the two countries. Despite Trump's campaign rhetoric attacking China, the letter marks a cautious approach to engagement with the Asian giant. The move has been welcomed by China, with a spokesperson praising the letter as a "festive greeting" and a sign of a willingness to cooperate.

site_title: China Railway backs project to mine cleaner iron ore
summary: China Railway Group Ltd is backing a US$3.4 billion project on Australia's Eyre Peninsula to develop a 24 million tonne per year mine of high-quality, lower-emission iron ore. The project aims to supply Chinese steel mills facing stricter environmental rules, with China's demand for premium-quality iron ore expected to increase due to stricter regulations and improved profitability. The project is part of South Australia's goal to secure A$10 billion in investments to fund new iron ore mines by 2021, and could help China reduce its carbon emissions by displacing domestic magnetite supplies.

site_title: The Pillowman is coming back
summary: Pangdemonium, a Singaporean theatre company, is re-staging its 2007 production of Martin McDonagh's award-winning play "The Pillowman." The play, which explores the blurred lines between fact and fiction, will feature original cast members and a new creative team. The company's co-artistic director, Tracie Pang, cited requests from audiences and the play's continued relevance to freedom of speech as reasons for the revival. The production will open Pangdemonium's 2017 season, which includes a new Singapore play and the Singapore premiere of the musical "Fun Home."

site_title: S Korea's embattled ruling party changes name
summary: South Korea's ruling party, the Saenuri, has changed its name to the Liberal Korea Party in an effort to distance itself from a corruption scandal surrounding President Park Geun-Hye. The name change comes as the party seeks to regain voter support ahead of this year's elections. The decision was made after the party's initial suggestions, including "Conservatives' Power Party" and "Money Power Party," were met with ridicule due to the scandal. The change is seen as a bid to sever ties with a tainted past and appeal to a wider audience.

site_title: Missing Razzle Dazzle and All That Jazz would be a crime
summary: Chicago, the longest-running and most successful musical in Broadway history, returns to Singapore for a limited season at Marina Bay Sands. Based on a 1926 play by Maurine Dallas Watkins, the show tells the story of a nightclub dancer who murders her lover and hires a lawyer to make her look like the victim. The musical, which has been performed over 29,000 times globally, boasts a timeless appeal due to its fantastic story, music, and dance. The UK cast promises to deliver the same "Razzle Dazzle" experience as its Broadway and West End counterparts.

images.alt_text: Chicago is a stunning spectacle filled with social satire, love, betrayal, rivalry and friendship - with the action shifting between reality and fantasy, and moving from prison to the courtroom to the stage.
Chicago has been performed over 29,000 times (and counting) to a global audience of 30 million in more than 473 cities.

site_title: Character study that's hard to fathom
summary: Martin Scorsese's film Silence, a character study of two Jesuit priests in 17th-century Japan, is both powerful and dull. The priests embark on a mission to find a missing colleague, but encounter a theological dilemma that challenges their faith. The film, written by Scorsese and Jay Cocks, is a long and provocative exploration of spirituality and doubt. Despite its slow pace, Silence is a thought-provoking and emotionally charged experience that delves into the complexities of faith and the human condition.

site_title: Frasers Centrepoint reports 90% jump in Q1 net profit
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Limited reported a 90% jump in its Q1 net profit, driven by a 45% increase in revenue, primarily from its Singapore and International business units. The company attributed the growth to higher contributions from these units.

site_title: A life of grit amid the glam
summary: Singapore-based actor Yeo Yann Yann shares a hyper and honest glimpse into life as a mid-career actress in her monologue "Actor, Forty." The character, an actress expecting her first child at 40, juggles her career and filming schedule. The monologue explores the glamour and challenges of her profession, offering a candid look at the realities of life as a working actress.

site_title: Separating reality from alternative fact
summary: The film "The Founder" portrays Ray Kroc as the mastermind behind McDonald's, but disputes his claim as the founder. The movie depicts Kroc, played by Michael Keaton, as a struggling salesman who identifies the potential of the McDonald brothers' semi-automated burger system and eventually buys the rights to franchise it. As Kroc expands the business, he prioritizes profit over loyalty and sentiment, ultimately leading to the downfall of the McDonald brothers' original vision. The film presents a nuanced portrayal of Kroc's character, highlighting both his ambition and ruthlessness.

site_title: Going on the offensive by deepening, widening external ties
summary: The Committee on the Future Economy (CFE) in Singapore has released a 109-page report urging the country to go on the offensive and deepen international connections to counter the rising tide of anti-globalization sentiment. The report recommends the establishment of a "Global Innovation Alliance" to build connections with global innovation and technology networks, as well as increased trade and investment cooperation. The CFE also suggests boosting knowledge of Singapore's markets and facilitating more overseas internships for students. The report aims to power Singapore's yearly growth of 2-3% on average and stay open to trade and investment.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Singapore Airlines' 3QFY17 revenue declined 2.5% year-over-year to S$3.84 billion due to lower passenger yields. Despite a S$79 million write-down for the Tigerair brand, core profit after tax and minority interests (PATMI) grew 20.3% to S$256.2 million. The company's fuel expenses fell 17.6% year-over-year, driven by hedging losses. Analysts maintain a positive outlook, raising forecasts and increasing target prices for the airline.

site_title: TFA: A ray of hope for the global economy
summary: The Trade Facilitation Agreement (TFA), agreed in 2013, is set to enter into force as two-thirds of WTO members (110 nations) ratify it. The TFA aims to create a level playing field for small and medium-size businesses by tackling inefficiency and rent-seeking behavior at borders. By promoting digital transformation and transparent rules, it seeks to remove obstacles for entrepreneurs in developing countries to access global markets. The agreement is seen as a key step towards the democratisation of trade and could help countries like Rwanda, Sri Lanka, and others become integral parts of the global economy.

site_title: Switch off social media and plug into real life
summary: More people are disconnecting from social media and focusing on real life, according to an article in The Business Times' Weekend magazine. The issue explores this trend, as well as other topics such as romantic dinner recipes, the world's largest condom maker, and startup initiatives aimed at promoting women in the industry. The article also features reviews of new products and services, including a turntable and a Swedish heavy metal band's latest album. The shift away from social media is seen as a desire for more meaningful connections and experiences.

site_title: Founders taking Spindex private at S$0.85 a share
summary: Spindex Industries Limited, a Singapore-listed company, has received a takeover offer from its founding Tan family to acquire all shares at S$0.85 apiece under a scheme of arrangement. The offer represents a 21.4% premium over the last traded price and 23.4% over the volume-weighted average price for the three-month period. The deal aims to provide the management greater flexibility to manage the business for a longer horizon, as the company has not carried out any equity fund-raising since its listing.

site_title: Artivision Tech says online articles on company could be behind heavy trading
summary: ARTIVISION Technologies stated that articles about the company on investment websites and forums may have caused unusual trading activity. The company responded to a query by the Singapore Exchange (SGX) regarding the heavy trading.

site_title: Soo Kee moves into Thailand with its bridal jewellery brand
summary: Soo Kee Group, a Catalist-listed company, has signed a memorandum of understanding with Thailand's Aurora Group to form a 40:60 joint venture company for its bridal jewellery brand, Love & Co. The joint venture aims to capture the Thai market, which is dominated by gold and lacks contemporary brands in the diamond market. With an initial paid-up capital of 30 million baht, the joint venture plans to open 20 retail outlets in five years in Bangkok, Phuket, and Pattaya. Soo Kee expects the joint venture to break even after the first year and contribute to the brand's expansion in Thailand.

site_title: Foreign talent 'can plug gaps in economy'
summary: Singapore remains open to foreign talent, particularly in areas with pressing market needs, Minister for Industry S Iswaran said, as the country seeks to strike a balance between growing its economy and addressing population needs. The Committee on the Future Economy (CFE) recommended augmenting local talent with foreign talent possessing specialized skill sets, and the government will review work-pass schemes to allow in more startup founders and key executives. Foreign talent can contribute to Singapore's future economy, with a multiplier effect of 4.3 jobs created for every job in the high-tech sector.

site_title: Old age is no excuse for dullness
summary: A wine expert shares the importance of freshness in evaluating wine quality, citing acidity as the key factor. Freshness is determined by a wine's "tartness," "sharpness," and "brightness" on the palate, which are affected by factors such as storage conditions, temperature, and exposure to air. The author argues that patience is essential when it comes to aging wine, as a well-balanced wine with sufficient freshness can last longer than one that is too acidic or flat.

site_title: New condo in Tanah Merah inspired by luxury wellness
summary: CEL Development is launching Grandeur Park Residences, a 720-unit condominium in Singapore's Tanah Merah area. The luxury wellness-inspired development features a three-generational family gym, aqua gym, and aqua-aerobic pool. Units range from one-bedroom to five-bedroom and start from over S$500,000. The 99-leasehold development offers smart home capabilities and is expected to draw buyers, with an anticipated strong response in the first week of its launch.

site_title: Manufacturing sector to be 'around 20%' of GDP in medium term
