summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector is expected to reach around 20% of the country's GDP in the medium term, according to the Committee on the Future Economy. This target aims to make the sector globally competitive and generate strong spillovers to the rest of the economy. Economists believe achieving this goal may require more reliance on foreign multinational corporations, which can bring in high-value manufacturing. The sector already accounts for 14% of total employment and has seen real productivity growth of 6.2% per year, higher than the overall economy.

site_title: Facebook creates 'Community Help' feature for disaster assistance
summary: Facebook is set to launch a "Community Help" feature, which will connect people affected by disasters to provide and receive assistance locally. The feature will be part of "Safety Check", allowing users to assure others they are safe after natural disasters and major accidents. The initiative aims to facilitate local support and aid in crisis situations.

site_title: Cloud Gate 2 leaves crowd on cloud nine
summary: Taiwanese dance company Cloud Gate 2 performed a triple bill debut, leaving the audience in awe. The evening began with "Wicked Fish," showcasing fluid and synchronized movements, followed by "The Wall," which featured sharp, precise movements, and concluded with "Beckoning," a complex and layered production with a mix of folk-style and tribal-like moves. The company's artistic director, Cheng Tsung-Lung, wowed the crowd with his choreography, solidifying Cloud Gate 2's reputation as an exemplary dance company.

images.alt_text: Taiwanese Cloud Gate 2's triple-bill debut was a breathtaking display of choreography. The pieces included Beckoning (left), whose accompanying music evoked sounds of religious ceremonies, and Wicked Fish (right), inspired by piscine activity.

site_title: CFE hits most of the right notes
summary: The Committee on the Future Economy (CFE) released a report outlining ambitious objectives for Singapore's future, including deepening international connections, acquiring new skills, and building digital capabilities. The proposals are sensible and imaginative, but some areas, such as social policies, are missing. The report emphasizes the need for Singapore to focus on Asian economies and deepen its understanding of the region. However, it is unclear whether the objectives are sufficiently bold, realistic, and comprehensive. The report highlights the urgent need for advanced skills from overseas, particularly in areas such as data science and cybersecurity. The government must re-open its doors to foreign talent, and companies must be free to hire them. Social policies, including addressing an ageing workforce and income inequality, are also crucial.

images.alt_text: This is the world that the Committee on the Future Economy (CFE) is looking to help us navigate, and its report comes not a moment too soon. It also comes at an ominous time, when the system of liberal global trade is under threat.

site_title: Tata Steel UK agrees to sell speciality steel business to Liberty House
summary: Tata Steel UK has agreed to sell its speciality steel business to Liberty House Group for £100 million, securing 1,700 jobs in South Yorkshire. The deal, subject to regulatory clearances, will make Liberty House one of Britain's largest steel employers with 4,000 workers. The speciality business supplies the aerospace industry, including Rolls-Royce, Boeing, and Airbus. The sale is part of Tata Steel UK's restructuring efforts, with the company employing around 9,000 people in Britain.

site_title: Swedish film festival heads into lesser-explored territory
summary: The Swedish Film Festival is set to take place at The Projector in Singapore, showcasing a mix of classic and contemporary films by Swedish directors such as Roy Andersson and Karin Ekberg. The festival, in its second year, will include films like Andersson's debut "A Swedish Love Story" and "A Pigeon Sat on a Branch Reflecting on Existence", as well as documentaries like "Nice People" and "We are the Best". The event aims to highlight Swedish films' ability to combine stunning visuals, social commentary, and exploration of the human condition.

site_title: UK on track to trigger Article 50 by end-March
summary: The UK is on track to trigger Article 50, the formal process to leave the EU, by the end of March, following an overwhelming majority vote in the House of Commons. The House of Lords is expected to pass the Brexit Bill, paving the way for the government to begin negotiations with the EU. However, parliamentary interventions could hinder the UK's strategy to secure favorable deals, with Labour opposition and some parliamentarians urging the government to consider the impact on jobs, living standards, and the economy.

site_title: Election freebies set to herald spending spree in rural India
summary: India's Uttar Pradesh state is set to vote in legislative elections, with politicians promising freebies such as smartphones, pressure cookers, and toilets. Prime Minister Narendra Modi's Bharatiya Janata Party is offering a range of freebies, including a laptop loaded with one year's worth of free internet and a toilet for each household within five years. Analysts expect sustained spending could lift rural incomes and benefit sectors like autos and consumer goods, potentially benefiting from a period of depressed consumption following the government's November ban on larger-denomination rupee notes.

site_title: Heavy snow hits US northeast
summary: A heavy winter snow storm hit the northeastern US on February 9, 2017, causing near-blizzard-like conditions in New York, with 10-14 inches of snow expected to accumulate. Flight cancellations were reported, with nearly 3,000 flights affected, and schools and the UN headquarters closed. Mayor Bill de Blasio urged people to stay home, while Governor Chris Christie closed state offices in New Jersey. The storm's impact was felt across the region, with Boston and Philadelphia also closing schools.

site_title: A different Metallica on new record
summary: Metallica guitarist Kirk Hammett discusses the band's new record, Hardwired... To Self-Destruct, which marks their first studio effort in eight years. Due to lead singer James Hetfield's vocal strain, the band postponed a concert and Hammett focused on guitar solos, resulting in a unique sound. To promote the album, Metallica released music videos for all 12 tracks, aiming to stake their claim on the songs and create lasting visuals. The band is now touring behind the album, playing epic shows with a focus on recovery and maintenance.

site_title: More support for 'high-growth' enterprises to scale up
summary: Singapore's Committee on the Future Economy (CFE) released a report outlining the country's economic direction for 5-10 years, focusing on strengthening enterprise capabilities to innovate and scale up. Minister for Trade and Industry S Iswaran emphasized the importance of developing such capabilities to sustain economic growth. The report suggests ideas such as twinning big and small firms, improving access to financing, and encouraging digitalization to support high-growth enterprises.

site_title: China tightens controls on Bitcoin trading platforms
summary: China's central bank has introduced new controls on bitcoin trading platforms, banning margin trading and practices that could be linked to money laundering or foreign exchange violations. The move aims to curb capital flight, estimated at $700 billion in 2016, as investors move out of China. The restrictions apply to nine Beijing-based platforms, including BTC China, Okcoin, and Huobi, which account for 98.4% of global bitcoin trade. The crackdown may boost the price of bitcoin, with traders shorting the currency due to regulatory uncertainty.

site_title: SBST profit soars 87.6% to S$31.4m
summary: SBS Transit, a unit of ComfortDelGro, reported a 87.6% surge in net profit to S$31.4 million for the year ended Dec 31, 2016, driven by a turnaround in its public transport business. Revenue climbed 7.3% to S$1,098.7 million, with public transport services contributing 7.5% growth. The company expects revenue from public transport services to be higher in 2017, with bus and rail services expected to benefit from the Bus Contracting Model and higher ridership.

site_title: Air France to hire 1,000 cabin crew, wants to save US$37.37m
summary: Air France plans to hire 1,000 new cabin crew for its low-cost, long-haul company, which aims to reduce operating costs by 20% compared to Air France. The move is expected to save $37.37 million, primarily due to lower pilots' costs. The airline's CEO, Franck Terner, aims to achieve these savings through the new company, which will operate independently. The hiring of new cabin crew is part of Air France's efforts to expand its low-cost operations and improve its financial performance.

site_title: Singtel prepares for NetLink Trust IPO
summary: Singtel is preparing to divest more than 75% of its shareholding in NetLink Trust (NLT), a subsidiary that operates fibre broadband networks in Singapore. Analysts estimate the IPO could raise S$2.5 billion. NLT's operating revenue rose 12% and Ebitda 11% in the last quarter, driven by growth in residential fibre end-users. Singtel's net profit grew 2% to S$973 million, despite a 1.5% drop in revenue. The company has appointed three investment bankers to advise on the IPO, which is expected to occur in the second quarter of this year.

site_title: Buyout firm KKR to hike dividend payout; earnings disappoints
summary: KKR & Co LP, a private equity firm, will raise its quarterly dividend payout to 17 cents a share from 16 cents, starting from March. The move comes after posting lower-than-expected fourth-quarter earnings due to unrealized losses in its buyout investments. KKR earned $339.2 million in economic net income, beating analyst forecasts of 43 cents a share. The company's private equity returns rose 3.4% in the fourth quarter, in line with the S&P 500 index.

site_title: KSH posts 33.9% fall in Q3 net profit
summary: KSH Holdings reported a 33.9% decline in Q3 net profit to S$9.1 million, down from S$13.8 million a year ago. Revenue dropped 33.6% to S$35.9 million, primarily due to a decrease in construction segment revenue. Associate shares fell 86.8% and joint venture shares gained S$4.0 million, reversing a Q3 loss last year. The company's counter ended trading unchanged at 54.0 S cents.

site_title: Nokia seeks to buy Finnish telecoms software firm Comptel for US$370m
summary: Nokia is seeking to acquire Finnish telecoms software firm Comptel for $370 million, as mobile operators increasingly rely on software to make their networks more intelligent. Nokia aims to build a standalone software business, while Comptel's virtualisation product could potentially weaken Nokia's network sales. The cash offer represents a 29% premium compared to Comptel's last closing price, with Comptel's board of directors backing the deal.

site_title: US: Oil prices prop up Wall St; Nasdaq hits record high
summary: US stocks rose on Thursday, with the Nasdaq hitting a record high, driven by higher oil prices and a strong earnings season. Oil prices rose 1.5% for the second straight day, supported by a draw in US gasoline inventories. The S&P 500 energy sector was up 0.9%, while the Nasdaq Composite rose 0.2% to a record high. Despite a muted reaction to corporate earnings, investors remain cautiously optimistic, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 0.16% and the S&P 500 just 2 points shy of its all-time high.

site_title: No-frills, enjoyable Korean food
summary: Ho Rang I, a no-frills Korean eatery in Goldhill Centre, offers straightforward and tasty dishes without pretenses. The restaurant, previously known as Your Woul, serves classic Korean favorites like Tteokpokki, japchae, and Naengmyeon with a comprehensive variety of kimchi and gochujang-based flavors. The food is enjoyable, if not exceptional, and the prices are friendly, making it a great option for those seeking authentic Korean cuisine without the fuss. The restaurant's lack of polish is part of its charm, with friendly service and a welcoming atmosphere. Rating: 7/10.

site_title: Wind blows by coal in Europe: data
summary: Wind power has overtaken coal as the second largest form of power generation by capacity in Europe, according to WindEurope's annual review. Europe installed 12.5 GW of gross additional wind capacity in 2016, bringing the total installed capacity to 153.7 GW. Wind power accounted for 51% of new power installations and covered 10.4% of Europe's electricity demand. The industry lobby group notes that government policy on energy across Europe is less clear and ambitious than it was a few years ago, with over half the member states investing nothing in wind energy last year.

site_title: Workers launch strike at Escondida, world's number 1 copper mine
summary: Workers at BHP Billiton's Escondida, the world's largest copper mine, launched a strike in Chile, disrupting global copper supply. The strike, which began on Thursday, follows weeks of labor negotiations over a new salary and benefits scheme. The union, citing unequal treatment of new and longtime workers, has warned of a lengthy strike. Production at the mine and port has been halted, with only a few workers remaining to perform critical duties. The strike threatens to impact the international supply of copper, with copper prices easing slightly amid the supply disruption.

site_title: Alibaba accuses IP firms of filing fake counterfeit claims
summary: Alibaba accused several intellectual property agencies of filing false claims against vendors on its e-commerce platforms. The company singled out Hangzhou Wangwei Technology Ltd, stating it would no longer process claims made by the firm. Alibaba called for a boycott of these "reputation-protection" firms, which are hired by businesses to manage IP rights. The company aims to protect its vendors from false claims and ensure the integrity of its systems.

site_title: Twitter reports slowest quarterly revenue growth, shares slide
summary: Twitter reported its slowest quarterly revenue growth, with a 1% increase to $717.2 million, missing analyst estimates. The company's shares fell 10% to $16.81. Despite this, Twitter's user base grew 4% to 319 million average monthly active users, beating expectations. The company cited increased user growth due to the US Presidential election and President Trump's Twitter usage. Twitter's adjusted profit beat lowered estimates, but the net loss widened to $167.1 million.

site_title: EU must shut coal plants by 2030 to meet climate pledge: study
summary: The European Union must shut all 315 of its coal-fired power plants by 2030 to meet its Paris climate agreement commitments. This goal, set in 2015, aims to limit global temperature increases to less than 2°C. Climate Analytics reports that the phaseout is necessary for a rapid decarbonization of the power sector. The EU's coal plants must be closed by 2030 to meet this target, marking a significant step towards reducing greenhouse gas emissions and achieving the Paris Agreement's goals.

site_title: Deepen training, adapt to changes
summary: The Committee on the Future Economy has proposed seven strategies to help Singaporeans adapt to a rapidly changing job market. The strategies include deepening and refreshing skills, building on the SkillsFuture movement, and offering more modularized training programs that are technology-enabled and industry-approved. The government is also recommended to set up an online one-stop education portal and enhance the National Jobs Bank to improve job matching. The committee aims to ensure that workers can apply their skills in their work and adapt to new job demands, switch jobs or industries as the economy transforms.

images.alt_text: Singaporeans need to stop merely chasing grades and start seeking knowledge and experience. They must also be given opportunities in their work to apply what they have learnt.

site_title: US jobless claims near 43-year low; wholesale inventories surge
summary: US jobless claims fell to near a 43-year low, dropping 12,000 to 234,000 in the week ended Feb 4, indicating a strong labor market. Wholesale inventories surged 1.0% in December for a second straight month, with sales increasing 2.6% - the largest gain since 2011. The labor market is near full employment, with the unemployment rate at 4.8%, potentially boosting wage growth.

site_title: EU to take more legal action against nations soft on carmakers
summary: The European Union plans to take more legal action against nations that have failed to enforce regulations on car industry cheating, following the Volkswagen emissions scandal. Industry Commissioner Elzbieta Bienkowska said governments have obstructed the EU's efforts, and a draft proposal aims to overhaul rules on authorizing new vehicles. The EU executive has already begun legal cases against Germany, Britain, and five other EU members, with more cases to come. A new type approval system is needed to prevent similar scandals. Lawmakers are expected to approve the draft with minor amendments.

site_title: Tiong Woon swings into profit of S$1.82m in Q2
summary: Tiong Woon Corporation Holding Ltd reported a net profit of S$1.82 million for Q2 2017, reversing a net loss of S$67,000 in the previous quarter. Revenue decreased 12% to S$31.26 million, primarily due to a slowdown in demand. The company expects public sector infrastructure development in Singapore to drive business opportunities. Tiong Woon plans to manage costs, explore strategic collaborations, and target high-value projects to grow its business.

site_title: Pan-United reports 43% rise in Q4 profit
summary: Pan-United Corporation Ltd reported a 43% rise in Q4 profit to S$3.55 million, driven by lower losses from discontinued operations and higher share of associate results. Revenue slipped 10% to S$176.8 million due to weak demand and prices in the concrete and cement division. Group CEO May Ng emphasized the need for cost improvement initiatives and investing in innovation and new technologies to fortify fundamentals against future market conditions.

site_title: Coca-Cola reports seventh straight drop in quarterly revenue
summary: Coca-Cola Co reported its seventh consecutive quarter of declining revenue, with a 6% drop in quarterly revenue due to high inflation in Latin America and a strong dollar. Net income fell to $550 million, or 13 cents per share, from $1.24 billion, or 28 cents per share, in the previous year. The company attributed the decline to a $919 million charge related to refranchising bottling operations in North America.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: The Committee on the Future Economy (CFE) in Singapore released 7 strategies to help the country achieve a 2-3% annual growth target. After consulting over 9,000 stakeholders, the recommendations focus on transforming the economy, enhancing innovation, and increasing productivity. Meanwhile, global economic trends show Vietnam being surprised by the US tariff announcement, and the Asian garment industry bracing for higher tariffs. Additionally, China's GDP growth is expected to slow, and the UK economy contracted for the second month in a row, with Malaysia seizing assets from Daim Zainuddin.

site_title: Snap to spend US$1b on Amazon cloud services
summary: Snap Inc plans to spend $1 billion over five years on Amazon cloud services, in addition to its existing $2 billion contract with Google. This investment may lead to the company building its own infrastructure. The filing also revealed that users outside North America and Europe, with limited cellular networks, tend to be more interested in consuming content rather than creating it, making them easier targets for competitors. Snapchat has over 100 million active users, mostly millennials, and may be valued at $20-$25 billion in its planned IPO.

site_title: Founding Tan family to take Spindex private in cash offer of 85 cents/share
summary: The founding Tan family of Singapore-listed Spindex Industries Limited has accepted a cash offer to acquire the company at 85 cents per share under a scheme of arrangement. The offer represents a 23.4% premium over the volume weighted average price for the three-month period. The takeover is expected to result in the delisting of the group, and the offeror intends to use private vehicle Hong Wei Holdings Ltd to undertake the acquisition.

site_title: Canada's Manulife hits US$3.1 billion profit milestone
summary: Canada's Manulife Financial Corp achieved an annual profit of US$3.1 billion in 2016, exceeding analyst expectations. The company's core earnings totaled C$4.02 billion, driven by investment gains and improved results in Asia, where insurance sales surged 27% in 2016. Manulife's expansion in Asia, particularly through a partnership with DBS Group, contributed to the milestone. The company's shares have risen by over a quarter since Donald Trump's election, driven by expectations of infrastructure spending and higher interest rates.

site_title: Commerzbank's weak earnings' outlook disappoints investors
summary: Commerzbank reported flat fourth-quarter earnings, blaming low interest rates, weak loan demand, and its shipping industry exposure. The bank expects net profit to remain low this year, with no specific earnings target given. As part of its restructuring efforts, Commerzbank cut more than a fifth of its workforce and suspended its dividend in September. The bank also reduced 2016 bonus payments by a third, approximately 100 million euros.

site_title: Viacom profit beats on higher theater, affiliate revenues
summary: Viacom Inc reported a better-than-expected quarterly profit, driven by growth in domestic affiliate and theatrical revenues. Revenue from the film business increased 24% to $758 million, beating analyst estimates. Viacom's media networks business saw a 5.39% rise in revenue to $3.32 billion, while net income fell to $396 million. The company's new CEO, Bob Bakish, is focusing on six "flagship" brands: Nickelodeon, MTV, Comedy Central, and Paramount, as part of a strategy to turn around the business.

site_title: Singapore shares finish higher, STI and Catalist Index at 52-week highs
summary: Singapore's stocks reached 52-week highs on Thursday, with the FTSE ST Catalist Index jumping 0.6% to 512.58, and the Straits Times Index rising 13.43 points to 3,079.96. The STI index has now reached its highest point this year. NOBLE Group reclaimed the top spot in the actives list with 250 million shares traded, driven by rotational trading of penny stocks. The rally comes ahead of Singapore's GDP data release.

site_title: Frasers Centrepoint reports 79% leap in Q1 net profit
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Limited reported a 79% jump in Q1 net profit to S$253.3 million, driven by higher contributions from its Singapore and international business units. Revenue increased 45% to S$972.0 million. The company attributed the growth to development profits from China and the sale of a Holland Park bungalow in Singapore. Despite the strong earnings, Frasers Centrepoint shares ended 0.5 cents down at S$1.60.

site_title: West Coast Vale private housing site fetches 9 bids
summary: A 99-year leasehold private housing site along West Coast Vale in Singapore attracted nine bids, with China Construction (South Pacific) Development Co. securing the top bid of S$291.99 million (S$591.51 per square foot). This is 0.7% above MCC Land's second-highest bid of S$289.9 million (S$587.28 per square foot). The 1.64-hectare site may yield up to 520 residential units.

site_title: HMI posts 1% drop in Q2 profit
summary: Health Management International Ltd (HMI) posted a 1% drop in net profit for Q2 2016 to RM5.33 million, driven by revenue growth of 11% to RM106.9 million. Patient load increased 5.8% and average bill sizes rose 7.6% and 4.7% for inpatient and outpatient services, respectively. A new hospital extension block is planned, increasing capacity and expected to begin construction in 2017. HMI also plans to consolidate its ownership of Mahkota and Regency to 100% for RM556.5 million.

site_title: Post-Brexit customs barriers threaten end of seamless UK-EU supply chains
summary: A post-Brexit customs barrier is threatening the UK-EU supply chains, potentially causing increased costs and time delays. The EU's customs union allows for tariff-free trading between member states, but when Britain leaves, tariffs and administrative burdens may be imposed. UK manufacturers, such as Brandauer, which exports to the EU, are concerned about the impact on their competitiveness and customer strategies. The government has not provided a clear plan for managing the transition, and manufacturers are waiting to see what impact the tariffs will have on their businesses.

site_title: Bank of England fines two Japanese banks for lack of communication with regulator
summary: The Bank of England fined Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi UFJ Limited (BTMU) £17.85m and MUFG Securities EMEA PLC £8.9m for failing to be open with the regulator about a US enforcement action. The action, by the New York Department of Financial Services, had previously fined BTMU £315m for pressuring a consultant to water down a report on dealings with sanctioned countries. The two banks did not inform the regulator of the DFS action until after it was publicly announced.

site_title: PEC Limited wins maintenance contract for Vietnam petrochem plant
summary: PEC Limited has secured a seven-year contract to provide daily maintenance services for Vietnam's largest refinery and petrochemical plant, Nghi Son Refinery and Petrochemical Limited Liability Company. The contract, valued in millions of dollars, is expected to affirm PEC's reputation as a trusted partner and grow its overseas maintenance business. The plant is expected to reach full capacity by 2020 and will not have a material impact on PEC's earnings or balance sheet for the current financial year.

images.alt_text: PLANT and terminal engineering specialist PEC Limited has secured a seven-year contract for the largest refinery and petrochemical plant in Vietnam.

site_title: Germany brings its gold stash home sooner than planned
summary: Germany's central bank, the Bundesbank, is bringing home its gold reserves faster than planned, with 583 tonnes already moved from New York and Paris. The goal is to have half its 3,378-tonne gold stockpile in Frankfurt by the end of 2017, ahead of its 2020 schedule. This move aims to boost confidence in the euro and counter concerns about the currency's stability, particularly amid rising nationalism in Europe. The relocation has cost 6.9 million euros so far, and the Bundesbank has no plans to move more of the reserves.

site_title: SIA to place US$13.8b order for Boeing aircraft to drive additional growth
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) has agreed to place firm orders with Boeing for 39 aircraft, valued at US$13.8 billion, to drive additional growth and fleet modernization through the next decade. The order includes 20 777-9s and 19 787-10s, with deliveries starting from 2020/21 and 2021/22 financial years, respectively. The move aims to maintain the airline's industry-leading position, according to CEO Goh Choon Phong.

site_title: Quick takes: CFE paints broad strategies, key is in implementation
summary: The Committee on the Future Economy (CFE) released seven strategies to reshape Singapore's economy, aiming for 2-3% annual growth. The recommendations include maintaining a globally competitive manufacturing sector, focusing on skills acquisition and lifelong learning, and innovation. Economists note that implementation is key to success, with some predicting a 1.8% GDP growth in 2017. The strategies are seen as a response to emerging shifts towards protectionism and insular growth, and the need for Singapore to stay connected through free trade and investments.

site_title: Euro zone bond yields back away from multi-month highs
summary: Euro zone bond yields retreated from multi-month highs on Thursday, as investors calmed concerns about French election risks and unwinding of ECB monetary stimulus. France's 10-year bond yield dropped 1 basis point to 1%, while Italy's and Spain's yields fell 3 basis points each. German bonds rose 1 basis point, narrowing the gap with safe-haven yields. Despite relief, analysts warn that renewed worries about Greece's bailout program and potential debt relief could impact investor sentiment.

images.alt_text: Most euro zone government bond yields pulled back from recent multi-month highs on Thursday, as investors put aside worries about political risks and returned to some of the bloc's most beaten-down markets.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks fall as investors brace for US-Japan talks
summary: Tokyo stocks fell Thursday as investors awaited Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's weekend meeting with Donald Trump, citing uncertainty over the global economic outlook and US economic policy. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index lost 0.53%, while Toyota, Nissan, and Hitachi plummeted due to concerns over the US president's trade policies and Japan's economic prospects. The yen's erratic performance also weighed on investors, making it difficult to predict market movements.

site_title: Hot stock: Artivision Tech says online articles on company could be behind heavy trading
summary: Artivision Tech, a video advertising tech company, attributed unusual trading activity to online articles on investment websites and forums. The company stated that it had not provided writers of online content with non-disclosed information, and their views remain their own. Shareholders and investors are urged to exercise caution when trading the company's shares. On Thursday, Artivision Tech's shares dropped 6.45% after over 108 million units were traded.

site_title: India's Vijay Mallya sacked from United Breweries board
summary: India's United Breweries has fired Vijay Mallya from his non-executive chairman role following an order from the Securities and Exchange Board of India (SEBI). Mallya, who owes banks at least $1 billion, has been barred from holding key managerial roles in any listed company. The decision comes after a Karnataka high court issued a 'winding-up' order on United Breweries Holdings Ltd, directing an official liquidator to take over all assets. Mallya remains a part-owner of the Force India Formula One team.

site_title: Japan took in just 28 refugees in 2016, despite record applications
summary: Japan accepted just 28 refugees in 2016, despite a record 10,901 asylum applications, according to a government document. This represents a 44% increase from the previous year, when 27 refugees were accepted. The accepted refugees came from Afghanistan, Ethiopia, and Eritrea, but it's unclear if any Syrians applied for or received asylum. The low acceptance rate highlights Japan's reluctance to accept foreigners, sparking criticism.

site_title: SocGen says 2016 profits hit by Croatian sale
summary: Societe Generale reported a 3.2% drop in net profit to 3.87 billion euros in 2016, largely due to losses from the sale of its Croatian subsidiary and accounting expenses. The bank beat forecasts, with CEO Frederic Oudea attributing the results to good commercial and operating performances despite an uncertain economic environment. The bank simplified its banking model, optimised capital allocation, and continued to invest in future businesses.

site_title: Boustead Projects reports 19% growth in Q3 net profit
summary: Boustead Projects reported a 19% increase in Q3 net profit to S$8.5 million, despite a 22% decline in revenue to S$66.6 million, mainly due to lower expenses. The company's design-and-build business contributed less to revenue, while lower selling and distribution expenses boosted the bottomline.

site_title: Total on hunt for acquisitions as cost cuts lift profit
summary: French oil company Total reported a 16% year-over-year increase in adjusted net profit to $2.4 billion, beating analyst forecasts, and raised its quarterly dividend to 0.62 euros per share. CEO Patrick Pouyanne attributed the results to cost cuts, which reduced production costs to $5.9 per barrel of oil equivalent, and savings of $2.8 billion in 2016. Total plans to invest $16-$17 billion in 2017, including resource acquisitions, and forecasts production growth of over 4%. Pouyanne said the company is in a "field of opportunities" to buy assets from struggling rivals, citing a prolonged downturn in oil prices.

site_title: Germany reports new record trade surplus in 2016
summary: Germany reported a new record trade surplus in 2016, with exports reaching 1.2 trillion euros and imports at 955 billion euros, resulting in a surplus of 253 billion euros. This marks the highest surplus on record. The high surplus may fuel criticism that Germany exports too much and fails to reinvest the proceeds.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.17% on Thursday, following a similar trend in most Asian markets, as investors sought undervalued mainland firms listed in the city. The Hang Seng Index ended at 23,525.14, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also gained 0.51% and 0.66% respectively. This uptick was attributed to investors' optimism about the Chinese economy.

site_title: ARA Asset Management Q4 2016 net falls 28%; firm gets regulatory approval for privatisation
summary: ARA Asset Management reported a 28% decline in Q4 2016 net profit to S$18.5 million due to lower acquisition fees and increased costs. The company, set to be privatized, has obtained regulatory approvals for the scheme of arrangement. The privatisation bid, led by founder John Lim, values the company at S$1.78 billion and will be implemented through a scheme of arrangement. ARA and the special-purpose vehicle, Athena Investment Company, will hold a shareholders' meeting by March 31, 2017, to obtain shareholder approval and a court order.

site_title: SBST profit soars 87.6% to S$31.4m
summary: SBS Transit's net profit for the year ended Dec 31, 2016, surged 87.6% to S$31.4 million, driven by a turnaround in its public transport business. Revenue rose 7.3% to S$1.09 billion, with earnings per share increasing to 10.12 cents. A tax-exempt one-tier final dividend of 2.70 cents per share has been proposed, up from 1.05 cents the previous year. This marks a significant improvement from the previous year, with net asset value per share increasing to S$1.35.

site_title: China jails former chief of state-owned automaker FAW for graft
summary: A Chinese court has jailed former chairman and party secretary of China FAW Group Corp, Xu Jianyi, for 11-1/2 years on graft charges. Xu accepted 12.2 million yuan (US$1.8 million) in bribes and cooperated with authorities to return the illegal gains. The conviction is part of China's ongoing anti-corruption campaign led by President Xi Jinping, who has vowed to target both high-ranking officials and lower-ranking "flies".

site_title: Nordic Group bags S$7.7m worth of contracts
summary: Nordic Group, a Mainboard-listed company, has secured contracts worth approximately S$7.7 million from new and repeat customers across various industries. The contracts involve maintenance, insulation, scaffolding, and other services for ad-hoc and capital projects. The company's wholly-owned subsidiaries won these contracts, marking a significant milestone for the organization.

site_title: Soo Kee to expand into Thailand through JV
summary: Soo Kee Group, a Catalist-listed company, is expanding into Thailand through a joint venture with Aurora Group. The 40:60 joint venture will operate Love & Co, Soo Kee's bridal jewellery brand, with initial paid-up capital of 30 million baht. The partnership aims to capitalize on Thailand's growing luxury market and large population. Soo Kee will license intellectual property rights, products, and support, while Aurora will run operations. This move is seen as a strategic entry into the Thai market, driven by increasing affluence and rising consumerism.

images.alt_text: CATALIST-LISTED Soo Kee Group is expanding into Thailand by bringing its bridal jewellery brand Love & Co there through a joint venture.

site_title: Nissan Q3 profit below expectations on yen strength, cost rise
summary: Nissan Motor Co. reported a weaker-than-expected operating profit of 163.5 billion yen (US$1.46 billion) for the third quarter, due to higher marketing costs and a stronger yen. Despite improving domestic sales and strong demand for certain models in North America and China, the decline was attributed to the yen's average rate of 109.4 yen to the US dollar during the quarter. Nissan left its full-year net profit forecast unchanged at 525.0 billion yen, while maintaining its operating profit forecast at 710.0 billion yen.

site_title: Seoul: Won, stocks move narrowly ahead of US, Japan summit
summary: South Korean won traded narrowly ahead of a summit between US President Donald Trump and Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe, closing at 1,145.8 to the US dollar. The won remained steady despite offshore investors buying 54.8 billion won worth of Kospi shares. South Korean shares held steady at 2,065.88 points, and investors took a cautious stance due to potential influence on Japan's yen currency and Asian currencies. The summit's outcome could have significant effects on global markets.

site_title: SBF welcomes CFE's recommendations, to play bigger role in supporting businesses
summary: The Singapore Business Federation (SBF) has welcomed the Committee on the Future Economy's (CFE) recommendations to better position Singapore's economy. The SBF aims to partner the government in supporting businesses, particularly small and medium enterprises (SMEs), through transformation and upgrading to the new economy. However, the SBF cautions that addressing near-term issues is crucial to help viable businesses and SMEs overcome economic headwinds in the short term.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets rise at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets rose at the start of trading on Thursday, with London's FTSE 100 index up 0.2% to 7,203.23 points, and the eurozone's Frankfurt DAX 30 gaining 0.3% to 11,584.4 points. The Paris CAC 40 added 0.6% to 4,793.01. The gains were attributed to mining and healthcare stocks, while US-EU trade talks were also in focus.

site_title: Moody's upgrades Indonesia outlook to positive as finances improve
summary: Moody's upgraded Indonesia's credit outlook to "positive" from "stable", citing the country's progress on reforms and efforts to control finances despite falling commodity prices. The upgrade comes as Indonesia seeks to attract foreign investment, with its rupiah currency and stock index edging up. Moody's reaffirmed its Baa3 investment-grade debt rating and noted Indonesia's increased stability and fiscal discipline. A potential ratings upgrade by S&P is expected, with analysts citing improving fiscal spending and stabilized bank non-performing loans.

site_title: 7 'mutually reinforcing' strategies to keep Singapore open, focus on innovation and adaptability
summary: Singapore's Committee on the Future Economy (CFE) has proposed seven strategies to spur quality economic growth over the next decade, focusing on innovation, adaptability, and staying connected to the world. The strategies include developing in-market expertise, establishing a Global Innovation Alliance, and promoting a broad-based, progressive, and competitive tax regime. The CFE aims to give Singapore a competitive edge against larger countries, while acknowledging the need to address "nativist politics and protectionist economics" that gained ground in 2016.

site_title: Former DBS bankers back fintech remittance start-up
summary: Former DBS bankers Rajan Raju and Edwin Khoo are backing Singapore fintech start-up SingX, which has launched a cheaper and faster online remittance platform. The platform charges a fraction of typical remittance fees, saving consumers up to 90% of usual charges. SingX, led by Atul Garg, offers live foreign exchange rates and secure data transmission methods, and plans to expand its services to Malaysia, Hong Kong, Australia, and other countries.

site_title: Baidu to fold embattled medical business into AI, search units
summary: Baidu Inc, China's search engine giant, is refocusing its business strategy after authorities cracked down on medical advertising, leading to a decline in sales. The company will close some medical businesses and integrate others into its artificial intelligence and search teams, aiming to develop medical applications such as drug development and patient diagnosis. CEO Robin Li sees artificial intelligence as a key driver for growth, following the appointment of former Microsoft executive Qi Lu as chief operating officer.

images.alt_text: Chinese search engine giant Baidu Inc will close some of its medical businesses and fold other health segments into its artificial intelligence and search teams, the firm said in a statement sent to Reuters on Thursday.

site_title: Alibaba's Ant Financial to raise US$2-US$3b in debt: source
summary: Ant Financial, a subsidiary of Alibaba Group, is in talks with banks to raise US$2-US$3 billion in debt for international expansion. The funds will be used for acquisitions, such as the upcoming purchase of MoneyGram International Inc, and boosting existing investments. Ant Financial, valued at US$60 billion after a recent funding round, is making a push to expand its presence overseas amid increased competition from Tencent Holdings' Wechat payment system. The company is controlled by Alibaba founder Jack Ma and is set to go public, although a specific timeframe or listing venue has not been announced.

site_title: Singapore manufacturing to be at 20% of GDP over medium term: CFE
summary: The Committee on the Future Economy (CFE) has proposed that Singapore's manufacturing sector should contribute around 20% of GDP over the medium term. The report emphasizes the importance of high-tech manufacturing and high-end services, such as advanced manufacturing and the Industrial Internet of Things. This recommendation aims to position Singapore as a globally competitive manufacturing hub, driving economic growth and diversification.

site_title: Australia shares edge up, AMP jumps on plan to trim business risk; NZ also rise
summary: Australian stocks rose 0.2% to 5,664.6, supported by AMP Ltd's 4% gain after plans to trim business risk. Real estate companies GPT Group and Westfield Corp also rose. Meanwhile, New Zealand's benchmark index rose 0.8% to 7,121.63, driven by expectations of stimulatory central bank policy. AGL Energy and SkyCity Entertainment also saw significant gains. The Australian central bank held interest rates steady, and the New Zealand central bank flagged a potential two-year or more period of low rates.

site_title: China to take fingerprints of foreign visitors as security step
summary: China will begin taking fingerprints of all foreign visitors aged 14-70 at Shenzhen airport, starting Friday, as part of enhanced security measures. The fingerprinting will be gradually rolled out at other entry points nationwide. The move aims to strengthen border security without specifying whether other biometric data will be collected.

site_title: Greece should quit euro zone, get debt relief, German party leader says
summary: Greece should leave the euro zone and receive debt relief, according to Christian Lindner, leader of Germany's Free Democrats party. Lindner stated that Greece needs debt relief outside the euro zone, suggesting a "Grexit" strategy. He also emphasized that Greece should remain in the European Union to access subsidies for infrastructure and small businesses. This proposal comes after Lindner criticized Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras for not implementing agreed reforms.

images.alt_text: Greece should leave the euro zone and then be given debt relief, the head of Germany's pro-business Free Democrats (FDP) told a German radio station on Thursday.

site_title: 9/11 mastermind tells Obama attacks were America's fault
summary: Khalid Sheikh Mohammed, the self-proclaimed mastermind of the 9/11 attacks, wrote a 2015 letter to former President Barack Obama, blaming American foreign policy for the attacks and saying God aided the hijackers. The letter lists grievances against the US, including its treatment of Palestinians and support for Israel. Mohammed, who faces a potential death sentence, expressed happiness at the prospect of death and meeting Allah and his deceased friends. The letter was delivered to the White House two years later, during Obama's presidency.

site_title: IBM to train 25m Africans for free to build workforce
summary: IBM plans to invest $99.19 million over five years to train 25 million Africans in digital skills, aiming to build a future workforce on the continent. The program, starting in South Africa, will also benefit Nigeria, Kenya, Morocco, and Egypt. With 31% of South Africans aged 15-24 unemployed, the initiative seeks to address unemployment and equip the workforce for the digital age. The move is part of IBM's efforts to expand its digital-skills training program across Africa.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks hit over 20-month high; techs jump
summary: Taiwan's stocks reached a 20-month high, with the main Taiex index rising 0.49% to 9,589.88, driven by gains in technology exporters like Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co and Hon Hai Precision Industry, a major Apple iPhone assembler. The broader index has gained 4% year-to-date, boosted by investor sentiment following the Dow Jones' multiple breaches of the 20,000 level.

site_title: China's response to Thaad does not warrant South Korean action: minister
summary: South Korea's finance minister, Yoo Il-Ho, stated that China has not taken retaliatory measures against South Korean companies due to plans to deploy the US Terminal High Altitude Area Defence (Thaad) system. China strongly objects to the deployment, which South Korea is set to proceed with later this year. If necessary, South Korea is prepared to lodge a formal complaint.

site_title: Indonesia accepts Australian apology over military row
summary: Indonesia has accepted an Australian apology over military row, following a dispute over teaching materials deemed offensive to Jakarta. The materials, containing comments on Papua's independence movement and Indonesia's state ideology, were found at an Australian army base where Indonesian forces were training. The partial suspension of military ties was lifted after Australian Army Chief Angus Campbell apologized and promised improvements to the Indonesian language education program. Indonesia's military chief Gatot Nurmantyo accepted the apology and will report to President Joko Widodo on restoring full ties.

site_title: Singapore's HDB resale prices, volume fall in January: SRX
summary: Singapore's HDB resale prices and volume decreased in January, according to a SRX flash report. Resale prices fell 0.3% month-on-month, with 3-room and 4-room flats experiencing a 0.6% and 0.5% drop, respectively. However, 5-room and executive flats saw a 0.4% and 0.9% increase. Resale volume decreased 13.9% to 1,174 units, compared to 1,364 in December 2016. HDB prices in mature estates dropped 0.7%, while non-mature estates remained unchanged.

site_title: Singtel hires three banks for NetLink Trust IPO
summary: Singtel hires Morgan Stanley, UBS Group AG, and DBS Group Holdings Ltd as advisers for the initial public offering (IPO) of its NetLink Trust fiber broadband network unit. The company aims to divest over 75% stake by April 2018, citing a regulator's deadline. Proceeds from the sale may be used for capital management and investments, or returned to shareholders. NetLink Trust's operating revenue and earnings have grown, driven by increased fiber penetration in Singapore, and contributed 42% to Singtel's profit in the fiscal third quarter.

site_title: Judge blocks Anthem-Cigna health insurance mega-merger
summary: A US judge blocked Anthem's plan to merge with Cigna, citing concerns that the merger would substantially lessen competition in the health insurance market. The $50 billion deal was opposed by the Department of Justice and 11 US states, which argued that it would lead to increased health insurance prices and reduced innovation. The judge ruled that Anthem's argument that the merger would outweigh anticompetitive effects was not a valid defense. This is the second major health insurance merger to be blocked in recent months, following the rejection of Aetna's $37 billion acquisition of Humana.

site_title: Seoul: Won, stocks calm; cautious ahead of Trump-Abe summit
summary: South Korea's won remained stable against the US dollar ahead of the Trump-Abe summit, trading at 1,146.8 to the dollar. Stocks also remained nearly unchanged, with the Kospi index at 2,068.81 points. Offshore investors sold Kospi shares worth 55.5 billion won, with Posco climbing 2.2% and SK Hynix falling 3.5%. The market is cautious, with analysts expecting the summit to have a significant impact on financial markets.

site_title: Japan firm drops Mexico plant plan over Trump warnings
summary: A Japanese auto parts maker, Nisshinbo Holdings, has dropped plans to build a factory in Mexico after US President Donald Trump criticized Toyota for a plant in the country. This marks the first time a Japanese company has abandoned a Mexico facility due to Trump's protectionist comments. The decision comes as Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe is meeting with Trump in Washington, aiming to strengthen ties and Japan's investment in the US.

site_title: Polls show French far-right Le Pen winning election first round, but losing knockout
summary: Marine Le Pen, leader of the French far-right National Front, is projected to win the first round of France's presidential election with 24% of the vote, according to a survey. Emmanuel Macron, a centrist, would take 21%, while Francois Fillon, a conservative, trails with 19%. Le Pen is expected to lose the runoff to Macron, who would win by a 63-37 margin. The top two candidates will advance to the May 7 runoff, with only they eligible to compete for the presidency.

site_title: China's yuan firms, traders wary of depreciation impulse
summary: China's yuan strengthened against the US dollar, firming to 6.8710 per dollar, amid falling US bond yields. However, traders remain cautious, expecting further depreciation over the short term. The yuan fell 6.6% against the dollar in 2016, but recent measures to curb capital outflow have stabilized it. The spread between onshore and offshore yuan rates narrowed to 200 pips, with offshore yuan trading 0.25% firmer than the onshore spot.

site_title: Jeff Sessions confirmed as next US Attorney General
summary: The US Senate voted 52-47 to confirm Republican Senator Jeff Sessions as the next Attorney General of the United States. Sessions, known for his tough stance on immigration enforcement and early support for President Donald Trump, was nominated for the job.

images.alt_text: The US Senate voted on Wednesday to confirm Republican Senator Jeff Sessions as the next attorney general of the United States.

site_title: Asia: Markets edge up but uncertainty reigns
summary: Asian markets rose on Thursday, with Hong Kong and Shanghai gaining 0.4% and 0.2% respectively, while Seoul and Sydney edged lower. The uncertainty surrounding US President Donald Trump's protectionist agenda continues to weigh on markets, with the dollar falling against the yen and euro. Despite the US stock market reaching new highs, Asian traders remain cautious, with investors focusing on the potential for a trade war. Gold prices extended their gains, rising 8% since the start of the year.

site_title: Australian banks face renewed push for intrusive inquiry
summary: Australian lawmakers have won support for a wide-ranging inquiry into the country's major banks, amid public anger over corporate misconduct and market dominance. Independent lawmaker Bob Katter will introduce a bill in parliament to set up an inquiry, which could create a headache for the "Big Four" banks. The inquiry comes after years of record profits and a series of financial scandals, with the major lenders controlling 80% of the country's lending. A Royal Commission has been ruled out by Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull's conservative government, instead opting for a lesser parliamentary inquiry.

site_title: PM Abe to propose US-Japan cabinet level talks to Trump: govt source
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe plans to propose a new cabinet-level framework for US-Japan talks on trade, security, and macroeconomic issues during his meeting with President Donald Trump on Friday. The proposal aims to address Trump's concerns over Japan's military spending and currency, which he claims are contributing to the US trade deficit. Abe hopes to persuade Trump to maintain the decades-old alliance and reduce tensions on trade and currency issues.

site_title: Trump blasts retailer Nordstrom, raising new concern on business ties
summary: US President Donald Trump criticized department store Nordstrom for dropping his daughter Ivanka's clothing line, calling it a "direct attack" on his policies. Nordstrom cited declining sales of the line as the reason for the decision. Critics accused Trump of misusing public office to benefit his family's business interests, with ethics experts saying the tweet was unprecedented and troublesome. Trump's arrangement with his business empire remains opaque, and his daughter's brand still sells at other retailers. The incident has sparked a boycott effort and raised concerns about conflicts of interest.

site_title: Jack Nicholson to make big screen return: reports
summary: Jack Nicholson is set to make his first film appearance in 7 years with the English-language remake of German dramedy Toni Erdmann, alongside Kristen Wiig. Paramount Pictures has acquired the rights to the Oscar-nominated film, with Adam McKay producing. Nicholson, 79, had previously retired from acting after 2010's How Do You Know. The remake is a remake of Ade's Oscar-nominated film, which tells a bittersweet father-daughter tale. Nicholson's return to the big screen marks his first film since 2010.

site_title: NZ dollar drops after RBNZ disappoints hawks, Aussie dollar dragged lower
summary: The New Zealand dollar dropped to US$0.7225 after the Reserve Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ) kept interest rates at 1.75% and indicated no rate hike until at least two years away, disappointing market expectations. The kiwi has shed over 1% this week, its first weekly loss this year. The Aussie dollar also fell in sympathy, down 0.3% against its US peer. The RBNZ's decision reduced the likelihood of a rate hike by the end of 2017, now seen at just 50%.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.21% on February 9, 2017, extending the previous day's gains, driven by a record close on Wall Street. The Hang Seng Index reached 23,533.52 points. In contrast, Shanghai and Shenzhen composite indexes edged down. The gains were attributed to investor optimism despite US-EU trade tensions.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Singtel, GLP, Natural Cool, Neo Group, AA Reit
summary: Singapore Telecommunications (Singtel) posted a 2% increase in net profit to S$972.8 million for the third quarter, driven by higher dividends from its cables unit and currency revaluation gains. Global Logistic Properties (GLP) reported a 7.3% fall in net profit to S$170.7 million, while Natural Cool Holding ousted its entire board except for the CEO. Neo Group's net profit plummeted 97.4% to S$0.125 million, and AIMS AMP Capital Industrial Reit (AA Reit) saw a 2.8% decrease in distribution per unit to 2.77 Singapore cents.

site_title: Trump, in letter to China's Xi, seeks 'constructive relationship'
summary: US President Donald Trump sent a letter to China's President Xi Jinping, expressing his desire to develop a "constructive relationship" between the two countries. The letter, sent on February 9, 2017, thanked Xi for his congratulatory note on Trump's inauguration and wished the Chinese people a prosperous Year of the Rooster. This marks Trump's first direct communication with Xi since taking office on January 20. The letter comes after China's top diplomat, Yang Jiechi, discussed potential cooperation on managing disputes and sensitive problems with Trump's National Security Advisor, Michael Flynn.

site_title: Natural Cool board, except for CEO, ousted at second EGM
summary: Natural Cool Holdings' entire board, except CEO Tsng Joo Peng, was ousted at the second extraordinary general meeting (EGM). Disgruntled shareholders voted to remove executive chairman Joseph Ang, his brother Eric Ang, and other directors. This is the second attempt to oust Ang and most board members, following a narrow margin of votes in December. New directors Lau Lee Hua, Tan Siew Bin Ronnie, Goh Teck Sia, and Wong Leon Keat were appointed. The ouster is linked to shareholders unhappy with the board's decision to issue new shares to incoming CEO Ng Quek Peng.

site_title: Australia shares slip on basic materials stocks; NZ higher
summary: Australia's shares fell 0.2% to 5,641, as losses in basic materials stocks outweighed gains in the utilities sector. The materials index dropped 1.1% despite higher commodity prices, with miners Rio Tinto, BHP Billiton, and Fortescue Metals experiencing declines. In contrast, the utilities sector rose, driven by AGL Energy's 3.7% increase in underlying profit. New Zealand's benchmark index rose 0.67% to 7,113.82, led by consumer and industrials stocks.

site_title: Australian new home sales edge up in Dec: survey
summary: Australian new home sales rose 0.2% seasonally in December, following a 6.1% jump in November, according to the Housing Industry Association. House sales dipped 1.6%, while apartment sales climbed 6.4%. The strong December sales rebounded from a weak October, with HIA chief economist Harley Dale noting it's better for sales to bounce back rather than decline.

site_title: UK house buyers lose interest as weak supply represses market
summary: UK house buyers lost interest in January, with new buyer inquiries at a 5-month low due to weak supply and waning affordability. The Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors reported a decline in instructions from sellers, marking an 11th consecutive month in negative territory. The national housing market remains resilient, but economists expect price inflation to cool in 2017. The government aims to increase supply by forcing local councils to set out plans for more housing construction, amid concerns that home ownership is becoming prohibitively expensive for many young people.

site_title: Gold hovers near 3-month highs; political uncertainty provides support
summary: Gold prices hovered near three-month highs, supported by political uncertainty and concerns over US President Donald Trump's policies. Spot gold dipped 0.1% to $1,240.46 per ounce, while US gold futures rose 0.2% to $1,242 an ounce. Investors are cautious due to risks from European elections, Trump's policies, and potential interest rate hikes. Speculators increased net longs, and gold-backed exchange-traded funds rose, driving gold prices up.

images.alt_text: Gold held near three-month highs on Thursday as political risks from elections in Europe and worries over US President Donald Trump's policies buoyed safe haven demand for the bullion.

site_title: Trump slams courts as judges mull travel ban
summary: US President Donald Trump criticized the courts as "so political" as a panel of federal appeals judges considers reinstating his travel ban targeting mainly Muslim countries. The ban, which was suspended nationwide after a federal court froze it, has sparked a firestorm and eroded public support. Trump's comments have also drawn criticism from his own Supreme Court nominee Neil Gorsuch, who described the ban as "disheartening" and "demoralizing". The court must decide whether to maintain the suspension or lift it before the end of the week, with experts predicting an uphill struggle for the government's argument.

site_title: GLP's Q3 profit down 7.3% to US$170.7m
summary: Global Logistic Properties (GLP) reported a 7.3% decrease in net profit to US$170.7 million in its third quarter, due to higher forex losses. Revenue rose 16.9% to US$232.5 million, driven by completed development projects in China and increased management fee income. Earnings per share fell 7.4% to 3.48 Singapore cents. No dividends were declared for this period.

site_title: US queries PayPal in money laundering probe
summary: US authorities have demanded information from PayPal as part of a money laundering investigation, according to a regulatory filing. PayPal stated it received subpoenas from the US Department of Justice seeking information related to its historical anti-money laundering program. The company is cooperating with authorities and did not speculate on the outcome of the investigation. No further details were provided.

site_title: Kellogg to switch delivery model for US snacks unit to cut costs
summary: Kellogg Co will switch its US snacks business' delivery model from direct store distribution to a warehouse model to cut costs and adapt to changing retail landscapes. The decision is part of Kellogg's "Project K" programme, which aims to save US$475 million annually by 2018. The change will result in the closure of distribution centers and layoffs, although details are not provided. The move is expected to be completed by the fourth quarter of 2017, and Kellogg believes it will help grow the business in the long term.

images.alt_text: Corn Flakes maker Kellogg Co said on Wednesday it would stop distributing its US snacks business'products directly to stores and switch to its more widely used warehouse model to cut costs and adapt to a changing retail landscape.

site_title: Japan Dec core machinery orders rise 6.7% month-on-month: Govt
summary: Japan's core machinery orders rose 6.7% in December from the previous month, exceeding economists' expectations of a 3.1% gain. This follows a 5.1% decline in November and suggests a tentative pickup in capital expenditure. Core orders, excluding ships and electric power utilities, grew 6.7% year-over-year in December. Manufacturers forecast a 3.3% increase in core orders for the January-March quarter. The data provides a tentative sign of economic recovery in Japan.

site_title: Catering group Neo's Q3 profit plunges 97.4%
summary: Neo Group's Q3 2017 net profit plummeted 97.4% to S$0.125 million due to the absence of a one-time gain from the bargain purchase of subsidiaries in Q3 2016. Revenue grew 23.4% to S$46.7 million, primarily driven by a S$7.6 million increase in the food and catering supplies business. Earnings per share dropped to 0.09 Singapore cents, compared to 3.34 cents in the previous year.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Thursday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Thursday, with the benchmark Nikkei 225 index falling 0.44% to 18,924.77. The decline was driven by a strong yen and investor caution ahead of a meeting between Japanese Prime Minister and US President Donald Trump. The Topix index also fell 0.52%. The market's cautious tone follows recent tariff threats between the US and EU, which has sparked concerns about global economic stability.

site_title: Singtel's Q3 profit rises 2% to S$972.8m
summary: Singtel reported a 2% increase in net profit to S$972.8 million for Q3 2016, driven by higher dividends from its cables unit and currency revaluation gains. Revenue fell 2% to S$4.41 billion due to mandated mobile termination rate cuts in Australia. Excluding this impact, revenue would have grown 3%. No dividends were proposed for the period.

site_title: Malaysia: Markets closed for public holiday
summary: Malaysia's financial markets are closed on Thursday due to Thaipusam, resuming trading on Friday, Feb 10. Meanwhile, global markets experienced fluctuations, with European stocks down due to bank and healthcare sector drag, while US stocks edged down from records amid tariff threats. Asia's stocks continued their rally, and traders brushed off new Trump threats. Notable news includes a mandatory offer for PSC shares and stocks to watch, including Singtel, Sinarmas Land, and Cordlife.

site_title: South Korea says weak consumption may persist, drag on economy
summary: South Korea's finance ministry stated that weak consumption may persist, negatively impacting the economy, due to US policy changes and domestic consumer sentiment affected by a political scandal. The recent export recovery is a positive factor, but slow growth in consumption remains a drag on the overall economy. The ministry's assessment noted that the economy is recovering, but consumption continues to be a significant obstacle to growth.

site_title: Singapore shares open flat on Thursday
summary: Singapore stocks opened 0.02% higher on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) adding 0.61 point to 3,067.14, following a slight retreat in Tokyo. Investors became cautious ahead of a weekend meeting between Japanese Prime Minister and US President Donald Trump. About 55 million shares worth S$37.7 million changed hands, with International Healthcare Corporation rising 5% to S$0.10 after announcing a convertible loan facility.

site_title: Tesla aims to start pilot production of Model 3 cars on Feb 20: sources
summary: Tesla plans to start pilot production of Model 3 cars on February 20, according to sources, potentially alleviating concerns about meeting its July production target. The initial production will likely involve a small number of vehicles to test the assembly system and quality of parts. Tesla CEO Elon Musk previously stated he aimed to start building Model 3s in July 2017, but this move could indicate a shift in the timeline.

site_title: UK's May has reasons to worry despite her Brexit law victory
summary: Theresa May's Brexit law victory in the UK House of Commons may come at a price. The prime minister's concession to lawmakers allowing an early vote on the final pact could be seen as a temporary measure to buy off rebels, potentially undermining her Brexit strategy. The outcome hinges on whether opponents can organize a vote against her deal, with some predicting the government could collapse if lawmakers reject it.

images.alt_text: Theresa May's latest Brexit victory should leave her happy - but might ultimately come at a price.

site_title: AA Reit's Q3 DPU down 2.8% to 2.77 cents
summary: AA Reit reported a 2.8% decrease in distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.77 Singapore cents for its Q3 2016, down from 2.85 cents last year. The decline was due to a 6.7% fall in gross revenue, mainly from lower rental contributions and redevelopment expenses. Net property income also slipped 6% to S$19.8 million. Higher property expenses offset the decrease, with higher rental and recoveries at 29 Woodlands Industrial Park E1.

site_title: World's biggest shipping company voices alarm at Trump trade war
summary: AP Moller-Maersk, the world's largest container shipping company, is warning of a potential trade war with China due to US President Donald Trump's rhetoric. A trade war could negatively impact Maersk's business, with Goldman Sachs estimating a 25% drop in Chinese exports to the US and a 1% decrease in China's economic growth. Maersk's CEO, Soren Skou, expressed concern that a trade war would have a "very negative effect" on their business, while also noting potential benefits from US tax proposals and infrastructure investments.

site_title: Italy unveils plan to better integrate fewer migrants
summary: Italy's government has unveiled a plan to better integrate fewer migrants, including a new push for integration and efforts to curb the influx. Asylum seekers will be asked to work on civic projects with little or no pay, and migrants whose applications are rejected will be expelled. The government aims to distribute migrants more evenly across the country and provide 100 million euros to municipalities accepting increased shares. However, critics argue the plan exploits migrants and may exacerbate youth unemployment, with some regional councils opposing the initiative.

site_title: Katy Perry sets off global scavenger hunt with new song
summary: Katy Perry launched a global scavenger hunt on social media, encouraging her 95 million followers to find disco balls in cities worldwide. Those who find a disco ball can hear a snippet of her new song "Chained to the Rhythm," a retro dance track combining disco and reggae. The song is set to be released on Friday, and Perry is scheduled to perform at the Grammy Awards on Sunday. The scavenger hunt is believed to be a preview for a new album, which follows the success of her 2013 album "Prism."

site_title: US dollar slips as US Treasury yields decline
summary: The US dollar fell on Wednesday due to declining US Treasury yields amid uncertainty about President Donald Trump's economic policies. Investors have priced out a March rate hike by the Federal Reserve, and concerns about Trump's protectionism and immigration policy have weakened the dollar. The yen rose as investors sought a safe-haven asset amid global political risks, particularly in Europe. US Treasury yields fell to a three-week low, and the euro inched higher against the US dollar.

site_title: Europe: Britain's FTSE steadies as housebuilders offset weaker commodities
summary: Britain's FTSE 100 index closed flat at 7,188.82 points, despite a rally led by housing stocks, as a drop in energy stock prices offset the gain. The index underperformed European peers, with the STOXX 600 index up 0.3%. Housebuilder Redrow rose 4% after posting a first-half profit increase. The UK mid-cap index reached a fresh record closing level, 0.3% higher.

site_title: Indonesia's biggest lender Bank Mandiri to boost loans to miners
summary: Indonesia's largest bank, Bank Mandiri, plans to boost lending to the country's mining industry, citing improved cash flow and stronger prices for coal. The bank's CEO, Kartika Wirjoatmodjo, expressed confidence in the sector, but noted caution in lending. This move comes after Indonesian banks reduced their lending exposure to mining in recent years due to falling commodity prices. Lending to miners now accounts for 6% of Bank Mandiri's total outstanding loans, up from 5% in the previous year.

site_title: Pentagon seeks to rent space in Trump Tower
summary: The Pentagon has requested to rent space in Trump Tower in New York for equipment and military personnel accompanying President Donald Trump during his stays at the residence. The request is part of a broader effort to support the President's official duties, despite potential concerns over conflicts of interest due to Trump's vast real estate holdings. The lease is reportedly around $1.5 million per year for a full floor, and the Pentagon has previously rented space near private presidential residences.

site_title: France's Hollande plans farewell Asia tour for March
summary: French President Francois Hollande plans a farewell Asia tour in late March, visiting Singapore, Malaysia, and Indonesia. He praised Singapore as a "country of innovation" and Malaysia as one of France's main economic partners in Asean. Hollande also highlighted Indonesia's large Muslim population and tolerant Islam, allowing for shared messages of peace. This tour comes as Hollande has decided not to run for re-election in April and May.

site_title: Boeing said front-runner for US$13.8b Singapore Air order
summary: Singapore Airlines is close to ordering 20-35 wide-body aircraft from Boeing, valued at $13.8 billion, to replace aging models and gain rights to Boeing aircraft not yet on the market. The order includes 19 Boeing 787-10 jets and possibly a longer version of the twin-engine 777. The deal would provide a boost to Boeing's 777X family and its 787-10 product, amid a tough market for twin-aisle jets.

site_title: Impairment, revaluation dampen Perennial's Q4
summary: Perennial Real Estate Holdings reported a 37.8% fall in Q4 net profit due to impairment costs and revaluation of investment properties. Despite this, the company remains bullish on China's healthcare sector, with plans to expand into the market. The group's CEO expects flat growth in Singapore and is focusing on China's growing healthcare sector, which he believes lacks medical care and is being promoted by the Chinese government.

site_title: World's biggest copper mine faces 'long, hard' strike
summary: Workers at the world's largest copper mine, Escondida in Chile, are launching a "long and hard" strike on Thursday, citing pay increases as the reason. The 2,500 workers, 99% of whom voted to strike, are protesting a 7% raise and bonuses of 25 million pesos offered by BHP Billiton, the world's largest mining company. The strike, which may last for an extended period, has sent copper prices higher due to fears of a shortage. The Chilean mine supplies one-third of global copper output.

site_title: Europe: Earnings support shares but political jitters hit banks
summary: European shares rose 0.3% on Wednesday, driven by strong earnings updates, but bank stocks fell, weighed down by concerns over the region's election agenda. The French presidential election, with Marine Le Pen's strong showing, kept investors on edge. Despite this, good earnings reports from Vinci, ACS, Storebrand, and Vestas supported the STOXX 600 index, which remains flat for the week.

site_title: Travel to US down 6.5% after Trump travel ban: report
summary: Travel bookings to the US fell 6.5% in late January compared to last year, following President Trump's travel ban, according to a report. Bookings from seven Muslim-majority countries were down 80% due to the ban. The US travel industry saw a significant drop in bookings from Western Europe and the Asia Pacific region, with declines of 14% and 6.6% respectively. The data suggests the travel ban had an immediate impact on future travel, posing a challenge to the US economy.

images.alt_text: Travel bookings to the United States fell 6.5 per cent in late January compared to last year in the wake of President Donald Trump's travel ban, according to a report Wednesday.

site_title: IMF 'ruthless truth tellers' on Greece economy: Lagarde
summary: IMF chief Christine Lagarde defended the organization's pessimistic outlook for Greece's economy, calling itself a "ruthless truth teller" despite criticism. The IMF report highlighted incomplete reforms and overly optimistic growth estimates. Greece Finance Minister Euclid Tsakalotos disputed the report, saying it underestimates growth and progress. The central issue is Greece's ability to deliver a primary balance of 3.5% of GDP, which the IMF says is not feasible. The dispute has delayed progress on Greece's 86-billion-euro bailout program.

site_title: New Zealand leaves interest rates at record low
summary: New Zealand's central bank maintained its record-low interest rate of 1.75% as it indicated it would stay there for a considerable period, barring global shocks. The decision was made after the country's inflation rate hit the Reserve Bank's target of 1.0-3.0% for the first time in two years. Governor Graeme Wheeler expressed concerns over geo-political uncertainty and the high New Zealand dollar, but did not see a need for an imminent rate move, citing well-anchored long-term inflation expectations.

site_title: British MPs approve bill to start Brexit
summary: British MPs voted 494-122 in favor of a bill allowing Prime Minister Theresa May to start Brexit negotiations, bringing the UK a step closer to leaving the European Union. The two-clause bill now moves to the House of Lords, where opposition from peers may intensify. The vote puts May on course to begin the withdrawal process by the end of March, despite concerns from lawmakers about the potential consequences of leaving the single market.

images.alt_text: British MPs overwhelmingly backed a bill on Wednesday empowering Prime Minister Theresa May to start negotiations on leaving the European Union, bringing Brexit a significant step closer.

site_title: Boris Johnson renounces US citizenship
summary: British Foreign Minister Boris Johnson has renounced his US citizenship, according to a US Treasury Department document. Johnson, born in New York, had held both British and US passports and previously stated his intention to give up dual nationality for patriotic reasons. The renunciation was made early in 2016, but the process took time to complete. Johnson's decision comes after he settled a capital gains tax bill sent by the US, calling the demand "absolutely outrageous".

site_title: Pinterest lets phones spy eye-catching items
summary: Pinterest has introduced "Lens," a test version that allows users to take pictures with smartphones from within Pinterest applications, using "visual search" to find similar items or themes. This feature enables users to identify products they might want to pursue more easily. According to Pinterest co-founder Evan Sharp, this feature addresses the challenge of searching for products online after spotting them in real life.

site_title: UK business investment hit by pressure for shareholder returns: BoE
summary: The Bank of England found that 80% of publicly listed UK companies believe short-term shareholder returns pressure hinders investment. One-third of firms feel they haven't invested enough in their operations. Business investment in the UK has grown at 1.5% annually, half the rate of the past 40 years. The BoE expects weak investment to persist as the UK prepares to leave the EU, citing access to finance and target return rates as potential issues. This is a factor in the country's poor productivity growth, which lags other rich nations.

site_title: Intel CEO joins Trump to tout US chip factory
summary: Intel CEO Brian Krzanich announced a $7 billion chip factory in Arizona, with plans to produce advanced 7-nanometre semiconductor chips and create 3,000 high-tech jobs. The investment was made in partnership with President Donald Trump, who credited the plan to his administration's tax and regulatory policies. Intel had previously considered investing in the facility in 2011 but ultimately decided against it due to lack of demand. The company's move comes as the tech sector has opposed the Trump administration's travel ban, which affects the hiring and retention of foreign-born scientists and engineers.

site_title: US: Nasdaq edges to record while Dow retreats
summary: US stocks closed with mixed results on Wednesday, with the Nasdaq Composite Index reaching a record close of 5,682.45, up 0.2%, and the S&P 500 gaining 0.1%. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.2% to 20,054.34, pressured by weak banking stocks. EBay and Tesla Motors drove the tech sector higher, while Macy's, Gap, and Wal-Mart Stores scored gains. However, Gilead Sciences plummeted 8.6% on disappointing forecast, and Goodyear Tire & Rubber lost 0.3% due to higher raw material costs.

site_title: Oil prices edge up on short covering, gasoline jumps
summary: Oil prices rose slightly on Wednesday as investors covered short positions after a smaller-than-expected increase in US crude inventories.
