Crude stocks rose 13.8 million barrels, while gasoline stocks decreased. Gasoline futures jumped 3% after a surprise decline in inventories. Analysts say the market is now in a "technical game" of price levels, with speculators potentially retreating from positions.

images.alt_text: Oil prices rose slightly on Wednesday as investors covered short positions when a big rise in US crude inventories was not as massive as many had feared, while gasoline futures jumped more than 3 per cent after a surprise decline in inventories of the fuel.

site_title: China developers priced for disaster are bargains to Goldman, Citigroup
summary: China's property developers are undervalued, according to top analysts from Goldman Sachs and Citigroup, despite recent curbs on the market. The Bloomberg Intelligence real estate index is near an all-time low, but contracted sales at leading developers are expected to jump 15% this year. Analysts predict a sector-wide rally lasting 3-4 months, with some developers' shares surging over 20% in the first quarter. Despite government restrictions, analysts believe the sector is due for a rebound, with Morgan Stanley upgrading the property sector to "attractive".

site_title: New York City frames fresh rules to help 'three-quarter home' tenants
summary: The New York City Council passed five bills aimed at improving living conditions and protecting tenants of "three-quarter houses," unregulated flophouses that provide temporary housing for people with substance-abuse problems or mental illnesses. The laws, sponsored by several council members, would prohibit landlords from interfering with tenants' medical treatment, improve access to emergency relocation services, and require public assistance recipients to be informed of their housing rights. The bills also mandate regular inspections of three-quarter homes and create a way for tenants to take landlords to Housing Court.

site_title: Volvo Cars posts strong earnings on record sales
summary: Volvo Cars reported a 90% increase in net profit to 5.94 billion kronor (S$896.7 million) in 2016, driven by record sales of over 534,000 cars, a 6% rise from 2015. The company's sales climbed by 10% and CEO Hakan Samuelsson expects 2017 to be another record year. Volvo has made a remarkable comeback since 2010, when it was taken over by Chinese group Geely. The company plans to hire 800 people at its plant in Gothenburg and manufacture cars in the US in 2018.

site_title: JLL research head leaves to join ARA
summary: JLL's head of South-east Asia research, Chua Yang Liang, is leaving the company to join ARA Asset Management's private funds arm as head of research and strategies. Dr. Chua, 47, will join ARA in April after submitting his resignation at JLL. He has held the position at JLL since 2006 and previously lectured at the University of Pennsylvania. JLL is seeking a replacement for Dr. Chua, who will oversee ARA's portfolio of funds including the ARA Asia Dragon Funds series.

site_title: Netflix plans new toys, merchandise based on hit TV shows
summary: Netflix is expanding into the toy and merchandise business, hiring an executive to oversee licensing of shows for books, comics, and toys. The company has already conducted a test with Hot Topic Inc, selling merchandise tied to the hit show Stranger Things. This move aims to generate additional revenue and market hit programs to a wider audience. Netflix is in an experimental phase and is not seeking to become a major player in the toy industry, but rather leveraging consumer products to promote its titles.

site_title: China woos Trump family in bid to maintain stable ties with US
summary: China is attempting to establish a direct link with US President Donald Trump's family to maintain stable relations and avoid a trade war or military confrontation. Following a private meeting between Jared Kushner and Chinese Ambassador Cui Tiankai, Ivanka Trump visited the Chinese Embassy in Washington, meeting with Ambassador Cui and showcasing a positive image of China-US relations. China views this approach as a successful strategy, similar to one employed with the Bush family, and aims to empower the Trump family's role in decision-making, despite criticism from some in the administration.

site_title: Baltimore brings in the bulldozers as it seeks to bring back its rich past
summary: Baltimore is spending millions to demolish blighted rowhouses, hoping to revitalize the city's struggling communities. The city has torn down over 500 rowhouses in the past two years, with plans to clear away all 17,000 boarded-up properties costing around $500 million. Residents, including the last owner of one of the demolished homes, Mable Olds, are divided on the issue, with some fearing the demolitions will displace long-time residents. City officials say the demolitions will boost property values and create green space, but critics argue it may be a ploy to gentrify the area and displace low-income residents.

site_title: Serba fails to sustain intraday high in Bursa debut
summary: Serba Dinamik Holdings Bhd, an oil and gas engineering solutions provider, rose to an intraday high of RM1.59 on its debut on Bursa Malaysia, but shed gains to close two sen higher due to a lacklustre market and investor cautiousness. Despite valuations as high as RM2.25, analysts see positives, including a 23-year track record, strong management, and international presence. However, the sector remains underweight, with AffinHwang Research now neutral, and faces competition from bigger players. Analysts predict earnings growth of 26% for FY17F, but note risks including lower-than-expected orderbook replenishments and competition.

site_title: China stops major Lotte construction project amid Thaad tension
summary: China has halted major construction on a multi-billion dollar real estate project by South Korea's Lotte Group in Shenyang, amid tensions over the US missile defense system Thaad. The halt comes amid a string of inspections at Lotte's Chinese ventures, which South Korean media believes is retaliation by Beijing. Lotte's project, which includes a department store and movie theatre, was halted in December. The move is seen as a response to South Korea's decision to deploy Thaad, which Beijing claims threatens its security.

site_title: AECOM picked to conduct engineering study for HSR
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) of Singapore has appointed AECOM Singapore to conduct the advanced engineering study (AES) for the design of the High Speed Rail (HSR) infrastructure within Singapore, including the Jurong East terminus, tunnels, and bridge across the Strait of Johor.

site_title: UK's May gets invite to China's Silk Road summit: sources
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May has been invited to attend China's "One Belt, One Road" summit in May, diplomatic sources confirmed. The summit aims to invest billions of dollars in infrastructure projects across Asia, Africa, and Europe. May will visit China to discuss trade ties, as London seeks to strengthen its relationship with China before negotiating Britain's exit from the European Union. The summit will feature leaders from about 20 countries, with Sri Lanka and the Philippines already confirmed attendees.

images.alt_text: Chinese President Xi Jinping with Mrs May in Hangzhou during the G-20 Summit in September, when he invited her to visit China again.

site_title: US solar industry clamours for workers as jobs climb by 25%
summary: US solar industry employment surged 25% in 2016, with 260,000 workers, making one out of every 50 new American jobs. The industry expects a 29% increase in installed capacity this year. Companies like SunPower and Canadian Solar are hiring, and solar jobs are considered well-paying with a median wage of $26 an hour. Despite President Trump's pledge to boost the coal industry, the solar industry is expected to continue growing, driven by energy security and national security concerns.

site_title: Now there's an app for those affected by Trump's refugee ban
summary: A group of lawyers and software developers created an app, AirportLawyer.org, to connect travelers arriving at US airports from countries affected by President Trump's refugee ban with volunteer attorneys for free legal help. The app, launched Monday, allows travelers to upload personal information and travel plans, which are then shared with volunteer lawyers who can track arrivals and meet travelers. The app aims to help alleviate the challenges faced by thousands of travelers detained or struggling to clear customs since the ban was signed in January.

site_title: Airbnb partners aid agency for refugees
summary: Airbnb has partnered with the International Rescue Committee to provide short-term accommodation for refugees over the next five years, aiming to house 100,000 people. The company has pledged $4 million to the IRC and encourages customers to host refugees through its campaign. This move follows Airbnb's previous offer of free accommodation to refugees barred from entering the US due to President Trump's immigration curbs, which have since been temporarily suspended. The partnership aims to provide a sense of belonging to those displaced by conflict or other factors.

site_title: Saudi Aramco and SGX not quite an odd couple
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) has seen its bid to acquire a piece of Saudi Aramco's planned initial public offering (IPO) gain momentum due to the shift in global political winds over the past year. As anti-Muslim sentiment increases in the US and Europe, Singapore appears more politically stable, which may favor Saudi Aramco's decision to consider listing on multiple exchanges. SGX has held discussions with Saudi Aramco, which is planning an IPO next year, amid rising global market uncertainty and geopolitical tensions.

site_title: Canada pledges S$401m loan to Bombardier for jet programmes
summary: Canada has pledged S$401.1 million in repayable loans to Bombardier Inc for its jet programmes, including the CSeries and Global 7000 business jet. The loans, worth C$372.5 million, are interest-free and will be provided over four years. The move is aimed at supporting Bombardier's financial situation, but it risks exacerbating trade tensions with Brazil, which has threatened to take Canada to the World Trade Organization over a similar investment by Quebec. Canada's Trade Minister has vowed to defend the deal.

site_title: Raffles Education posts S$3.9m Q2 loss
summary: Raffles Education Corporation reported a net loss of S$3.91 million for the second quarter ended Dec 31, 2016, with revenue declining 17% to S$24.44 million. The decline was attributed to the discontinuation of a joint venture college, reduced utility income, and lower foreign student intake. The company also incurred higher operating expenses and a currency translation loss in the previous period. Despite this, Raffles Education aims to seek opportunities in new territories, but faces challenging market conditions due to global economic uncertainty.

site_title: Penny fever rages while STI dips
summary: Penny fever continued in the Singapore stock market, with 258 rises and 213 falls excluding warrants, indicating a firm broad market. The Straits Times Index dropped 5.11 points to 3,066.53, but unit volume remained high at 3.5 billion units. Interior design firm Serrano's counter rose 148% to S$0.072 on volume of 142 million, following a 3,500% two-day rise.

site_title: Globetrotting banker appeals to Nigerian diaspora to send money home
summary: A Nigerian banker, Tunji Adeyemi, is encouraging the Nigerian diaspora to deposit their pounds into Sterling Bank's vaults in Lagos. The bank aims to open 5,000 new accounts this year through its diaspora services program. Adeyemi met with a receptive audience in a Glasgow arts center, demonstrating the bank's push to engage with Nigerians abroad. This effort is part of the bank's year-old initiative to cater to the financial needs of the Nigerian diaspora.

images.alt_text: As head of Sterling Bank's year-old diaspora services programme. Mr Adeyemi travelled from Lagos to Glasgow, Manchester and Belfast to drum up 5,000 new accounts in Nigeria from Nigerians living in Britain. He is planning another multi-city trip, probably to Chicago and Atlanta, by April.

site_title: New Asia forex platform aims to create sparks
summary: A new Asia-based forex platform, Spark Systems, plans to launch a live trial in March, aiming to attract institutional investors and traders with lower fees than existing Western-dominated platforms. Backed by Singapore's central bank and Dymon Asia Capital, Spark seeks to improve liquidity in the region, which currently ranks third globally. The platform promises to charge lower fees, around $3 per $1 million in trades, and claims to match orders in just two milliseconds, compared to 200 milliseconds for routes to New York or London.

site_title: YouTube adds mobile video streaming for popular creators
summary: YouTube has introduced mobile live streaming for popular creators, allowing them to broadcast on the go using smartphones. The feature, available to creators with over 10,000 subscribers, is a challenge to Facebook and Twitter in the live-streaming arena. YouTube also introduced a "Super Chat" tool, enabling creators to earn money from fans who pay for highlighted chat messages. The move comes as Facebook has been testing a live audio streaming service, offering an alternative to its live video streaming tool.

site_title: Beijing tightens smog data controls amid public anger
summary: Beijing has established a single national network to monitor air pollution levels, aiming to control the spread of information and accelerate pollution reduction. The move comes after public anger over the country's toxic smog, following incidents of falsified data. The network will track pollutants using satellite sensing and airborne platforms, reducing the risk of manual forgery. The initiative coincides with government efforts to suppress reports on pollution's health risks, which have been linked to 257,000 excess deaths in Chinese cities.

site_title: Will driverless cars drive motor insurers to the wall?
summary: Singapore's motor insurance industry faces disruption from the increasing adoption of autonomous vehicles (AVs), which could lead to a 4% drop in premiums and a shift in the industry's business models. AVs equipped with sophisticated sensors can detect and prevent accidents, reducing claim ratios and premiums. New entrants in the market will offer innovative insurance products, increasing consumer choices and online purchases. The industry is expected to undergo significant changes, driven by digitalization, with a focus on transparency, simplicity, and convenience. Analysts predict that consumers will still need insurance even if they own self-driving cars, presenting opportunities for those who innovate and transform.

site_title: NYC officials step up efforts to create new, modern garment district
summary: New York City officials are launching a modern garment district in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, with a $115 million renovation of the Brooklyn Army Terminal. The initiative aims to support local garment manufacturers by providing affordable rents, access to transit and parking, and technology grants. The program, in partnership with the Council of Fashion Designers of America, has already awarded $1.8 million in grants to 19 companies since 2014. This move seeks to revitalize the city's struggling garment manufacturing industry, which has been impacted by rising costs and competition from overseas.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Singapore hospitality sector reports mixed results, with CDL Hospitality Trusts (-8.6%), OUE Hospitality Trust (-5.7%), and Ascott Residence Trust (-3.0%) experiencing decline in full-year RevPAR/RevPAU growth rates. However, analysts remain optimistic, citing global economic optimism and expected acquisitions. DBS Group Research recommends buying OUEHT, Frasers Hospitality Trust, and Courts Asia, citing compelling valuations and dividend yields. Analysts expect Courts Asia to post 30% core earnings growth and Frasers Hospitality Trust to pursue acquisition opportunities.

site_title: Freeport to cut mining activities at Indonesia copper mine
summary: Freeport-McMoran Inc will scale back activities at its Indonesian copper mine, Grasberg, amid a worker strike and other issues. The mine, the world's second-largest copper mine, will reduce output, affecting PT Smelting's copper smelter. The cutback is due to labor issues and disruptions, which have helped support a jump in copper prices. Freeport aims to meet its commitments to clients despite the strike and production delays.

site_title: Don't cry over stock market exits. Until growth returns, there'll be more
summary: Auric Pacific, a Singaporean bread maker, has delisted from the Singapore bourse, joining a growing list of companies exiting the market. The delisting is not a result of poor performance, but rather a strategic move by the company to restructure and focus on growth. Retail investors will continue to shrug off exits, as companies that can sell a story of growth will still be rewarded. The delisting trend is a reflection of the slow-growth environment and risk-averse investors, who prefer to stick to established companies like those in the top 30 stocks of the Straits Times Index.

site_title: English law faces Brexit uncertainties
summary: English law faces uncertainty due to Brexit, which threatens its continued viability in governing cross-border business contracts. The UK's decision to leave the EU has created uncertainty regarding the enforceability of English court judgments in EU member courts, and the jurisdiction of the English courts. In contrast, Singapore law is gaining acceptance as a viable alternative, particularly among Asian corporates, due to its established legal system and predictability. While English law's dominance is unlikely to diminish overnight, commercial considerations may dictate otherwise, with businesses increasingly opting for Singapore law in light of Brexit uncertainties.

site_title: Annual job creation over next 3-5 years to be 25,000-40,000: Swee Say
summary: Singapore aims to create 25,000 to 40,000 jobs annually over the next 3-5 years due to economic restructuring and an ageing workforce. Minister for Manpower Lim Swee Say stated that the number of jobs created in the last two years had decreased significantly, with 120,000 jobs lost. Efforts by Workforce Singapore and the Employment and Employability Institute have helped match about 20,000 people to jobs last year. Lim emphasized the need to address mismatches between jobseekers and job openings, focusing on professional conversion programmes and inclusive outreach to various segments of the workforce.

site_title: RBI to remove cash withdrawal limits
summary: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) announced that it will remove cash withdrawal limits entirely from March 13, allowing individuals to withdraw up to 50,000 rupees from ATMs. This decision comes after the government's surprise move to demonetize 500 and 1,000 rupee notes in November to combat tax evasion. The RBI also left interest rates unchanged at 6.25% despite pressure to cut rates amid concerns the cash ban has slowed economic growth.

site_title: Working women in Japan driving demand for wine
summary: Japan's growing ranks of working women are driving the demand for wine, with Chilean vintners benefiting the most. Since 2012, wine consumption in Japan has reached a new record, with sales increasing 4.5% annually. Chilean wines, priced under 2,000 yen, have found a receptive niche among women in their 40s and 50s, who are expanding their disposable incomes. The country has overtaken France as Japan's top wine supplier, with Vina Concha & Toro SA reporting a 24% jump in third-quarter sales volumes to Japan in November.

site_title: German carmakers bet on the digital wave
summary: German carmakers, including BMW, Daimler, and Volkswagen, are investing heavily in digital technologies to stay ahead of Silicon Valley competitors. The industry is shifting towards autonomous driving, electric cars, and ride-hailing apps, with many executives warning that the next 10-15 years will see more change than the last 100 years. German carmakers have formed partnerships with tech companies, such as Intel and IBM, to develop self-driving cars and use artificial intelligence. Industry 4.0, a government-backed initiative, aims to merge traditional manufacturing with digital technology to rejuvenate Germany's industrial base.

site_title: Playing the game of golf diplomacy
summary: US President Donald Trump's golf diplomacy with world leaders has had mixed results. Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull's attempt to build a personal connection with Trump through golf ended in a heated phone call after Trump rejected a refugee deal. Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe also used golf to create chemistry with Trump, but their relationship has also been strained. While golf diplomacy can be effective in forging personal connections, it has also led to embarrassing situations, such as when Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak faced criticism for playing golf with President Obama while his country was dealing with floods. Trump's golf resorts have raised concerns about foreign governments pressuring him or currying favor with him, and the issue of security for his businesses remains a concern.

site_title: Yum China's maiden quarterly earnings beat forecasts
summary: Yum China Holdings Inc, the Chinese fast food company spun off from its US parent, reported its first quarterly earnings beating forecasts with a profit of 17 US cents a share. Same-store sales growth at KFC helped, while Pizza Hut's performance was weaker. The company added 575 outlets last year, with plans to add 600 annually, to stay ahead of competitors like McDonald's and Starbucks. Despite a 2.4% drop in stock price, the results show a respectable start for the independent company.

site_title: What if China's forex reserves keep shrinking?
summary: China's foreign exchange reserves fell to $2.998 trillion in January, their lowest level since 2008, with a $12.3 billion drop in the month. The reserves, which hold roughly two-thirds of US dollars, are shrinking due to capital flight spurred by slowing growth and the weakening yuan, now near eight-year lows. Beijing is working to curb outflows through regulations and has recently rolled out stricter rules on foreign currency purchases and overseas acquisitions. If the yuan depreciates further, it could destabilize markets and fuel instability, which the Communist Party seeks to avoid.

site_title: China urges cornbelt regions to offer subsidies to boost use: sources
summary: China is urging regional authorities in the nation's top four corn-producing regions to offer subsidies to livestock feed companies to boost demand for a bumper crop. The State Administration of Grains and the Ministry of Finance issued a joint document on January 13 outlining the recommendations. This move aims to increase consumption of the surplus corn, which could help prevent a storage crisis.

site_title: Deutsche Bank investment chief in talks to leave: report
summary: Deutsche Bank's investment banking head, Jeffrey Urwin, is reportedly in talks to step down from his post, potentially passing responsibilities to CFO Marcus Schenck. Urwin, 61, has told colleagues he plans to retire after joining the bank in 2015 from JPMorgan Chase. His departure would be a stark turnaround, given his significant expansion of responsibilities under current CEO John Cryan. No immediate comment was available from the bank, and it's unclear if Schenck may be replaced as finance chief.

site_title: US fails to understand anti-terror duties: China state media
summary: US President Donald Trump's temporary ban on visitors from seven Muslim-majority countries has been criticized by Chinese state media as a failure to understand its counterterrorism duties. The ban, which was suspended by a federal judge, has been deemed unfair and could be used to justify terrorist causes. China's official Xinhua news agency stated that the US administration's move could pose a global threat and that the US should recognize its responsibility in the fight against terrorism.

site_title: Abe embarks on charm offensive to strengthen US-Japan ties in face of rising China
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe embarked on a charm offensive to strengthen US-Japan ties amid rising concerns about China's influence in the region. During his meetings with US President Donald Trump, Abe announced a multi-billion dollar package of Japanese investment measures to create jobs in the US, playing to Trump's "America First" narrative. The move aims to mitigate potential risks in the bilateral relationship given Trump's earlier negative comments on Japan. Abe also seeks to overturn Japan's post-war pacifist security identity, potentially leading to a more internationally engaged Japan, but this could exacerbate regional tensions with China.

site_title: Japan's Sharp may break ground on US$7b US plant in H1: source
summary: Sharp Corp may break ground on a US$7 billion plant in the US in the first half of 2017, taking the lead on a project initially outlined by its Taiwanese parent Foxconn. This move comes as Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe prepares to meet US President Donald Trump, who has vowed to prioritize US interests. Foxconn's CEO Terry Gou had previously discussed investing around US$7 billion in a display-making plant, but no decision has been made by Sharp.

site_title: Startup activity starts strong in February
summary: Singapore-based startups are off to a strong start in February, with ConneXionsAsia (CXA) raising US$25 million in Series-B funding, Paktor acquiring three global dating companies, and iFashion Group acquiring lifestyle-marketplace brand Megafash for S$3.15 million. CXA plans to expand into 10 Asian markets, while Paktor aims to accelerate the development of next-generation dating apps. iFashion is reportedly seeking an initial public offering on the Australian Securities Exchange. These deals demonstrate the growth and investment in Singapore's startup ecosystem.

site_title: Survey: One in four US tech workers feels discriminated against
summary: A survey of 1,002 US tech sector workers by Indeed.com found that 24% reported feeling discriminated against at their workplace due to race, gender, age, religion, or sexual orientation. The survey, conducted last December, highlights the issue of diversity in the tech industry. This finding is consistent with previous criticisms of the sector's lack of diversity.

site_title: Former Amazon's Fire TV head hired to help run Apple TV
summary: Apple has hired Timothy D Twerdahl, former head of Amazon's Fire TV unit, as a vice-president in charge of Apple TV product marketing. The move aims to revitalize the Apple TV product and negotiate more content deals. Twerdahl, who joined Apple this month, reports to Greg Joswiak, and his hiring frees Pete Distad to focus on content deals. This shift in focus comes as Apple TV sales decreased year-over-year in the 2016 holiday quarter. Twerdahl brings significant experience in internet-connected TV devices from his previous roles at Netflix and Roku.

site_title: How Goldman sees trade war hurting US-China GDP growth
summary: Goldman Sachs analysts predict a trade war between the US and China could lead to a 1% decrease in China's annual GDP growth and a 25% decline in China's exports to the US. The US could also suffer, with a potential 1.6% decrease in its annual GDP growth. To prevent the trade war, China could promote outbound tourism or open service industries to the US. The Trump administration is likely to impose targeted tariffs on Chinese products, and China may retaliate proportionately, potentially reallocating reserves or weakening the yuan.

site_title: Erdogan wants to erase secular Turkey: critics
summary: Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan is expected to call an April referendum to approve constitutional changes that would concentrate all executive power in the presidency, abolish the post of prime minister, and give him greater control over judicial appointments. Critics argue that Erdogan is attempting to erase the secular state established by Mustafa Kemal Ataturk, while supporters believe Turkey is changing and Erdogan's opponents are crying wolf. The government has been renaming streets and squares after the victory over last year's coup plotters, and thousands of new mosques have been built, including inside Erdogan's new presidential palace.

site_title: Work on Dakota pipeline might start in June
summary: The US Army is set to grant the final permit for the Dakota Access oil pipeline, allowing the $3.8 billion project to begin operation as early as June. This decision comes after President Donald Trump ordered the expedited project despite protests from Native American tribes and climate activists. The pipeline will tunnel under Lake Oahe in North Dakota, enabling its operation.

site_title: France's Fillon struggles to win back voters after job scandal
summary: French presidential candidate Francois Fillon is struggling to regain voter support after losing his frontrunner position due to accusations of fake jobs for his family. Despite attempts to regain momentum, Fillon's popularity ratings remain low, and his party lacks a clear "Plan B". The 62-year-old's reputation for integrity is at stake, and he faces a tough battle to convince voters. Fillon's appeal to voters via a newspaper column is a last-ditch effort to salvage his campaign.

site_title: Djibouti-Ethiopia rail showcases China's expertise and funding
summary: China has successfully completed a 745.6 km rail line connecting Djibouti and Ethiopia, showcasing its expertise and funding. The first electric, transnational railway in Africa, the train was inaugurated with a ceremonial run to Addis Ababa, with leaders from both countries praising its potential to change the social and economic landscape of the region. The project highlights China's growing influence in Africa's transportation infrastructure.

site_title: UK unveils measures to help renters
summary: The UK government has unveiled plans to make renting more affordable, protect tenants, and punish developers for not building quickly enough. The "Fixing our broken housing market" White Paper proposes building more homes for rent, extending tenancy lengths, and changing planning laws to boost supply. Local councils may also be given power to rescind planning permission or take control of land from underperforming developers. This shift marks a departure from decades of policy prioritizing home ownership, aiming to address the issue of demand outstripping supply and rising rents.

site_title: F&N posts 12% drop in first-quarter earnings to S$22.4m
summary: Fraser & Neave Limited (F&N) posted a 12.1% drop in net profit for the first quarter ended Dec 31, 2016, to S$22.44 million due to higher operating expenses. Revenue rose 0.2% to S$495 million, driven by growth in beverages and dairies segments. Operating expenses rose 7.9% to S$143.4 million, mainly due to distribution costs. F&N expects challenges in the printing and publishing segment and subdued consumer demand for food and beverages in core markets.

site_title: Connecting Trump's dots
summary: US President Donald Trump's incoherent worldview is leading to crises, including a potential trade war with China, a weakened US economy, and a strained relationship with Mexico and other Asian-Pacific allies. Trump's lack of respect for institutions and truth has resulted in reckless decisions, such as scrapping the Trans-Pacific Partnership and imposing tariffs on Vietnam, which may harm the Asian garment industry. His policies also threaten to disrupt the North American security envelope and exacerbate the global migrant crisis, with potentially disastrous consequences for the US economy and global stability.

site_title: Passenger car COE premiums fall on bigger quota
summary: Singapore's passenger car COE premiums fell in the first February bidding exercise, with Category A and B premiums dropping to S$48,401 and S$48,209, respectively. Category E, the open category, also decreased, while Category C for goods vehicles and Category D for motorcycles saw increases. The larger quota led to expectations of falling COE premiums, but some dealers reported speculation and scrambling for limited COE availability, despite weak market demand.

site_title: Stamp duty hike an effective cooling measure, says HK housing secretary
summary: The Hong Kong government has deemed the November 2016 stamp duty hike on residential property transactions as an effective cooling measure. The 15% flat rate is the second increase in three years to curb soaring real-estate prices, making the city one of the world's least affordable. The decision was made by Housing Secretary Anthony Cheung Bing-leung, marking the first public evaluation of the stamp-duty hike. The measure aims to stabilize the market and prevent further price growth.

site_title: Singapore Myanmar Investco to distribute Shiseido products
summary: Singaporean company SMI has signed an exclusive distribution agreement with Shiseido Asia Pacific for three years. This deal will allow SMI's high-end retailers to market Shiseido products in Myanmar, a growing market with a growing middle class. The agreement follows SMI's existing franchise agreements for F&B products and is seen as an opportunity to introduce globally recognized brands to the market. SMI is expected to turn profitable in fiscal 2018, driven by its duty-free business and growing leisure and business travelers in Myanmar.

site_title: India central bank holds rates, surprises with neutral policy stance
summary: India's central bank, the Reserve Bank of India (RBI), kept its policy rate unchanged at 6.25% and changed its policy stance to "neutral" from "accommodative", surprising markets. The decision was seen as hawkish due to warnings about high inflation and the impact of the government's crackdown on "black money". The RBI cited a need to ensure inflation returns to its target of 4% "on a durable basis and in a calibrated manner". The move sent bond prices lower and shares ended flat, with the rupee rising slightly.

site_title: Small cheesemakers invest in a stinky science
summary: Small US cheesemakers, like Jasper Hill Farm, are investing in microbiology technology to improve their products, as traditional methods and limited domestic starter cultures hinder individuality. Partnering with scientists, they're developing their own starters and studying the microflora in their cheese caves to create better cheeses with distinctive aromas, flavors, and textures. This approach has led to significant discoveries, such as Jasper Hill's removal of starter cultures from one of its cheeses, resulting in a more naturally ripened and delicious product.

site_title: US told to 'brush up on S. China Sea history'
summary: The US needs to brush up on its history about the South China Sea, according to Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi. Wang stated that World War II-related agreements mandate that all Chinese territories taken by Japan must be returned to China. China is upset by previous US comments on the disputed waterway, with Secretary of State Rex Tillerson and Defense Secretary James Mattis having differing views on the issue. Wang emphasized that China is committed to peaceful resolution through talks with the parties directly involved, based on historical facts and international law.

site_title: Trump under pressure to list Muslim Brotherhood as terrorist organisation
summary: US President Donald Trump's advisers are debating designating the Muslim Brotherhood as a foreign terrorist organisation, which would freeze assets, block visas, and ban financial interactions. The move would roil US relations in the Middle East, particularly with Egypt and the United Arab Emirates. Critics argue that the designation would alienate allies and target Muslim charities and mosques in the US. The proposal is part of a broader plan to designate Iran's Islamic Revolutionary Guards Corps, but momentum has slowed amid objections from career officials at the State Department and the National Security Council.

site_title: Trump travel ban: Hearing discusses courts' right to review order
summary: A US Justice Department lawyer, August Flentje, argued that President Trump's travel ban should not be reviewed by courts, citing national security concerns. However, a three-judge federal appeals panel expressed skepticism, with one judge questioning the administration's position and another suggesting the government's evidence of terrorism connections to the seven countries was thin. The appeals court is expected to rule within days, with a potential appeal to the US Supreme Court possible if the decision is unfavorable.

site_title: Courts to increase online sales to 10% of total revenue by 2020
summary: Courts Asia, a Singapore-based electronics retailer, aims to increase online sales to 10% of total revenue by 2020, up from 2-3% currently. The company plans to boost online sales to 5% in the next 12-15 months. To achieve this, Courts will focus on improving the online shopping experience and integrating digital capabilities with physical retail. The company has posted a 24.4% increase in net profit despite a 8.6% dip in revenue due to decreased corporate sales for digital products.

site_title: Uber rebuts reports that close to 1,000 of its cars idling in carparks
summary: Uber Singapore has denied reports that nearly 1,000 of its cars are idling in carparks, stating that only a small number of cars are being used for inspection, IU installation, or cleaning. The company claims to have 9 out of 10 cars in use at any given time, with the remaining 1% being used for these purposes. Uber is expanding its fleet in Singapore and bidding for Certificates of Entitlement to build assets, a move that is part of its strategy to establish a car rental company and control pricing.

site_title: Michael Kors drops after it cuts profit forecast on lower retail traffic
summary: Michael Kors Holdings Ltd fell 15% to $35.12 after cutting its annual profit forecast to $4.19 per share, citing dwindling retail traffic and a plan to reduce reliance on department stores. The company also reported a 7.4% decline in Americas revenue and a 2.7% decline in Europe, with comparable sales dropping 6.9%. The negative trends were attributed to falling customer traffic, currency fluctuations, and political uncertainty, with CEO John Idol expressing concern about upcoming elections in Germany and France.

site_title: Wading through ways to get US infrastructure plan on the road
summary: US President Donald Trump's plan to use corporate profits returned from overseas to finance nationwide infrastructure improvements gained support from House Transportation and Infrastructure Committee Chairman Bill Shuster. Shuster plans to use repatriated profits to offset broader tax-rate cuts, but disagreements remain about how to allocate the resulting tax revenue. Democrats are willing to work with Trump on infrastructure, but Republicans are pushing for increased private investment. Witnesses at a hearing last week stated that additional private funding may not be enough to meet the nationwide need, emphasizing the need for additional federal spending.

images.alt_text: Mr Trump has proposed spending US$1 trillion during the next decade on nationwide improvements to roads, bridges, airports and other public works and wants to leverage more private sector dollars.

site_title: Ditch the plastic airport chairs and recharge in a lounge
summary: Airport lounges are becoming more accessible, with airlines, credit card companies, and independent operators offering various options. Some popular first-class lounges include Lufthansa's First Class Terminal at Frankfurt Airport, Qatar Airways' Al Safwa First lounge, and Singapore Airlines' lounge in Singapore Changi Airport. Co-branded airline credit cards and travel credit cards, such as the Chase Sapphire Reserve and American Express Platinum, offer lounge access. Day passes for individual lounges can range from $20 to $75, while membership in Priority Pass Select can provide access to over 1,000 lounges worldwide.

site_title: Duterte rubbishes claims of illegal killings, rejects advice of 'idiot' ex-Colombia president
summary: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte defended his war on drugs, rejecting allegations of extrajudicial killings and criticism from former Colombian President Cesar Gaviria, who warned of a security-centred approach doing more harm. Duterte called Gaviria an "idiot" for advising against his approach, promising to stand behind those on the front lines. He reiterated his stance on the war, which has been marked by thousands of deaths, despite international criticism and concerns about human rights abuses.

site_title: Abe prepares to 'buy' Trump's favour with major deals
summary: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe is set to present a $450 billion economic package to US President Donald Trump in a bid to win favor and deter accusations of unfair trade and currency manipulation. The package includes infrastructure projects, financing deals, and job creation initiatives in the US, aiming to create up to 700,000 jobs over 10 years. Analysts say the move is a "charm offensive" to secure a more favorable deal, particularly given Trump's uncertain stance on China.

site_title: Who's paying to fix the US$750m 'Tilting Tower of San Francisco'?
summary: The 58-storey Millennium Tower in San Francisco is sinking and tilting due to its foundation on loose, wet soil. Residents, including retired director Nina Agabian, have filed multiple lawsuits against the developer and city officials, claiming their lifetime investments are at risk. The building's developer, Millennium Partners, is insured for $100 million in damages, but experts say the actual cost of fixing the building could be much higher, potentially in the tens of millions of dollars. The city has asked for information on how much the building can further settle without compromising stability, but the developer has declined, citing ongoing litigation.

site_title: HL Global Enterprises secures extension of loan repayment date till July 2018
summary: HL Global Enterprises has secured an extension of its loan repayment date to July 2, 2018, from China Yuchai International. The company, which has faced financial difficulties, will continue to receive financial support from Venture Lewis. HLGE reported a net loss of S$1.1 million for the nine months ended Sept 30, 2016, and has negative working capital and a deficit in shareholders' equity. The loan extension is considered an interested person transaction, as China Yuchai has a deemed stake of 48.91% in HLGE.

site_title: Vicom profit down 10.4%, difficult business challenges expected
summary: Vicom, a vehicle inspection and testing business, reported a 10.4% drop in net profit to S$28.2 million for the year ended Dec 31, 2016. Revenue declined 5.2% to S$101.2 million due to lower business volumes. The company expects difficult business conditions, with its vehicle testing business facing a high de-registration rate and its non-vehicle testing business weakening due to a general slowdown in its served industries. Earnings per share fell to 31.77 cents, down from 35.45 cents the previous year.

site_title: Entertainer Rolf Harris cleared of three sex charges
summary: Veteran Australian entertainer Rolf Harris was cleared of three sex charges by a London court, but a jury failed to reach a verdict on four other counts. Harris, 86, was accused of six counts of indecent assault and one of sexual assault between 1971 and 2004. He was previously convicted of 12 sex offenses in 2014 and is serving a six-year sentence. Harris's defense team claimed the initial convictions were "wrong" and that media coverage made him vulnerable to accusations. The prosecution has one week to decide on a retrial.

site_title: Taxi firms tweak rental deals in face of private hire disruption
summary: Singapore taxi operators have responded to the disruption from private-hire services like Uber and Grab by slashing rental rates and restructuring their rental schemes. The move aims to retain inactive drivers, with some firms offering more flexible rental options and reduced daily fees. However, industry watchers believe that incumbent taxi operators need to reinvent themselves to compete with agile and innovative new players. As a result, about half of Singapore's taxi drivers with a vocational licence are now inactive, with over 1,000 cabs sitting idle in taxi lots.

site_title: Latest Earnings
summary: Oil prices rose over 2% amid market uncertainty, with investors weighing tariffs, sanctions, and market outlooks. US stocks edged down from records due to tariff threats, while Europe's stocks declined due to bank and healthcare sector drag. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss for the second half. London's Heathrow plans to increase airport fees for a £10 billion upgrade, and Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case.

site_title: IHC, ousted CEO in tangle over documents
summary: International Healthway Corporation (IHC) and ousted CEO Angeleca Lim Beng Choo have filed separate police reports against each other following a heated EGM on January 23. Lim alleged she was harassed and wrongfully detained by four men, while IHC claimed she left office premises with her computer and documents. IHC also discovered 4.5 gigabytes of deleted emails from Lim's email account, which she disputes. The EGM removed four board directors, including Lim, and appointed new ones nominated by Oxley Holdings' Eric Low and his sister Audrey.

site_title: Global oil and gas M&A hit US$395b in 2016 despite slow start: EY
summary: Global oil and gas merger and acquisition activity reached US$395 billion in 2016, up from US$340 billion in 2015, despite a 27% decline in deal volume. Upstream deal value fell 14% to US$130 billion, while midstream deal value rose 29% to US$146 billion. Downstream deal value increased by 30% to US$65.9 billion. EY predicts a stronger 2017 year for deals, driven by integration strategies to create value. Oilfield services also showed signs of recovery, with a 106% increase in deal value to US$53 billion.

images.alt_text: Global oil and gas merger and acquisition activity ramped up from a slow start to the year to reach US$395 billion in 2016 compared to US$340 billion the year before even as deal volume fell 27 per cent year-on-year, EY Global oil and gas transaction review showed.

site_title: EMAS seeks further time extension for AGM
summary: EMAS Offshore Ltd, a Singapore-based offshore contractor, is seeking an additional 90-day extension to hold its annual general meeting (AGM) for FY2016, citing unresolved matters in its annual report. The company had previously received a 60-day extension and now plans to release its annual financial report in early May 2017. This decision comes after discussions on fund-raising and consolidating funding requirements with its parent company, Ezra Holdings Limited, remain uncertain. The AGM is now expected to take place in late May 2017.

site_title: Water scarcity plagues key mining regions
summary: Top mining companies warn that assets will be stranded and investors will walk away unless they address water scarcity in key mining regions like Africa, Australia, and Latin America. The issue has gained prominence after the hottest global year on record in 2016. Companies are urging governments to implement measures to ensure a sustainable water supply for mining operations.

site_title: Water-tariff hike will not blunt S'pore's competitive edge: Masagos
summary: Singapore's water-tariff hike will not compromise the country's competitive edge, said Minister for the Environment and Water Resources Masagos Zulkifli. The government aims to improve water efficiency among large industrial and commercial users to moderate water demand, which is expected to more than double by 2060. The non-domestic sector, currently accounting for 55% of water use, is expected to grow to 70% by then. Masagos emphasized the need for efforts to enhance water efficiency in this sector to ensure Singapore remains cost-competitive globally.

site_title: Yen up as political risks weigh on euro
summary: The euro fell another third of a percent against the US dollar, marking its worst run of daily losses in almost two months, due to concerns over the French presidential election and potential international financial support for Greece. The dollar index rose 0.3 percent, while the yen inched up to 112.20 per dollar, seeking perceived security. The euro's decline was driven by uncertainty over the French election and investors' concerns about the eurozone's stability, with opinion polls showing far-right leader Marine Le Pen leading in the first round.

site_title: In a trade war with China, the US loses
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump's trade policies with China are likely to lead to a trade war that the US would almost certainly lose. China has a significant advantage in the global economy, with foreign currency reserves of over $3 trillion, while the US has $120 billion. A trade war would cripple the US economy, with tariffs on imported goods increasing prices beyond the reach of lower-income Americans. China would emerge relatively unscathed, with the potential to shift its trillion-dollar future aircraft purchases to European companies and gain a significant advantage over the US as the world's leading economic power.

site_title: Saudi Aramco said to pick Moelis to advise on biggest IPO
summary: Saudi Arabian Oil Co, also known as Aramco, has hired Moelis & Co as its adviser for the world's largest initial public offering (IPO), valued at approximately $100 billion. This marks a significant win for Moelis, a boutique investment bank, and could lead to a fee of "tens of millions of dollars". The IPO is part of Saudi Arabia's plan to set up the world's largest sovereign wealth fund and reduce its reliance on hydrocarbons.

site_title: Non-US funds top list of best performing hedge funds, says research firm
summary: Non-US hedge funds outperformed US-based funds over the last three years, with top performers from Mauritius, Great Britain, and India, according to research firm Preqin. Arcstone Capital's Passage to India Opportunity Fund, Stratton Street Capital's Japan Synthetic Warrant Fund, and Fair Value Capital Management's India Insight Value Fund ranked as the top three, with average annual returns of 44.84%, 36.4%, and 35.9%, respectively. These funds were selected based on their annualized returns and volatility, with Preqin also considering Sharpe and Sortino ratios.

site_title: LH Group renamed Pacific Star Development, transfers to Catalist Board
summary: LH Group, a Singapore-listed company, has been renamed Pacific Star Development Limited after obtaining shareholder approval for a reverse takeover. The company will transfer its listing status to Catalist and undergo a one-to-three share split. Trading will resume on February 16. Pacific Star Development has experience in real estate investment and development, with ongoing projects in Malaysia and Thailand.

site_title: Drawing a line from alternative theories to untruths
summary: US President Donald Trump has sparked controversy by claiming that the press does not report on terrorism episodes, echoing false claims made by conspiracy theorist Alex Jones. Trump's statement was based on a list of 78 incidents of "Islamic violence" released by the White House, which was largely covered by The New York Times and other news outlets. The false claims echo Jones's conspiracy theories about 9/11 and other events, including the Sandy Hook Elementary School shooting, which Trump has not endorsed. The article notes that the 9/11 attacks were caused by hijackers, not a controlled demolition, as reported by the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) in 2005.

site_title: Thailand keeps rate near record low to shield growth
summary: Thailand's central bank kept its key interest rate near a record low of 1.5% to shield the nation's economic recovery amid rising trade protectionism. The decision was unanimous, with all 22 economists surveyed predicting the move. Policymakers cited US economic and trade policies as risks, and vowed to maintain accommodative monetary policy to support the economy. Thailand's economic growth is forecasted to expand 3.3% this year, with private investment remaining weak. The central bank will review its forecasts and monitor the impact of US President Donald Trump's policies on the economy.

images.alt_text: Consumer prices rose 1.55 per cent in January from a year earlier, the fastest in 28 months. The central bank aims to keep inflation in a range of one per cent to 4 per cent this year.

site_title: Glaxo warns Advair rivals in US could erase profit growth
summary: GlaxoSmithKline warned that US rivals could erase profit growth due to cheaper copycat versions of its top-selling asthma medicine Advair. If generic competitors enter the US market, US sales of Advair could drop to £1 billion, leading to a "flat to slight decline" in profit growth. The company expects 5-7% profit growth if generics don't enter the market, but faces a challenge in accelerating revenue from new medicines to offset the erosion of Advair's sales. The company's new CEO, Emma Walmsley, will inherit this challenge.

site_title: Singapore-based Acromec secures $8.7m contract from pharmaceutical firm
summary: Singapore-based Acromec secures an $8.7 million contract from a pharmaceutical company to fit out production facilities in an extension project at a plant. The contract, valued at $42 million, is expected to be completed by the third quarter of 2017. This deal brings Acromec's order book to a record high and is expected to positively contribute to its per-share earnings and net tangible assets for the current financial year.

site_title: Qatar National Bank eyes S-E Asia for growth
summary: Qatar National Bank (QNB) is shifting its focus to South-east Asia for growth, three years ahead of schedule, after achieving expansion goals in Africa and the Middle East. The bank, with operations across 30 countries, plans to boost its presence in India, Indonesia, Vietnam, and Myanmar, and introduce Islamic finance products in Singapore. QNB aims to maintain a 20% return on equity, despite a slowdown in major projects in Egypt and Turkey, and a 20% increase in oil prices in Qatar. The bank's CEO, Ali Al Kuwari, believes South-east Asia offers the best growth opportunity.

site_title: Diversity to rock the runway at New York Fashion Week
summary: New York Fashion Week is set to feature a diverse range of styles, including faux furs, statement outerwear, floral prints, and pants suits, across various seasons. Designers will showcase 2017 fall/winter apparel and in-season spring/summer designs, allowing consumers to purchase the latter immediately. This trend, started last year, aims to provide consumers with a wider range of options for different seasons.

site_title: US:Wall St slips as bank, health stocks drag
summary: US stocks declined on Wednesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 40.95 points, or 0.2%, at 20,049.34. Bank and healthcare stocks led the decline, with the S&P 500 financial index falling 0.83% and healthcare down 0.66% due to Gilead's disappointing sales projections. Despite this, the fourth-quarter earnings season is expected to end on a high note, with combined S&P 500 earnings estimated to have risen 8.2% for the first time in nine quarters.

site_title: OUE raises stake in IHC to 21.83%
summary: OUE has increased its stake in International Healthway Corporation (IHC) to 21.83% by acquiring 154.13 million shares at 7.7 cents apiece, totaling S$11.87 million. This move comes after OUE acquired an initial 12.54% stake in IHC last month.

site_title: OCBC adviser in major stake sale of Indon toll road
summary: OCBC Bank's Indonesian unit, OCBC Sekuritas, advised a consortium in the sale of a 22.3% stake in Indonesia's Cikopo-Palimanan Toll Road for $272 million. The deal, valued at over three times book value, is the largest M&A deal advised by an Asian bank in Indonesia over the past year. The toll road is a crucial link in the Trans-Java Toll Road network. OCBC sees tremendous promise in Indonesia's growth prospects, with the country poised to be one of the fastest-growing economies in the world.

site_title: EU to phase out China solar panel duties
summary: The European Union plans to phase out anti-dumping duties on Chinese solar panel imports after 18 months, ending a dispute that began in 2013. The duties were initially imposed to protect European panel manufacturers, but other companies claimed they harmed them by increasing costs. The EU's decision follows US President Donald Trump's protectionist stance, with the EU touting its free trade credentials. The phase-out aims to allow European solar panel producers to adapt to the new situation and maintain thousands of jobs in the renewable energy industry.

site_title: Britons face smaller pay rises, buttressing central bank's slowdown forecast
summary: The Bank of England reported that British employers plan to offer the lowest pay rises since 2012, with average settlements of 2.2%, down from 2.7% in 2016. This comes as the economy is expected to slow, with inflation projected to reach 2.7% by the end of 2017. The central bank's slowdown forecast is attributed to the effects of the Brexit vote, with the pound's fall pushing up inflation and eating into household spending power.

site_title: Libra warns of earnings decline for FY16
summary: LIBRA Group Limited expects to report a decline in earnings for its FY16 due to lower operating margins and potential provisions for doubtful receivables. This is attributed to the challenging economic environment. The company will disclose further details of its financial performance with its unaudited results for FY2016, set for release by March 1.

site_title: Indian airports face capacity crunch as market booms
summary: India's aviation industry faces a capacity crunch due to rapid growth in demand and limited expansion of airport infrastructure. Airlines have 880 aircraft on order, with domestic passenger numbers exceeding 100 million last year. Most airports will exceed design capacity within a decade, and the government estimates India may run out of capacity within 3-5 years. The government plans to open 50 disused airports and build new ones, but delays in acquiring land and investment constraints hinder expansion. Airlines expect to lose $250-300 million this year due to intensifying competition.

site_title: BMW poaches Skoda's chief designer Kaban after in-house departures
summary: BMW appoints 44-year-old Slovakian Jozef Kaban as head of design for its main BMW brand, replacing Karim Habib who left the company. This move comes after a string of departures from BMW's design department, including Anders Warming, Benoit Jacob, and Richard Kim. Kaban's appointment aims to strengthen BMW's design team, as vehicle design becomes increasingly important for traditional carmakers under threat from start-up brands and stricter pollution rules. He will report to Adrian van Hooydonk, BMW Group's design chief.

site_title: India to remove cash withdrawal limits
summary: India's central bank has announced that cash withdrawal limits will be removed entirely from March 13, nearly doubling the current limit of 24,000 rupees to 50,000. The move comes as the country recovers from the cash crunch caused by Prime Minister Narendra Modi's demonetization policy in November. Interest rates remain unchanged at 6.25%, despite pressure for a cut to stimulate the economy. The Reserve Bank of India also stated that the impact of demonetization is transitory, but economists warn that the move may not be enough to boost growth.

site_title: Singapore shares close higher: blue chips weak but broad market firm on penny fever
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index dropped 5.11 points to 3,066.53, despite high trading volume. Penny stock fever continued, with the average value per unit traded at S$0.34. Interior design firm Serrano rose 148% to S$0.072 after a 3.8 billion share placement at S$0.002 per share. Excluding warrants, there were 258 rises versus 213 falls, indicating a more firm trading environment.

site_title: Raffles Education posts net loss of S$3.9m in Q2
summary: Raffles Education Corporation reported a net loss of S$3.91 million for Q2 2016, down from a net loss of S$5.17 million in the same period last year. Revenue declined 17% to S$24.44 million due to the discontinuation of a joint venture college and a decrease in utility income. However, the group made a S$13.7 million currency translation gain from consolidated foreign operations.

site_title: Malaysia: Stocks finish lower
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 0.34 points to 1,688.500, closing lower on Wednesday. The index saw 2.28 billion lots traded, valued at RM2.43 billion, with 471 gainers and 389 losers.

site_title: Chairman leads deal to buy stake in Arab Bank for US$1.12b
summary: A consortium led by Arab Bank Chairman Sabih al Masri has bought Oger's 20% stake in Jordan's Arab Bank Group for $1.12 billion, beating a $1.1 billion offer from the Hariri family. The deal involves 40 investors, mostly Jordanian, after negotiations led by Masri. The consortium secured the stake following the Hariri family's withdrawal from the deal.

site_title: Vicom profit falls 10.4% to S$28.2m
summary: Vicom, a unit of ComfortDelGro, reported a 10.4% decline in net profit to S$28.2 million for the year ended Dec 31, 2016, due to lower business volumes. Revenue dropped 5.2% to S$101.2 million. Earnings per share fell to 31.77 cents, down from 35.45 cents the previous year. A tax-exempt one-tier final dividend of 8.50 cents per share and a special dividend of 10.00 cents per share are proposed. The decline is attributed to a decrease in demand for vehicle inspection and testing services as Singapore's older vehicle population decreases.

site_title: F&N posts 12.1% drop in Q1 net profit
summary: F&N posted a 12.1% drop in Q1 net profit to S$22.44 million due to higher operating expenses offsetting revenue growth of 0.2% to S$495 million, primarily driven by the beverage and dairies segments. The printing and publishing business declined 8.3%.

images.alt_text: FRASER and Neave Limited (F&N) recorded a 12.1 per cent drop in net profit for the first quarter ended Dec 31, 2016 to S$22.44 million as higher operating expenses offset the rise in revenue.

site_title: India JSW Infrastructure aims to list shares in 2018/19
summary: India's JSW Infrastructure Ltd, owned by billionaire Sajjan Jindal, plans to list its shares on local bourses in 2018/19 to expand its operating profit and cargo-handling capacity. The company aims for a 30% growth in operating profit and targets 300 million tonnes of cargo-handling capacity by 2025. JSW Infrastructure is constructing an 18 million tonnes iron ore terminal and plans to expand its capacity to 200 million tonnes by 2020, with strategic partnerships with global container companies and shipping lines. The company also plans to diversify its cargo-handling capabilities.

site_title: Ho Bee still keen on London properties despite Brexit
summary: Ho Bee Land's chairman Chua Thian Poh stated the company remains keen on acquiring investment properties in London despite selling its Rose Court freehold office block for £94.5 million. The sale will yield a net gain of £4.5 million to reduce borrowings. Chua believes London's fundamentals as a global financial city remain sound despite Brexit, citing the city's continued economic strength.

site_title: Ho Bee Land sells London office block for £94.5 million
summary: Ho Bee Land sold its London office block, Rose Court, to a Guernsey property unit trust for £94.5 million, yielding a net gain of £4.5 million. The sale, completed on Feb 21, 2017, will be used to reduce borrowings and provide working capital. Ho Bee Land initially acquired Rose Court in 2013 for £67.2 million as part of its recurring income strategy.

site_title: Indian central bank keeps policy rate on hold, with eyes on inflation
summary: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) kept its policy rate on hold for the second meeting in a row, maintaining the 6.25% rate, amid concerns over inflation and the impact of demonetization on the economy. The RBI also changed its stance to "neutral" from "accommodative," citing a need to monitor inflation. The decision was seen as a risk, with private forecasts predicting a slower economy growth, and disappointed investors, causing bond yields to rise.

site_title: OCBC Sekuritas closes largest M&A deal advised by an Asian bank in Indonesia
summary: OCBC Sekuritas completed the sale of a 22.3% stake in Indonesia's Cikopo-Palimanan Toll Road for 2.57 trillion rupiah (S$272.4 million), the largest M&A deal advised by an Asian bank in Indonesia. The transaction valued the stake at over three times book value, exceeding average valuations in the infrastructure sector. OCBC Sekuritas was the exclusive financial adviser to the consortium of sellers, led by Saratoga Capital. The toll road is a crucial link in the Trans-Java Toll Road network, connecting Jakarta to major industrial and agricultural regions in Java.

site_title: Malaysia says refines existing rules for interbank forex trades
summary: Malaysia's central bank, Bank Negara Malaysia, has refined existing rules for interbank forex trades. Onshore banks will now be allowed to utilize export proceeds conversion of less than US$1 million per transaction to meet clients' foreign currency requirements. This move aims to better manage conversion operations during the day. The new rules come after previous measures to clamp down on offshore trade of the ringgit.

site_title: AP Moller-Maersk misses Q4 forecasts as impairments weigh
summary: AP Moller-Maersk missed Q4 profit expectations due to impairments, low prices, and oversupply in the oil and freight sectors. The company announced a major restructuring plan in September, took a $2.7 billion net operating loss, and cut its dividend. New Chairman Jim Hagemann Snabe will replace outgoing Chairman Michael Pram Rasmussen, who stepped down at the end of March. Maersk expects higher underlying net profit and 2-4% growth in global demand for seaborne container transportation in 2017.

site_title: EU fines Ecobat, 2 others 68m euros for taking part in cartel
summary: EU antitrust regulators fined Ecobat Technologies and two peers, Recylex and Campine, a total of 68 million euros for participating in a cartel to recycle car batteries, reducing competition and maximizing profits. The fine, totaling 32.71 million euros for Ecobat, 26.74 million euros for Recylex, and 8.16 million euros for Campine, was announced by European Competition Commissioner Margrethe Vestager, who stated that the companies had colluded to limit competition in the recycling chain. Johnson Controls was not fined as it reported the cartel to the European Commission.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: AECOM won a tender to design Singapore's high-speed rail infrastructure. The Singapore Budget 2017 aims to boost business and household purchasing power with enhanced tax reliefs. The government expects an annual job growth of 25,000 to 40,000 over the next three to five years. Ho Bee Land sold its London office block for £94.5 million. Car COE premiums fell, with Category A dropping to S$48,401. The Singapore shares closed higher, despite blue chip weakness, amid "penny fever" in the market.

site_title: SoftBank profit jumps as Sprint trims loss; readying launch of US$100b fund
summary: SoftBank Group Corp reported a 71% rise in third-quarter operating profit to 295.7 billion yen (US$2.63 billion) due to shrinking losses at US unit Sprint Corp and strength in its domestic telecommunications business. The company's founder and CEO, Masayoshi Son, announced plans to launch a US$100 billion tech fund, with investments from Apple, Foxconn, and others, aiming to create 50,000 new jobs in the US.

site_title: Netflix plans new toys, merchandise based on hit TV shows
summary: Netflix plans to enter the toy and merchandise market, hiring an executive to oversee licensing and partnerships with retailers. The company aims to generate additional revenue and promote hit shows to a wider audience. This move follows Netflix's evolution from a technology company to a media company producing and licensing intellectual property. The company has already conducted a test with Hot Topic Inc. for Stranger Things merchandise, and plans to expand into other shows and characters.

site_title: Freeport to reduce Indonesian mining activities: smelter official
summary: Freeport-McMoRan Inc plans to scale back activities at its Indonesian copper mine, Grasberg, due to a worker strike and other issues. The mine, the world's second-largest copper mine, had aimed to produce around one-third of Freeport's total copper output this year. The reduced output would affect PT Smelting, a copper smelter in Indonesia, which processes around 40% of the mine's copper concentrate production. The move comes amid a halt in export shipments of copper concentrate and supply concerns in the global copper market.

site_title: Singapore Myanmar Investco to distribute Shiseido products in Myanmar
summary: Singapore Myanmar Investco (SMI) has signed an exclusive distribution agreement with Shiseido Asia Pacific, allowing the group to distribute the cosmetic firm's products in Myanmar for three years, with the option to extend for two more years. SMI CEO Mark Bedingham described Myanmar as a promising economy in Asia, with the majority of Asian and global brands considering it a new frontier market. This partnership aims to expand Shiseido's presence in the country.

site_title: Annual job growth of 25,000 to 40,000 for next three to five years
summary: Singapore aims to create 25,000 to 40,000 jobs annually for the next three to five years, following a decline in job creation in the last two years due to economic restructuring and an ageing workforce.

site_title: Etihad CEO defends strategy as airline swells wide-body fleet
summary: Etihad Airways CEO James Hogan defended his strategy as the airline expands its wide-body fleet, adding 12 new aircraft, including two A380 superjumbos, in 2017. Despite challenges, the airline remains optimistic, with a 6% increase in customers to 18.5 million and 8% growth in passenger traffic, holding seat occupancy levels at 79%. Hogan's departure in the second half is seen as a response to losses at European partners, but he believes the airline's robust business model will succeed and endure.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks end higher after seesaw session
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 0.51% to 19,007.60, with the Nikkei 225 and Topix indices closing at 19,007.60 and 1,524.15 respectively, after a seesaw session. The gains followed a lunch break in negative territory.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks get boost from China property developers, brokers
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed at a 3-1/2-month high on February 8, 2017, driven by gains from China property developers and brokers. The Hang Seng index rose 0.7% to 23,485.13 points, while the Hong Kong China Enterprises Index gained 1.1%. China Vanke Co Ltd jumped 3.8% after reporting a 90% increase in January sales. Capital inflows from mainland China also lifted sentiment, with over 14% of the daily southbound quota used on Wednesday.

site_title: Oil market 'responding positively' to output cut: OPEC president
summary: Qatar's energy minister and OPEC president, Mohammed Saleh al-Sada, said oil markets are responding positively to the output cuts implemented by OPEC and non-OPEC producers, resulting in a drop in supply. The cuts, initially for six months, aim to rebalance the market. Al-Sada stated that the degree of adherence to the cuts is "very high" and helped pare back a slide in prices following a surge in US stockpiles. Benchmark West Texas Intermediate fell 1% on Tuesday, trading down 46 cents at $51.71 per barrel.

site_title: Australia: Shares advance, led by gains from financials; NZ soft
summary: Australian shares rose 0.52% to 5,651.4, driven by gains in financials, while New Zealand's benchmark fell fractionally. The Reserve Bank of Australia kept interest rates steady, and the RBNZ is expected to keep its cash rate at a record low. Industrials, led by Cimic Group's 9.2% gain, also contributed to the Australian rally, while copper prices rose due to supply concerns.

site_title: Euro licks its wounds after skidding on political woes
summary: The euro slumped against the US dollar due to uncertainty surrounding France's presidential election, with investors seeking safe-haven assets amid concerns of a potential eurozone exit. The euro's losses were exacerbated by US President Donald Trump's criticism of European currencies, but his protectionist stance may limit the dollar's gains. Meanwhile, China's foreign exchange reserves fell below the $3 trillion level, putting pressure on the yuan.

site_title: Rio Tinto annual profit surges on spiking commodity prices
summary: Rio Tinto reported a surge in annual net profit of $4.62 billion, exceeding analyst expectations, driven by improving commodity prices, particularly iron ore, which rose above $80 a tonne. The company's underlying profit increased 12% to $5.10 billion. Rio Tinto rewarded shareholders with a $3.6 billion return, including a full-year dividend and a $500 million share buyback. The company's shares rose 0.81% in Sydney, marking a 60% increase from a year ago.

site_title: KFC operator Yum China beats earning expectations
summary: Yum China, the operator of KFC, Pizza Hut, and Taco Bell in China, reported a 31% increase in operating profit to US$640 million in 2016, beating expectations. The company added 575 new restaurants, bringing its total to over 7,500. CEO Micky Pant attributed the growth to the company's leading position in the Chinese market, despite Pizza Hut's 7% decline in same-store sales. Yum China's performance came after the company split from its US parent Yum Brands in October 2016, following a tainted meat scandal in 2014.

site_title: Europe: Earnings push European shares higher
summary: European shares rose on Wednesday, led by mining stocks and financials, as regional corporate results showed strong earnings. The pan-European STOXX 600 index increased 0.5%, with Norwegian insurer Storebrand rising 6.9% to a nine-year high. The UK's FTSE 100 remained flat. Investors reacted positively to Storebrand's forecast-beating earnings and first dividend in six years.

site_title: China halts construction at major Lotte project amid THAAD tension
summary: China has halted construction on a major Lotte real estate project in Shenyang amid tensions over the US THAAD system, which China views as a threat to its security. The halt follows a series of inspections by Chinese authorities, including fire and facility inspections at Lotte's Chinese ventures, in response to South Korea's deployment of the system. The project, valued at billions of dollars, was set to include residential facilities and a theme park. Lotte has declined to comment on the motives of Chinese authorities.

site_title: Car COE premiums fall
summary: COE premiums for passenger cars in Singapore fell in the first bidding exercise of February, with Category A premiums decreasing by S$2,440 to S$48,401 and Category B premiums dropping by S$389 to S$48,209. The open category, Cat E, also saw a decrease of S$4,044 to S$48,556. This marks the first time the big car COE costs less than the small car COE. The price drops are attributed to a larger quota being offered.

site_title: Credit Suisse to shift some Swiss mortgages into fund
summary: Credit Suisse is shifting some Swiss mortgages into a new investment fund, the Swiss Mortgage Fund I, to be managed by Tavis Capital AG. The fund's initial volume is expected to reach 200 million Swiss francs ($200.2 million) by the end of March, with a potential maximum of 3 billion francs (10% of mortgage volume). This move aims to free up capital on the bank's balance sheet for company loans. Client relationships with mortgage holders will remain with Credit Suisse.

site_title: Japan logs strong trade data ahead of Abe-Trump meeting
summary: Japan logged its largest annual current-account surplus since the 2008 financial crisis, reaching 20.65 trillion yen (S$261 billion) in 2016. The surplus comes ahead of a meeting between Prime Minister Shinzo Abe and President Donald Trump, who has criticized Japan for allegedly devaluing the yen to boost exports. The data also shows Japan's trade deficit with the US narrowed, and the country's economy is expected to maintain its growth pace, with a 0.3% expansion in the fourth quarter.

site_title: China: Stocks end near one-month high
summary: Shanghai stocks rose to a near one-month high, with the CSI300 index up 0.5% to 3,383.29 points, as investors focused on the smallest drop in foreign exchange reserves in seven months, signaling tighter capital controls. Despite initial bearish sentiment, gains were led by brokerage firms after mixed January results. The Shanghai Composite Index closed up 0.4% to 3,166.98 points, its highest since January 11.

site_title: Gold near 3-month highs on political, economic uncertainty
summary: Gold prices held near three-month highs on Wednesday, boosted by US and European economic uncertainty, with spot gold edging up 0.1% to $1,234.20 per ounce. The metal's price rise is attributed to the Fed's decision not to raise rates, Trump's policies, and a weaker dollar. However, analysts predict prices may drop after January CPI data is released, potentially influencing the possibility of a March rate hike.

images.alt_text: Gold on Wednesday held near three-month highs hit the session before, buoyed as political and economic uncertainty in the United States and Europe stoked safe-haven demand.

site_title: Asia: Markets take fresh hit as Europe crises brew
summary: Asian markets fell on Wednesday, hit by concerns over Donald Trump's presidency and Europe's crises, including France's and Greece's. The euro sank to US$1.0656, while the yen strengthened against the dollar. China's foreign exchange reserves fell below US$3 trillion, boosting selling in Hong Kong and Shanghai. Analysts warn of rising populism and the risk of another EU crisis, with elections in Germany, Italy, and the Netherlands this year.

site_title: China global trade settled in yuan drops to more than 3-year lows: StanChart
summary: China's yuan settlement in cross-border trade dropped to its lowest levels in over three years in December, falling to 11.5% of total goods trade.
