The yuan's 6.6% annual decline against the dollar has reduced its attractiveness to traders and investors. Stricter capital controls and fears of further yuan weakness are seen as major factors. Analysts predict the yuan's decline will continue if the US raises interest rates, which could trigger fresh capital outflows. This marks a setback for Beijing's efforts to promote the yuan's global usage.

site_title: URA appoints team led by KCAP Architects&Planners as consultant for Jurong Lake District
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has appointed KCAP Architects&Planners as the consultant for the Jurong Lake District master plan. The team's proposal received the highest score among five shortlisted teams, emphasizing a sensitive focus on water and greenery. The proposed master plan will integrate with the green setting beside Jurong Lake, creating active and walkable streets, and interactive public spaces. The team will work with URA to refine the plan and draw up detailed proposals, which will be exhibited in mid-2017 for public feedback.

site_title: 'Islamic Bonnie and Clyde' charged with Australia terror plot
summary: A 19-year-old Australian couple, Sameh Bayda and Alo-Bridget Namoa, have been charged with planning a terrorist act in Sydney. They allegedly planned a stabbing attack and were found with documents on making an improvised explosive device. The couple, described as the "Islamic Bonnie and Clyde," were denied bail and face life imprisonment. This incident follows a growing concern over homegrown extremism in Australia, with authorities preventing 11 terror attacks on home soil in the past two years.

images.alt_text: A self-described Australian "Islamic Bonnie and Clyde" couple were Wednesday charged with planning a terrorist act, which reportedly involved a Sydney stabbing attack.

site_title: AECOM wins LTA tender to design Singapore's high speed rail infrastructure
summary: AECOM has won a tender to design Singapore's high-speed rail infrastructure, with the project expected to be completed by December 31, 2026. The 350-km line will connect Singapore and Kuala Lumpur, reducing travel time to 90 minutes. AECOM, which has worked on similar projects in China, the UK, and Hong Kong, will provide architectural, civil, and other design services for the Jurong East terminus, tunnels, and bridge. The project is a strategic collaboration between the Malaysian and Singaporean governments.

site_title: Trump tells Spanish leader he backs Nato
summary: President Donald Trump told Spain's leader Mariano Rajoy that the US is committed to Nato, despite past criticism of the alliance. Trump reiterated the US commitment to Nato and emphasized the importance of member nations sharing defense spending. This move comes ahead of a May meeting with fellow Nato leaders, where the US will provide significant funding. Trump's stance on Nato has been under scrutiny, particularly given his friendly relationship with Russian President Vladimir Putin, who has been a major concern for European leaders.

site_title: Thailand delays launch of US$2.9b infrastructure fund to second quarter
summary: Thailand has delayed the launch of its US$2.9 billion infrastructure fund, initially planned for the first quarter, to the second quarter. The "Thailand Future Fund" aims to boost the country's sluggish economy by offering higher returns, around 7-8%, compared to banks' deposit rates of 0.5-1.5%. The fund will initially sell units worth 40-50 billion baht to Thai and foreign investors.

site_title: Badminton: Angry Lee lashes out at Malaysia association
summary: Malaysian badminton star Lee Chong Wei is threatening to cut ties with the Badminton Association of Malaysia (BAM) after suffering a medial collateral ligament injury in his left knee while training on a new, slippery court. Lee had complained about the court mats to the association, but his concerns were ignored. He expressed frustration and anger, stating that the injury is the "last straw" and that he has "lost my patience" with the association's technical director, Morten Frost. Lee had been training at the new facility only a week ago and will miss the upcoming All England Championship.

site_title: Directing a Smurfs flick, by the book
summary: Kelly Asbury, 57, is directing the new Smurfs animated movie, Smurfs: The Lost Village, after being turned down for a job at Hanna-Barbera Productions 30 years ago. Asbury was given a strict rule book to work within, including the Smurfs' dietary restrictions, before starting the project. He took a crash course on the Smurfs' history and worked closely with the original creator, Peyo, to ensure the characters remained true to their original forms. The movie features a star-studded voice cast, including Julia Roberts and Demi Lovato, and is set to release in March and April.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks hit near 4-week low on foreign selling; won flat
summary: South Korean stocks hit a near four-week low on February 8, 2017, as foreign investors sold market heavyweight shares, driven by increased volatility in the won. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) fell 1% to 2,055.01. Tech giant Samsung Electronics dropped 1.6%, while chipmaker SK Hynix Inc slid 1.7%. The won remained flat at 1,145.7. Foreign investors were net sellers, offloading 141.1 billion won worth of Kospi shares, with decliners outnumbering advancers 581 to 227.

site_title: China invites Britain to attend new Silk Road summit: sources
summary: China has invited British Prime Minister Theresa May to attend a major "One Belt, One Road" summit in May, diplomatic sources reported. The summit, to be held in Beijing, aims to build a new Silk Road with infrastructure projects across Asia, Africa, and Europe, with a focus on railways, ports, and power grids. China has committed $40 billion to the Silk Road Fund, and the summit will also discuss the US$50 billion China-backed Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank. Details on the summit attendees remain scarce, with China giving few hints about who will be in attendance.

site_title: In Norway, everyone's tax info is just a click away
summary: Norway has implemented a system where everyone's tax information is publicly available online, with earnings, wealth, and tax payments published annually on the tax agency's website. This culture of transparency is seen as a key factor in high tax compliance and has boosted public revenues by approximately $60 million annually. The practice, which dates back to the 19th century, has led to a high level of trust in the tax administration, earning it a prize for having the best reputation in 2015.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks extend losses at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell 0.54% on Wednesday, mirroring losses across Asia, following China's forex reserve hitting a six-year low in January. The Hang Seng Index dropped to 23,205.79, while the Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indices also declined. The losses come as China fights to support the yuan against capital outflows.

site_title: Crime rate in Singapore falls: MHA
summary: Singapore's crime rate has fallen in 2016, with a decline in violent and serious property crimes, housebreaking, and theft. The overall drug situation remained stable, but a rise in new abusers is a concern. Scams, such as e-commerce and internet love scams, continue to be a significant issue. Road safety improved, with fewer fatal accidents, but elderly pedestrians are at risk. Immigration offenders remain low, with a decrease in those arrested for harbouring or employing them. The country's overall crime rate has fallen for the second consecutive year.

site_title: Facebook co-founder backs Singapore-based startup CXA
summary: Facebook co-founder Eduardo Saverin's B Capital Group has led a $25 million financing round for Singapore-based online health insurance startup CXA, valuing the company at $100 million. The round also includes investments from the Singaporean government's EDBI, Royal Philips, and Reinsurance Group, alongside existing backers. CXA plans to expand to 10 countries across Asia, with CEO Rosaline Koo joining the board of directors.

site_title: Trump administration defends travel ban in court
summary: The US Justice Department defended President Donald Trump's travel ban targeting seven Muslim-majority countries in a court of appeals hearing. The ban, which was suspended by a federal judge, aims to temporarily restrict travel from the countries. The hearing, attended by over 130,000 people, followed a federal judge's decision to put the ban on hold. The Justice Department urged the court to reinstate the ban, which would allow the US to implement the travel restrictions. The court has yet to make a decision on the matter.

images.alt_text: The US Justice Department faced tough questioning Tuesday as it urged a court of appeals to reinstate President Donald Trump's travel ban targeting citizens of seven Muslim-majority countries, put on hold in a legal challenge last week.

site_title: Colombia's Santos linked to Odebrecht bribe: prosecutors
summary: Colombian prosecutors have linked President Juan Manuel Santos to a bribe from Brazilian construction firm Odebrecht, allegedly for his 2014 re-election campaign. The claim emerged from a probe into a former senator accused of taking and making bribes to secure a government contract. The Santos administration denied the claim, accusing the opposition of fabricating it. The investigation is ongoing.

site_title: BOJ sees improvements in economy but warns on inflation expectations
summary: The Bank of Japan's (BOJ) latest meeting showed improvements in exports, consumer spending, and capital expenditure, with some members believing the central bank's current ultra-easy policy is appropriate. However, they warned that inflation expectations may take time to pick up and expressed concerns over uncertainty surrounding the Trump administration's policies and Britain's exit from the EU. The BOJ maintained its policy, raised its growth projection, but warned its 2% inflation target remains elusive, citing the need for flexibility in its market operations desk.

site_title: Poll shows support for Scottish independence rising: Herald
summary: A recent BMG survey for Herald Scotland found that 49% of Scots support independence, with 51% opposing it, following the UK's decision to leave the European Union. This result is similar to the 2014 Scottish independence referendum. Scotland's devolved parliament rejected British Prime Minister Theresa May's plan to exit the EU. A Scottish Greens lawmaker predicted that a new independence referendum is likely after the UK triggers the EU exit process.

site_title: Japan's Sharp may begin construction on US$7b US plant before June 30: source
summary: Sharp Corp may begin construction on a US$7 billion plant in the US before June 30, taking the lead on a project initially considered by its Taiwanese parent Foxconn, according to a source. This move comes ahead of Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's US trip to meet President Donald Trump, who is expected to receive investments promising up to 700,000 US jobs. Sharp has not confirmed the decision, and Foxconn declined to comment.

images.alt_text: Japanese display maker Sharp Corp may start building a US$7 billion plant in the United States before June 30, taking the lead on a project initially considered by its Taiwanese parent Foxconn, a person with knowledge of the plan said.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on February 8, 2017, driven by a cheaper yen and gains on Wall Street. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.28% to 18,963.88 and the Topix index rose 0.23% to 1,519.66.

site_title: Australia: Shares eke out marginal gains; New Zealand flat
summary: Australian shares rose 0.2% to 5,633.5, driven by gains in financials and industrial sectors. Financial stocks, including the "Big Four" banks, rebounded after a previous interest rate announcement, while CIMIC Group's 12% net profit rise lifted industrial stocks. Basic materials declined due to BHP Billiton's strike concerns and gold stocks fell as gold prices slipped. New Zealand's benchmark index remained flat, with healthcare and financials offsetting losses in utilities and consumer cyclicals.

site_title: Singapore shares open flat on Wednesday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.48% to 3,071.64 on Wednesday, driven by gains on Wall Street, Europe, and Tokyo. The most actively traded counter, International Healthcare Corporation, surged 19% to S$0.08 after receiving a convertible loan facility. Gainers outnumbered losers 66 to 54, with about 82.9 million shares changing hands.

site_title: Meinhardt partners IE Singapore to expand into Africa, Middle East
summary: Meinhardt Group, a global engineering firm, has partnered with International Enterprise Singapore to expand into Africa and the Middle East. The partnership is facilitated by Meinhardt's acquisition of African engineering consultancy Bhundia Associates (BA) in late 2016. IE Singapore has provided on-ground support and connected Meinhardt to key business partners in Kenya, leading to the acquisition. This expansion aims to capitalize on growth opportunities in the region.

site_title: Australian dollar fails again at 77 US cents, NZD steps back from 12-wk peak
summary: The Australian dollar fell for its third straight day, losing 0.1% to US$0.7621, failing to breach the 77 US cents chart resistance level. This decline was attributed to the US dollar's strength, fueled by rising European political uncertainty. The New Zealand dollar also retreated, pulling back from its 12-week high of US$0.7375 to US$0.7304, as investors await the Reserve Bank of New Zealand's monetary policy statement on Thursday.

site_title: Strong 6.3 quake strikes off Pakistan coast: USGS
summary: A 6.3-magnitude earthquake struck off Pakistan's coast, 23km southwest of Pasni, at 3:03am local time. There were no immediate reports of casualties or damage in the remote province of Balochistan. The quake's epicentre is near the boundary of the Indian and Eurasian tectonic plates, making Pakistan prone to earthquakes. This is the second major quake to hit Pakistan in recent years, following a 7.5-magnitude quake in 2015 that killed almost 400 people.

site_title: Apple hires Amazon's Fire TV head to run Apple TV business
summary: Apple has hired Timothy D Twerdahl, former head of Amazon's Fire TV unit, as vice-president of Apple TV product marketing. Twerdahl, who joined Apple in February, will oversee Apple TV product marketing and negotiate media content deals. The move suggests a renewed focus on the Apple TV, following past efforts that stalled due to failed negotiations. This shift aims to provide more content for the device, a key strategy for the company.

site_title: Perennial Real Estate's Q4 profit falls 38% to S$25.56m
summary: Perennial Real Estate Holdings reported a 38% decline in Q4 net profit to S$25.56m, down from S$41.1m last year, due to lower rental revenue from expiring leases at TripleOne Somerset. Revenue fell 24% to S$21.5m. The company recommended a 0.4c dividend per share for the FY2016.

site_title: China says both sides will lose from conflict with US
summary: China's Foreign Minister Wang Yi said that a conflict with the US over the South China Sea would benefit no one and that both sides would lose. Wang made the statement amid increased tensions following comments from US officials, including White House spokesman Sean Spicer and Secretary of State Rex Tillerson. China has built artificial islands in the region, which the US sees as a potential flashpoint. Wang emphasized the importance of diplomatic efforts and cooperation between the two countries, as Australian Foreign Minister Julie Bishop noted that Beijing is keen on engaging with the Trump government.

site_title: Stocks to watch: IHC, HMC, Perennial Real Estate, Olam
summary: International Healthway Corporation (IHC) entered into a non-binding term sheet with lenders for a S$50 million loan facility at 6% interest. Healthway Medical Corporation (HMC) received a S$103 million takeover offer. Perennial Real Estate Holdings reported a 38% decline in net profit to S$25.56 million for its fourth quarter. Olam International plans to repurchase up to S$235.8 million in securities and redeem outstanding securities on Sept 1 at 100% of principal amount.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2017: UOB says enhanced tax reliefs to boost business, purchasing power needed
summary: UOB economist Francis Tan expects Singapore's Budget 2017 to provide enhanced tax reliefs to boost business and household purchasing power, addressing the country's slow economic growth. Tan hopes for a single-year tax relief measure to support businesses and households during difficult times.

site_title: UK recruiters struggle to find staff, pay jumps: REC
summary: UK recruiters face challenges in finding staff, with demand for staff hitting a 17-month high despite Brexit uncertainty. Permanent placements rose at the softest pace in nine months, while starting salaries increased at the fastest pace in nine months. The REC's Chief Executive Kevin Green warned that employers may outsource abroad or automate activities if they can't find candidates, putting UK jobs at risk. This comes as the BOE monitors inflation pressures in the labor market, which could lead to higher interest rates.

site_title: Water scarcity tops list of world miners' worries
summary: The world's top mining companies are warning that water scarcity will strand assets and deter investors if not addressed in regions such as Africa, Australia, and Latin America. Water is a critical constraint to the mining industry, with 23 major firms citing water-related conflicts and financial costs. Companies are investing in water-saving technologies, such as recycling and reducing consumption, to mitigate the risk of water scarcity. The industry is also adopting best practices to ensure water stewardship, with the International Council on Mining and Metals publishing a position on water stewardship.

site_title: Turkey sacks another 4,500 civil servants after coup bid
summary: Turkey has ordered the dismissal of nearly 4,500 civil servants, including 2,585 education ministry employees, 893 gendarmerie members, and 88 TRT workers, following last July's attempted coup. The sackings are authorized by the cabinet and do not require parliamentary approval under the state of emergency. The purge, which has already seen 41,000 arrests and 100,000 firings, is aimed at those blamed for the failed putsch that left 248 people dead. The European Union and human rights activists have criticized the scale of the crackdown.

site_title: Brexit risks 30,000 UK jobs and 17% of bank assets, study says
summary: A study by Brussels-based research group Bruegel predicts that a UK withdrawal from the European Union could result in 30,000 UK jobs and 17% of bank assets being relocated to the continent. This includes 10,000 employees and 18,000 to 20,000 associated professionals. The relocation is expected to occur in response to the potential loss of "passporting" rights, which allow firms to service EU customers from London. The UK financial services industry generates £205 billion annually and employs 1.1 million people, with some predicting as many as 70,000 jobs could be relocated.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open slightly lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened slightly lower on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 1.700 points to 1687.140. The market saw a slight decrease in volume, with 51.16 million lots worth RM23.30 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 99 to 55.

site_title: Israel arrests local Deutsche Bank CEO over VAT
summary: Israel arrested Boaz Aaron Schwartz, managing director of Deutsche Bank Israel, on suspicion of misreporting VAT on deals worth over 550 million shekels (S$208.5 million). Schwartz was released on bail after being taken into custody by the Tax Authority. The arrest is related to alleged unlawful reporting of transactions.

site_title: Canada to announce aid package for Bombardier: source
summary: The Canadian government is set to announce an aid package for Bombardier Inc, with a source indicating the amount will be significantly less than the requested $1 billion. The package includes C$372 million in repayable loans, with one-third going to the C-Series passenger jet and the rest to the Global 7000 business jet. Negotiations have been ongoing for over a year, with concessions made by Bombardier, including changes to its governing structure. The company is now in a stronger financial position, having initially sought aid from the province of Quebec.

site_title: Crude oil falls by more than 1% as petrol weighs
summary: Oil prices fell more than 1% on Tuesday, driven by growing petrol stockpiles in the US and evidence of a resurgence in US shale production. Brent crude settled at $55.05 a barrel, while US crude ended at $52.17 a barrel. US petrol futures dropped to $1.4875 a gallon, threatening to leave refiners struggling with inventory. Analysts warn that rising US shale production and slowing demand growth could offset Opec's efforts to reduce supply, putting pressure on prices.

site_title: Melania Trump revives suit against escort allegations
summary: Melania Trump has relaunched a lawsuit against the publishers of the Daily Mail Online for reporting she worked as an escort in the 1990s, seeking multi-million dollar damages. The original case was rejected due to lack of jurisdiction, but she settled a related case against a blogger who made the same claims. The new case will be heard in New York, where the allegations originated.

site_title: Israeli drugmaker Teva says CEO has stepped down
summary: Teva Pharmaceutical Industries Ltd announced that CEO Erez Vigodman is stepping down effective immediately, to be replaced by interim CEO Yitzhak Peterburg. The move comes amid poor performance of Teva shares, which have fallen 2% in extended trading. The separation of chairman and CEO roles due to Israeli company law will prevent Mr. Peterburg from heading the board. The company faces recent challenges, including patent invalidation and a US investigation into generic drug price fixing, prompting investors to call for a shakeup.

site_title: Europe: Strong earnings boost shares, but France lags
summary: European shares rose 0.3% on Tuesday, driven by strong earnings from some companies, but French stocks fell 0.5% due to disappointing BNP Paribas results and election jitters. French bond yields spiked, and losses in the French CAC index have reached over 2% for the year. The decline in French banks was partly attributed to concerns about the far-right winning the French presidential election and potentially taking the country out of the EU.

site_title: US could ask visa applicants for social media passwords
summary: US Homeland Security Secretary John Kelly proposes asking visa applicants for social media passwords as part of enhanced vetting for visitors from seven Muslim-majority countries. The move aims to screen out potential security threats, with Kelly suggesting that those who refuse to cooperate may not be granted US visas. The proposal is part of a broader effort to tighten vetting processes, which may lead to longer delays for awarding US visas.

images.alt_text: US embassies could ask visa applicants for passwords to their own social media accounts in future background checks, Homeland Security Secretary John Kelly said Tuesday.

site_title: 500 years of robots go on show in London
summary: A London exhibition showcases 500 years of robots, from a 16th-century monk to a 1773 silver swan, highlighting human fascination and fears about machines. The show aims to dispel misconceptions that robots will destroy the world and enslave humans, instead revealing their potential to improve society. Robots on display include ones designed to entertain, educate, and assist people with autism, such as Kaspar and Zeno R25. The exhibition runs until September 3, providing a unique perspective on the evolution of machines and their impact on human society.

site_title: Sarkozy to be tried over 2012 campaign financing
summary: Former French President Nicolas Sarkozy is set to face trial on charges of illegally financing his 2012 re-election campaign, spending nearly double the legal limit of 22.5 million euros. The prosecution alleges Sarkozy's campaign team, including Bygmalion and Jerome Lavrilleux, used false billing to cover the excess costs. If convicted, Sarkozy could face up to a year in prison and a fine of 3,750 euros. The trial marks the first time a French president has been tried, following a similar case in 2011 involving Jacques Chirac.

site_title: SEC probing claims of chicken-pricing collusion, says Tyson
summary: The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) is investigating allegations of chicken-pricing collusion involving Tyson Foods Inc, the country's largest chicken producer. Tyson has been subpoenaed and is cooperating with the probe, which is related to antitrust litigation involving broiler chickens. The company's shares have declined 3.5% due to the scrutiny of industry pricing practices. Analysts predict that the charges may lead to a valuation overhang on Tyson's equity.

site_title: British fighter jets divert Heathrow-bound Pakistani plane
summary: British fighter jets diverted a Pakistan International Airlines flight bound for London's Heathrow airport due to a "disruptive passenger". The Royal Air Force intercepted and escorted the plane to Stansted airport, where authorities made enquiries. A passenger was arrested at Stansted Airport on arrival, with police not confirming if this was the same individual who prompted the diversion. The incident was not deemed a hijack or terrorism matter, and security clearance was underway with all passengers safe.

site_title: IHC receives convertible loan facility of up to S$50m from Oxley
summary: IHC receives a non-binding term sheet from Oxley Holdings, Ching Chiat Kwong, and Low See Ching to grant up to S$50m in convertible loans at 6% interest. Mr. Ching and Mr. Low propose a separate loan of up to S$5m. The loan is subject to shareholder approval. Additionally, IHC files a police report against former director Lim Beng Choo after 4.5GB of emails were deleted from her account, which occurred after her removal as a director. IHC also faces various claims from lenders and claimants.

site_title: Gary Cohn should not weaponise bond-liquidity fears
summary: Gary Cohn, President Donald Trump's top economic adviser, has sparked concern over US markets being "fundamentally flawed" due to high regulatory costs. However, the US market is functioning orderly, with investors adapting to electronic trading systems and smaller brokerages. The solution to improving liquidity lies in increasing transparency, not returning to prolific proprietary trading. The Federal Reserve attributes reduced bond-market liquidity to the Volcker Rule, but encouraging banks to hold bigger pools of debt would exacerbate the last crisis and harm markets.

site_title: US authorities clear pathway for Dakota pipeline
summary: The US Army Corps of Engineers has approved a permit for the Dakota Access pipeline, allowing for its completion despite months of protests by Native Americans. President Donald Trump had ordered officials to reconsider the plans, which were initially rejected by the Obama administration. The pipeline, spanning 1,886km across four US states, will facilitate the last stretch of pipeline connecting North Dakota oil production areas to an existing crude oil terminal. Thousands of protesters had camped in freezing temperatures to block the pipeline's planned route, citing concerns over water pollution and sacred historic sites.

site_title: Blockchain insurance consortium grows to 15 members
summary: A consortium of 15 insurance companies, including Hannover Re and Assicurazioni Generali SpA, has formed the Blockchain Insurance Industry Initiative (B3i) to test blockchain technology in data sharing. The pilot project aims to simplify reinsurance contracts among member firms, with expected results to be shared in June 2017. The initiative follows other collaborative efforts to advance blockchain development, including a consortium led by Cisco Systems to secure the "internet of things." Companies hope the technology can help reduce costs and improve efficiency in the insurance sector.

site_title: Asia inflation surge fueled by currency rout that's already gone
summary: Asia-Pacific inflation surged in January, driven by currency fluctuations and rising oil prices. Key countries including South Korea, Indonesia, Thailand, and the Philippines saw higher-than-expected price gains. However, this may be short-lived, as a strengthening US dollar could reduce inflationary pressure and lead to slower consumer price gains. Central banks are unlikely to respond, as emerging currencies have gained ground against the dollar, potentially reversing inflation trends.

site_title: US dollar rises on political uncertainty in Europe, technical buying
summary: The US dollar rose to a one-week high, gaining for a fifth consecutive session, driven by technical buying and political uncertainty in Europe, including elections in the Netherlands, Germany, and possibly Italy. The dollar index rose 0.4% to 100.27, while the euro fell 0.5% to $1.0695, its worst daily performance in two weeks. The dollar's gain was also influenced by China's foreign exchange reserves falling below $3 trillion for the first time in nearly six years.

images.alt_text: The US dollar climbed to a more than one-week high on Tuesday as it gained for a fifth straight session, bolstered by technical buying after recent losses as well as political uncertainty in Europe with a slew of elections this year.

site_title: Singapore Air extends fuel hedging as Opec cuts sway crude oil
summary: Singapore Airlines has extended its fuel-hedging contracts to up to five years, betting on rising crude oil prices amid Opec production cuts and US-Iran tensions. The airline has hedged 33-39% of its projected annual fuel consumption at $53-59 a barrel. This move aims to cut costs as passenger yields continue to be under stress. Analysts say the move is cautious but may prove correct, given the current market outlook.

site_title: China tightens monetary policy going into 2017
summary: China's central bank raised interest rates by 10 basis points each on the seven-day repurchase agreement, 14- and 28-day repo rates, and standing lending facility loans, signaling a shift from growth-focused monetary policy to preventing asset bubbles and deleveraging. The move follows a series of measures to curb credit growth and mortgage lending, amid concerns of saddling corporates and local governments with debt and fueling asset bubbles. Analysts expect a widening yield advantage for Chinese bonds over US debt, supporting the yuan, and a downward correction in the bond market.

site_title: US: Nasdaq edges up to record; GM falls
summary: US stocks rose modestly on Tuesday, with the Nasdaq Composite Index reaching a fresh record, despite declines in petroleum-linked shares and General Motors. Analysts attributed the gains to beating earnings expectations, a sign of an improving economy. However, some economists expressed concerns that momentum behind President Trump's proposals is fading. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 also rose, with gains in tech-heavy stocks such as Apple and IBM.

site_title: Geopolitical tensions could drive real estate flows to Asia: RCA
summary: Geopolitical tensions in Europe and the US could divert real estate capital to Asia, according to Robert White, founder and president of Real Capital Analytics. Asia's fundamental growth drivers, such as urbanization and population growth, make it an attractive destination for investors. In 2016, Singapore was the sixth most active market in the Asia-Pacific region, with close to $8 billion in deals done, while Japan and Australia saw a decline in transactions due to investors buying to hold. Asia's capital footprint is growing, with Chinese investors dominating cross-border capital flows, and investors are shifting towards less glamorous properties for higher yields.

site_title: Paris woos Brexit-hit bankers with promises of romance
summary: Paris is wooing Brexit-hit bankers with promises of a high quality of life, healthcare, and childcare, positioning itself as the only global financial center remaining in the EU after the UK exits the bloc in 2019. The city is competing with Dublin and Frankfurt, with global bank chiefs warning UK Prime Minister Theresa May that they will soon start shifting operations and jobs from London. Paris aims to attract over 20,000 workers, with HSBC already committing to relocate 1,000 traders to the city.

site_title: Climate change may overload US electricity grid: study
summary: US electricity grid may be unable to meet peak energy needs by the century's end due to climate change, according to a study. The estimated cost to upgrade the grid is around $180 billion, mainly for capacity, storage, and transmission investments. Peak electricity demands are expected to rise by 18% and 2.8% by the century's end, mainly due to frequent and intense heat. Increasing solar energy use could smooth some peak demand, but sunny days don't always coincide with hot days.

site_title: China forex reserves fall by more than expected, to below US$3t
summary: China's foreign exchange reserves fell below $3 trillion for the first time in six years, dropping $12.3 billion to $2.998 trillion in January. The decline is attributed to capital flight due to slowing economic growth and a weakening yuan. Authorities' efforts to prop up the yuan have drained reserves, and a strong US dollar under President Donald Trump's presidency may further pressure the currency. China's policymakers may need to implement more forceful steps to stem capital outflows, potentially including re-imposing restrictions on outflows.

site_title: 'Trumpflation' is a sure thing; Europe may even rebound
summary: US President Donald Trump's presidency may bring 'trumpflation,' a potential economic surprise. Three transformative developments could shake the world economy and financial markets, including changes in US foreign policy, the global AI talent war, and the evolving regulatory landscape for cryptocurrencies. Trump's presidency marks a new chapter in US foreign policy, and his economic policies may lead to 'trumpflation,' which could impact Europe's economy.

site_title: Leaked emails tarnish golden-boy Beckham
summary: David Beckham's reputation as a British cultural icon has been tarnished after leaked emails revealed he swore at his PR team when told he wouldn't be knighted due to tax concerns. The emails, released by the Football Leaks website, also showed Beckham refused to fund his own charity and tried to reimburse expenses from UNICEF. A spokesman for Beckham denied the emails were genuine, but tabloid media and TV host Piers Morgan have criticized him as a "fraud" and "egotist".

site_title: Trump - the American Mao?
summary: US President Donald Trump's presidency has sparked widespread confusion and chaos, both domestically and internationally, with his mercurial behavior and executive orders. Like China's Mao Zedong, Trump has a vision of restoring the US to greatness, but his methods are causing global instability. Trump's actions have unified American protesters and antagonized world leaders, including Germany, Japan, and Mexico. His policies, including tariffs and a travel ban, have destabilized global markets and the US dollar. Trump's behavior and policies have drawn comparisons to Mao's disruptions and authoritarian tendencies, raising concerns about the potential for global conflict and economic disaster.

site_title: Threat to Advair from cheap generics greets GSK's new CEO
summary: GlaxoSmithKline's new CEO, Emma Walmsley, faces a significant challenge in navigating the loss of Advair's sales due to the approval of cheap generic versions. The company will focus on maintaining momentum for its newer respiratory drugs and improving its pharmaceutical growth. Walmsley, who will present her strategic vision in the summer, has a solid consumer health business and a weak pound that has helped the company weather pressure from US President Donald Trump's criticism of high drug prices. She will also make key choices in the pharmaceuticals division and prioritize products with promising clinical trial results.

images.alt_text: GlaxoSmithKline's incoming CEO Emma Walmsley will be taking over the reins at a time when the company's inhaled lung drug Advair faces threat from cheap generics.

site_title: S Korea to dispel 'misunderstanding' on US trade pact
summary: South Korea's trade minister announced a new committee to address concerns from the Trump administration about the country's free-trade agreement with the US. The agreement, enacted in 2012, has been under scrutiny since Trump's election, with the US President criticizing South Korea's trade policies. However, South Korea argues that the pact has helped create jobs and boost exports, with the countries' trading volume increasing by 15% since its ratification. The government plans to explain the benefits of the pact to the Trump administration and may offer incentives for US carmakers to invest in Korea.

images.alt_text: Hyundai Motor and affiliate Kia Motors announced last month a US$3.1 billion investment in the US over the next five years.

site_title: Singapore Airlines' Q3 earnings fall 36%
summary: Singapore Airlines reported a 36% year-on-year drop in net profit to S$177.2 million for its fiscal third quarter, primarily due to a S$79 million write-down of the Tigerair brand and trademark. Operating profit rose to S$292.9 million, driven by cheaper fuel costs, but revenue declined 2.5% and earnings per share fell to 15 cents. The airline warned that 2017 would be another challenging year due to global economic conditions, geopolitical concerns, and market headwinds.

site_title: Study on fatigue at sea yields interesting nuggets
summary: A three-year US$1 million study on fatigue at sea, funded by The TK Foundation, presented its findings to the International Maritime Organization (IMO). The study, known as MARTHA, gathered data from nearly 1,000 seafarers and found that ships' masters suffer from fatigue and stress more than their crew. Fatigue can lead to long-term physical and mental health issues, including decreased motivation and sleep quality. The study recommends the introduction of fatigue-risk management systems to mitigate the issue, which would require ownership by all parties involved in the company.

site_title: Frasers Tower attracts diverse sectors
summary: Frasers Tower, a new office development in Singapore, has received interest for 30% of its office space, with regional serviced office provider The Executive Centre securing a 20,000 sq ft lease for an entire floor. The development was officially launched on February 7, 2017.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Frasers Logistics & Industrial Trust (FLT) reported 1QFY17 results, meeting expectations with gross revenue at A$39.7m and DPU of 1.74 S cents exceeding forecasts. FLT's portfolio remains resilient with minimal lease expiries and a low gearing ratio of 29.7%. Religare Health Trust (RHT) reported decent organic growth, but faces pressure from reduced distribution payout. Singapore Myanmar Investco (SMI) reported a core net loss of US$2.6m, but inks a 10-year duty-free retail concession at Yangon International Airport.

site_title: Another query as Best World shares dive
summary: The share price of Best World International, a Singapore-based direct seller of skincare and wellness products, plummeted by 10% to close at S$1.76 on Tuesday, prompting a query from the Singapore Exchange. The company attributed the unusual trading activity to a lack of new information, despite a 99% revenue growth in the third quarter of 2016. The stock had previously rallied after research reports by CIMB and Maybank Kim Eng, but a local brokerage's decision to put the stock on its restricted list is also a possible cause.

site_title: Taiwan to build 66 jet trainer aircraft by 2026 to bolster defences
summary: Taiwan plans to build 66 jet trainer aircraft by 2026 to bolster its defenses against China. The project, valued at NT$68 billion (S$3.1 billion), aims to improve the country's air combat capability and develop its aerospace industry. The aircraft will be developed jointly by the National Chung-shan Institute of Science and Technology, the defense ministry, and Aerospace Industrial Development Corp. Taiwan's defense industry has "stagnated" for nearly 30 years, and the project is seen as a critical step to address this issue and counter China's growing military presence.

site_title: Deutsche Boerse, LSE offer sale of French clearing house to ease merger
summary: Deutsche Boerse and London Stock Exchange (LSE) plan to sell French clearing house LCH Clearnet to ease regulatory approval of their planned merger. The firms, which operate the London and Frankfurt stock markets, have submitted a proposal to sell the business to address EU competition concerns. The sale is valued at 510 million euros (S$772 million) and will be conducted by Euronext, a European rival. The move aims to alleviate concerns that the merger could lead to reduced competition in the financial markets.

site_title: IMF, Greece split on outlook for economy
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) and Greece are at odds over the country's economic outlook, delaying further IMF financing. Greece's Finance Minister Euclid Tsakalotos disputes the IMF's report, which underestimates growth and overestimates budget surpluses. The IMF requires Greece to achieve a primary balance of 3.5% of GDP, but Tsakalotos argues this is unrealistic given the country's recovery. The IMF warns that aiming for this high surplus will harm growth, while Greece insists it can sustain a higher surplus. The dispute hinders Greece's 86-billion-euro bailout program.

images.alt_text: Greece Finance Minister Euclid Tsakalotos said the IMF report on the economy, released Tuesday, "fails to do justice" to his country by underestimating growth and the progress made through years of sacrifice.

site_title: Google coordinates brief against Trump's order
summary: Alphabet Inc, the parent company of Google, is coordinating the funding of a legal brief opposing US President Donald Trump's executive order on immigration, filed by over 120 companies. The brief emphasizes the economic and social contributions of immigrants, citing examples from tech giants like Apple, Facebook, and Microsoft. A federal judge temporarily blocked the ban, and the appellate court in San Francisco is set to hear arguments in the case. The brief argues that the US should maintain its commitment to welcoming immigrants while maintaining security measures.

site_title: Is China joining the currency war?
summary: China's recent yuan devaluation against the US dollar has raised concerns of joining a currency war. However, the devaluation is largely driven by market forces and Beijing's efforts to target the trade-weighted exchange rate, rather than a deliberate policy to weaken the yuan. China's large trade surplus and excessive savings rate make devaluation counterproductive, and the country is likely to resist such a move. The People's Bank of China (PBOC) has intervened in the market to stabilize the yuan and is expected to continue this approach, rather than pursuing sharp devaluation or capital controls.

site_title: Uber hires veteran Nasa engineer to develop flying cars
summary: Uber has hired Mark Moore, a veteran NASA engineer, as director of engineering for aviation to develop flying cars. Moore's research on electric aircraft, known as VTOLs, inspired billionaire Larry Page to secretly fund startups to develop the technology. Uber's vision is to create a network of "vertiports" for air taxis, with the goal of making flying cars a reality. Moore acknowledges the technical challenges but believes Uber's 55 million active riders can demonstrate a profitable and safe market, making it an attractive investment opportunity.

site_title: IBM CEO receives biggest bonus in five years
summary: IBM CEO Ginni Rometty received a $4.95 million bonus in 2016, the largest since becoming CEO in 2012, following the company's 21% stock rise. The bonus was tied to operating net income, cash flow, and revenue from strategic imperatives.

site_title: Malaysia's ringgit crackdown deterring overseas investors
summary: Malaysia's crackdown on currency speculators has reduced ringgit volatility but is deterring overseas investors. Global funds cut their holdings of Malaysian debt by a combined 25.2 billion ringgit in November and December, the largest two-month outflow since 2008. The currency's volatility has dwindled to the lowest in four years, but its value has fallen 2% since November 15, making it the region's worst performer after the yen. Experts predict the currency will continue to slide, reaching 4.54 by mid-year.

site_title: UOL, SingLand confident of year's first launch
summary: UOL Group and Singapore Land are set to launch the first project of the year, The Clement Canopy, on February 25. The 99-year leasehold development, built by a 50:50 joint venture, boasts affordable prices and a prime location near educational institutions and Singapore's biomedical hub. The showflats will open to the public on February 11, with prices ranging from S$850,000 to S$1.62 million. The developers are optimistic about the market sentiment, citing healthy take-up rates across their projects, with 8,136 private homes sold in 2016, up 9.4% from the previous year.

site_title: Airbnb landlord slapped with record fine in Amsterdam
summary: The city of Amsterdam has fined a landlord and agency 297,000 euros (S$449,639) for breaking council rules in renting out 11 apartments via Airbnb. The owners and agency must pay 13,500 euros each for each apartment, totaling 11 times the usual fine. This is the first record fine imposed by the municipality, which has almost 200 such fines in 2016. The fine was issued after neighbors complained of disturbances, and the owners were required to comply with a 60-day rental limit per year, set in a pioneering agreement with Airbnb.

site_title: Nets unveils digitised payment strategy
summary: Nets, a 32-year-old cashless payment solutions company in Singapore, has unveiled "Nets 2.0," a new fintech strategy aimed at digitizing consumer payment experiences. The company will issue digitized debit-linked cards, allowing users to pay with their smartphones, and introduce contactless, physical debit-linked cards and a mobile wallet app. Nets will also develop an open platform and wearables for seamless payments. The company's initiatives are expected to roll out by mid-2017, with all merchants and Nets POS terminals expected to accept contactless payments by 2018.

site_title: Made-in-China large passenger plane targets 2017 debut
summary: China's state-owned Commercial Aircraft Corp of China (Comac) is set to unveil its large passenger plane, the C919, with a maiden voyage in the first half of 2017. The plane, which can seat 168 passengers, is a result of an 8-year effort to reduce China's reliance on foreign plane makers. With 570 orders received, the C919 aims to challenge Airbus and Boeing for market share in the lucrative segment. This move is part of China's plan to become a major player in the global aviation industry.

site_title: Snagging IPO of the decade won't be that easy for Singapore
summary: Singapore's bid to host the IPO of Saudi Arabian Oil Co, potentially the world's largest share sale, faces uncertainty. The city-state is considering measures to lure Aramco, including a state investment company as a cornerstone investor. Singapore is the Asia's No 1 oil trading centre, but its suitability for the massive IPO remains unclear.

site_title: Surbana's actions in axing staff not acceptable: Swee Say
summary: Manpower Minister Lim Swee Say has criticized Surbana Jurong for publicly labeling 54 axed employees as "poor performers." He deemed the move unacceptable and called on employers to handle performance management responsibly and sensitively. Lim emphasized the importance of a fair process and substantiation of claims, and warned that employers must be able to justify their decisions. He also noted that the affected workers have since reached an agreement with the company and the ministry regards the settlement as "fair."

images.alt_text: Mr Lim: "Poor performance in one organisation doesn't mean the person cannot do well in other places."

site_title: Start-up fever grips young tech-savvy Indians
summary: Young Indians are flocking to tech start-ups, with a quarter of a century after liberalisation, India now has 4,750 tech start-ups, the highest in the world after the US and Britain. The country's rising middle class has given young people the freedom to experiment, with many opting to go it alone and pursue their own ideas. Success stories include Flipkart and Big Basket, and the trend is expected to continue, with 200,000 to 250,000 people set to work in tech start-ups by 2020.

site_title: Offshore wind moves into energy's mainstream
summary: Offshore wind energy is gaining mainstream acceptance as technology improves and costs decrease, attracting investors from banks, private equity funds, and wealthy individuals. The industry has expanded, with more major players entering the market, and competition driving innovation and cost reductions. Advances in vessel design, installation techniques, and weather management have also contributed to the decline in costs. With the US under President Trump rethinking its stance on renewables, offshore wind is seen as a more attractive option for Europe, with the potential to compete with conventional power sources without subsidies.

site_title: Hyundai Merchant Marine expects losses until mid-2018
summary: Hyundai Merchant Marine, South Korea's largest shipping company, expects to post losses until mid-2018 due to the industry's struggle to recover from Hanjin Shipping's bankruptcy and excess capacity. The company aims to turn around its finances by investing in box terminals in Southeast Asia and ordering new ships to meet emission rules. Hyundai Merchant plans to make an operating profit in the third quarter of 2018 and expects freight rates to recover as the industry pares capacity. The company has secured financial support from the Korean government and is buying overseas terminal assets.

site_title: Jobs mismatch a pressing issue for PMETs
summary: Singapore's jobs market experienced a structural shift in September 2016, with employers seeking white-collar workers, despite a low number of job openings. The Ministry of Manpower reported 53,800 job vacancies, the lowest in six years, but 47.9% of them were for Professionals, Managers, Executives, and Technicians (PMETs). The mismatch in skills between job seekers and available positions is a pressing issue, with employers citing a lack of necessary work experience, pay, and competition for local candidates as reasons for unfilled vacancies.

images.alt_text: A noticeable structural shift is underway in Singapore's jobs market, as employers indicated strong demand for white-collar workers in September last year, even as the number of job openings fell to a multi-year low, according to a report on job vacancies released by a Ministry of Manpower (MOM) unit on Tuesday.

site_title: China's conflicting goals keep investors out
summary: China's efforts to open its capital markets to foreign investors have been hindered by tightening capital controls, sparking concerns among investors. Despite China's growing domestic capital markets, regulators' aggressive steps to curb outflows have created uncertainty, deterring investors. Foreign investors, such as QSuper, are hesitant to invest in China due to concerns over transparency and property rights. The country's conflicting goals of growth and leverage reduction have led to a lack of transparency in decision-making, making it difficult for investors to understand the rules.

site_title: Twitter plans to hide abusive tweets, block repeat offenders
summary: Twitter plans to hide abusive tweets and block repeat offenders, aiming to combat abuse and harassment on its platform. The company will hide content from banned users, making it harder for them to be heard, and prevent them from creating new accounts. The updates, announced by CEO Jack Dorsey, come after years of criticism and are part of a new push to clean up the social media service. The changes do not immediately delete harmful content but require more clicks to access it.

site_title: China firms in UK urged to take 'precautions' over Brexit
summary: China's ambassador to London advises Chinese firms in the UK to take precautions due to Brexit uncertainty. This comes after the UK's vote to exit the European Union in June last year. China initially viewed Brexit as an internal matter and sought a strong, stable Europe. The advice aims to mitigate potential risks and disruptions to Chinese businesses in the UK's financial sector.

site_title: BP misses profit estimates, posts 'small loss' from oil trading
summary: BP Plc reported fourth-quarter earnings of $400 million, missing analyst estimates of $567.7 million due to lower refining income despite higher oil prices. The profit was adjusted for one-time items and inventory changes. The company's earnings fell short of expectations, despite the increase in oil prices.

site_title: Hot yoga, cool party under one roof
summary: Boutique yoga and Pilates studios in New York have introduced heated classes with a party-like atmosphere, combining physical challenge, spiritual growth, and social interaction. Studios like Inferno Hot Pilates and Tangerine Hot Power Yoga have seen increased demand, with some classes reaching capacity. Proponents claim the heat enhances flexibility and mood, while others, including an orthopedic surgeon, warn of potential health risks, such as heat exhaustion. The trend is seen as a response to busy, type-A New Yorkers seeking a holistic workout experience.

site_title: Honda and Hitachi forming JV to build electric motors
summary: Honda Motor Co. and Hitachi Automotive Systems Ltd. are forming a joint venture to develop, produce, and sell electric motors for electric vehicles. The venture, set to manufacture in Japan, the US, and China, aims to capitalize on the increasing demand for electric cars. The partnership will combine Honda and Hitachi's advantages, reducing costs and advancing competitiveness. Honda will continue to produce its own motors and maintain production lines in Japan. The venture's motors will be used for hybrids, plug-in hybrids, and electric vehicles.

site_title: Indonesia postpones court hearing into Goldman's dispute with tycoon
summary: Indonesia postponed a court hearing into a billion-dollar dispute between Goldman Sachs and tycoon Benny Tjokrosaputro, who claims the Wall Street firm unlawfully sold shares he owned. Goldman counter-sued Tjokrosaputro for reputational damage. The hearing was initially set for February 7 but has been delayed until February 21, marking a test for Indonesia's legal system.

site_title: CDLHT's overseas business can mitigate domestic headwinds
summary: CDL Hospitality Trusts (CDLHT) faces challenges in the Singapore hotel industry due to a significant increase in hotel room supply and weaker corporate demand. Occupancy rates for its Singapore hotels declined 2.9 percentage points to 83.6% in Q4FY16, while average room rates fell 7.5% to S$184. Despite this, CDLHT's overseas presence, particularly in Australia and Japan, helped cushion the impact, driving a 3.3% increase in distribution per stapled security. The trust is expected to continue scouting for acquisition opportunities abroad to diversify income streams.

site_title: SGX to launch sustainability reporting workshops
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) will launch a series of workshops on sustainability reporting, starting February 20, to educate listed companies on producing sustainability reports. The workshops are designed to equip companies with the skills to produce reports, with SGX subsidizing up to two employees per company to attend. Mandatory sustainability reporting was introduced in June 2016, with the first report due by December 31, 2017. The workshops aim to encourage early starters and provide investors with insights into non-financial factors affecting companies' long-term strategies and performance.

site_title: Fitbit under criminal probe for trade secrets theft: Jawbone
summary: Fitbit is under investigation by a criminal grand jury for allegedly stealing trade secrets from Jawbone, a rival wearable technology company. Jawbone claims that Fitbit hired five employees who brought over 350,000 confidential files, including materials and profit margins. Fitbit denies the allegations, stating that its trade secret claims were previously rejected by the US International Trade Commission and that the criminal investigation is "without merit". The case is set for a hearing on February 15, with both companies seeking dismissal.

site_title: Australia central bank holds interest rate steady at 1.5%
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia held interest rates steady at 1.5% as expected, with Governor Philip Lowe citing rising leverage and a pickup in home loans. Lowe also reaffirmed growth would accelerate to about 3% over the next two years, despite a contraction in the third quarter. The Aussie dollar gained, and bets on rate cuts slid, following the central bank's more optimistic outlook. Lowe noted the global reflation story and stronger growth in developed countries, spurring commodity prices, but also highlighted the need to absorb weak inflation to shore up financial stability.

site_title: GM readies SUVs to shore up shrinking margins after record year
summary: General Motors (GM) posted record annual profits despite a shrinking US car market, thanks to new SUVs and cost-cutting measures. The company expects to match or exceed last year's results due to the introduction of three new SUVs in North America, which will help shore up profit margins. GM also cut temporary workers without paying costly buyouts, reducing supply challenges. The company's net income fell 71% in the quarter to $1.8 billion, but revenue rose 11% to $43.9 billion.

site_title: In Japan's countryside, villages fight to keep cultural traditions alive
summary: In Japan's rural town of Kanegasaki, the centuries-old "deer dance" is at risk of being lost due to a lack of participants. The dance, a prayer for a bountiful harvest, is performed by only one dancer, who is 61 years old and suffering from back pain. Similar cultural events have been abandoned or suspended in 20 prefectures due to declining populations and aging. Experts say the loss of these traditions reflects the overall health of the community and highlights the importance of folk culture in keeping communities resilient and connected.

site_title: US study warns of dire results unless Washington finds a way to engage China
summary: A bipartisan US task force warns that strained US-China relations could lead to a trade war or armed conflict unless Washington takes a tougher line on Beijing. The report urges the Trump administration to engage China through high-level negotiations, maintain economic ties, and reaffirm the One China policy. The task force recommends swift action to reassure allies, initiate talks with China, and develop constructive policies on critical areas of engagement, including North Korea's nuclear program.

site_title: Fox tops profit estimates on sports, political ads
summary: 21st Century Fox Inc posted second-quarter profit beating analyst estimates, driven by strong sports and political advertising sales. The company's TV networks experienced tailwinds from high TV ratings for baseball and the election year, while its cable division generated growth from advertising and affiliate fees. Revenue rose 4% to $7.68 billion, missing estimates due to currency fluctuations in India. The company's broadcast division carried the Super Bowl, which delivered its first $500 million day.

site_title: Euro tumbles against US$ on political worries
summary: The euro plummeted 0.8% against the US dollar on Tuesday, its largest daily fall of 2017, due to concerns over Marine Le Pen's rise in the French presidential election. Investor worries about European politics, including elections in the Netherlands and Germany, and a potential bailout for Greece, also contributed to the decline. Meanwhile, the US dollar strengthened against other currencies, including the Japanese yen and British pound, after China's foreign exchange reserves fell below the $3 trillion level for the first time in nearly six years.

site_title: Facebook says it cannot monitor all its customers' posts for racist language
summary: Facebook cannot monitor all its customers' posts for racist language, according to the company's lawyers, who testified in a German court. Syrian refugee Anas Modamani sued Facebook over a photo of Chancellor Angela Merkel that was misused in hate-speech postings. Facebook offers a tool to notify the company of illicit content, but a judge may order the social network to block the photo. European regulators and the German government are pushing for legislation to curb the spread of malicious posts on social media.

images.alt_text: Mr Modamani (right) appeared in a Wuerzburg court on Monday next to his attorney Chan-jo Jun (left) to argue that Facebook must make sure that his picture with Mrs Merkel will not be misused again.

site_title: Industry cool to tweaking short-term rentals of private homes
summary: Singapore's government proposes reducing the minimum rental period for private homes to six months, allowing for short-term rentals. This could affect the hotel sector and security in condos, with property tax issues also arising. Industry representatives, including property consultants and condominium representatives, express concerns about a fair playing field, potential cannibalization of demand, and security issues. A new class of private homes for short-term rentals may be created, requiring approval by the Urban Redevelopment Authority.

site_title: Trump's US$1t plan may buy less metal than assumed
summary: US President Donald Trump's $1 trillion infrastructure plan may not lead to the expected surge in metal demand, according to estimates from Goldman Sachs and Bloomberg Intelligence. The plan is expected to add only 0.4 percentage point to global demand growth for steel and copper, and may not have a significant impact on demand for other metals like zinc and nickel. The US government's current infrastructure spending is dwarfed by China's $1.7 trillion spending in 2016, and most of the additional spending will go towards design, land acquisition, and labor rather than raw materials.

site_title: Lippo makes S$103m takeover offer for Healthway Medical
summary: Lippo China Resources has made a S$103 million takeover offer for Healthway Medical, Singapore's largest clinic chain, with a bid of S$0.042 per share. The offer aims to establish Lippo's presence in the country's healthcare industry. Gentle Care, a subsidiary of Lippo, has also proposed a S$70 million convertible notes issue, which could be swapped for up to 90.17% of Healthway's existing share capital. This move could provide an exit for Healthway shareholders ahead of a potentially dilutive convertible notes issue.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Ezra Holdings received a statutory demand from Forland Subsea for approximately 25.5 million Norwegian krone (S$4.4 million) due as a parent corporate guarantor for a 2012 charterparty. Yanlord Land Group acquired a 19.9% stake in Shenzhen Long Wei Xin Investment Co for 1.665 billion yuan (S$343 million). Courts Asia reported a 24.4% net profit rise to S$5 million for its third quarter, despite revenue decline. United Overseas Insurance's net profit more than doubled to S$7.1 million in its fourth quarter.

site_title: Singapore to raise water tariffs as production, supply costs increase
summary: The Singapore government plans to raise water tariffs due to increasing production and supply costs. Masagos Zulkifli stated that the nation is currently under-pricing water. This decision comes as the country relies on desalination and NEWater plants to supplement its water supply. The low water level in the Linggiu reservoir in Johor further exacerbates the need for alternative sources. The tariff hike is expected to help manage the rising costs and ensure a stable water supply for the nation.

images.alt_text: Minister for the Environment and Water Resources Masagos Zulkifli being shown round the Tuas Desalination Plant that is still under construction.

site_title: Harvard's US$1.2b haul erased by investing loss, payout
summary: Harvard University raised a record $1.2 billion in donations, but the haul was offset by $2 billion in investment losses and spending. This brings the total to $0, marking a reversal of previous years. The top 20 schools collected $41 billion, with Harvard and Stanford leading the way, despite a 2% decrease in overall donations.

site_title: SICC - 180 years serving business interests in Singapore
summary: The Singapore International Chamber of Commerce (SICC) is celebrating its 180th anniversary, marking 183 years of serving business interests in Singapore. Founded in 1837 to advocate for free trade and protect Singapore's free port status, the Chamber has evolved to represent a diverse mix of local and foreign businesses. Today, SICC champions key themes such as Asean integration, collaborative innovation, and inclusivity, with a focus on supporting the country's sustainability and economic growth.

site_title: Passion investing, while commendable, can be detrimental to investors
summary: Passion investing, guided by personal causes rather than profit, can be detrimental to investors, as seen in the case of SETH Holehouse, who has lost money on his five-year focus on renewable energy and recycled products. Unlike impact investing, which seeks practical accommodations between today's reality and tomorrow's aspirations, passion investing can lead to a "slippery slope" in finding companies that meet investors' ethics and morality standards while still growing their assets. Experts caution that passion investing can narrow options and increase risk, particularly in private investments.

site_title: Hyflux pumps S$30 million into automation, sets up new lab
summary: Hyflux invests S$30 million in automation to boost productivity and global competitiveness, aiming to enhance operational efficiency by 25% and reduce reliance on foreign labor. The company will also set up a new lab at Belvedere Close in Tanglin, offering ELO water therapy, and collaborate with Nanyang Technological University on advanced membrane technologies for water-treatment processes.

site_title: Brexit pushes prime Hyde Park home prices down 14%
summary: Brexit has led to a 14% drop in home prices in the Hyde Park district of London, with prices falling by an average of 6.7% across prime central London neighborhoods. The Chelsea neighborhood saw a 13.3% drop, and Kensington a 11.9% drop. The decline is attributed to reduced demand due to Brexit and successive sales-tax increases, but has lured buyers back into the market, with sales increasing in the final quarter of 2016.

site_title: First Sponsor profit jumps on partial divestment of stake in China project
summary: First Sponsor Group reported a net profit of S$72.9 million for the three months ended Dec 31, 2016, more than doubling from S$31.9 million a year ago, driven by "other gains" of S$98.8 million from the partial divestment of its stake in a China project. The company also announced a collaboration with Provast to develop residential blocks in Amsterdam.

site_title: Philippine miners say closures illegal as minister sticks to her guns
summary: Philippine Environment and Natural Resources Secretary Regina Lopez has ordered the closure of 23 mines, accounting for half of the country's nickel ore output, citing environmental concerns. Industry group Chamber of Mines of the Philippines claims the decision is "illegal and unfair", citing a lack of due process. The closures are expected to affect 1.2 million people, with the chamber asking President Rodrigo Duterte to review the decision. Lopez maintains the closures are necessary to protect the environment, despite industry pushback.

site_title: Riady family moves to take Auric Pacific private
summary: The Riady family, owners of Lippo Group, have made a S$48.3 million takeover bid to acquire Auric Pacific Group, offering S$1.65 per share, a 13.4% premium. The deal, if successful, would take the food company private and join the growing trend of privatisations in Singapore. Minority shareholders may benefit from the offer, but CIMB Research deemed it "not favourable" due to the low price compared to its target price. Auric Pacific's fundamentals have improved in the past two years, but the offer's value is still uncertain, with an independent financial adviser's report expected to assess the fairness and reasonableness of the offer.

site_title: Penny stocks rule as banks bolster STI
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 14.73 points to 3,071.64, driven by gains in OCBC, UOB, Keppel Corp, and City Developments. Turnover reached S$1.3 billion, with 252 rises and 207 falls. Penny stocks, particularly Elevated and Serrano, saw significant gains. The market's momentum may be influenced by speculation that investors are shifting out of regional outperformers like Thailand and Indonesia and into Singapore.

site_title: Airbnb seeks truce with Barcelona as tourist hordes spur backlash
summary: Airbnb seeks a truce with Barcelona, publishing guidelines for hosts as the city struggles to balance tourism with preserving its character. The home-sharing platform's business in Barcelona has nearly doubled, with 20,000 listings, but has sparked backlash from civic authorities over concerns of unregulated hotels and pressure on local businesses. The city aims to make tourism compatible with residents' way of life, with limits on the number of guests and an official register for hosts. Airbnb's rapid growth has led to fines and criticism, but the company claims to want to work with regulators and be a positive partner.

site_title: Making continuous R&D a business habit
summary: Singapore aims to become the world's first "Smart Nation" by encouraging innovation and entrepreneurship. The government proposes a new Innovation Tax Credit scheme to incentivize companies to undertake continuous research and development, focusing on improving existing products rather than finding new breakthroughs. This shift in mindset recognizes that innovation is a continuous journey, and the goal is to support companies in creating value through innovation, rather than solely focusing on successful outcomes. The scheme aims to promote a culture of self-review and encourage businesses to develop unique products and intellectual property, giving them a competitive edge in the long run.

site_title: UK govt will not renegotiate Brexit deal if rejected by parliament
summary: The UK government will not renegotiate its Brexit deal if it is rejected by parliament, junior Brexit minister David Jones said. He stated that going back to the negotiating table would be a sign of weakness and that Britain would fall back on World Trade Organisation terms if a deal couldn't be reached within the two-year timeframe.

site_title: Latest Earnings
summary:
Here is a 100-word summary of the article content:

Oil prices rose over 2% amid market uncertainty. US stocks fell, edging down from records, amid tariff threats. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer received 9.8 times oversubscription. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss in the second half. London's Heathrow Airport plans to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. US stocks were also affected by Trump's tariff salvo on Canada, with Wall Street opening lower. Market outlook and global events are influencing various sectors and economies.

site_title: Investors eye buyout premium in undervalued Singapore stocks
summary: Singapore investors are targeting undervalued stocks for potential buyouts or delistings, driven by significant price declines and the prospect of takeover premiums. Companies like Global Logistic Properties, Wheelock Properties, Mermaid Maritime, and Dyna-Mac Holdings are considered attractive targets due to their low valuations and controlled ownership structures. Experts expect an increase in delistings and takeovers this year, with Aberdeen Asset Management Asia predicting opportunities for "patient investors" to buy cheap shares.

site_title: China reserves edge below US$3t as yuan pressure increases
summary: China's foreign-currency reserves fell to $2.998 trillion in January, edging below $3 trillion, the lowest since early 2011. The drop was driven by the yuan's steepest annual decline in two decades and central bank intervention. This may prompt policymakers to tighten measures to control outflows, following stricter requirements for converting yuan into foreign currencies. Economists warn that further erosion of the reserves will increase pressure on the government to stem capital outflows and maintain confidence in the yuan.

site_title: Hewlett Packard Enterprise CEO gets US$35.6m for fiscal 2016
summary: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Co CEO Meg Whitman received a compensation package worth US$35.6 million for fiscal 2016, more than doubling from the prior year. The package includes stock options worth US$11.7 million and restricted shares worth US$19 million. Whitman led efforts to pare down the company amid growing competition from cloud-based service providers. The total value of her pay package is tied to performance targets until 2018, with the restricted shares vesting if she meets those goals.

site_title: Tata steel swings to profit for first time in five quarters
summary: Tata Steel Ltd reported its first profit in five quarters, with a net profit of 2.3 billion rupees in the third quarter of 2016. The company's revenue increased to 293.9 billion rupees, driven by a recovery in product prices and higher production. This follows a global trend, with steel mills in South Korea and India also experiencing profits after steel prices advanced due to government stimulus in China.

site_title: Between a rock and a Thaad place
summary: US Defence Secretary James Mattis's trip to Seoul and Tokyo provided reassurance on the US's defence commitments to South Korea and Japan, reaffirming American policy despite President Donald Trump's criticism of allies. China denounced the deployment of the Thaad anti-missile system and the US-Japan security treaty, which it claims does not include the disputed Senkaku islands. Trump's criticism of allies has created uncertainty about the US's stance in East Asia, but Mattis's visit suggests a continued commitment to defending allies in the region.

site_title: India said to sell 66.9b rupees ITC Stake to state-owned LIC
summary: India sold a 2% stake in ITC Ltd to state-owned Life Insurance Corp of India for approximately 66.9 billion rupees, meeting the year's divestment target of 455 billion rupees. The sale, priced at 275.85 rupees per share, represents a 0.3% discount to Monday's close. The move aims to demonstrate the government's commitment to meeting its divestment targets, with Prime Minister Narendra Modi's administration still 100 billion rupees shy of its initial goal of 565 billion rupees.

site_title: US trade deficit falls as exports hit more than 1-1/2 year high
summary: The US trade deficit fell 3.2% to $44.3 billion in December, the lowest in two months, as exports rose to a 1 1/2 year high of $190.7 billion. The trade deficit with China decreased 9.0% to $27.8 billion, and with Germany declined 6.2% to $5.3 billion. Despite the improvement, economists warn that the Trump administration's protectionist policies could harm the country's economic health.

site_title: US: Dow and Nasdaq hit record highs
summary: The Dow Jones Industrial Average and the Nasdaq Composite reached record highs on Tuesday, with the Dow up 65.43 points and the Nasdaq up 11.81 points. The S&P 500 was less than five points away from hitting another all-time high. Investors are assessing corporate earnings to determine if stock valuations are justified after a post-election rally, with fourth-quarter earnings estimated to have risen 8.1%. Despite uncertainty surrounding President Trump's tax cuts and trade policies, the market remains cautious, and the S&P 500 has not moved more than 1% in either direction since December.

site_title: Companies must be responsible and sensitive when terminating staff
summary: Surbana Jurong, a Temasek Holdings-owned infrastructure consultancy, terminated 54 employees just before the Chinese New Year, sparking criticism from Manpower Minister Lim Swee Say. He described the actions as "unacceptable" and called for employers to be responsible and sensitive when letting staff go, emphasizing the need for fairness, transparency, and accountability. The incident highlights the importance of conducting terminations in a sensitive and responsible manner, with employers also considering the impact on the affected staff and the company's HR practices.

site_title: Q&M Dental says Malaysia court has granted injunctions on Johor improprieties
summary: MAINBOARD-LISTED Q&M Dental Group has secured injunctions in a Malaysia court against two individuals, Dr. Matthew Hong An Liang and Madam Chong Lee Lee, for improprieties in its Johor Bahru dental business. The court ordered the individuals to refrain from interfering with the company's business and property, and also charged Dr. Hong with using criminal force against a dentist. The Johor contributions do not significantly impact the company's performance and financial results, according to Q&M.

site_title: Madonna adopts twin girls from Malawi: court official
summary: US superstar Madonna adopted two four-year-old twin girls, Esther and Stella, from Malawi, according to a court official. This is her third adoption from the country, following David Banda in 2006 and Mercy James in 2009. Madonna denied any involvement in an adoption application just two weeks prior, but the court granted an adoption order. The singer's charity, Raising Malawi, has been supporting a surgical unit at the Queen Elizabeth hospital in Blantyre since 2006.

site_title: US solar jobs grew 25 per cent last year
summary: US solar jobs surged 25% last year, reaching over 260,000 workers, according to the Solar Foundation. This growth, the largest annual increase in six years, is attributed to a 30% federal tax credit for solar systems. The industry now employs more people than the coal sector and fossil fuel electric power sector.
