California, the largest solar market, saw a 32% growth in solar jobs, while Nevada and Massachusetts experienced contractions due to policy changes. Advocates hope this growth will convince President Trump to maintain federal support for solar power.

site_title: Malaysia: Stocks end the day lower
summary: Malaysian shares closed lower on Tuesday, with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index dropping 2.4 points to 1,688.84. Despite trading 2.13 billion lots valued at RM2.10 billion, the index saw a slight majority of gainers (436) over losers (420).

site_title: Longest flight links Qatar and Auckland in latest endurance test
summary: Qatar Airways has established the world's longest flight, connecting Doha to Auckland with a 9,030-mile (14,535km) service. This surpasses Emirates' previous record of 9,030 miles. The daily flight using a 259-seat Boeing 777-200LR aircraft takes about 17.5 hours. The route aims to meet demand for flights from Europe and the US East Coast to New Zealand, with plans to expand to other destinations in the region.

site_title: Statoil takes hit as cuts long-term oil price view
summary: Norway's Statoil reported a net operating loss of $1.9 billion in the fourth quarter of 2016 due to lower oil prices, with the company cutting its long-term oil price view and taking a $2.3 billion impairment charge. Despite this, Statoil raised its 2017 production forecast and cut costs by $1 billion. The company now expects oil prices to reach $75 a barrel by 2020 and $80 a barrel by 2030, down from previous forecasts.

site_title: Sing Investments & Finance's 2016 net profit up 8.2%
summary: Sing Investments & Finance reported a 8.2% increase in net profit to S$13.9 million for the year ended Dec 31, 2016, driven by higher margins and loan yields. However, allowances for bad debts rose 29.2% to S$5.1 million. Earnings per share increased to 8.8 cents, while the company declared a five-cent dividend. Total loans fell 3.2% to S$1.91 billion, while deposits and savings accounts rose 0.2% to S$2.3 billion.

site_title: Spain's Banco Sabadell sees return to profit growth in 2017
summary: Spain's Banco Sabadell expects a 13% increase in net profit to 800 million euros in 2017, driven by stable lending income. The bank aims to contain costs, including the closure of 250 branches, and finalize the integration of its British unit TSB. This marks a return to profit growth after earnings stalled in 2016 due to sterling depreciation and mortgage contract charges. The bank's strategic update focuses on improving profitability over the next few years.

site_title: Hu An Cable says chairman is quitting, subsidiary assets may be sold in bankruptcy auction
summary: Hu An Cable Holdings chairman Dai Zhi Xiang is resigning due to personal reasons. The company is preparing to announce his resignation and is also selling subsidiary assets, Shenhuan Cable Co, Ltd, in a bankruptcy auction. This follows operational difficulties in 2015 when the local government in China asked the company to sell three subsidiaries, including Shenhuan. The company's shares rose slightly after the announcement.

site_title: FIFA's internal investigation said to uncover more crimes
summary: FIFA's internal investigation into corruption allegations has uncovered additional wrongdoing, potentially leading to fresh charges in the US and Switzerland. The investigation, led by Quinn Emanuel Urquhart & Sullivan LLP, has found evidence of bribery and kickback schemes related to media and sponsorship rights worth over $200 million. The findings could prompt new charges and add to the global scandal that has unseated FIFA's top leaders and cast a shadow over the World Cup.

site_title: Lippo-linked group makes S$103m offer for Healthway Medical
summary: Healthway Medical Corporation received a takeover offer from Gentle Care, a Lippo-linked entity, valued at S$103 million. The offer price is a 5% premium over the last trading price, with Gentle Care seeking to acquire all shares at S$0.042 each. Lippo China Resources (LCR), a subsidiary of the Lippo Group, aims to establish its presence in Singapore's healthcare industry and acquire quality management capabilities. The offerer controls approximately 13.3% of Healthway's issued shares.

site_title: Catholic Church beatifies samurai who refused to renounce faith
summary: A Japanese Christian samurai, Takayama Ukon, was beatified by the Catholic Church in an Osaka ceremony on Tuesday. Born in 1552, Takayama protected Christians during a time of official persecution in the 16th and 17th centuries. He died in exile in 1615 after refusing to renounce his faith. The beatification is a step towards possible sainthood, coinciding with renewed attention on Christianity in Japan, including the release of the Martin Scorsese film "Silence".

images.alt_text: A Japanese Christian samurai who died in exile about 400 years ago after refusing to renounce his faith was beatified by the Catholic Church in an elaborate mass on Tuesday.

site_title: Hot stock: Best World tumbles, prompting 3rd query from SGX in six months
summary: Best World International's share price tumbled 10.5% to S$1.75, prompting a third query from the Singapore Exchange in six months. The stock had previously been trading at a high of S$1.955 on Monday before falling. Some brokers attributed the decline to a local brokerage putting the stock on its restricted list. Best World reported a 99% revenue growth in the third quarter to S$52.1 million, driven by strong growth in China and Taiwan markets. The company is set to release its full-year financial results on February 22.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets dip at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets fell slightly at the start of trading Tuesday, with London's FTSE 100 index dipping just two points to 7,189.73. The eurozone's Frankfurt DAX 30 eased 0.1% to 11,498.49 points, and the Paris CAC 40 slipped 0.3% to 4,762.17. The declines were attributed to bank and healthcare stocks, with US-EU trade tensions also in focus.

site_title: IFC arranges US$140m loan for Armenia's power sector
summary: The International Financial Corporation (IFC) has arranged a US$140 million loan for Armenia's power sector to upgrade the 404-megawatt Vorotan hydro-power complex. The funding includes a US$45 million IFC loan, US$65 million from FMO, and US$30 million from DEG. The project aims to boost electricity reliability and provide clean power to 60,000 residential customers, increasing the Vorotan Cascade's annual electricity generation to 1,150 gigawatt hours. The upgrade is expected to bolster Armenia's supply of clean energy and reduce its reliance on imported fuel.

site_title: HK: Stocks flat as mainland demand offset by weakness overseas
summary: Hong Kong stocks remained flat on Tuesday, with the benchmark Hang Seng index dropping 0.1% to 23,331.57 points. Despite mainland China's rising capital inflows through the Shanghai-Hong Kong Stock Connect scheme, global markets weakness limited gains. The energy sector declined 0.7%, while resource stocks rose 0.6% due to a firm commodity market. Analysts will monitor the sustainability of the trend.

site_title: Indonesia port disruptions cause coal shipping delays
summary: Indonesia's port disruptions are causing coal shipping delays, affecting one of the world's largest thermal coal mining regions. As of Feb 6, 136 ships were waiting to take on coal, with 28 more ships than the previous week. The issue is attributed to local authorities blocking coal shipments, which may impact seaborne thermal coal prices, particularly from Australia. This could lead to increased demand for Australian coal, potentially affecting global prices.

site_title: Yanlord acquires additional stake in Shenzhen site for S$343m
summary: Singapore-listed developer Yanlord Land Group acquired an additional 19.9% stake in Shenzhen Long Wei Xin Investment Co for 1.665 billion yuan (S$343 million) on a willing-buyer, willing-seller basis. The acquisition increased Yanlord's interest in the subsidiary from 75% to 94.9%, offering good value as it was below the market price. The deal was made on a net tangible asset (NTA) value of 113 million yuan, based on the accounts at end-2016.

site_title: United Overseas Insurance posts higher Q4 and full year net profit
summary: United Overseas Insurance reported a 24.6% increase in net claims and a 10% rise in net earned premium in Q4 2016, contributing to a more than doubled net profit of S$7.1 million year over year. Gross premium grew 3.1% to S$21.5 million, while expenses decreased. The company's growth in premium, retention, and lower expenses led to the higher net profit.

site_title: BP misses forecasts as annual earnings slide for second consecutive year
summary: BP reported a decline in earnings for the second consecutive year, with underlying replacement cost profit falling to $400 million in the fourth quarter. This marks the lowest earnings in at least 10 years. Despite this, BP expects 2017 production to rise due to new projects, but warns that OPEC's production cut may impact final output. The company also revised its capital expenditure guidance to the higher end of its previous range at $16-17 billion.

site_title: Deutsche Boerse, LSE offer clearing house sale to ease merger
summary: Deutsche Boerse and the London Stock Exchange (LSE) plan to sell French clearing house LCH Clearnet as a condition for regulatory approval of their merger. The move comes after the European Commission expressed anti-trust concerns. The British firm, LSE, had previously agreed to sell its clearing house business to European rival Euronext, but the German exchange operator DBS decided to offer to sell LCH Clearnet instead. This decision aims to alleviate concerns and facilitate the merger.

site_title: Fujitsu's biggest shareholder to unload US$1b worth of stock
summary: Fujitsu's largest shareholder plans to sell approximately US$1 billion worth of the Japanese electronics conglomerate's stock as part of a plan to unwind cross-shareholdings with the firm. This move comes amid increased pressure for Tokyo-listed firms to justify their holdings following the introduction of a new corporate governance code in 2015. The sale aims to address concerns that cross-shareholdings can make management less responsive to individual and overseas shareholders.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close down on US, Europe worries
summary: Tokyo stocks fell on Tuesday, with the Nikkei 225 index losing 0.35% to 18,910.78, amid US and European political uncertainty that boosted the yen. The Topix index also declined 0.28%. The market's decline follows recent US and European stock market trends, with the US S&P 500 and Nasdaq edging to fresh records despite tariff concerns.

site_title: Courts records higher Q3 profit despite revenue drop
summary: Courts Asia reported a 24.4% increase in net profit to S$5 million for its Q3 2016, despite an 8.6% drop in revenue to S$187.2 million. The decline in revenue was mainly due to lower corporate sales of digital products, with Singapore revenue falling 12.3%. The company's higher profit was a positive outcome despite the revenue decline.

site_title: Honda, Hitachi Automotive say to form EV motor joint venture
summary: Honda and Hitachi Automotive announced a joint venture to develop, produce, and sell EV motors, with an investment of 5 billion yen (US$44.69 million). The venture, established in July, will have sales and manufacturing functions in the US, China, and Japan, with Hitachi Automotive holding 51% and Honda holding 49%. The partnership aims to boost scale and contain costs in the growing EV segment, as environmental regulations continue to increase globally. This move highlights Honda's efforts to develop more lower-emission cars.

site_title: China: Stocks fall on tightening concerns
summary: China's stocks fell 0.2% and 0.1% on the CSI300 and Shanghai Composite Index, respectively, due to concerns over government efforts to deflate potential credit bubbles. The People's Bank of China (PBOC) sent "window guidance" to banks to control credit quotas, and skipped open market operations for the third straight session, citing high liquidity. Economists forecast record loan extensions in January, with the PBOC reaffirming its tightening bias and analysts warning of a near-term downside risk to the A-share market.

site_title: Singapore shares finish higher with banks, penny stocks in play
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 14.73 points to 3,071.64, driven by gains in OCBC, UOB, Keppel Corp, and City Developments. The index's rise was largely attributed to funds switching out of Thailand and Indonesia due to their softness last year. Penny stocks, including low-priced issues, saw significant trading, with 18 of the 20 most actively traded stocks priced below S$0.50. The average value per unit traded was S$0.35.

site_title: Dubai government, companies team up with IBM on blockchain project
summary: Dubai has partnered with IBM to launch a blockchain project that aims to process transactions and track goods being shipped in real-time. The initiative will provide information to customs and trade agencies, as well as companies involved in the trade process. Dubai, a major trading hub, has registered $176 billion in non-oil trade in 2016 and is one of the largest re-export centers for goods between Asia and the Middle East and Africa. The project is part of Dubai's plan to become a blockchain center, following a similar plan announced in 2016.

site_title: German industrial production falls back in November
summary: Germany's industrial production fell 3.0% in December, according to federal statistics office Destatis, after two months of modest gains. Industry production declined 3.4%, construction 1.7%, and energy 0.9%. Capital goods makers suffered the largest decline, 5.4%, while consumer goods producers dropped 3.1%. Despite the decline, December's industrial orders rose 5.2%, signaling potential growth in the coming months. However, cold winter weather and global uncertainty are expected to weigh on the industry.

site_title: Jewellery maker Pandora sees slower 2017 revenue growth
summary: Pandora, a Danish jewellery maker, expects a 14-16% revenue rise in 2017, down from a 21.5% increase in 2016. The company expects single-digit revenue growth in Q1 2017 due to shipment timing and a strong Q1 2016 performance. Profit margins are expected to decline to 38% from 39.1% in 2016. Pandora will almost triple its dividend payouts to 36 crowns in 2017, despite lower-than-expected forecasts. The company attributes the slowdown to higher commodity prices and shipment timing.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: The Ministry of Manpower reported that nearly half of job vacancies in 2016 were for professionals, managers, executives, and technicians (PMETs). Singapore Exchange has discussed a potential secondary listing with Saudi Aramco. Meanwhile, Vietnam expressed surprise over the US's announcement of tariffs on certain goods and is seeking a lower rate. The Asian garment industry also faces higher US tariffs, while Malaysia plans to seize assets worth RM3 billion. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, and Citigroup predicts a target of 1,150 for the global equity index by mid-2026.

site_title: BNP Paribas targets stronger profitability, dividends by 2020 as Q4 profits rise
summary: BNP Paribas set a plan to boost profitability and dividends by 2020, despite low interest rates and regulatory pressures. The bank reported a 2% revenue rise to 10.66 billion euros in Q4, with corporate and institutional banking revenues increasing 8%. Net income rose to 1.44 billion euros, below analyst estimates, but the bank aims to improve return on equity by 2020. The plan includes increased dividend payouts and aims to mitigate headwinds in the coming years.

site_title: Hot stock: Auric Pacific up 13% on takeover offer
summary: Auric Pacific Group shares surged 13% on Tuesday after Silver Creek Capital made a voluntary conditional cash offer of S$1.65 per share to delist and privatize the company. The mainboard-listed food manufacturing and retail company halted trading before announcing the takeover offer. The stock resumed trading at S$1.65, its highest level since the announcement, with over 1.8 million shares changing hands by 3pm.

site_title: Philadelphia Fed's Harker says March is on the table for a hike
summary: Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia President Patrick Harker suggests the US central bank may consider raising interest rates in March if the job market momentum holds up and growth continues. Harker's comments make him the second Fed official to publicly indicate the possibility of a rate hike at the March 14-15 meeting, with investors giving a one-in-four chance of a quarter-point increase. The Fed's goal is to keep inflation around 2% and maximum employment while avoiding stoking inflation.

site_title: Australia shares steady after central bank holds rates; NZ slides
summary: Australia's shares rose 0.1% to 5,621.9, as the central bank held interest rates steady at 1.5% for the seventh straight month. The financial sector fell 0.3%, while materials and industrials gained. Key performers included Transurban Group, which rose 6.9% after a 42% profit jump, and Newcrest Mining Ltd, which rose 3.3% for its seventh consecutive gain. In contrast, New Zealand's benchmark index fell 0.4% due to consumer discretionary and healthcare stocks, with Trade Me Group and Skycity Entertainment falling 4.1% and 3.5% respectively.

site_title: Citigroup gets bond settlement agent licence in China
summary: Citigroup's China unit has received a Type A bond settlement agent licence from China's central bank, allowing it to participate in the interbank bond market. This is the first time a US-based bank has been granted such a licence, joining Deutsche Bank AG and BNP Paribas SA. The licence enables Citi to trade, settle, and provide custody for interbank bond products, following China's expansion of the market to foreign investors. The Chinese bond market has grown significantly, reaching $9.3 trillion in outstanding bonds.

site_title: Rickmers Maritime completes sale of vessel to pay down loan
summary: Rickmers Maritime has completed the sale of vessel Kaethe C Rickmers to pay down a loan. The sale, worth US$31.6 million, will be used to cover operating costs of other secured vessels and partially repay the loan. The company expects a US$31.6 million impairment loss in the fourth quarter of 2016. Additionally, Rickmers will make voluntary prepayments of US$10.4 million towards senior loan facilities extended by multiple banks.

site_title: Channeling Steve Jobs, Apple seeks design perfection at new "spaceship" campus
summary: Apple's new "spaceship" campus in Cupertino, California, is a symbol of the company's commitment to design perfection. The 2.8 million-square-foot main building, featuring the world's largest piece of curved glass, has been constructed with meticulous attention to detail, with no aspect too small to attract scrutiny. The project, valued at around $5 billion, has taken nearly six years to complete and has generated about 13,000 full-time construction jobs. While some question whether the focus on design perfection has clashed with construction realities, Apple's dedication to its vision has resulted in a unique and iconic campus that will house up to 14,200 employees.

site_title: Asia: Markets track global losses as Trump woes weigh
summary: Asian markets declined on Tuesday, tracking global losses due to concerns over European elections and US President Donald Trump's presidency. The yen surged to three-month highs against the dollar, while gold prices rose, as investors sought safe-haven assets. Markets had rallied in November after Trump's election, but the current uncertainty has led to a two-month decline. Key markets, including Tokyo's Nikkei, Hong Kong, and Shanghai, were affected, with some, like Singapore, showing a slight increase.

site_title: Trump's America: A new realm of unpredictable protests
summary: Anti-Trump protests have become a regular occurrence in multiple US cities since the president's inauguration. Demonstrations take place daily, particularly on weekends, with a seemingly unending passion from those not previously civically engaged. The impact of these protests is yet to be determined, but they are unlikely to stop soon due to Trump's four-year term and widespread discontent. The rallies have become an integral part of daily life in cities like New York, Boston, Chicago, and Los Angeles.

site_title: Deutsche Boerse says clears CEO after analysis of talks with LSE
summary: Deutsche Boerse's supervisory board has cleared CEO Carsten Kengeter after an investigation into secret merger talks with the London Stock Exchange found no evidence of wrongdoing. Kengeter had bought shares in 2015 amid the investigation. The board stated that "extensive conversations with external experts" and a renewed analysis of 2015 processes cleared Kengeter, with the board expressing full confidence in him. German police and prosecutors continue to investigate Kengeter over potential insider trading.

images.alt_text: Deutsche Boerse's supervisory board backed its Chief Executive Carsten Kengeter, who is the focus of an insider trading investigation, saying it had found that talks with the London Stock Exchange had not yet started in 2015.

site_title: Start-up fever grips young tech-savvy Indians
summary: A quarter of a century after India's economic liberalization, a new generation of young people are capitalizing on their parents' financial security to pursue tech start-ups in Bangalore. Hundreds of young Indians are working in the city's tech hub, with many aiming to become the next Steve Jobs or Mark Zuckerberg. The rise of start-ups is driven by the availability of resources and a growing demand for innovative solutions. This trend is expected to continue, with the young Indians seeking to make a name for themselves in the competitive world of tech start-ups.

site_title: China advises companies to take "precautions" over Brexit
summary: China's ambassador to London, Liu Xiaoming, advises Chinese companies operating in Britain to take "precautions" due to uncertainty over Brexit, citing potential economic losses for China as a major trading partner. China respects Britain's choice and hopes for an early arrangement acceptable to both parties. The warning comes as China values Britain as a strong advocate for free trade within the EU, despite past disputes over human rights and Hong Kong. China and Britain have warmed ties in recent years, with significant economic links, referred to as a "golden age".

site_title: Singapore Exchange holds talks with Saudi Aramco on secondary listing: sources
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) has held talks with Saudi Aramco on a potential secondary listing, with the planned listing expected to be the world's biggest IPO. Aramco, set to list in 2018, is considering concurrent listings on multiple exchanges including New York, London, Hong Kong, and Japan. SGX is promoting its international appeal, particularly its status as a leading oil trading hub, with 80% of top 30 oil and gas companies having a presence in the city.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks slip on profit-booking; HTC slides on weak sales data
summary: Taiwan's stocks fell 0.1% on Tuesday, following regional bourses, as investors locked in profits from recent gains. HTC Corp slid 3% after reporting weak January sales data, while the electronics subindex dipped 0.1%. The Taiwan dollar softened to NT$31.000 per US dollar. The TAIEX index hit its highest level since early June 2015 in the previous session.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 3.510 points to 1687.730 on Tuesday, with a trading volume of 48.07 million lots worth RM16.51 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 94 to 55.

site_title: Toshiba wants funds not peers to buy chip stake: source
summary: Toshiba is seeking investment funds like Bain Capital to buy a stake in its flash memory business, rather than industry peers, to speed up the planned sale. The company needs to raise funds by March to offset a multi-billion dollar writedown on its US nuclear power business. Toshiba has received initial bids from Micron Technology, SK Hynix, and Western Digital for a stake in its NAND flash unit, with the target stake being less than 20%. The company may consider other chipmakers once its financial crisis passes.

site_title: Seoul: Won slips on profit-taking, EU/US political uncertainty
summary: The South Korean won dropped 0.3% to 1,141.4 against the US dollar, as investors took profits and amid EU/US political uncertainty. France's far-right leader Marine Le Pen's poll lead and potential EU exit fueled concerns, while US President Donald Trump's policies and potential Federal Reserve rate hikes also impacted the currency. South Korean shares were flat, with chipmaker SK Hynix rising 1% after submitting an initial bid for Toshiba's memory chip business, while Samsung Electronics fell 1.5%.

site_title: Badminton: Malaysia's Lee left fuming over injury caused by slippery court mats
summary: Malaysia's world number one badminton player Lee Chong Wei suffered a medial collateral ligament injury in his left knee after slipping on slippery court mats at the Academy Badminton Malaysia on Saturday. The incident may have cost him his last shot at the All England Championship, which he was gunning for. Lee, 34, will be out for weeks, and with his potential retirement plans, this setback may impact his chances of securing his fourth title at the prestigious tournament next month.

site_title: IMF board says Greece needs further debt relief
summary: The International Monetary Fund's (IMF) board agreed that Greece likely needs further debt relief, with most members agreeing that the country's debt is becoming "explosive" in the long run. The board stated that Greece must implement strong policies to restore growth and sustainability, but there is a split over the goal for the country's finances, with some directors favoring a 3.5% primary balance. The IMF's review of Greece's debt sustainability analysis warned that the country's debt is highly unsustainable and will become explosive if not addressed.

site_title: As China's doors open, foreign investors worry about exits
summary: Foreign investors are concerned about exiting China's markets despite the country's efforts to open up to foreign investment. Fourteen months after qualifying for reserve-currency status, foreign investment remains below estimates due to regulators' efforts to curb outflows. The Chinese government's curbs on money flows have stoked anxiety among foreign businesses, and some investors prefer emerging markets like Brazil over China. While foreign investors see curbs on outflows as a price to pay for currency stability, concerns about transparency, property rights, and capital controls persist. Foreign investment in China's markets remains limited, with overseas holdings of Chinese shares and bonds rising but still far from what other big economies hold.

site_title: China proposes further tightening of internet oversight
summary: China is proposing the establishment of a new commission to vet internet services and hardware, amid concerns over growing threats such as hacking and terrorism. The proposed commission would consider risks to national security and stop approved purchases of online products and services by Communist Party and government departments. This move comes as China tightens internet oversight, with a cyber security law adopted in November and a sweeping national security law in 2015. The proposed commission's creation is part of a broader crackdown on civil society by President Xi Jinping, aiming to quash dissent and ensure national security and social stability.

site_title: Almost half of job vacancies in 2016 are for PMETS: MOM
summary: The Ministry of Manpower reported that 25,800, or nearly half, of the 53,800 job vacancies in 2016 were for professionals, managers, executives, and technicians (PMETs). This marks a steady increase in PMET job openings in recent years. The number of vacancies has been on a broad downtrend in the previous two years, likely due to a slower economy and efforts to achieve a manpower lean economy.

site_title: UK lawmakers reject first set of amendments to Brexit law
summary: UK lawmakers rejected the first set of proposed amendments to Brexit legislation, allowing Prime Minister Theresa May to notify the EU of Britain's intention to leave by March 31. Lawmakers voted against adding conditions to the plan, including parliamentary scrutiny of the withdrawal process and involvement of Britain's devolved administrations. The rejection clears the way for May's plan to proceed with the Brexit talks.

site_title: PUB calls for proposal for Jurong Island desalination plant
summary: Singapore's national water agency PUB has invited four companies to submit proposals for a new desalination plant on Jurong Island. The plant, expected to be completed by 2020, will add 30 million gallons of desalinated water daily to the country's supply. The successful bidder will enter a 25-year water purchase agreement and will be sited next to an existing power or steam generation plant on the island. This new plant will increase Singapore's desalination capacity to 130 million gallons daily, aiming to meet up to 30% of the country's water needs by 2060.

site_title: New Zealand central bank chief to retire, deputy to stand in
summary: New Zealand Reserve Bank Governor Graeme Wheeler announced his retirement, ending his five-year term on September 26. Deputy Governor Grant Spencer will serve as acting governor for six months while the central bank searches for a successor. Wheeler stated his intention to serve one term and take on governance roles. The New Zealand dollar dropped to US$0.7307 after the announcement.

site_title: New Zealand's inflation expectations jump in Q1
summary: New Zealand's near-term inflation expectations rose to 1.56% in Q1, up from 1.29% in November, according to a Reserve Bank of New Zealand survey. Two-year inflation expectations also increased to 1.92% from 1.68%. This rise in expectations may prompt the central bank to reconsider its monetary policy.

site_title: Icahn to sell closed Trump Taj Mahal casino in Atlantic City
summary: Billionaire activist investor Carl Icahn plans to sell the shuttered Trump Taj Mahal casino in Atlantic City, New Jersey, likely at a loss, instead of investing $100-200 million to keep it open. The casino was closed in October 2016 after failing to reach a new contract with union employees. New Jersey Governor Chris Christie vetoed a bill that would have disqualified Icahn from holding a gambling license for five years, allowing him to exploit bankruptcy laws and casino regulations to his advantage.

site_title: Singapore looking to raise water tariffs
summary: Singapore's government plans to raise water tariffs due to increasing costs in producing and supplying water. Rising urbanization and need for upgrading transmission pipes and plants contribute to the higher costs. The last time water tariffs were raised was 17 years ago, and the exact increase and implementation date will be announced in the Budget debate. The government aims to ensure a sustainable water supply, citing the example of the upcoming Tuas Desalination Plant, which is expected to be operational by the end of this year.

site_title: Australia shares dragged down by financials, energy stocks; NZ lower
summary: Australia's shares fell 0.4% on Tuesday, tracking the US market, as financial and energy stocks declined. Bank stocks suffered the most, with the financial benchmark falling 1.3% and the "Big Four" banks declining 0.8-1.2%. Energy shares also fell after global oil prices dropped. In contrast, material stocks rose, with gold miners gaining 3.5-4.9% after gold prices jumped to their highest in nearly three months. New Zealand's benchmark index fell 0.4%, led by industrials and healthcare stocks.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks slip at open
summary: Hong Kong shares slipped at the open on Tuesday, following a healthy gain the previous day, with the Hang Seng Index dipping 0.31% to 23,276.19. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also edged down, influenced by US and European market retreats. Investors tracked the US-EU tariffs and European stocks, which were impacted by mining and healthcare sectors.

site_title: China's PBOC to skip open market operations: statement
summary: China's central bank, the PBOC, announced it will skip open market operations to maintain stable liquidity in the banking system. This is the third consecutive day the PBOC has skipped daily reverse repurchase agreement operations, following a 10 basis point interest rate increase on Friday. The decision aims to keep liquidity at a "relatively high level" and follows a net drain of 270 billion yuan (US$39.36 billion) this week.

site_title: Trump vows US, allies will defeat 'radical Islamic terrorism'
summary: President Donald Trump vowed to defeat "radical Islamic terrorism" and keep it from taking root in the US, during his visit to US Central Command in Florida. He promised an unspecified "historic financial investment" in the US military and accused Islamic State fighters of committing atrocities worldwide. Trump did not offer details on his strategy to defeat the Islamic State group, which has claimed responsibility for attacks in several countries, including the US.

site_title: US travel ban a 'lawful exercise' of Trump's authority: Justice Dept
summary: The US Justice Department defended President Donald Trump's travel ban as a "lawful exercise" of his authority, stating it was a valid measure to control entry into the US. A federal court's decision to bar enforcement of the ban was deemed a mistake, and the nationwide injunction was deemed "vastly overbroad." The Justice Department argued that the court's relief was excessive and that the ban was a legitimate use of presidential power.

site_title: Australia central bank keeps interest rates on hold
summary: Australia's central bank, the Reserve Bank of Australia, kept interest rates at a record low of 1.50% amid soft inflation and growth figures. The decision was consistent with sustainable growth and achieving the inflation target over time, according to Governor Philip Lowe. The economy shrank in the third quarter of 2016, but Lowe noted growth was "weaker than expected" due to temporary factors, with inflation remaining below the 2.0-3.0% target band. Economists expect future rate cuts, with some predicting a rate cut in the first half of the year.

images.alt_text: Australia's central bank held interest rates at a record low of 1.50 per cent on Tuesday but soft inflation and growth figures kept the door open for future cuts.

site_title: UK consumers cut back on spending in January as inflation worries mount: BRC
summary: British consumers cut back on spending in January, with like-for-like sales falling 0.6% compared to the same period last year, according to the British Retail Consortium. This marked the first time like-for-like sales declined since August. Economists had expected a 0.8% increase, and the slowdown reflects growing concerns over inflation. A separate survey by Barclays credit card division also showed a 4.4% annual increase in retail spending, but with a significant surge in petrol spending, while spending on electronics and department store goods fell.

site_title: Singapore shares open flat on Tuesday
summary: Singapore stocks opened 0.13% lower on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) slipping 3.86 points to 3,053.05, amid lower oil prices and US and European political uncertainty. The most actively traded counter was Ezra, which fell 6% to S$0.028. Gainers outnumbered losers 66 to 46.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Auric Pacific Group, Ezra, First Sponsor Group
summary: Auric Pacific Group received a voluntary conditional cash offer of S$1.65 per offer share to delist and privatize. Ezra Holdings received a statutory demand for payment of about S$4.4 million related to a claim by Forland Subsea. First Sponsor Group posted a net profit of S$72.9 million for its fourth quarter, despite a significant decline in revenue.

site_title: French PM, Juncker say Brexit deal must be worse than membership
summary: French Prime Minister Bernard Cazeneuve and European Commission chief Jean-Claude Juncker warned Britain that any Brexit deal must not be better than full EU membership. Cazeneuve stated that Britain must discuss its exit bill before talks on a future relationship can begin, emphasizing the need to protect EU interests. Juncker agreed, saying the deal should not be advantageous to the UK. The warning comes as Britain prepares to trigger Article 50 and negotiate a Brexit deal by the end of March.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Tuesday, with the Nikkei 225 index falling 0.68% and the Topix index down 0.64%. The yen jumped due to US and European political uncertainty, affecting exporters. The decline was attributed to uncertainty over US-EU trade talks and recent Trump threats.

site_title: Li Ka-Shing to purchase UK broadband assets from younger son
summary: Billionaire Li Ka-shing has agreed to buy UK broadband assets from his younger son, Richard Li, for £300 million. The deal involves PCCW Ltd paying £250 million in cash and £50 million in credit vouchers to Three UK, a subsidiary of CK Hutchison Holdings Ltd. PCCW expects to post a gain of about HK$1.3 billion (S$237 million) from the transaction.

site_title: Barclays to overhaul back-office operations to cope with ring-fencing
summary: Barclays is overhauling its back-office operations to comply with post-crisis rules requiring separation of retail and riskier business operations. A new standalone unit will provide support services to retail and investment banking when formally separated. This restructuring aims to help the bank meet new ring-fencing requirements, ensuring the separation of retail and investment banking operations. The new unit will operate as a separate entity, providing services to both retail and investment banking operations.

site_title: Brexit, Trump make Britons 'anxious'
summary: A recent poll by the Mental Health Foundation found that 49% of Britons reported experiencing anxiety due to US President Donald Trump's election, while 43% were anxious about Britain's decision to withdraw from the European Union. The survey also revealed that women, the 18-24 age group, Londoners, and higher social classes were more likely to experience anxiety. Mental health charities have reported increased calls and concerns over the impact of Brexit and Trump's presidency on personal relationships.

site_title: Two men get US prison terms for US$250m stock fraud scheme
summary: Two US men, Gregg Mulholland and Robert Bandfield, were sentenced to lengthy prison terms for a US$250 million stock fraud scheme. Mulholland, 47, received a 12-year sentence, while Bandfield, 72, was given a 6-year term. They orchestrated a series of pump-and-dump schemes, manipulating shares of over 40 companies, including Cynk Technology Corp, whose value soared to US$6 billion. The scheme involved thousands of shell companies and offshore operations. Both men pleaded guilty to conspiring to commit money laundering and were found to be recidivists in securities fraud.

site_title: Yen supported by risk aversion, euro sags on political woes
summary: The US dollar is near a 10-week low against the yen due to rising risk aversion, with investors seeking refuge in the safe-haven Japanese currency. The euro also falls on French political woes. The yen reached 111.730 against the US dollar, its lowest since November 29. This decline follows a 0.7% drop in the previous day.

site_title: Indonesia to hold court hearing into Goldman Sachs's billion-dollar dispute with tycoon
summary: Indonesia will hold a court hearing into a billion-dollar dispute between Goldman Sachs and tycoon Benny Tjokrosaputro over the sale of shares he owned. Goldman Sachs counter-sued Tjokrosaputro for reputational damage after the tycoon claimed the Wall Street giant's unit unlawfully sold shares he had pledged to a US hedge fund. The outcome could indicate whether Indonesia's civil court proceedings protect the rights of foreigners, particularly in a time when the country is embarking on its biggest drive for foreign investment in a decade.

site_title: Undervalued Singapore stocks see investors eyeing buyout premium
summary: Singapore investors are buying undervalued stocks, seeking buyout premiums, as more than half of the city-state's equities trade below their net worth. Companies like Global Logistic Properties, Wheelock Properties, and Mermaid Maritime are targeted for takeovers by firms such as Blackstone and Warburg Pincus. Undervalued stocks offer attractive value for potential buyout or takeover premiums, with some investors seeing a higher probability of privatization this year. However, investors caution against taking risks, citing difficulties in predicting delisting outcomes.

site_title: Update: Riady-linked Silver Creek mounts takeover of Auric Pacific at S$1.65/shr
summary: Silver Creek Capital, jointly owned by Stephen Riady and Andy Adhiwana, has made a voluntary conditional cash offer to delist and privatize Auric Pacific Group at S$1.65 per share. The offer is final and aims to privatize the food manufacturing and retail company, which includes brands like Sunshine Bread and Buttercup. Dr. Riady and Dr. Adhiwana are executive directors and controlling shareholders of Auric Pacific Group, with Dr. Adhiwana as group CEO. The offer is expected to be accepted, allowing for the company's delisting and privatization.

site_title: Ezra receives statutory demand by Forland for payment of 25.5m Norwegian krone
summary: Ezra Holdings received a statutory demand from Forland Subsea for payment of approximately 25.5 million Norwegian krone (S$4.4 million) as the parent corporate guarantor for a 2012 charterparty. The demand states that failure to pay within three weeks may lead to the company being wound up by the High Court of Singapore. Ezra is currently seeking advice and is required to respond to the demand within the specified timeframe.

site_title: Oil falls as US supplies, speculative length counter Opec cuts
summary: Oil prices fell on Monday, with Brent futures dropping 1.9% to $55.72 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude losing 1.5% to $53.01. Ample US supplies and excess speculative length outweighed Opec output curbs and rising tensions between the US and Iran. Hedge funds boosted their bullish bets in US crude futures, and US gasoline futures fell 2.8%. The decline was attributed to weakness in gasoline futures and a large increase in the US oil rig count, which may lead to increased US production and mitigate Opec cuts.

images.alt_text: Oil fell on Monday as ample US supplies and excess speculative length outweighed Opec output curbs and rising tensions between the United States and Iran.

site_title: Election for next president pushed back to September
summary: Singapore's presidential election has been postponed to September to avoid clashes with the National Day celebrations in August. This historic election will feature candidates from the Malay community, marking the first time a Malay person will serve as the head of state in 47 years.

site_title: How will Singapore face the wave of global tax competition?
summary: Singapore faces intensifying global tax competition as major economies like the US, UK, and Japan lower corporate tax rates. The country's tax regime, including a 17% corporate tax rate and Goods and Services Tax (GST), may need to be rethought to maintain its attractiveness to investors. Singapore's strong rule of law, business infrastructure, and political stability are key factors in attracting businesses, but the government must adapt its tax system to the changing global economic landscape. Any changes to the tax regime should balance incentives with measures to broaden the tax base and soften the impact on lower-income groups.

site_title: US: Oil shares, Tiffany drop as stocks retreat
summary: US stocks retreated on Monday, with petroleum-linked shares falling 3.2% and Tiffany declining 2.5% after its CEO departed. The Dow Jones shed 0.1%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Indexes dropped 0.2% and 0.1%, respectively. The market was still absorbing the impact of a solid US jobs report and President Trump's plan to review banking regulations. This week's earnings calendar includes Coca-Cola, General Motors, and Disney.

images.alt_text: Wall Street stocks retreated on Monday with petroleum-linked shares falling on lower oil prices and Tiffany declining on the departure of its chief executive.

site_title: Malaysia's ringgit crackdown saps volatility, deters investors
summary: Malaysia's crackdown on currency speculators has reduced ringgit volatility but may deter overseas investors. The central bank's restrictions on offshore non-deliverable forwards led to a $25.2 billion outflow of Malaysian debt by global funds in November and December, the largest two-month outflow since 2008. The ringgit's volatility has dropped to 2.5% since mid-November, but it has still fallen to its weakest level since 1998, reaching 4.5002 per US dollar. The currency is expected to slide further to 4.54 by mid-year.

images.alt_text: Malaysia's crackdown on currency speculators has come at a cost. While it successfully reduced ringgit volatility, it is threatening to discourage overseas investors.

site_title: First Sponsor Group's Q4 net profit more than doubles to S$72.9m
summary: First Sponsor Group reported a net profit of S$72.9m for its Q4 2016, more than doubling from S$31.9m a year ago. Revenue fell to S$21.6m, mainly due to lower property sales and financing. The company reported a record net profit of S$113.1m for FY2016, a 67% increase. A dividend of one Singapore cent was recommended for the year, a 17.6% increase from FY2015.

site_title: Tech sector leads resistance to Trump travel ban
summary: A coalition of tech giants, including Apple, Facebook, Google, and Microsoft, has filed a joint legal brief opposing President Donald Trump's travel ban on refugees and travelers from seven Muslim-majority countries. The brief argues that the ban has created disruption in the sector, which depends heavily on foreign-born talent, and will impede US companies from competing in the global marketplace. The move signals a contentious relationship between the tech sector and the White House, with many tech companies opposing Trump's policies.

images.alt_text: A coalition led by some of the world's biggest tech firms is taking on President Donald Trump's travel ban, signaling the contentious relationship between the sector and the White House could be about to get worse.

site_title: France's Fillon apologises for expenses scandal but refuses to step aside
summary: French presidential candidate Francois Fillon apologized for hiring his wife as parliamentary aide, admitting an "error" in the process. He claimed his wife, Penelope, was paid over $1 million in after-tax earnings for a job that was mostly informal, and that he had done nothing illegal. Fillon also acknowledged hiring two of his children for pre-tax payments, totaling 84,000 euros. Despite the scandal, Fillon announced he would continue his presidential campaign, saying "I am a candidate for the presidency to win it." The scandal has tarnished his reputation and may impact his chances in the upcoming election.

site_title: Europe: Shares weighed down by auto and bank sectors
summary: European shares fell 0.6% on Monday, weighed down by the auto and bank sectors. Investors sold carmakers and Italian banks, while buying defensive shares and gold. Risk-off trades benefited precious metals stocks, pushing gold to its highest level since November. Analysts attributed the decline to rising political risk and investors' reluctance to invest.

site_title: Yahoo Japan soars the most since 2013 as ads, e-commerce lift profit
summary: Yahoo Japan Corp surged 17% in intraday trade, its largest gain since 2013, after beating quarterly earnings estimates due to strong growth in advertising and e-commerce from smartphones. The company's shares hit their daily upper price limit, adding about US$3.4 billion in market value. The strong performance is attributed to the rise in online shopping and advertising on mobile devices.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: StarHub Ltd reported 4Q16 revenue of S$634.8 million, a 0.2% increase year-over-year, but operating expenses grew 2.7% and Ebitda and profit after tax (Patmi) plunged 13.6% and 33.2% respectively. The company is expected to cut its FY17 dividend, with analysts cutting Ebitda forecasts by 17.2% and lowering terminal growth rate to 0.50%. SIA Engineering's share price recovered to its target price of S$3.53, supported by a large cash balance and potential special dividend.

site_title: Bigger car loans taken last year, but fewer are delinquent, says study
summary: A study by Credit Bureau Singapore found that car buyers in Singapore took out larger loans in 2022, with the largest loan being S$837,135. This is lower than the record S$1,075,766 set the previous year. Despite bigger loans, delinquency rates decreased, indicating improved financial stability among car buyers. The study suggests that the relaxation of vehicle-financing curbs seven months prior to the study period may have contributed to this trend.

site_title: US, Japan conduct test of joint missile
summary: The US and Japan successfully tested a joint missile defense system, intercepting a ballistic missile target using a variant of the Standard Missile-3. The test, conducted off Kauai in Hawaii, marks the first successful hit of its kind. The US has spent approximately $2.2 billion on the system, while Japan has invested about $1 billion. The joint effort aims to enhance defense capabilities against North Korea's missile program, with Pentagon chief Jim Mattis reaffirming a "strong and determined" US stance against the country.

site_title: Budget raises India's capital market ambitions
summary: India's Finance Minister Arun Jaitley has set a 725 billion rupees (S$15 billion) target for public share sales over the next 12 months, aiming to cut the country's annual deficit. The target includes 110 billion rupees from state-owned insurance companies, 465 billion rupees from stake sales in state-owned companies, and 150 billion rupees from strategic sales. Analysts welcomed the budget, citing promises of tax cuts and a lower fiscal deficit. The government plans to list state-owned units, including Indian Railways, and use exchange-traded funds to hold stakes in public-sector companies.

site_title: Banks, GLP help STI rebound 15 points
summary: The Straits Times Index rose 14.97 points to 3,056.91 on Monday, driven by gains in three local banks and Global Logistic Properties. US banks and their local counterparts rose after new US President Donald Trump announced his intention to review the Dodd-Frank Act. Despite concerns over the banks' exposure to the O&G industry, Macquarie Warrants upgraded DBS and OCBC, while downgrading UOB, citing their relatively low prices and potential for future re-rating.

site_title: Apple hits out at Australian banks over Apple Pay boycott motive
summary: Apple has accused Australian banks of attempting to delay or block the expansion of Apple Pay into the country. In a submission to the Australian Competition & Consumer Commission, Apple claimed the banks are seeking to avoid paying fees to use Apple Pay and discourage customers from using the technology. The banks, however, deny this, stating their goal is to provide real choice and competition for consumers. The final ruling on the banks' collective negotiations is expected in March.

site_title: Russia uses soft power in bid to win control
summary: Russia employs soft power tactics, including information warfare, to expand its influence in the former Soviet republics, with the ultimate goal of re-establishing Russian power and control. Since 2000, Moscow has been actively pursuing its "geographical plan," which includes handing out Russian citizenship and passports to compatriots abroad. Russia has already achieved success with these policies in Ukraine, where it has created institutions, laws, and policies to co-opt the Russian diaspora and promote its interests. The US-Russia relationship remains uncertain, with Secretary of State Rex Tillerson stating that the two countries are unlikely to become friends.

site_title: Talk of unwinding QE puts Fed's mortgage bond stash in focus
summary: The Federal Reserve is considering unwinding its $1.75 trillion mortgage-backed securities (MBS) stash, which could lead to increased mortgage rates and reduced demand for homebuyers. Fed officials have discussed the need to reduce its bond holdings, prompting concerns about the impact on the US housing market. Analysts predict that unwinding QE could lift 30-year mortgage rates past 6% within three years, with some expecting the Fed to start paring its investments in the fourth quarter. The move could also widen spreads in the bond market, making it harder for investors to absorb the extra supply.

site_title: Hudson's Bay Co approaches struggling Macy's about potential takeover
summary: Hudson's Bay Co, the Canadian owner of Saks Fifth Avenue, has approached Macy's about a potential takeover, sparking a possible combination of the two department store giants. Macy's has been struggling, with declining sales and increasing competition from e-commerce and discount retailers. The proposed deal could lift Macy's fortunes, with investors reacting positively, causing the company's shares to rise 12% on Friday. A potential partnership or sale is still uncertain, with Hudson's Bay Co facing financing challenges due to its existing debt.

site_title: Trump's stance towards China, Russia heralds US policy change
summary: US President Donald Trump is shifting US foreign policy, particularly towards China and Russia, with a "new foreign policy direction" that may be the biggest shake-up since 1945. Trump has already scrapped the Trans-Pacific Partnership, placed new sanctions on Iran, and introduced a temporary immigration ban for seven Muslim-majority countries. His stance towards China is hawkish, with a focus on containing the country's growing influence, while his approach to Russia is more conciliatory, with potential economic sanctions lifted if the country is "helpful". This shift could lead to a significant change in US foreign and trade policy.

site_title: China hails US defence chief's emphasis on South China Sea diplomacy
summary: US Defense Secretary Jim Mattis has emphasized the need for diplomacy in the South China Sea, downplaying the possibility of major US military action against China. China has welcomed his comments, with a Foreign Ministry spokesman stating that the approach aligns with regional interests. Mattis' remarks come after previous statements from the Trump administration suggested potential military action or a naval blockade. China claims most of the South China Sea, while other countries in the region also have claims. Diplomatic efforts are seen as a way to resolve disputes without risking an armed confrontation with China.

site_title: British businesses say they're already feeling the brunt of Brexit
summary: A survey of Britain's top executives found that 58% of businesses have been negatively impacted by Brexit. The Ipsos Mori Captains Of Industry poll also showed that more than half of the respondents believe the vote to quit the EU has had a lasting effect on their businesses. The negative impact is felt even before Prime Minister Theresa May triggers the start of Britain's withdrawal from the EU.

site_title: Wanted: high-tech grads to work with Australian farmers
summary: Australian farmers are recruiting high-tech graduates to work with cutting-edge machinery, robots, and automated sensors on remote farms. The industry is shifting towards automation, with jobs available in areas like drone development and data analysis. The push comes as the sector faces a labor shortage, and companies like Ruralco and Australian Agricultural Company are hiring tech-savvy youngsters. New degrees in agri-sciences are being added to universities, and students from non-farming backgrounds are being attracted to the industry.

site_title: Australia retail sales hit two-year high in Q4, but dip in December
summary: Australia's retail sales reached a two-year high in Q4, with a 0.9% increase, suggesting the economy may have avoided its first recession in 25 years. However, December sales fell 0.1%, and homeware sales dropped 2.3%, indicating a slowdown in consumer spending. Despite this, online retail sales rose 14.1% in December, and economists expect the pace of growth to rebound after a contraction in the July-September quarter.

site_title: Ezra shares dive on news of US$170m subsea JV impairment
summary: Ezra Holdings' shares plummeted 37.5% on Monday after the company announced a US$170 million writedown tied to its subsea joint venture. The writedown, part of a larger US$640 million impairment, was triggered by two separate announcements from partners Emas Chiyoda Subsea and Nippon Yusen Kabushiki Kaisha. The company's share price traded heavily, with over 267.6 million shares changing hands. Ezra faces a "going concern issue" if restructuring options are not completed in a timely manner.

site_title: Changes to Singapore's patent legislation tabled in Parliament
summary: Singapore's Parliament has tabled changes to the country's patent legislation, aiming to enhance patent quality and make the rules more user-friendly for inventors. The Patents (Amendment) Bill, introduced by Senior Minister of State for Law and Finance Indranee Rajah, will require all patent applications to be fully examined by the Intellectual Property of Singapore (IPOS). This change is expected to increase work for 124 Singapore-registered patent attorneys.

site_title: JPMorgan wins China approval to underwrite corporate bonds
summary: JPMorgan Chase & Co has received approval from China's National Association of Financial Institutional Investors (NAFMII) to underwrite corporate bond sales in China's interbank market. This marks the first time a US bank has received the licence, allowing JPMorgan to challenge domestic players in the world's third-largest note market. The move comes as China continues to open its debt markets, despite a slow pace of reform. The approval follows agreements between JPMorgan and BNP Paribas SA to underwrite debt financing instruments issued by non-financial entities.

site_title: DRB shares surge as investors bet on Geely buying Proton
summary: DRB-Hicom shares surged 6.7% to RM1.27 on Monday as investors speculate Geely Automobile Holdings is close to acquiring Proton Holdings Bhd. Despite ongoing due diligence, Geely's shares spiked 8.4% on the Hong Kong stock exchange following a report that the Chinese carmaker is the leading contender. Geely's acquisition of Proton could give it access to Asean's growing car market, and investors believe it's a matter of time before a deal is sealed.

site_title: Queen Elizabeth II sets new sapphire jubilee record
summary: Queen Elizabeth II, the world's longest-reigning sovereign, has reached her sapphire jubilee, marking 65 years on the throne. Born in 1930, she became monarch at 25 after her father's death in 1952. Gun salutes and commemorative coins will be fired in her honor across Britain. The queen, now 90, is gradually handing over duties to younger family members, including her 34-year-old grandson Prince William.

images.alt_text: The queen, now 90, rose to the throne in 1952 at the age of 25 upon the premature death of her father, King George VI.

site_title: Taiwan top tech fund sees Apple's next iPhone, self-driving cars as best bets
summary: Taiwan's top-performing technology fund has identified Apple's next iPhone and self-driving cars as the best bets for 2017. The fund's 28% return in the past 12 months is the top performance among 49 peers, driven by bullish bets on iPhone orders and foreign investors pumping $1.5 billion into local shares. Companies supporting wireless charging and augmented reality, such as Taiwanese suppliers Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co and Largan Precision Co, are also expected to benefit. The fund's manager predicts a diversified market with small caps advancing amid accelerating earnings growth.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: China Environment has engaged a Chinese legal firm to handle civil cases, including contractual and payment disputes with subsidiaries FDEP and ADEP. The company will also report alleged fraud against former executive chairman Huang Min to Chinese authorities. XMH Holdings formed a joint venture with Myanmar MarcoPolo Co Ltd to manufacture generator sets in Myanmar. Chasen Holdings sold 60% of its management consultancy firm EONS Global Holdings for 9.6 million yuan. These moves come as companies navigate various business and regulatory challenges.

site_title: Tech firms to urge Trump to alter US travel ban: sources
summary: US technology companies, including Apple, Facebook, Google, and Microsoft, plan to send a letter to President Donald Trump urging the administration to alter the travel ban on seven mainly Muslim nations. The companies welcome recent changes to the Department of Homeland Security's implementation of the ban and express concern that it will affect visa holders who contribute to the US economy. They stand ready to help the administration identify opportunities to ensure visa holders can travel predictably. The letter aims to promote a more inclusive and efficient travel system.

site_title: Proposed changes to Planning Act to give URA more teeth
summary: The Singapore government proposes amendments to the Planning Act, granting the Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) more powers to regulate developers. Stricter penalties for unauthorized development or works are also introduced, including fines and jail time. The URA will be able to impose conditions on developers, such as providing public spaces and night lighting, and will require developers to appoint qualified persons to oversee development. The amendments aim to ensure that planning controls and regulatory standards are followed, safeguarding the quality of the environment and maintaining industry standards.

site_title: Bank of S'pore inks deal to let clients book assets in Switzerland
summary: Bank of Singapore has signed an agreement with Swiss banking group Bank Vontobel AG to allow its private bank clients to book assets in Switzerland, offering a third booking centre option alongside Singapore and Hong Kong. The move aims to cater to increasing demand from Asian ultra-high and high net worth individuals seeking stable and transparent offshore wealth management options. This partnership is part of Bank of Singapore's strategy to work with global providers and diversify its financial solutions.

images.alt_text: From left: Marc Van de Walle and Mr Denis from Bank of Singapore, and Martin Sieg and Mr Fischer from Vontobel. There is rising interest from Asian clients to have their assets in Switzerland, says Mr Denis.

site_title: Uniqlo JV helps to lift Wing Tai's H1 profit
summary: Wing Tai Holdings reported a 3% lift in net profit for the first half of 2017, reaching S$3.19 million, despite a 55% drop in revenue to S$131 million. The property and retail company attributed the increase to higher profits from its joint venture to sell Uniqlo in Singapore and Malaysia. Net earnings per share rose to 0.41 Singapore cents, and the company expects subdued sentiment in the property market for the current year.

site_title: GSH, Vibrant stand to book nice gains from GSH Plaza sale
summary: GSH Corporation and Vibrant stand to reap significant profits from the sale of GSH Plaza. GSH Corp will make a net profit of nearly S$80 million, while Vibrant will make S$28 million. The sale is part of a binding term sheet with Fullshare Holdings for S$725.2 million, which includes the equity, loans, and bank loans of Plaza Ventures. The valuation is based on the net asset value of Plaza Ventures and the value of available office units at GSH Plaza, valued at S$2,900 per square foot.

site_title: Post-election bulls may be overlooking Trump risk
summary: Investors are becoming increasingly concerned that a shift in US trade policies under President Trump's administration could lead to a trade war with dire consequences. Despite initial optimism following the election, analysts warn that the market is too complacent and that Trump's pledge to "America First" implies a retreat from global trade, potentially sparking a selloff. Experts point to the potential for a tariff on imports, which could lead to inflation and sap consumer spending, and warn that a full-blown trade war with China could tip the global economy into a recession.

site_title: Miners shift away from South Africa as costs climb while production shrinks
summary: South Africa, once a major hub for the mining industry, is experiencing a decline in investments and production due to rising costs, resource depletion, and regulatory uncertainty. Major miners such as Anglo American and BHP Billiton are shifting their focus elsewhere, with Anglo American selling half its assets in the country. The country's mining industry has faced issues stemming from its turbulent past, including cheap labor and safety concerns, and is now facing challenges from the government's push for black ownership.

site_title: Can Catalist continue outperforming?
summary: The Straits Times Index has risen 5.5% in 2017, while the FTSE ST Catalist Index has surged 12.7% since the start of the year, more than double the STI's gain. This outperformance has led to increased trading volume, particularly in stocks priced below S$0.50. However, for investors and those looking to list on the Catalist board, caution is advised as the market's upward thrust may not be sustainable. The article questions whether Catalist can continue to outperform the broader market.

site_title: Euro fades in face of French election risks
summary: The euro fell around half a percent on Monday due to concerns over French presidential elections in April and May, drawing investors' focus away from the currency. The US dollar remained steady despite poor wages data, while the Aussie dollar dropped due to weaker retail sales numbers. The euro traded at a two-month low of US$1.0734, with investors shifting to safer German debt. French conservative candidate Francois Fillon faces a fightback against a fake-job scandal, threatening his campaign and market stability.

site_title: Vodafone-Idea India merger may result in cheaper spectrum
summary: A proposed merger between Vodafone Group's India unit and Idea Cellular Ltd could result in cheaper spectrum for carriers, as the companies may be forced to shed spectrum and subscribers to secure regulatory approval. The merger, which could create a new leader in India's competitive mobile market, may also lead to a loss of market share for Idea and Vodafone. Spectrum worth over $1.3 billion could be sold at a lower price, benefiting carriers such as Bharti Airtel and Telenor.

site_title: Private home rentals: Govt looking at shortening minimum stay
summary: The Singapore government is considering shortening the minimum six-month requirement for private housing rentals, and creating a new class of use for private homes to allow for short-term rentals. The proposed amendments to the Planning Act make it illegal to rent out private homes for under six months and to house more than six tenants in each unit. The government aims to regulate short-term home-sharing platforms and ensure proper standards, while allowing for flexibility for residents to rent out units for short periods. The URA is studying the option of creating a new "use class" for private residences to approve short-term rentals.

site_title: Australia orders sale of properties bought illegally by foreigners
summary: Australia's government has ordered the sale of 15 properties in Victoria and Queensland, acquired by foreign buyers in breach of foreign investment laws. The properties, valued between $140,000 and $5.9 million, have a combined purchase price of over A$14 million. The move is part of the government's crackdown on foreign investment breaches, with Treasurer Scott Morrison stating the sale will ensure compliance with the laws.

site_title: Increasing risk created by Trump likely to draw investors to gold
summary: Investors are shifting to gold due to rising political risk surrounding President Donald Trump, with prices expected to rise to $1,300 an ounce by year's end. This is attributed to increased international tension and uncertainty, potential trade wars, and concerns over inflation. Experts, such as David Roche, predict negative returns for most assets, including bonds, while gold is seen as a safe-haven asset.

site_title: Britain to shake up construction system as house building remains behind schedule
summary: The UK government plans to shake up the construction system to address the country's chronic shortage of new homes. Housing Minister Gavin Barwell stated that the housing market is too dependent on large homebuilders. Despite previous plans to build a million homes between 2015 and 2020, the country is behind schedule. The government aims to incentivize developers and build 17 new towns and villages to boost the housing supply. The move is part of the government's latest attempt to fix the shortage, which has been ongoing for years.

site_title: Schoolings named ST Singaporean of the Year 2016
summary: The Schooling family, comprising Colin, May, and Joseph, has been awarded Singaporean of the Year 2016 by THE Straits Times. The award recognizes individuals who have made significant contributions to Singapore, overcoming adversity or achieving great success. The family, who are avid supporters of their son Joseph's swimming career, were praised for their sacrifices, including spending over $1 million on his education and training. The award was presented by Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam, with a cash prize of S$20,000 and a trophy.

images.alt_text: Colin, Joseph and May Schooling beat 11 other contenders to the Singaporean of the Year 2016 award. The judges for the award noted how Mr and Mrs Schooling had made sacrifices and staunchly supported their child's aspirations.

site_title: A US border adjustment tax can cost globalisation dearly
summary: A US border adjustment tax could significantly impact globalisation, particularly for Asian suppliers. The tax's uneven impact on different suppliers could lead to both benefits and drawbacks. Some companies, like Li & Fung Ltd, might benefit from helping global retailers navigate tariff structures. However, others may face increased costs, potentially disrupting global supply chains. The tax's effects on the garment industry, China's GDP growth, and the global economy are also being closely monitored.

site_title: FSL Trust warns of 'significant' loss; CEO quits after 'breach of duties' accusations
summary: FSL Trust, a Singaporean shipping company, warned of a "significant net loss" for the financial year ended December 31, 2016, citing impairment provisions and loss on vessel disposal. CEO Alan Hatton quit after being accused of "breach of duties" and "potential misconduct", including disclosure of confidential information. The board cited concerns over corporate governance and Hatton's actions, leading to his immediate cessation as director and CEO. Acting CEO Roger Woods has taken over.

site_title: Trump's early clash with courts portends years of legal battles
summary: US President Donald Trump's order to temporarily ban refugees and visitors from seven predominantly Muslim countries from entering the US is facing a court battle, with lawyers for the administration ordered to submit a brief defending the ban. An appeals court in California refused to reinstate the ban after a lower court blocked it, foreshadowing years of legal battles as the administration pushes the boundaries of executive power.

site_title: A pill to prevent jet lag may soon be a reality
summary: Scientists have made progress in finding a potential cure for jet lag, a common issue for long-haul travelers. A study published in Cell suggests that a protein called REV-ERBa may regulate the body's circadian rhythm, which is controlled by sleep, metabolism, and hormone production. By regulating this protein, it may be possible to prevent jet lag and other circadian-related issues. Researchers recommend strategies such as waking up at normal hours, eating at the right times, and exposing oneself to natural light to adjust to a new time zone. A pill to prevent jet lag is still in the works, but simple tactics can help travelers adjust.

site_title: Experts warn Aussie home prices may crumble
summary: Experts warn that Australian home prices may decline as the frenzied bidding of past years fizzles out due to Beijing's curbs on overseas property purchases and a drop in Chinese buyers. The number of home listings has decreased 25% from last year, but prices have only surged 0.7% in the nation's eight biggest cities. Real estate experts and hedge fund investors predict a sharp correction, which could stress those who paid high prices and damage financial institutions. A severe correction is forecasted, with prices potentially falling by 30% to come back into line with economic fundamentals.

images.alt_text: Waterfront properties in Sydney. A sharp correction in prices would heap stress on those who paid a lot to enter the big east coast property markets, while damaging the country's financial institutions as home loans account for up to 60 per cent of the major banks' total loan books.

site_title: GLP surges on talk of potential suitors
summary: Global Logistic Properties (GLP) surged 6% to S$2.78, its highest price in a year, after receiving several proposals from potential suitors, including CEO Ming Z Mei and non-executive director Fang Fenglei. The logistics group stated that non-binding proposals from various parties have been submitted but no definitive deal is assured. GLP ended the day 4.58% higher at S$2.74, with 48.5 million units changing hands. The company recently acquired 448,000 square feet of distribution facilities in Chicago for US$33 million.

site_title: National Australia Bank first quarter earnings fall 1% as costs rise
summary: National Australia Bank (NAB) reported a 1% fall in first quarter unaudited cash profit to A$1.6 billion, as costs grew faster than revenue. The bank attributed the increase in costs to annual salary increases and higher redundancy costs. Despite this, NAB's net interest margin remained "broadly stable". The bank's Tier 1 capital ratio fell to 9.5% due to a final dividend payment. NAB is considering issuing a Tier 2 capital security to shore up its capital position.

site_title: Japan resumes work on controversial US base on Okinawa
summary: Japan has resumed construction work on a US airbase on Okinawa island, despite local opposition and protests. The Futenma airbase, currently located in a crowded city, will be moved to a sparsely populated area in the north to address safety concerns. The Supreme Court's December ruling in favor of the central government allowed the project to proceed, with the Japanese and US governments citing it as the only solution to relocate the base. Protests and clashes with police have erupted, with many Okinawans demanding the base be removed from the island altogether.

site_title: Toyota, Suzuki courtship intensifies as talks begin
summary: Toyota Motor Corp and Suzuki Motor Corp have agreed to begin formal talks on a potential partnership, aiming to share procurement, green vehicles, IT, and safety technologies. Suzuki, a Japanese carmaker, seeks access to Toyota's technology to keep pace with industry consolidation, while Toyota gains access to Suzuki's supply chain network in India. The partnership could benefit both companies, with Suzuki potentially developing and selling more mainstream cars in India and Toyota benefiting from Suzuki's strong market position. Talks are expected to focus on a business partnership.

site_title: Japan banks brave negative rates, thanks in part to Trump
summary: Japan's major banks, Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group, Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group, and Mizuho Financial Group, have navigated through a year of negative interest rates with their profits intact, thanks to surging global bond yields, market volatility, and a weaker yen. These factors have boosted their fixed-income trading and offset weak lending profitability. Bank shares jumped in Tokyo trading, with Mitsubishi UFJ surging 5.2% and Mizuho reaching a record-low net interest margin of 0.9%. The banks' combined net income rose 0.3% in the third quarter, exceeding analysts' estimates.

site_title: More companies warn of full-year loss
summary: Three Singaporean companies, CSC Holdings, Metal Component Engineering, and SBI Offshore, have warned of reporting full-year net losses in their upcoming financial results due to high costs and reduced margins. Metal Component Engineering cited costs from exiting a hard disc drive business segment, while CSC and SBI Offshore will reveal further details later. The companies advise shareholders and investors to seek independent advice before making any investment decisions.

site_title: China to improve PR policies for foreigners to boost talent pool
summary: China plans to improve its permanent residence policies for foreigners to boost its talent pool, following a 163% increase in foreign permanent residents in 2016. The reforms aim to create millions of jobs in urban areas, amid slowing economic growth. President Xi Jinping's strategy responds to social concerns and follows progress made in easing residence and entry policies since 2015. Internet restrictions and heavy smog remain challenges in attracting foreign talent.

site_title: China firm in contenders shortlist to save Takata
summary: China's Key Safety Systems, a unit of Ningbo Joyson Electronic Corp, has been selected to rescue Takata Corp, the Japanese air-bag maker behind the largest automotive safety recall. Key Safety, which acquired Joyson for $920 million last year, was chosen over industry leader Autoliv Inc of Sweden. The deal, recommended by a restructuring panel, aims to stabilize Takata's supply of replacement air bags and keep its main businesses, including air bags, seat belts, and steering wheels. The move marks a significant coup for Joyson's CEO, Wang Jianfeng, who has built the company into one of China's largest private-sector automotive manufacturers.

site_title: Singapore wrestles with corporate life support
summary: Singapore is struggling with corporate life support, with debt restructuring becoming a major issue. Companies such as Ezra Holdings Ltd and Swiber Holdings Ltd face debt hurdles, leading to potential liquidation.
