Patent owners who license their patents will receive a 50% discount, and those releasing their patents will have administrative costs waived. The changes aim to discourage intellectual property hoarding and encourage businesses to actively use or release their patents.

site_title: Late-2016 pick-up sees Julius Baer hit target for drawing in new money
summary: Switzerland's third-largest private bank, Julius Baer, reported 12 billion Swiss francs (S$17.1 billion) in net new money in 2016, a 4% growth rate, below its target range of 4-6%. The bank attracted 116 relationship managers, and assets under management rose to 336 billion francs. Despite lower activity by risk-averse clients, net commission and fee income improved in the second half of the year, leading to a 705.5 million franc adjusted net profit.

site_title: French presidential hopeful Fillon accused of giving his family well-paid fake jobs
summary: French presidential hopeful Francois Fillon is facing a scandal over allegedly giving his family highly-paid fake jobs. The Canard Enchaine newspaper claimed Fillon obtained jobs for his wife and children that paid a total of around one million euros. This accusation threatens to derail his presidential bid later this year.

images.alt_text: The Canard Enchaine newspaper alleges that Mr Fillon obtained jobs as parliamentary aides for his children as well as his wife Penelope that paid a total of around one million euros.

site_title: Small savers flock to Singapore Savings Bond
summary: The Singapore Savings Bond (SSB) programme has exceeded S$1 billion in outstanding amount, with over 37,000 investors. Most applications come from small savers, with 55% investing S$10,000 or below. To cater to this demographic, three additional online application channels are now available, including OCBC and UOB's internet banking portals. The MAS will provide regular email updates on the latest interest rates starting March 1, 2017.

site_title: US to apply 'extreme vetting' in resettling deal with Australia
summary: The US has agreed to resettle up to 1,250 asylum seekers from Australia, mainly from Afghanistan, Iran, and Iraq, under a deal that includes "extreme vetting" for the refugees. The asylum seekers, held in Papua New Guinea and Nauru, must satisfy recently tightened immigration policies. Despite US President Donald Trump's suspension of the refugee programme and travel restrictions, he assured Australia that the US would honour its agreement. The deal was finalized despite concerns from international rights groups and the UN.

site_title: Japan Exchange invests in UK fintech startup OpenGamma
summary: Japan Exchange Group Inc (JPX) has invested a minority stake in UK-based fintech company OpenGamma Limited, a software provider for derivatives traders. The investment will aid OpenGamma's expansion in the Japanese market. This follows a $13.3 million investment by Accel Partners, Euclid Opportunities, and Cristóbal Conde in October. OpenGamma's CEO, Peter Rippon, sees JPX's credibility and presence in capital markets as ideal partners for achieving its objectives.

site_title: Seeds of populist agenda planted in Bannon's past
summary: Stephen Bannon, a key strategist for President Donald Trump, has been developing a populist agenda since his days as executive chairman of Breitbart News. His past statements, aired on conservative platforms, outline a vision for remaking the US and its role in the world. Bannon's focus on American sovereignty, reducing immigration, and withdrawing from multinational agreements reflects his belief that the US is losing a war against an expansionist Islamic ideology. His views have led to controversy, with intense fury from Democrats, discomfort among many Republicans, and a growing sense of unease in the world.

site_title: SoundHound raises US$75m to take on Amazon, Google in voice-enabled AI
summary: SoundHound, a 12-year-old music recognition app, raised $75 million to compete with Amazon and Google in the voice-enabled AI market. The startup aims to encourage device makers to use its voice AI tools rather than building their own. With the fresh capital, SoundHound plans to expand its operations to Asia and Europe, adding more customers to its speech AI platform, Houndify. The company has integrated its software with Samsung hardware and Nvidia's auto infotainment systems, and has partnered with various companies to access data sources for its Collective AI.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary:
Here is a 100-word summary of the article content:

Best World International, a Singaporean cosmetics company, has been successful in Taiwan and is expanding into China, where the cosmetics sector is forecasted to grow at 12.9% CAGR. Best World has received a direct selling licence in China, providing credibility and a platform for growth. In other news, ST Engineering is acquiring a 51% stake in SP Telecommunications for S$54 million, and Ascendas India Trust has a healthy DPU CAGR of 6% and a 5.4-5.9% yield, making it a buy. The stock market is also reacting to global economic concerns, with oil prices rising over 2% and stocks down in Europe.

site_title: Time for Singapore to revisit World Cup dream
summary: Singapore should consider revisiting its World Cup bid after FIFA announced plans for a 48-nation tournament starting from 2026. The city-state had high hopes for its Goal 2010 initiative in 1996, with the government and then-Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong backing the project. Although the bid ultimately failed, the recent FIFA announcement could revive interest in hosting the tournament.

site_title: Glencore unit's fake warehouse receipts renew worries of fraud
summary: Glencore's Access World has discovered counterfeit receipts bearing its name, rekindling concerns over warehousing fraud. The discovery was made in Asia, two years after the Qingdao scandal in China, which cost banks hundreds of millions of dollars. Glencore has alerted police to the issue. This incident raises concerns about the authenticity of commodity-storage receipts and the potential for fraud in the industry.

site_title: The 'slippery eel' ends up at a rough turn
summary: Former UN Secretary General Ban Ki-moon, nicknamed the "slippery eel" for evading controversy, ended his career in a rough manner after short-lived presidential ambitions in South Korea. Born in 1944 in Japanese-occupied Korea, Ban rose through the diplomatic ranks, handling key issues like nuclear negotiations with North Korea and climate change. Despite criticism of his communication skills, he pushed for initiatives on equal rights and human rights. His final year in office was marred by controversy, including the removal of a Saudi-led coalition from a UN blacklist of child rights violators.

site_title: Diageo back on the whiskey wagon with premium Roe & Co
summary: Diageo is investing S$25 million in a Dublin distillery to produce a new premium-priced Irish whiskey brand called Roe & Co. The brand will be priced at about £30 (S$54) a bottle and will join Diageo's high-end Reserve division. Production is expected to begin in 2019, with the brand initially blended from whiskeys of undisclosed existing distilleries. Diageo's return to Irish whiskey comes as the category experiences growth, driven mainly by Jameson, with Irish whiskey expected to reach 12% of the spirits market by 2030.

site_title: Trump's tax cuts, spending will worsen government debt
summary: US President Donald Trump's tax cuts and infrastructure spending will worsen government debt, according to experts. The yield on the 10-year US Treasury has jumped 61 basis points, and global bond investors agree that increased borrowing will lead to higher debt levels. Stock markets have rallied, with the MSCI World Index climbing 6% since Trump's victory, but experts warn that protectionism and a trade war could negatively impact growth. Storebrand Asset Management's Olav Chen sees a "positive Trump effect" for the next 3-12 months, but cautions that a trade war with China could be devastating.

site_title: Proposed strata rule changes a nod to governance and transparency
summary: The Building Maintenance and Strata Management Act (BMSMA) in Singapore is set to undergo proposed rule changes aimed at improving governance and transparency in strata-titled developments. Proposed changes include capping proxy votes, allowing MCSTs to pay council members honorariums, and defining common property. The amendments also aim to provide clarity on maintenance charges and safety grilles, and to allow electronic strata rolls and notices. A total of 33 items are listed in the proposed amendments, which will be finalized after a public consultation round ending on February 21.

site_title: Activist funds are right: All-Japan deals are looking too cosy
summary: Activist funds in Japan are pushing for better terms for minority investors in mergers and acquisitions, citing potential mispricing of deals. Oasis Capital, led by Seth Fischer, is seeking improvements to a stock-swap offer for PanaHome Corp, citing a more competitive auction price. Japan's domestic M&A deals are found to be cheap, with median price-to-book value ratios and price to enterprise value significantly lower than in other countries. However, overcoming Japan's deeply ingrained culture of cosy corporate ties may be challenging for activist funds.

site_title: Amazon to spend US$1.49b on air cargo hub; analysts talk of bigger ambitions
summary: Amazon plans to invest US$1.49 billion in a large air cargo hub in northern Kentucky, with a 50-year lease for 364 hectares of property near Cincinnati/Northern Kentucky International Airport. The hub is expected to create over 2,000 jobs and will supplement, not replace, cargo carriers. Analysts suspect Amazon has larger ambitions in the delivery and freight forwarding market, with a potential US$400 billion-plus market opportunity. The hub will allow Amazon to handle more shipping in-house, cut costs, and deliver packages faster. A start date has not been announced.

site_title: Electrolux says Q4 profit in line with forecasts, margins up
summary: Electrolux reported a Q4 profit within market expectations, with operating earnings rising to 1.62 billion Swedish kronor and margins increasing to 5% from 4.6% last year. The company expects market demand in North America to grow 2-3% this year. Electrolux focused on driving sales of its most profitable product ranges, contributing to the improved margins. The company's Q4 results were in line with forecasts and marked a return to profitability after a 202 million kronor loss last year.

site_title: Is Trump a 'tooth fairy' or a 'disaster' in May's Brexit gamble?
summary: UK Prime Minister Theresa May's post-Brexit trade deal hopes are dashed after US President Donald Trump's immigration policies spark huge protests, leading some to view her reliance on him as a diplomatic headache. Trump's temporary measure preventing refugees and travellers from seven predominantly-Muslim countries from entering the US has complicated relations between the two leaders, with May initially refusing to condemn the move. The situation has raised concerns about the impact of a potential trade deal on Britain's economy, with some experts viewing ties with Trump as a "political risk" and a gamble that may not pay off.

site_title: Investors go for gold, a safe haven amid Trump uncertainty
summary: US investors are betting on gold as a safe haven amid uncertainty from President Donald Trump's governing style and upcoming elections in Europe. Despite Trump's lack of specifics on his spending plans, which could undercut the value of the dollar, gold prices rose 1.6% to $1,214.19 an ounce. Fund managers, including IVA, Ridgeworth, and Fidelity, are taking a contrarian bet on gold, citing increased volatility and potential economic uncertainty. However, gold has been one of the worst-performing assets since Trump's election, falling 5.5% and 10.5% over the past six months.

site_title: Consumer sector still attractive, says OCBC Investment Research
summary: OCBC Investment Research believes the consumer sector remains attractive, citing inexpensive valuations and sound long-term growth fundamentals for Asia. The analysts have a buy call on Sheng Siong, Thai Beverage, and QAF, with fair value prices of S$1.15, S$1.01, and S$1.46, respectively. They also note that BreadTalk may deliver a special dividend after selling a stake in TripleOne Somerset for S$350 million.

site_title: Massive impairment by Ezra's subsea JV partners clouds its future (Amended)
summary: EZRA Holdings faces uncertainty after its subsea joint-venture (JV) partners unveiled writedowns totaling 51 billion yen (S$635 million). The impairment charge on Ezra's stake in Emas Chiyoda Subsea (ECS) could range from US$185m to US$385m. The company's early-morning trading halt has fueled speculation about its ability to withstand another massive impairment charge.

site_title: Abe to beat back Trump's charges of currency manipulation
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe is set to defend the country's currency and trade policies against US President Donald Trump's charges of currency manipulation. Abe will meet Trump in Washington on February 10 to explain Japan's stance, while also emphasizing the importance of US leadership in the Asia-Pacific. The US has accused Japan, China, and Germany of devaluing their currencies to gain trade advantage, prompting a surge in Asian currencies. Abe has rejected the idea that Japan's monetary policy is aimed at depreciating the yen, citing its goal of ending deflation.

site_title: Macau's January casino revenue growth falls short of analysts' estimates
summary: Macau's casino revenue in January grew 3.1% to 19.3 billion patacas ($3.4 billion), missing analysts' estimates of an 8.5% increase. The growth was attributed to a slow Chinese New Year start, with betting volume from high-stakes players possibly softer than expected. New resorts are targeting casual gamblers and tourists, but challenges include a cannibalisation effect and pressure on profitability. Analysts predict a volatile recovery, with some expecting a sharper recovery in February.

site_title: Global M&A activity enjoying best start to the year since 2000
summary: Global M&A activity reached its highest volume in the first month of the year since 2000, totaling US$224 billion in January. Europe surpassed North America as the top target region, driven by deals involving Swiss and Italian companies. This marks the first time since 2008 that Europe has led North America in M&A activity.

site_title: Private sector adds more jobs in January than expected
summary: US private employers added 246,000 jobs in January, exceeding economists' expectations of 165,000. This is a revision from the previously reported 151,000 jobs. The ADP National Employment Report is due to be released by the US Labor Department on Friday, with forecasts predicting 169,000 private payroll jobs and a 4.7% unemployment rate remaining steady.

site_title: China Jan PMI slips but stays in expansion mode
summary: China's manufacturing sector remained in expansion mode in January, with the official PMI at 51.3, slightly higher than expected. Despite a slight drop, the sector has been fueled by a government-led credit and infrastructure boom. However, analysts warn that stimulus measures will wane out later this year, and systemic risks weigh on the economy. The manufacturing sector is expected to moderate further, driven by declining domestic demand and uncertain external environment.

site_title: VW to pay US$1.26b to fix, buy back diesel cars
summary: Volkswagen (VW) has agreed to pay at least $1.26 billion to fix or buy back nearly 80,000 polluting 3.0-liter diesel-engined vehicles in the US. The settlement, which must be approved by a US judge, includes compensation for owners who opt for fixes or buybacks, with costs potentially rising to $4.04 billion if regulators reject the fixes. German auto supplier Robert Bosch has also agreed to pay $327.5 million to compensate owners of polluting US vehicles, with Bosch paying $113.3 million to 3.0-liter owners and $163.3 million to 2.0-liter owners.

site_title: Peanuts, home of Snoopy and Charlie Brown, is up for sale
summary: Iconix Brand Group Inc, a US brand management company, is exploring the sale of its majority stake in Peanuts Worldwide LLC, which owns the rights to cartoon characters Snoopy and Charlie Brown. The move follows a significant increase in Iconix's shares after the news, with several investors expressing interest in acquiring the rights. The sale would give Iconix a 20% stake in Peanuts Worldwide, with the remaining 80% owned by the Peanuts Worldwide board of directors.

site_title: Political battles set to intensify in rural Malaysia
summary: Malaysia's ruling coalition, Barisan Nasional, is facing intensified political battles in rural areas ahead of a likely general election later this year. A Malaysian federal agency, Felda, has admitted to corruption, and a subsidiary, Felda Global Ventures, has seen a significant loss in shares for smallholders, affecting rural Malays. A new party, led by former Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamed, is threatening Umno's dominance, particularly in rural areas, by campaigning on racial issues and targeting projects backed by China. This sets the stage for social tension and intensified debate.

site_title: Amnesty International: Extrajudicial killings in Duterte's drug war may be crimes against humanity
summary: Amnesty International has accused the Philippine police of committing crimes against humanity by killing thousands of alleged drug offenders and paying others to murder as part of President Rodrigo Duterte's drug war. The report also highlights widespread police crimes targeting the poor. The investigation found that the police may have exceeded their authority, used excessive force, and disregarded due process. The Philippine government has not commented on the report.

site_title: Dependency rising with fewer workers to support more seniors
summary: The world's working-age population is shrinking, leaving fewer people to support a growing number of seniors, according to the Bloomberg Sunset Index. The index, which calculates dependency based on statutory pensionable age, reveals significant differences in support ratios across countries. Seniors in France and Singapore are the least supported, with a ratio of about two workers to each retiree. The US has a ratio of 4.4 to one, while countries like China and Japan face tougher choices in allocating resources to support their aging populations.

site_title: Democrats delay vote on Sessions to do 'thorough vetting'
summary: US Senate Democrats delayed votes on several of President Donald Trump's Cabinet nominees, citing thorough vetting, despite Republican accusations of unreasonable delays. The delays included a vote on Jeff Sessions' nomination as attorney general, as well as votes on Steve Mnuchin to be Treasury secretary and Tom Price to head the Health and Human Services Department. Democrats argued it was their obligation to thoroughly vet the nominees, and that delays would allow them to review information on price trades and foreclosure practices. The nominations are considered likely to be confirmed once sent to the full Senate.

site_title: West African oil exports to Asia surge to 5-year high
summary: West African oil producers are set to send a record 2.19 million barrels a day to Asia in February, the highest level since August 2011, due to Opec's production cuts. This surge in exports is driven by Asia's increasing demand for crude, particularly from China and India, as refineries in the region seek to replace supplies cut by Middle Eastern producers. The increased exports are part of a larger redrawing of oil-trade routes, with Asia now accounting for about one-third of global crude consumption.

site_title: AmEx joins Hyperledger Project, contributes codes and engineers
summary: American Express joins the Hyperledger Project, contributing code and engineers to develop blockchain technology for corporate use. As the largest credit-card issuer, the company sees blockchain as a "game-changing" technology in banking, particularly for digital payments. With over 100 members, Hyperledger aims to reshape the global financial system and other industries. Commercial deployments using Hyperledger's code could begin this year, according to the project's executive director. American Express' involvement aims to further explore blockchain technology's possibilities and use cases.

site_title: Slight recovery for US$ after worst start in 3 decades
summary: The US dollar experienced its worst start to the year in three decades in January, falling 2.6% against a basket of major peers, due to concerns over the US's potential shift away from a "strong dollar" policy. US President Donald Trump's comments, including a claim that the euro is "grossly undervalued," further fueled the decline. The dollar index traded near a seven-week low, while the euro rose above US$1.08, and the yen strengthened against the dollar. Despite Trump's comments, the dollar still attracted demand, with some analysts seeing opportunities for bargain hunters.

site_title: New exchange eyes rewards from trading loyalty points
summary: Affinity Capital Exchange plans to launch an exchange by mid-2017, allowing institutional investors to trade point-backed securities, potentially worth $1 trillion. These securities are based on loyalty points from airlines, banks, and other companies, with a book value of $350 billion in 2015 and estimated to reach $500 billion by 2019. The exchange aims to bring transparency and cost savings to the largely opaque loyalty point market, similar to electronic trading in other asset markets.

site_title: Ex-UN chief Ban takes himself out of presidential race
summary: Former UN Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon ruled out a run for South Korea's presidency, citing "malign slander" and "fake news" in the media. Ban, 72, had been considered a front-runner but had struggled to capitalize on his high profile and clean image due to a series of perceived PR gaffes and a corruption scandal involving his family. His decision is seen as a boost to minor candidates, and his support ratings had slipped to 16.5% in the latest poll.

site_title: STI up 20.7 points as sentiment turns bullish
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 20.69 points, or 0.68%, to 3,067.49, as market sentiment turned bullish amid a weaker US dollar. Trading was firm, with nearly 1.9 billion units traded worth S$1.2 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers 270 to 164, with OCBC, UOB, Singtel, and Jardine Matheson among the gainers. The rebound follows a rough start to the week, with the benchmark index closing lower on Monday.

site_title: Apple attracts new iPhone fans as existing owners await upgrade
summary: Apple attracted 3.5 million new iPhone customers in the three months ended Dec 31, 2016, despite existing users upgrading at a similar rate as the previous year. This growth suggests a significant upgrade to its flagship product this year and increased services revenue. Chief executive officer Tim Cook attributed the growth to new customers, indicating a strong demand for Apple's products. The new iPhone 7 models were released in 2016, which may have driven the sales.

site_title: Share buybacks in Jan shrink year-on-year
summary: Singapore listed companies spent about S$19.6 million on share buybacks in January, lower than the previous year's S$81 million. The top five spenders were DeClout, Citic Envirotech, Singapore Press Holdings, Sembcorp Industries, and Second Chance Properties, which accounted for over four-fifths of the total buybacks. DeClout, which spent the most, nearly exhausted its share buyback mandate of 23 million shares.

site_title: Between farmers and Big Meat, which side will Trump take?
summary: US President Donald Trump's administration has frozen new regulations that would have protected farmers from anti-competitive behavior by large agribusiness companies, such as Tyson Foods. The Obama administration's "Farmer Fair Practice Rules" aimed to address issues with the "tournament system" that companies use to pay farmers, which can lead to financial losses for those who fall behind. The rules, which were set to take effect on February 21, have been put in legal limbo due to a 60-day delay. Trump's stance on the issue is unclear, with some farmers and advocacy groups expressing hope that he will side with them, while others, including the National Chicken Council, oppose the rules, citing concerns about stifling innovation and higher costs for consumers.

site_title: Post-Brexit London will retain many of its strengths
summary: Post-Brexit London will retain its strengths as a global financial hub, benefiting from the free movement of capital, sound regulation, and international connectivity. Singapore, a global Asia hub, offers similar benefits but with a smaller scale. Economic growth in the euro area is expected to be supported by accommodative monetary policy, but uncertainty surrounding Brexit and elections in key EU member states may weigh against it. In contrast, the US is expected to raise interest rates, which could have implications for Asia's debt servicing capacities and financial stability risks.

site_title: UK financial watchdogs shake up enforcement system
summary: The UK's Financial Conduct Authority and the Bank of England's Prudential Regulation Authority have revised their enforcement system to speed up the process and increase flexibility. Firms can now challenge sanctions without risking fines, and those under investigation will receive more information and updates. The changes aim to improve transparency, fairness, and efficiency in enforcement decisions, following criticism over the handling of the HBOS collapse in 2008. The regulators also consider banning individuals involved in the collapse.

site_title: US manufacturing growth gathers steam in January: ISM
summary: US manufacturing activity expanded for the fifth consecutive month in January, according to the Institute for Supply Management, with the manufacturing index rising 1.5 points to 56% and a strong majority of industries reporting growth. The production and employment components also showed improvement, with the production index reaching 61.4% and the employment index reaching 56.1%. The report suggests upward momentum in the economy, but some economists caution that the strength may be temporary.

site_title: US private sector adds 246,000 jobs in January, topping estimates
summary: US private sector added 246,000 jobs in January, exceeding economists' expectations of 165,000 jobs. This marks a revision from the previous month's increase of 151,000 jobs. The US Labor Department's non-farm payrolls report, due on Friday, is expected to show a gain of 169,000 jobs, with the unemployment rate forecast to remain at 4.7%.

site_title: Owner sues to keep Austrian house where Hitler was born
summary: Austria's owner of the house where Adolf Hitler was born has filed a lawsuit against the government's decision to expropriate the property, citing the law as unconstitutional. The government had planned to demolish the building and replace it with a new structure, but the owner, Gerlinde Pommer, claims she will fight to keep the property. The lawsuit was filed after the government offered her 50,023 euros in rent, which she refused. A court is expected to review the case in coming months, potentially striking down the law and allowing Pommer to maintain ownership.

site_title: Trump's early moves spark alarm, resistance within the government
summary: President Donald Trump's early executive order limiting immigration from seven Muslim-majority countries sparked alarm and resistance within the US government. A draft memo criticizing the policy was circulated among diplomats, with over 900 signatures, and some officials feared backlash or disciplinary action. Others discussed quitting their jobs or seeking professional liability insurance. Despite this, many officials are more concerned about Trump's disregard for legislative and legal restraints on presidential power and the potential for chaos in the bureaucracy.

site_title: What does it mean to be an American?
summary: President Trump's executive order banning entry to citizens of seven Muslim-majority countries and refugees has sparked widespread protests and criticism. The order, which was temporarily halted by federal judges, has been described as a "Muslim ban" by critics, while the White House claims it's a "temporary ban" or "moratorium." The debate over the order's constitutionality and effectiveness has exposed deep divisions over national identity and immigration policies, with some viewing it as a necessary step to keep the country secure and others seeing it as a discriminatory and un-American move.

site_title: Germany says it's working at troubled Trump ties
summary: Germany is maintaining open channels of communication with US President Donald Trump's administration despite his attacks on Berlin's policies. Chancellor Angela Merkel emphasized the "historical friendship" between the two nations, saying the relationship is "a deep, I would say historical, friendship between two peoples." Germany is working to establish trust and cooperation, with Merkel's government offering her a visit to the US in the spring. Trump accepted an invitation to attend a G20 summit in Hamburg in early July, marking a tentative step towards improved relations.

site_title: US: Strong Apple earnings lift US stocks at open
summary: Apple's strong Q1 earnings lifted US stocks at open, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 0.5% and the S&P 500 rising 0.4%. Apple reported record revenues of $78.4 billion and 78.3 million iPhone sales. The strong results countered worries about President Trump's immigration executive order and ahead of the US Federal Reserve's monetary policy announcement. Analysts expect no interest rate hike, but the Fed may signal future rate increases.

site_title: EU clears final hurdle for ending mobile roaming charges
summary: European lawmakers have agreed to cap wholesale roaming charges, paving the way for the abolition of roaming fees in the EU by June 15, 2017. Wholesale charges for data will be capped at 7.7 euros per gigabyte, calls at 3.2 euros per minute, and text messages at 1 euro cent, as of June. The European Commission will review the caps every two years. The deal aims to ensure companies can afford to continue offering roaming within the EU without charging retail customers.

site_title: BMW CEO pleads for free trade after Trump border tax threat
summary: BMW CEO Harald Krueger defended free trade in response to US President Donald Trump's threat to impose tariffs to protect American jobs. Krueger stated that BMW's US factory in Spartanburg, South Carolina, is a key part of the company's global success, with 70% of its vehicles produced there being exported. He expressed confidence in continued cooperation with US administrations, despite Trump's criticism of the company's planned factory in Mexico.

site_title: EU, Mexico accelerate talks to update free trade pact
summary: The European Union and Mexico have set two new rounds of trade talks in 2017 to deepen economic ties, following the inauguration of US President Donald Trump. EU Trade Commissioner Cecilia Malmstrom and Mexican Economy Minister Ildefonso Guajardo have scheduled talks for April 3-7 and June 26-29. The move aims to counter the rise of protectionism globally, with the two countries emphasizing the importance of open cooperation.

site_title: Apple woos new iPhone fans as current owners await upgrade
summary: Apple sold 3.5 million more iPhones in the holiday quarter, driven by new customers, despite existing users upgrading to the iPhone 7 at a similar rate to the iPhone 6S. The company reported 3.3% revenue growth and exceeded analyst forecasts, with services revenue rising 18% to $7.2 billion. This growth is expected to continue as Apple prepares for a more significant upgrade to its flagship product later this year, potentially increasing upgrade rates among existing iPhone users.

site_title: Tesla drops 'Motors' from name as CEO Musk looks beyond cars Feb 1
summary: Tesla has dropped "Motors" from its name, becoming "Tesla Inc", as CEO Elon Musk expands the company's focus beyond electric cars to include diversified energy products. The name change comes after Tesla's acquisition of SolarCity Corp in a $2 billion stock swap deal. Musk aims to combine electric car and battery production with solar installation, showcasing the company's broader ambitions. The name change is effective February 1, 2017.

site_title: Technics Oil and Gas sells steel unit for S$950,000
summary: TECHNICS Oil and Gas is selling its 51% stake in Technics Steel Pte Ltd for S$950,000 to TTJ Holdings. The sale includes S$350,000 for shares and S$600,000 to settle inter-company loans. The transaction also releases Technics Oil and Gas from corporate guarantees and security arrangements for Technics Steel. The remaining 49% is owned by minority shareholders Teo Teck Heong and Ng Yiaw Heong, who also form the company's key management team.

site_title: Britain's Brexit bill set to clear first legislative hurdle
summary: Britain's Brexit bill is expected to clear its first legislative hurdle on Wednesday, paving the way for Prime Minister Theresa May to trigger the country's exit from the European Union by the end of March. The bill, which gives May the right to trigger Article 50 of the EU's Lisbon Treaty, could complete the legislative process by March 7. This comes after the Supreme Court ruled last week that May could not take the decision unilaterally.

site_title: Cities could save millions of dollars by preventing evictions
summary: New York City is facing potential annual costs of $280 million to $646 million from household financial insecurity, with nearly two-thirds of its 3.1 million households having less than $2,000 in liquid savings. This could lead to thousands of dollars in costs for homeless services, utilities, and property taxes. Researchers suggest setting aside millions to pay attorneys' fees for tenants facing eviction, as providing legal aid is cheaper than paying for a homeless shelter. Affordable healthcare also reduces the likelihood of being late on rent or mortgage payments.

site_title: India to inject 100b rupees capital into state-run banks
summary: India's Finance Minister Arun Jaitley announced a 100 billion rupees (S$2.096 billion) capital injection into state-run banks for the upcoming fiscal year, aligning with a previous pledge. The move aims to boost capital buffers and revive loan growth, but experts say it may not be sufficient to meet the lenders' needs to comply with Basel III norms. The government has set a target of 800 billion rupees of equity capital over the next two years, and additional funds may be required.

site_title: Oil snoozes after Opec jolt as market awaits supply cut proof
summary: The global oil market is in a "snooze mode" as investors await evidence of supply cuts from Opec and its allies, which agreed to reduce output in December. Despite a 1.8 million-barrel-per-day production cut, oil prices remain stuck between $50 and $55 a barrel, with estimates suggesting a $52 average price for the first quarter and $58 by the end of 2017. The market is awaiting Opec's February report and other data to gauge compliance with the production cuts.

site_title: US dollar gains on March rate hike hopes ahead of Trump speech
summary: The US dollar rose 0.3% to 113.16 yen ahead of US President Donald Trump's speech, driven by expectations of a March interest rate hike. Federal Reserve officials, including New York Fed President William Dudley and San Francisco Fed President John Williams, expressed concerns over rising inflation, fueling a 70% chance of a rate hike in March. Markets will closely watch Trump's speech for details on tax reform and fiscal stimulus, which could impact the dollar's value.

site_title: US dollar struggles after worst start to year in decades
summary: The US dollar experienced its worst start to the year in three decades, falling 2.6% against a basket of major peers in January due to concerns over the Trump administration's "strong dollar" policy. Senior adviser Peter Navarro and President Trump's comments on devaluation sent the euro soaring and knocked the US dollar index to a seven-week low. The Fed is expected to keep interest rates unchanged, and the lack of clarity on Trump's economic policies has weakened the dollar, which is now trading less than 2% above its pre-election levels.

site_title: GLP acquires 448,000 sq ft facilities for US$33m in Chicago
summary: GLP has acquired 448,000 sq ft of distribution facilities in Chicago for US$33 million in two transactions. The buildings, fully leased to GLP customers, add to the company's US portfolio of over 11 million sq ft. This acquisition brings GLP's total US space to 173 million sq ft. The facilities are located in Bedford Park and Western Cook County, near major highways and urban population density.

site_title: CEOs targeted more by activists but give them fewer board seats
summary: US CEOs were targeted by activists more than ever in 2016, with 212 companies approached by investors seeking board seats, a 14% increase from 2015. This marks a significant rise from 154 companies in 2014 and 186 in 2015. The increased activism has led to CEOs receiving fewer board seats, suggesting that investors are trying to exert more control over corporate decision-making.

site_title: No deterrent for Lego as toymaker expands its London base
summary: Lego A/S is expanding its London base, adding over 50% in office capacity, despite the UK's planned exit from the EU. The company now has 275 employees in the city and plans to provide more space for current employees and expand its workforce in the future. The expansion is strategically important for the company, which has had employees in its main London office since 2014. Lego's decision to expand in London comes as the UK navigates its path toward a full divorce from the EU.

site_title: China's factory gauge strengthens as producer prices rebound
summary: China's factory gauge strengthened in February, with the manufacturing PMI at 51.6, higher than the median estimate of 51.2. Producer prices rebounded, giving officials a solid economic backdrop ahead of the National People's Congress. The non-manufacturing PMI stood at 54.2. This rebound is seen as a positive sign for the near-term economic outlook, with economists predicting a shift in monetary policy to manage swelling debt. The growth target for this year is expected to be announced during the congress, signaling increased tolerance for slower yet sturdier economic expansion.

site_title: Trump travel ban will impact US tourism: UN agency
summary: President Donald Trump's travel ban on seven majority Muslim nations has sparked "deep concern and strong condemnation" from the UN World Tourism Organization, warning it will hinder tourism growth and create growing tensions. The ban, which affects nationals from Syria, Iraq, Iran, Sudan, Libya, Somalia, and Yemen, has led to international uproar and the detention of immigrants and legal permanent residents. The UNWTO chief, Taleb Rifai, stated that the image of the US imposing such a ban will deter potential visitors and risk "dumping travel demand to the USA".

site_title: Lufthansa, Etihad deepen ties with catering, maintenance pacts
summary: Deutsche Lufthansa AG and Etihad Airways PJSC announced a "new commercial partnership" with deals covering in-flight catering and aircraft maintenance. The $100 million agreements come as Etihad grapples with losses from minority investments and Lufthansa struggles to cut costs. The partnership builds on recent joint ticket sales and aircraft leasing agreements, marking a shift for the two airlines after years of clashes over state aid. The agreements aim to strengthen their ties amid changing market circumstances, with Etihad's CEO calling them the most significant outside of the airline's "equity alliance".

site_title: Lufthansa chief rejects 'subsidies' as he signs Etihad deal
summary: Lufthansa CEO Carsten Spohr signed a cooperation deal with Etihad, despite opposing state subsidies for airlines. The deal includes a codeshare agreement, a $100-million catering accord, and an engineering memorandum of understanding. Spohr emphasized the importance of "openness and fairness" in partnerships, while acknowledging the growing trend of protectionism worldwide. This move comes as Western legacy carriers have accused Etihad and other Gulf carriers of receiving government support, which gives them an edge over competitors. Lufthansa has leased 38 aircraft from struggling Air Berlin, which Etihad owns 29%.

images.alt_text: The Lufthansa chief on Wednesday reiterated the German carrier's opposition to state subsidies for airlines, as he signed a cooperation deal with Abu Dhabi's Etihad, one of the main Gulf carriers accused of receiving government support.

site_title: Glencore considering bid for Impala's chrome waste business
summary: Glencore is considering a bid for Impala Platinum Holdings Ltd.'s 65% stake in a chrome waste-retreatment operation in South Africa. The operation, which produces over 200,000 metric tons of chrome concentrate annually, is valued at 67 million rand. Impala sees the operation as a non-core asset and is looking to focus on its platinum mines. A partnership between Glencore and Chrome Traders Processing (Pty) Ltd is already in place, and Standard Bank Group Ltd is running the sales process for potential bidders.

site_title: UK inflation expectations for year ahead hit 3-year high
summary: UK inflation expectations have reached a 3-year high, with short-run inflation expectations rising to 2.6% in January, surpassing the Bank of England's forecast of 2.7% by the end of the year. Long-run expectations remain at 3%, their joint-highest level since 2014. The increase in expectations comes after the fall in sterling's value following the Brexit vote.

site_title: Snap expecting some new IPO investors to commit to year-long ban on selling
summary: Snap Inc. expects investors buying up to a quarter of its shares in its $3.2 billion IPO to agree to a year-long ban on selling. This move is seen as a sign of confidence in the company, which is targeting a valuation of $19.5-22.3 billion. The lock-up period is atypically long and could help moderate stock volatility. Orders for the IPO are already oversubscribed, with the "book" expected to be fully committed.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets rebound at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets rebounded at the start of trading on Wednesday, with London's FTSE 100 index up 0.7% to 7,150.36 points. Frankfurt's DAX 30 index jumped 1% to 11,646.42, while Paris' CAC 40 rose 0.8% to 4,786.85. The rebound came after a decline on Tuesday, driven by US President Donald Trump's executive orders, which fueled global economic worries.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's Intellectual Property Office (IPOS) will lower patent and trademark application fees starting April 1. The US and Singapore have implemented guidelines for cross-border insolvency proceedings, increasing cooperation. Technics Oil and Gas sold its steel unit for S$950,000. Indonesia's inflation rate rose to 3.49% in January, while South Korea's exports surged 21.4% in January, the fastest pace in nearly five years. The Federal Reserve is expected to hold interest rates steady to reassess the economy's outlook.

site_title: HC Surgical Specialists buys 51% of Julian Ong Endoscopy & Surgery
summary: HC Surgical Specialists acquired 51% of Julian Ong Endoscopy & Surgery (JOES) for S$2.175 million, expanding its presence in Singapore. JOES, a Singapore-based endoscopy clinic, will operate as a subsidiary, establishing a new clinic at Mount Elizabeth Novena Hospital. Dr. Julian Ong, who owns 90% of JOES, will join the group as a specialist surgeon. The acquisition aligns with HC Surgical Specialists' growth plan, strengthening its capabilities with Dr. Ong's expertise.

site_title: Japan will tell US to respect WTO rules: Abe adviser
summary: Japan's adviser, Yasutoshi Nishimura, stated that Japan will inform the US that any border tax should respect World Trade Organization rules. Japan is open to a bilateral trade agreement, but talks may be delayed due to the US prioritizing the renegotiation of the North America Free Trade Agreement. The two countries have agreed to establish a new economic dialogue framework but have not set a schedule. Nishimura emphasized the importance of WTO rules and multilateralism, indicating Japan's willingness to lobby for these principles in trade discussions.

site_title: India mulls law to seized assets of financial crooks
summary: India is considering a law to seize assets of financial crooks who flee abroad. Finance Minister Arun Jaitley said the proposal aims to confiscate domestic holdings of criminals and financial offenders who escape Indian authorities. This move comes after tycoon Vijay Mallya left for Britain last year owing over $1 billion. The law would ensure that the law takes its course against big-time offenders.

site_title: US dollar firms on Fed rate hike talk, eyes on Trump
summary: The US dollar strengthened in Asia on Wednesday after two top Federal Reserve officials hinted at a potential interest rate hike as soon as this month. The comments, combined with a speech by President Trump to Congress, have investors seeking clarity on the administration's economic plans. Markets were subdued in other regions, with Tokyo stocks rising 0.9% and Chinese factory activity showing a better-than-expected growth. The US dollar's rally is expected to continue, but uncertainty surrounding Trump's economic plans remains.

site_title: Singapore shares gain 21 points on Wednesday
summary: Singapore's benchmark Straits Times Index rose 20.69 points or 0.68% to 3,067.49, driven by gains from banking stocks OCBC and UOB, as well as Jardine Matheson, Singtel, and CapitaLand. Turnover was 1.9 billion units worth S$1.2 billion, with 270 gainers and 164 losers. The rally follows a 5-day streak, ahead of GDP data scheduled for release on Thursday.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks rise, won pares gains as US dollar recovers
summary: South Korean stocks rose on local institutional buying, while the won pared its gains against the US dollar after the dollar rebounded in global markets. The won closed at 1,158.1 to the US dollar, up 0.3% from Tuesday. The recovery in the US dollar reduced the won's gains, but South Korean shares continued to rise.

site_title: Late-2016 pick-up sees Julius Baer hit asset gathering goal
summary: Swiss private bank Julius Baer reported a 4% growth in net new money in 2016, reaching 12 billion Swiss francs (US$12.1 billion), at the bottom end of its 4-6% target range. The bank hired 116 relationship managers to attract new clients, with plans to return to a normal hiring pace. Assets under management rose to 336 billion francs, driven by solid net inflows from Asia, the Middle East, and western Europe. The bank posted an adjusted net profit of 705.5 million francs, ahead of estimates.

site_title: German workers must get higher wage increases: Schulz
summary: German centre-left candidate Martin Schulz has called for higher wage increases for workers, citing a gap between company profits and worker incomes. Schulz, nominated to run against Chancellor Angela Merkel, believes unions and management should prioritize worker pay in negotiations. Germany's federal government has a budget surplus, allowing for potential public salary increases. Real wages rose 1.9% in 2016, lower than the 2.4% in 2015 and 2.2% in 2014. Schulz's SPD party has seen support jump to 26% in a recent poll.

site_title: EU banks face 159 billion euro funding shortfall - watchdog
summary: EU banks face a 159 billion euro funding shortfall, less than a year before new rules require them to maintain a minimum source of longer-term funding. The European Banking Authority found that while the average funding ratio across EU banks is above 100%, some banks fall short, resulting in a shortfall of 158.7 billion euros. The new net stable funding ratio, or NSFR, takes effect from January 2018.

site_title: Dubai airport handles record 8m passengers in January
summary: Dubai International Airport set a record for the most passengers handled in January, reaching 8.04 million, a 9.7% increase from the previous year. This is the airport's highest monthly passenger count to date. The number of flights also rose 2.1% to 36,592, with an average of 230 passengers per flight, up from 215 last year. Cargo handled increased 3.4% to 208,271 tonnes.

site_title: London seen attracting more ultra-wealthy even as Brexit bites
summary: London is expected to attract more ultra-wealthy individuals despite Brexit concerns, with the number of those with US$30 million or more expected to rise by 30% to 6,058 over the next decade. New York remains the top spot worldwide due to US economic growth, while Asia is expected to see rapid growth in ultra-wealthy populations, particularly in cities like Shanghai and Ho Chi Minh City. The global ultra-high-net-worth individual population is expected to reach 275,000 by 2026, driven by stock-market gains and economic growth in countries like China and India.

site_title: SoftBank said to be in talks to merge OneWeb with Intelsat
summary: SoftBank is in talks to merge its satellite startup OneWeb with Intelsat, a satellite provider, in a potential $18 billion deal. The merger would combine their complementary radio-frequency licenses to provide internet access on airplanes and other markets. OneWeb has received $1.2 billion in funding from SoftBank and other investors, and the deal is conditional on purchasing Intelsat bonds at a price lower than their trading value. The proposed transaction would be a positive for Intelsat, which is highly leveraged and under stress, according to analysts.

site_title: Singapore's position will become tougher if US-China tensions rise: PM Lee
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong warns that the country's position will become increasingly difficult if US-China tensions rise. As a friend to both nations, Singapore could be caught in the middle, potentially straining its relationships. Lee emphasized the importance of navigating this delicate situation. His comments come amid rising tensions between the US and China, with Singapore's close ties with the US drawing Chinese discontent.

site_title: HK: Stocks ease after long holiday, Trump policies pressure
summary: Hong Kong stocks eased on their first day of trading after a long holiday, closing 0.18% down at 23,318.39 points, due to concerns over US President Donald Trump's protectionist policies and immigration curbs. The China Enterprises Index fell 0.48% to 9,756.61 points. Investors across the region were subdued, with equity markets awaiting the outcome of US-EU trade talks and the impact of Trump's policies on global markets.

site_title: Indonesia inflation rate rises to 3.83% in Feb: stats bureau
summary: Indonesia's annual inflation rate rose to 3.83% in February, driven by higher prices for processed and raw foods and healthcare. This surpasses January's rate of 3.49% and the predicted 3.90% in a Reuters poll. Core inflation, excluding administered and volatile food prices, also increased to 3.41% in February. The central bank targets annual inflation between 3-5% this year and will make its next policy decision on March 16.

site_title: Golden Agri's Q4 profit more than doubles
summary: Golden Agri-Resources reported a 136.7% increase in Q4 net profit to US$46.3 million, driven by higher sales volume and a large tax credit of US$47.4 million. Revenue jumped 37.8% to US$2.14 billion, with the palm and laurics segment contributing to the growth. The company's full-year net profit soared to US$399.6 million, despite a 10.7% revenue increase. A proposed final dividend of 0.635 Singapore cents per share was also announced.

site_title: Thai banks' bad loans to decline as economy improves
summary: Thai banks' non-performing loans (NPLs) are expected to decline over the next six months as the economy improves, according to Finance Minister Apisak Tantivorawong. NPLs, which accounted for 2.89% of total lending at the end of September, are expected to improve due to better economic conditions. The finance ministry forecasts economic growth at 3.6% for 2017 and 3.2% for 2016, with NPLs expected to follow this trend.

images.alt_text: Thai banks' non-performing loans (NPLs) are expected to fall over the next six months as the economy is improving, the finance minister said on Wednesday.

site_title: Keppel Reit issues 7.9m new shares as part of distribution reinvestment plan
summary: Keppel Reit has issued 7.9 million new shares as part of its distribution reinvestment plan, allotting and issuing units at S$1.0004 each. Eligible unitholders who chose to participate will receive the new units, increasing the total number of units to approximately 3.319 billion. Non-eligible unitholders will receive cash distribution payments on Feb 28.

site_title: US trade protection will end up hurting low-income Americans
summary: The Trump administration's trade protection methods, such as tariffs or border taxes, may ultimately hurt low-income Americans. These taxes distort markets, leading to a higher real standard of living for consumers of expensive domestic goods but a lower standard of living for those who buy cheaper imported goods. Trade protection taxes disproportionately affect low-income Americans, particularly those who spend a high proportion of their income on food, with a potential impact of 70% more serious than for high-income Americans.

site_title: VW, Robert Bosch agree to pay US$1.6b to settle US diesel claims
summary: Volkswagen AG has agreed to pay at least $1.26 billion to fix or buy back nearly 80,000 polluting 3.0-liter diesel-engined vehicles in the US, according to court documents filed Tuesday. The settlement, which must be approved by a US judge, offers owners compensation ranging from $7,000 to $16,000 if emissions fixes are approved in a timely fashion. If regulators don't approve fixes, costs could jump to up to $4.04 billion, with owners eligible for buybacks or compensation of $7,500 on top of vehicle value.

images.alt_text: Volkswagen AG has agreed to pay at least US$1.26 billion to fix or buy back nearly 80,000 polluting 3.0 liter diesel-engined vehicles - and could be forced to pay up to US$4.04 billion if regulators don't approve fixes for all vehicles, court documents filed late Tuesday showed.

site_title: Dollar falls against yen on US policy doubts
summary: The US dollar fell 0.6% against the Japanese yen, reaching a two-week low, due to investors' doubts over swift tax reform and spending boost from President Trump's administration. Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin's comments and Federal Reserve meeting minutes reinforced doubts about a rate hike next month, contributing to the decline. The euro slipped 0.2% against the dollar, while the dollar index gained 0.2% for its third straight weekly gain. Markets are becoming increasingly cautious about US fiscal stimulus, leading to skepticism about the Fed's ability to hike interest rates in the next two years.

site_title: Latest Earnings
summary: Oil prices rose over 2% as investors weighed market outlook, tariffs, and sanctions. US stocks edged down from records amid tariff threats, while Europe's stocks declined due to bank and healthcare sector drag. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and similar operating loss for H2. London's Heathrow airport plans to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case involving 285 trillion rupiah.

site_title: No slowing down for middle-of-the-road king
summary: James Taylor, 68, performed in Singapore for the first time in 23 years at The Star, delighting a middle-aged crowd with his self-deprecating jokes and stories behind his hits. Backed by a 10-piece all-star band, Taylor's two-hour show included fan favorites like "You've Got A Friend" and "Fire and Rain," with the band complementing him perfectly. The second half of the show became more lively, featuring electric guitar and a party atmosphere, showcasing Taylor's ability to deliver tight performances as a live performer despite his music being considered middle-of-the-road.

site_title: Sterling edges up as euro zone concerns eclipse worries over UK data
summary: Sterling edged up against the dollar and euro, rising 0.1% against the US dollar and 0.2% against the euro, due to concerns over the outcome of French presidential elections and growing worries over the euro zone. A poll showed Marine Le Pen trailing behind potential finalists, weakening the euro. Sterling traded at its lowest level since December 21, but analysts expect stronger gains ahead if it breaks through resistance at US$1.2580.

site_title: Boeing to invest £20m to open 1st European factory
summary: Boeing plans to invest £20m to open its first European factory in Sheffield, UK, producing actuators for 737, 737 MAX, and 777 aircraft. The 25,000 sq ft facility will work closely with its US plant to reduce supply chain costs. This move marks Boeing's commitment to in-house manufacturing in the UK, following Airbus' focus on UK-based wing-building operations.

site_title: German budget surplus soars as economy charges ahead
summary: Germany's economy is booming, with a record 2016 budget surplus of 23.7 billion euros. The surplus, driven by soaring tax revenues and low debt costs, has raised eyebrows in the European Union. Chancellor Angela Merkel's government plans to use the surplus to increase investment and lower income taxes, while also addressing refugee-related expenditure. Despite criticism from the European Commission, Merkel's conservatives promise more investment and tax cuts, while the Social Democrats vow to invest in education and infrastructure.

site_title: Slip these on for instant street cred
summary: Sabahs, handmade Turkish slippers, are the brainchild of Mickey Ashmore, who was gifted a traditional pair while working in Microsoft's Istanbul office. Inspired, Ashmore collaborated with a Turkish cobbler to update the shoe with a contemporary profile, resulting in a stylish and comfortable slipper. Each pair is handcrafted without machinery and marked with the cobbler's initials. Sabahs are available for men, women, and children, with prices ranging from $65 to $190. The company ships globally and offers a return/exchange policy, with Ashmore also sharing his perky emails with customers.

site_title: SGX looking at bringing back midday break, wider spreads for illiquid stocks
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) is considering reinstating a midday break and widening spreads for illiquid stocks. The move aims to boost trading and attract more day traders. The proposal, which will be subject to public consultation, includes a test to widen the price increment at which shares are quoted. This could encourage trading in small-cap companies and increase volume by up to 10%. The plan is part of SGX's efforts to make its market more accessible and competitive, following previous changes in 2007 and 2015.

site_title: Delfi Q4 profit jumps fourfold; group back in the black for full year
summary: Delfi Limited reported a fourfold jump in Q4 net profit to US$3.7 million, driven by a 5.6% revenue increase to US$105.6 million. The company attributed growth to Indonesia business and cost-containment initiatives. Delfi returned to profitability for the full year with a net profit of US$26.2 million, after a net loss of US$4.7 million in the previous year. The company expects economic and currency volatility to impact consumer spending but remains optimistic about future growth.

site_title: A peek inside Qatar's 'gas capital of the world'
summary: Ras Laffan, Qatar's "gas capital of the world," is a secretive industrial site that produces and exports liquefied natural gas (LNG) to the world. Located on a northern tip of Qatar, it is home to 30,000 people and is responsible for 30% of the global LNG market. Qatar's vast gas reserves will allow it to maintain production at current rates for another 137 years, fueling the country's unimaginable wealth, which has enabled it to invest in luxury projects such as skyscrapers and airports.

site_title: US-China ties back on track - at least on the surface
summary: US-China ties appear to be back on track after a telephone conversation between President Donald Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping on Feb 9. Trump had previously threatened to reject the "One China policy" unless China made trade concessions, but agreed to honor the policy during the conversation. The "One China policy" recognizes Beijing as the sole legal government of China and acknowledges Taiwan's status. The agreement marks a significant shift in US foreign policy, with Trump opening a new chapter in relations with China.

site_title: The artist as leader
summary: Telstra CEO Andrew Penn emphasizes the importance of being open to learning and trying new things, qualities he attributes to his success. Penn, a self-taught artist, believes that having a hobby or pastime that exercises a different part of the brain helps with brain regeneration and overall well-being. He credits his unconventional career path, which included a 20-year stint in the insurance industry, for his ability to approach problems from new angles and try creative solutions. As CEO of Telstra, Penn is focused on transforming the telecoms giant into a technology powerhouse by prioritizing customer experience and leveraging technology to facilitate it. He believes that a focus on what technology can do, rather than how it works, is key to driving innovation and improving lives.

site_title: NeraTel Q4 profit plunges 70%
summary: NeraTel's Q4 net profit plummeted 70% to S$1.3 million, largely due to a 5% decline in gross profit and increased administrative expenses. Revenue rose 26% to S$49.6 million, driven by better performance in telecom and infocomm business divisions. The company's directors recommended a special cash dividend of 0.5 Singapore cent, down from 1 cent last year.

site_title: Best World Q4 profit up 231% at S$12.3m; proposes 2-for-1 share split
summary: Best World International, a beauty products direct seller, reported a net profit of S$12.3 million for its fourth quarter, a 231% increase from the previous year. Revenues rose 51% to S$61.8 million, driven by growth in Taiwan and China markets. The company proposes a 2-for-1 share split.

site_title: Air France-KLM profits up in 2016, cautious for 2017
summary: Air France-KLM reported a sharp increase in profits to 792 million euros in 2016, driven by one-off gains from the sale of its catering arm and lower fuel costs. However, underlying operating profit grew 34% to 1.05 billion euros, while revenues declined 3.3% to 24.8 billion euros. The airline attributed the decline to lower unit revenues due to geopolitical uncertainty and industry overcapacity. Despite this, the company remains cautious for 2017, aiming to increase capacity by 3-3.5% and cut costs by 1.5%.

site_title: Sterling steady ahead of UK retail sales data
summary: Sterling holds near week lows against the dollar ahead of UK retail sales data, awaiting clues on consumer spending resilience since the UK's Brexit vote. Market analysts expect 3.4% year-on-year sales growth in January, potentially signaling a softening trend. Sterling underperformed other major currencies due to Brexit and economic uncertainty. The Bank of England is unlikely to raise interest rates due to softer inflation data.

site_title: HK unveils HK$92b Budget surplus
summary: Hong Kong's new Financial Secretary Paul Chan unveiled a budget surplus of HK$92 billion in his maiden address. The HK$61 billion will be allocated towards community services. Chan emphasized innovation and technology as a key driver of growth, setting the stage for a tax-system revamp and flexible fiscal policy.

images.alt_text: Mr Chan says he will use the surplus to care for the needy and ease the burden of the middle class

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 7.070 points to 1712.950. The market saw 148 gains and 72 losses, with a trading volume of 135.4 million lots worth RM53.08 million.

site_title: China unveils curbs on secondary share sales as IPOs speed up
summary: China's securities regulator has introduced curbs on secondary share sales, limiting companies to issuing up to 20% of their total shares in private placements. The move aims to control liquidity pressure and slow the pace of initial public offerings, which have raised concerns about a supply glut in the stock market. The regulator has also set a 18-month waiting period for additional share issues and clarified that some types of financings, such as convertible debt, are exempt. The curbs are part of efforts to speed up IPO approvals, with over 600 companies seeking approval for first-time share sales.

site_title: Govt reviewing land-use policies and planning guidelines
summary: The Singapore government is reviewing land-use policies and planning guidelines to facilitate greater flexibility in land use, allowing complementary activities to be located near each other and enabling synergies among developments. Industry players hail this as long overdue, but express concerns that changes may be limited to greenfield sites and may not translate to material changes for existing sites. Proposed changes include expanding zoning categories, relaxing the 60-40 rule for industrial space, and adopting a discretionary approach to land use. The review aims to create a more responsive and adaptable land-use regime.

site_title: Hot stock: Pacific Star Development dips on Catalist debut
summary: Pacific Star Development, a Singapore-based property developer, made its Catalist debut on Thursday, but tanked due to a sharp decline in its stock price. The company opened at 33 Singapore cents and fell to 31 Singapore cents, with a volume of 513,400 shares. The listing follows a reverse takeover by LH Group, which expanded Pacific Star's projects in Southeast Asia. The company aims to expand its brand equity in the region and has a market capitalization of about S$127 million.

site_title: Wheat and corn post weekly declines after fund-fuelled rally
summary: US wheat and corn futures fell for a second consecutive session, closing down 1.8% and 1.7% respectively, amid fund-driven rallies and traders liquidating long positions ahead of the US holiday weekend. Soyabeans also declined, pressured by falling vegetable oil prices in Asia and an advancing harvest in Brazil. Analysts attribute the decline to lack of fundamental drivers and bearish technical signals, with traders awaiting fresh acreage forecasts from the US Department of Agriculture's annual outlook forum.

site_title: Feet firmly grounded, Spieth puts a sensible shoe forward
summary: Jordan Spieth has introduced his new golf shoes, the Spieth One, designed for better stability and performance. The shoes, which feature distinctive utility elements, are part of a trend for Spieth to prioritize form over flash in his golfing attire and public persona. Following a four-stroke victory at the AT&T Pebble Beach Pro-Am, Spieth credited the win with helping him overcome the pressure of past performances, particularly his missed lead at the 2016 Masters. Spieth's understated approach to fame and his focus on work ethic are seen as key factors in his success as "America's 'It' player" in golf.

images.alt_text: Under Armour golf clothing and mock-up equipment (left) for Spieth (right). The Spieth One golf shoes, endorsed by the golfer and available soon at Under Armour retail outlets, are artwork for the sole. They are distinctive in ways that do not catch the eye: the springiness, the snug heel support and the wide placement of the spikes for better stability.

site_title: Australia shares end lower as materials sector falters; NZ down
summary: Australian shares ended slightly lower on Friday, closing 0.2% off at 5,805.8, following a two-day surge. Lower iron ore and copper prices dragged basic material stocks down, with BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto falling 1.1% and 2.1%, respectively. Healthcare stocks also declined, with CSL Ltd and Cochlear Ltd dropping 1.3% to 2.2%. New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index fell 0.1% at 7093.52.

site_title: Japanese PM Abe sees tougher US stance towards North Korea
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe stated that the US stance towards North Korea will become tougher following the recent ballistic missile test. This stance is in line with US President Donald Trump's commitment to Japan's security, as Trump said the US was behind Japan "100 per cent" in the aftermath of the missile launch. Abe previously noted that the Obama administration's policy would be rethought under Trump, indicating a shift in the US approach to North Korea.

site_title: Trump defence chief to Nato: Pay up or we reduce support
summary: US Defence Secretary James Mattis warned Nato allies to meet their spending pledges or risk moderate US commitment to the alliance. Mattis stated that the US would "moderate its commitment" if member countries do not meet the 2% of GDP spending goal, echoing President Trump's previous comments. Currently, only the US, Britain, Estonia, Greece, and Poland meet the spending threshold, and Mattis called for "milestone dates" to track contributions. Nato Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg denied the message was a threat, describing it as a "firm message" on fair burden-sharing.

site_title: Investors shrug off mortgage rivalry in Hong Kong
summary: Investors in Hong Kong's HSBC Holdings Plc are shrugging off the intense mortgage rivalry in the city's unaffordable housing market. At least 10 banks have cut mortgage rates to a spread of 1.3% to 1.32% over Hibor, the city's interbank rate. Despite concerns about rising borrowing costs and potential defaults, banks are well-capitalized and sitting on cheap liquidity, allowing them to absorb any hit from less profitable home loans. The mortgage business can earn a return on equity of 26%, making it a profitable venture for lenders.

site_title: China probes former media head linked to missing tycoon: report
summary: China is investigating Xie Zhenjiang, the former head of the Securities Daily newspaper, for links to a missing Hong Kong tycoon. Xie has been expelled from the Communist Party for "serious disciplinary violations," a standard code for graft, and is likely to face prosecution. This is the first step in a process that typically ends in prosecution. The investigation is the latest in a series of probes into China's business elite.

site_title: After GM loses billions in Europe, Barra moves to dump Opel
summary: General Motors has agreed to sell its Opel division to France's PSA Group, marking a significant shift in the company's strategy under CEO Mary Barra. The deal comes after GM has lost billions in Europe since 1999 and is seen as a step towards focusing on more profitable markets, particularly North America and China. The sale will render GM a seller of fewer than 9 million cars annually worldwide, falling behind the Renault-Nissan alliance. The move is expected to demonstrate Barra's commitment to posting strong profits and exiting unprofitable businesses.

site_title: Oil stress yet to hit bottom
summary: OCBC's CEO Samuel Tsien warned that the oil-and-gas sector may not attract additional capital if oil prices don't recover and surpass $60 per barrel. The bank reported an 18% fall in net profit for the fourth quarter, largely due to higher provisions for the oil-and-gas sector. Tsien expressed doubts over the sector's ability to attract capital, citing the need for oil prices to stabilize at $65 per barrel for vessel operators to generate reliable cash flows. The bank's net interest income fell 7% and non-interest income decreased 4% year-over-year.

site_title: UK wage growth slows in late 2016, employment picks up
summary: UK wage growth slowed to 2.6% in the fourth quarter of 2016, down from 2.8% in the previous quarter, due to higher inflation. The employment rate reached a fresh all-time high, with the unemployment rate remaining at 4.8%. The Bank of England expects interest rates to remain low, citing the impact of the Brexit vote on sterling. The data also showed a decline in the number of non-UK EU nationals employed in Britain, raising concerns about the attractiveness of the country to foreign workers.

site_title: Under Armour CEO hammered by analyst for praising Donald Trump
summary: Under Armour CEO Kevin Plank faced backlash for praising President Donald Trump, calling him a "real asset" to the country. The comment sparked controversy, with NBA star Steph Curry rebuking it. Analyst Sam Poser downgraded the company's stock to negative, citing a "nearly impossible" future for building a cool brand with Trump's presidency. Poser also cut his stock-price target to $14, putting him at the low end of Wall Street peers.

site_title: Hats off to Hariss Harun
summary: Singaporean footballer Hariss Harun is making his foray into European football after being released from his club Johor Darul Ta'zim to join third-tier side CE L'Hospitalet on loan. The 26-year-old midfielder, who became a national player in 2007, has a positive outlook on his venture and plans to bring his family along, aiming to alleviate homesickness. Hariss is following in the footsteps of Singaporean footballers Fandi Ahmad and V Sundram, who made their European debut in the 1980s, and is determined to make the most of this opportunity.

site_title: Brazil's former richest man to stand trial on corruption charges
summary: Brazil's former richest man Eike Batista will stand trial on corruption charges, along with ex-Rio de Janeiro Governor Sergio Cabral, for allegedly taking millions in bribes from Batista's enterprises in exchange for government contracts. The charges, accepted by a federal judge, involve Batista creating offshore shell firms to hide the money. Batista, 60, had a net worth of over $30 billion five years ago and is currently being held in jail. Prosecutors claim the bribes were paid to secure lucrative government contracts, including the construction of a $3.7 billion port and the Maracana stadium.

site_title: DBS Group selling PwC Building to Manulife
summary: DBS Group is selling its 28-storey office block, PwC Building at 8 Cross Street, to an indirect subsidiary of Manulife Financial Corp for S$747 million, or S$2,100 per square foot. The sale is valued at S$350 million net profit for DBS and is expected to contribute to the group's consolidated net tangible assets. Manulife, the buyer, will occupy part of the building and aims to increase its market share in Singapore's financial district. The sale is the first of an entire Singapore office building this year and is considered a "plain vanilla deal" by experts.

site_title: Rattled by drunk heckler's request for Summer Of '69
summary: Ryan Adams was performing at the Ryman Auditorium in Nashville in 2002 when a drunk heckler repeatedly requested his song "Summer of '69" by Bryan Adams. The disruptions caused Adams to lose his composure, and he eventually asked the heckler to leave, offering him $20 to take a taxi home. The incident was documented by a journalist and led to Adams being portrayed as a joke, with some fans even paying to heckle him. The experience left Adams feeling humiliated but also showed him the importance of standing up for himself.

site_title: Gold slips as US dollar strengthens against yen post Trump-Abe meet
summary: US President Donald Trump's meeting with Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe did not discuss currency policy, leading to a strengthening of the US dollar against the yen. As a result, gold prices slipped 0.3% to $1,229.77 per ounce, with US gold futures falling 0.4%. Analysts attribute the decline to Trump's set aside of protectionist rhetoric and rekindling of the "Trumpflation" trade, which is taking wind out of gold's safe-haven appeal.

site_title: French job creation strongest since early 2007 in Q4
summary: France's economy created jobs at the fastest pace since early 2007 in Q4, with a 0.4% quarterly increase in non-farm payrolls. Non-farm private sector payrolls rose 62,200, the most since 2007. For the year, 191,700 net new jobs were added, the highest level since 2008. The improvement was driven by the services sector, with payrolls rising 0.6% on the quarter. This marks a gradual turnaround in France's labor market, but may not provide a political boost to President Francois Hollande.

site_title: Investing in the age of Trump
summary: Seth Klarman, a 59-year-old value investor and founder of Baupost Group, has written a private letter to his investors expressing concerns about the current state of the hedge fund industry. He warns of "perilously high valuations" and "exuberant investors" ignoring risks from protectionism and trade barriers. Klarman believes investors have become "hypnotized" by pro-growth policies and is worried about a swelling national debt that could undermine the economy. He also criticizes President Trump's leadership style, describing it as "inconsistent with strong leadership and sound decision-making."

site_title: Manga legend Jiro Taniguchi dies at 69
summary: Japanese manga legend Jiro Taniguchi has died at 69, leaving behind an international following for his exquisite line drawings of everyday life. He first gained fame in Japan with "The Times of Botchan" and later hit the international manga scene with "A Distant Neighbourhood". Critics praised his gentle subject matter and detailed landscapes, drawing comparisons to European comic heroes like Tintin. Taniguchi was awarded the Knight of the Order of Arts and Letters by the French government and was known for his hand-drawn, painstakingly crafted panels.

images.alt_text: Jiro Taniguchi, a legend in Japan's comic art of manga, died in Tokyo on Saturday at the age of 69, leaving behind an international following for his exquisite line drawing of scenes from everyday life.

site_title: No glove, no love
summary: Malaysia's Karex, the world's largest condom maker, is expanding its product line to cater to diverse consumer preferences. The company's CEO, Goh Miah Kiat, or "MK," aims to provide condoms in various shapes, sizes, and materials to meet the needs of different cultures and regions. Despite being known for its affordable and reliable products, Karex is looking to innovate with new materials, such as hydrogel and polyurethane, to improve safety and comfort. The company plans to penetrate the Chinese market, which is expected to experience robust growth, and is also exploring the development of an app that measures penis size to ensure a proper fit.
